column2: GARDINER, Me., Sept. 11.--The last rally of the Republican campaign in the State was held in the spacious coliseum in this place tonight. In the course of his remarks Mr. Blaine said:

The Claremont Cricket Club was reorganized this season in Jersey City. With commendable pluck they put two teams in the field yesterday at Prospect Park and played matches against the Kings County and Anglo-Saxon Clubs.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 11.--John Jacobe, of Fair Haven, went out gunning this morning and rowed up the Quinnipiac River. Just above the Hampden town line he discovered the body of a male infant floating in the water.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11.--To-morrow night the New Windsor Theatre, on the north side, will be opened for its first season, which will extend over a period of 40 weeks. This new playhouse is intended exclusively for the use of stars and traveling companies, and will hold much the same relation to the other Chicago theatres that the Windsor...

CHICAGO, Sept. 11.--The International Association of Plumbers, Steam and Gasfitters, in secret session here, refused by a large majority to be merged as a body into the Knights of Labor. Harmonious relations between the two organizations will, however, be preserved.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11.--By this evening's mail advertisements are sent to the press by the Navy Department inviting proposals for a variety of work and material in connection with the new navy. American shipbuilders are invited to submit proposals for the construction of one cruiser of about 4,000 tons, one of about 3,700 tons, one heavily armed gunboat of about 1,700 tons, one light armed ...

LONDON, Sept. 11.--Cummings beat George in a four-mile run at Preston to-day. Geeorge led until they entered on the fourth mile, when Cummings spurted and went to the front. Cummings finished the distance alone, George retiring on the sixteenth lap. The time for the four miles was 20 2-5. The first two miles was made in 10 2-5. Twelve thousand persons witnessed the race.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 11.--An unknown man who was arrested at Middletown yesterday forenoon and placed in the lock-up, was found dead in his cell during the afternoon. He was identified as a painter who had been working about town for the past few days.
Buffalo Bill and his band of Indians, Mexicans, and cowboys will leave Staten Island on Sept. 25. The season has been very successful.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Sept. 11.--At 9:30 o'clock this morning a cry of "Fire!" was raised in Main-street, and in a short space of time D.C. Perrine's store was in flames. The fire burned steadily, the oil, turpentine, and gunpowder which Mr. perrine stores being the starting point. Mr. Perrine had just received a large cargo of Autumn goods...
The journeyman plumbers are preparing an open letter to Col. Auchmuty, the Superintendent of the Trade Schools, in which they explain their position in the difficulty with the master plumbers.

The Mayflower sailed the Galatea 20 miles to leeward and return yesterday, in the second of the races for the America's Cup, and beat her very close to half an hour. It was a signal victory for the white witch of Boston, for her designer, Mr. Edward Burgess, for her skipper, Capt. Stone, for her pilot, Capt. Joe Elsworth; and last, but far from least, for her...

Anthony Comstock's war upon District Attorney James W. Ridgway, of Kings County, promises to be a very lively one, judging by the charges and specifications, together with the exhibits in the shape of affidavits and newspaper clippings, which have been laid before Gov. Hill. In the long letter which accompanied the other documents, Mr. Comstock called the Governor's...

CHICAGO, Sept. 11.--It is now said that Miss Kitty Rober, the actress who is lying ill here, under peculiar circumstances, is no relation to Miss Sallie Reber, the actress whose secret marriage to Mr. Fish, in New-York a year ago, caused much coment.

Eight short stories from the farms and factories of New-England introduce the native rustics and operatives, the English, Irish, and French working people, citizens by adoption. No very happy lot is theirs if we are to take the author's characters for representatives; but it can be safely held that the tragedies which mark each...

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Sept. 11.--The seized schooner Everett Steele has been lucky enough to get out of the clutches of the Canadians without even a fine. The vessel was seized for an alleged infraction of the customs law on the occasion of her previous visit to Port Shelburne.

NYACK, Sept. 11.--Society in Nyack is sadly disturbed over a coming divorce suit, as foreshadowed this week when Mrs. T.F. Tasman instituted proceedings against her husband for an absolute divorce, the co-respondent being Mrs. Sarah E.F. Hunter, the wife of John H. Hunter, General Manager of the Consolidated Gas Company, of New-York.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 11.--The Louisville Club played listlessly in the first part of to-day's game and the home team obtained a lead which the visitors were unable to overcome.

The Rev. Father Chow Ju Tien, a Chinese Buddhist priest, arrived here yesterday. He was received with all the honors that could be be stowed upon him by the Chinese merchants of Mott-street. He made the store of Kwong Hing Lung, of No. 5 Mott-street, his headquarters. He was visited during the afternoon and even ing by hundreds of Celestials.

ANAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 11.--An eight-inch gun, in being removed from a barge at the Naval Academy to the wharf, to-day, broke a plank, knocked a sailor overboard, and broke the leg of Boatswain John S. Sinclair, of Washington.

The expedition of Roman Catholics from Portland, Me., to the shrine of Ste. Anne de Beaupre, in the Province of Quebec, is a result of the reported miraculous cure by faith of HERMINE LABRIE, the circumstances of which were so remarkable that they have attracted more attention to the ...

TOLEDO, Ohio, Sept. 11.--The police are to-night seeking to unravel a mysterious affair that may have a very commonplace sequel, but which has some of the elements of a first-class sensation. When the Wheeling and Lake Erie train from the East arrived this forenoon among an assortment of trunks was one from which there came a terrible odor.

The conviction that the Mayflower would defeat the Galatea, the experiences of Thursday, the departure of many of the Massachusetts visitors, the depletion of pocketbooks by the expenses of the two previous days, and the unwillingness of the owners of many craft to again run the risks of a long run to windward, operated disastrously against the interests of the steamboat companies yesterday.

--Life at a German bath begins early; at 6 A.M., or 7 A.M. at latest, the majority of health seekers walk down to the Homburg wells to take their prescribed quantity of water. The scene then in this charming valley is interesting and lively. The long alley leading from the Kaiser to the Elizabeth Spring is thronged with people...

The Rev. Charles B. Smyth, of the First United Presbyterian Church, in East One Hundred and Sixteenth-street, near Third-avenue, who has been under sentence of suspension from his ministerial functions since July, 1885 received yesterday from the commission to which he finally appealed the case news of the annulment of the sentence and the reasons for its reversal.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 11.--The saltiest testimony yet heard in the Converse trial was that given by Col. Bennet H. Young, a pillar of the church in this city and a business man of high standing.

TORONTO, Sept. 11.--The Knights of Labor demonstration to-day was a great success. Five thousand men were in the procession, which, with bands and banners flying, presented a novel and pleasing sight. All the trades were represented. The streets were lined with people.
NEWTOWN, Conn., Sept. 11.--Dodgingtown is one of the most remote parts of this town, and its district school is not overburdened with apparatus and other aids to modern learning.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11.--The Pittsburgs' fielding to-day was about the worst ever seen here. Both Atkisson and Galvin were hit hard, but the latter's miserable support permitted the Athletics to run up 16 unearned runs.

The past week has seen society interests chiefly centered in the international yacht races, and hence there has been little of social incident outside the waters of New-Yorg Bay. WASHINGTON, Sept. 11.--The leaves of absence of the following-named Second Lieutenants have been extended to Oct. 1: L.G. Berry, Fourth Artillery; R.G. Proctor, Fifth Artillery; J.J. Pershing,...

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Sept. 11.--A Canadian Pacific freight train ran into a large boulder near Port Portage yesterday. The engine and four cars were wrecked, and Conductor Herfferan and the fireman were killed.

--There are nearly 800 letters of Cicero now extant, besides at least 90 letters addressed to him; and we know that this large collection is a mere fragment of the immense correspondence that he left behind him. It extends over a period of less than 25 years--i.e., it gives us on the average a letter for about every 11 days of the last 25 years of his life.

BOSTON, Sept. 11.--A few days ago the New-England Shoe Leather Exchange issued a call to the leather manufacturers of Massachusetts to meet in this city to-day to discuss matters of vital interest to the trade. Almost to a man the manufacturers responded, and the meeting was probably the most important one in the history of the trade to manufacturers,...
OTTAWA, Sept. 11.--Archbishop Duhamel will shortly leave for Rome to confer with the Pope regarding the affairs of the Archdiocese of Ottawa.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11.--The Western managers who were so certain last night that a pool to stake the place of the old Western Freight Association had been formed found that they were mistaken. When they met again this morning the troublesome question...

Two of the Vanderbilt "boys," as it is still popular to call the sons of William H. Vanderbilt, sent in contributions yesterday to the Chamber of Commerce fund for relieving Charleston. Cornelius Vanderbilt gave $1,000 and William K. sent his check for the same amount. Another one-thousand-dollar contribution was from "A Friend," who insisted upon secrecy as...
OTTAWA, Sept. 11.--It is understood that at the meeting of the Cabinet to-day the idea of holding general elections this fall was abandoned in view of the recent defeats in Chambly and Haldimand.
FORT SMITH, Ark., Sept. 11.--A murder was committed last evening near Scullyville, Choctaw Nation, by Lewis Burrows, a half-breed. Burrows had a quarrel with William Morgan, a...

CHICAGO, Sept. 11.--The Washington Park Club has announced a special sweepstakes of $500 each for the trotters Oliver K., Harry Wilkes, and Belle F. for a race of mile heats, best...

The Brooklyn Athletic Association gave a testimonial to its Athletic Director, E.W. Johnston, on the club's grounds, at De Kalb and Classon avenues, Brooklyn, yesterday. Nine records were broken, of which Thomas F. Kearney, professional champion jumper, of Boston, broke four; G.A.J. Queckberner, of the New-York Athletic Club, and amateur champion weight thrower, two, and James Grant, champion professional...

BOSTON, Sept. 11.--Two indictments have been found against Samuel G. Snelling, Treasurer of the Lowell Bleachery, for embezzlement of funds of the bleachery company and for falsifying the statement of the debt of the company, which he made oath was $120,000 less than the true figures.
LONDON, Ontario, Sept. 11.--To-day while playing with a loaded revolver a 10-year-old lad named George Lewis accidentally shot and killed George Bruce, aged 5 years.
AUBURN, N.Y., Sept. 11.--The Republicans of the Second Cayuga District, in convention in Moravia to-day, nominated Coral C. White, of Scipioville, for member of Assembly.
SOFIA, Sept. 11.--The Regency has issued a decree convoking the National Assembly for the 13th inst. The following dispatch has been sent to Prince Alexander, signed by 200 Deputies:

CINCINNATI, Sept. 11.--Suit was brought to-day for a dissolution of the Westwood Railroad Company, which owns five and onequarter miles of narrow guage track, extending from Brighton, a station on the Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton Road, within the city limits, to Westwood.

The mysteries of the turf are becoming deeper and more inexplicable every day. On Thursday last a cow could have beaten Blue Wing in the Bridge Handicap and he was more than a furlong behind the winner. Yesterday, in the Sheepshead Stakes, he won with consummate ease in time within half a second of the record.

The subject of the present memoir was both intellectually and in the faithful discharge of duty among the worthiest of the educators and prelates which the Episcopal Church in the United States has produced. He was not what is called a brilliant man, or a man of striking genius and corresponding power, but he was something better than these.

--Aphrodite. A Romance of Ancient Hellas. By Ernst Eckstein. From the German by Mary J. Stafford. New-York: William S. Gottsberger.--Alma Tadema's art, because form and color are ever persistent, gives pleasure, but we are not so sure that imitative classicism in literature is as agreeable.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 11.--Drafts on New-York, sight, 15 cents; telegraphic, 20 cents.
The eighth annual regatta of the Union Boat Club took place yesterday afternoon on the Harlem River, over a mile course without a turn, between Macomb's Dam and the NewYork Central bridges.

The Irving Hall meeting of Friday night, at which ex-Senator Thomas C.E. Ecclesine referred to President Cleveland's administration of the Government as the "rule of an ingrate." and predicted the election of Gov. Hill to the Presidency, was much talked about among politicians yesterday.

Delightful dreams of the stage, they've laded away--Nina Varian, Venie Clancy, Maude Stuart, Daisy Murdoch! Young, pretty, interesting! I knew them as I have known others more substantial and vivid in mimic life, but all of whom alike, it seems, destined to be of the names forgotten save when revived under the fitful wave of the reminiscent wand that flashes them into momentary thought again.
Jockey Daniel Spaulding, who rides for the Dwyer Brothers, was a prisoner in Justice Waring's Court, at Coney Island yesterday, on a charge made by Maggie Gerraty.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11.--The Washingtons defeated the Philadelphias to-day in a very interesting and exciting game, which was won in the eighth inning through good batting and an excusable error by Irwin.

DANVILLE, Va., Sept. 11.--The losses by the fire last night were as follows: Worsham's box factory, $11,000; insurance, Western, $1,925; Imperial, $1,925. The ice factory loss was about $12,000; a large part of the machinery was saved; insured in the Western, Imperial,...

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Sept. 11.--Mail advices from St. John's. Newfoundland, give particulars of a sad affair that happened near that place. Four women and a girl--Mrs. Rose and her daughter, Mrs. Clark, Mrs. Bright, and Mrs. Cole--left Victoria Village and went to the woods berry picking.

For the second time in two months the New-York Lacrosse Club has upheld its title to the lacrosse championship of the United States. The game yesterday was on the Staten Island Cricket Ground, and the popularity of the game with the ladies was shown by the crowded state of the Ladies' Club house and the deep fringe of dresses on the two rows of benches erected on one side of the ground.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11.--Attorney-General George Hunt filed a petition in the Circuit Court yesterday against William H. Wills, Henry Hudson, William W. Younger, Joseph H. Thompson, and A.L. Crandall to have them removed from...
AUGUSTA, Ga., Sept. 11.--The end of the great strike and look-out in Augusta, which has rendered idle 5,000 people and seriously crippled a thriving town, is fast aoproaching.
Sergt. John H. Adams has been appointed Quartermaster-Sergeant of Company G, Seventyfirst Regiment.

GUILFORD, Sept. 11.--The population of this little town are alive to the importance of the sea serpent episode in the history of Connecticut. A close watch is being kept for his marine majesty, and some of the dwellers on the Menunkatuck River, which empties into the Sound...

For some time past I had been striving to obtain employment of a permanent kind which would be fairly paid, when the above advertisement in the Times caught my eye. It seemed to me the very thing I wanted. The salary of 300 would give me, a single man without any extravagant habits, enough to live on in comfort.

A gang of tramps boarded a Pennsylvania Railroad train at Philadelphia yesterday morning. Conductor Vogel discovered them when the train reached Frankford, and with the aid of his brakemen attempted to put them off.
The Sub-Executive Committee of the Independent Labor Party, which is said to consist of 10 men, met last evening at Clarendon Hall to make arrangements for opening the Fall campaign.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Sept. 11.--At a public meeting of the legal voters this evening at Mangold's Broadway Hotel for the purpose of selecting candidates for the new borough government to be voted for next Monday, between 2 and 7 P.M., the following candidates were nominated: For Mayor--William R. Woolley; Councilmen--R.P. Dobbins, Rufus Blodgett, D.M., Hildreth, R.V. Breece, F.W. Cooper, and Richard Flannigan; Tax Collector--John A. Howland.

The services to-day in the churches will be unusually solemn and impressive in honor of the feast of the Most Holy Name of Mary. Tuesday will be observed as the exaltation of the Most Holy Cross. Friday will be the feast of the stigmata on St. Francis and special services will be held in the Church of St. John the Baptist, in West Thirtieth-street, and in the...
Nathaniel Harsh, of No. 42 East Seventyfifth-street, walked along East Seventy-sixthstreet yesterday morning with a valuable little terrier in his arms.

A book of no little value, as the view of a loyalist of the American Revolution appeared some time ago under the above title. The compiler has found in the letters and papers of his great-grandfather sufficient that is of interest to form another book, which now appears as Vol. II.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., Sept. 11.--Dr. A.P. O'Malley was arrested here recently at the instance of the Prudential Life Insurance Company of Newark, N.J., charged with conspiracy...
BALTIMORE, Sept. 11.--The celebration of the anniversary of the battle of North Point, during the war of 1812, is of the past, and will be known no more by the defenders of Baltimore at that time.

Electric lighting has been before the business world now about ten years. Before that period it was a matter of laboratory experiment that had more or loss of interest to physicists and students. It was acknowledged that the electric light, and by that term the arc light alone was meant, ...

Philip Drieger, alias Carroll, a young man who is credited by the police with being an expert forger, was brought before Justice Smith at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday, to answer a charge of forgery.

Dewdrop, the noted filly of the Dwyers, died yesterday noon. The filly was out taking her usual exercise on Friday morning at the Sheepshead Bay track, but when she returned to the stable Matt Byrnes, who has charge of one division of the Dwyer stable, noticed that there was something wrong with her.

WILMINGTON, Del. Sept. 11.--Two of the three counties of the State held elections for the nomination of members of the State Legislature to-day and the result is an overwhelming victory for the Bayard faction.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11.--The war against the Lake Shore Railroad Company in the town of Lake has broken out afresh, this time in the use of explosives. A few moments before 12 o'clock last night James Calvin, the night operator, was sitting in the signal tower of the Lake Shore Company at the intersection of the main and stock yard tracks.

OTTAWA, Sept. 11.--Sir Charles Tupper, High Commissioner to England, arrived here today to confer with the Government regarding the proposal to make the Colonial Exhibition a permanent institution. He will return in October.

SANDUSKY, Ohio, Sept. 11.--Mrs. Henry Bennett, living seven miles from here, swore out a warrant to-day for the arrest of Louis Gildemeister, a wealthy farmer and business man, at Seven Mile House village, charging him with assaulting her in her house. Owing to the prominence of the parties the affair creates great excitement. Gildemeister was arraigned before a Justice of the Peace to-day, and gave $1,000 ball for his appearance.

DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 11.--The August product of the Lake Superior copper mines was Calumet and Hecla, 2,790 tons; Quincy, 321 tons; Franklin, 202 tons; Atlantic, 212 tons; Huron, 100 tons; Tamarack, (estimated,) 200 tons; Osceola, (estimated,) 165 tons.

ALTOONA, Penn., Sept. 11.--Annie Renner, a bright and pretty child of 10 years, was burned to death on the street this afternoon, her clothing having become ignited from a bonfire around which she was playing. She was horribly burned before assistance reached her.

A half block of conduit was joined on Sixth-avenue yesterday, and the trench went on to Thirtieth-street. The day being Saturday, work stopped early, and in the prophecies for the coming week it was announced that the...

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Sept. 11.--The striking weavers at the Potomska Mill held another meeting this morning, and upon securing a satisfactory adjustment of the existing troubles voted to return to work on Monday. The fine system will be observed, but the weavers are to be exempt except in instances where they themselves are at fault.
TORONTO, Ontario, Sept. 11.--The Mail, the Government organ, announces to-day that the Dominion Government intends to proceed at once with the matter of the establishment of a...

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 11.--Gustave Hultquist, while employed in oiling machinery in the Jamestown Worsted Mills to-day, was caught in the gearing. The skin on his arm from the elbow to the arm-pit and half way down his side was torn off. An effort will be made by local surgeons to graft small pieces of skin upon the flesh.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 11.--The Board of Health met in special session to-day and removed the quarantine that had been enforced on the town of Biloxi, Miss. This was done on the assurance that the fever at that point had entirely disappeared.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 11.--A 10year-old boy, named Thomas Pulley, was drowned this evening while bathing in the canal opposite this city. His body has not yet been recovered.

ERIE, Penn., Sept. 11.--Great excitement was created in political circles to-night by the appearance of a card signed by the Hon. William L. Scott accepting the renomination for Congress, which he had positively refused at the hands of the Democratic conferrees a month ago.

The statement made by some of the English papers that Mrs. John W. Mackay is desirous of purchasing Houghton Hall or any other estate in England is wholly incorrect, nor has Mr. Mackay any intention of making such a purchase.
A complaint has been made against Thomas Beloff, a baker, of New-Brunswick, for defrauding Mrs. Agnes Wessell, a 90-year-old woman, of her pension money.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11.--The sympathizers with the condemned Anarchists held another meeting last night at West Twelfth-street Turner Hall to express their indignation at the conviction of their compatriots and to raise money for their further defense.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Sept. 11.--With the exception of several slight shakes, which were only perceptible, however, to the more nervous, Charleston has been remarkably quiet to-day. There was a heavy rainfall this morning, which added to the discomfort of the homeless people in the camps, and induced a general return to the houses.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 11.--A collision occurred this morning on the Burlington and Northern Railroad at Potosi, Ill. Two engines and several cars were wrecked. Train Dispatcher Hyde, of La Crosse, and several passengers were injured.

The management of the Polo Grounds having generously offered the use of the same for the oc casion, the NEW-YORK TIMES Baseball Club and a picked Nine, under the management of Mr. W.C. Barnes, of the World Club, will play a game of ball for the benefit of their brother typos in Charleston, on Wednesday afternoon, Sept. 22.

It was James Pain's day at Manhattan Beach yesterday, and a great day it was. In the afternoon day fireworks, which were popular two seasons ago, were let off and the light bombs that departed into filmy figures sent high in the air.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 11.--Louis Ryder, one of the leading confectionery dealers of the city, recently sold out his business to James E. McKeon, of Blackstone, Mass. Ryder...
OTTAWA, Sept. 11.--It is officially announced that the elections for the Province of Quebec will take place on Oct. 12, and the nominations five days earlier.

A hundred and twenty jovial gentlemen sat around Nat C. Goodwin in Delmonico's dining hall last evening, the occasion being a complimentary dinner given to that gentleman by his friends to celebrate the commencement of another season.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 11.--W.R. Tuttle, a brakeman on Conductor Davis's Erie freight train, fell from a freight car while his train was passing through Chester yesterday, and received injuries from which he died soon afterward. Tuttle was a single man and boarded at Port Jervis. He fell from the car in front of his fathers' house, his parents residing at Chester.

For the past seven years the leading batters of the country have been trying to put a ball over the fence at One Hundred an Twelfthstreet on the Polo Grounds, but up to yesterday they had all been unsuccessful. Connor, of the New-Yorks, however, performed the feat yesterday when the New-Yorks defeated the Bostons.
The Prohibitionists in the Third Congressional District in Brooklyn have nominated A. A. Robbins, a plasterer, of the Seventh Ward, for Congress to succeed Darwin R. James.

COVINGTON, Ind., Sept. 11.--Arista Glover, who was implicated in the swindling transactions of Indiana Township Trustees during the Summet of 1885, was to-day sentenced to two years in the penitentiary and fined 1 cent for having accepted a bribe of $3,500 in consideration of issuing township orders to the amount of $10,000 to Davis Brothers and R.B. Pollard, of Chicago.

PARIS, Sept. 11.--In political circles the week has been rather quiet. It is true that Boulanger has played at inspecting the Italian frontier, which everybody said M. de Freycinet would not allow him to do, and that the Berlin mission has been filled by Herbette just when everybody had concluded that it would not be filled at all.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 11.--A special from Houston, Mo., says that night before last, at a farmhouse near Summerville, 21 miles southeast of Houston, occurred one of the most terrible tragedies ever known in this section.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, Sept. 11.--About 30 of the guests of the Tuller House had a glorious time the other night. They started out in coaches for a moonlight sail on Canadarago Lake, where they took possession of the steamer T.R. Proctor and started on their cruise around the lake. The party consisted of Mr. and Mrs. Vanderhoof, Mr. Smith, Mrs. Jewell, Mr. Scudder, Miss Van Buskirk,...

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 11.--The body of a young woman was found floating in the sound off Southport and brought to this city today. Foul play is suspected, and Dr. Garlick, the Coroner's physician, from his examination believes that a woolen shawl or nubia had been forced into the woman's mouth. It is supposed that the body was thrown into the water from some passing vessel.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 11.--F.J. Ditter, a shoe merchant doing business at No. 422 Mainstreet, made an assignment this morning, appointing Henry D. Parker his Assignee.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Sept. 11.--At the Republican District Convention held here to-day delegates were elected to the Congressional Convention instructed to favor N.W. Nutting for Congress. No candidate for member of Assembly was nominated to-day.
LONDON, Sept. 11.--The steamship Sacrobosco, (Br.,) Capt. Thompson, from Philadelphia Aug. 29 for Antwerp, passed the Lizard to-day.

The coming week will doubtless draw many riflemen and their admirers to Creedmoor, at the annual meeting of the National Rifle Association, which will last for six days, beginning at 9 o'clock to-morrow. Each day's practice includes some attractive feature, and the meeting promises not only to be well attended but to arouse a feeling of friendly rivalry that will insure zest in the competition.

Among the passengers who sailed yesterday for Liverpool on the Cunard steamship Etruria were E. Spencer Pratt, United States Minister to Persia; Secretary George Jenner, of the British Legation; Capt. Beaumont, of the...

MONTREAL, Sept. 11.--The cricket match between the English gentlemen and the Montreal Club began to-day and was witnessed by the largest crowd that has ever turned out on these grounds for a similar event. The greatest interest is taken in the match.

Rehearsals of "The Hermit of Cashel" have proceeded far enough to justify the management in predicting for its presentation at the Metropolitan Opera House, for the week beginning Oct. 4, a success worthy of its purpose.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 11.--The ravages of hog cholera in the central part of the State are a matter of serious study by those concerned. An important discovery in connection with the disease is alleged to have been made by a farmer named Sheppard, in Henry County.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 11.--The close of the second week in September finds Newport well filled with visitors. All the hotels and private boarding houses are still open. The cottagers will be found here for some time to come, and they will now enjoy the most delightful part of the year without being obliged to entertain or to be entertained.

The season is at present at its height at all the fashionable French Summer resorts. These are the days on which one can fully appreciate how varied and beautiful are the styles of the hour, and how the fashions of different periods are used to the best advantage.

Henry A. Stannynought, alias Sinclair, who shot himself Tuesday evening, was discharged from the New-York Hospital yesterday and arraigned at the Jefferson Market Police Court to answer a charge of attempted suicide.

OTTAWA, Sept. 11.--The Hon. G.T. Foster, Minister of Marine and Fisheries, returned to-day from a trip to British Columbia. Speaking to THE TIMES'S correspondent of the recent seizure of British vessels off the Alaskan coast while engaged in sealing he said: "At Victoria I personally took the depositions of several seamen who were on board one of the vessels at the time of the seizure.

The result of the race yesterday confirms the impression made by the race of Tuesday and the attempt to race on Thursday. It may be regarded as settled that in any weather in which yachting is a pastime the Galatea has no chance with the Mayflower on any point of sailing.

WATERBURY, Conn., Sept. 11.--The discussion as to why Robert Drakeley, the rich young man from Baltimore, shot his six weeks' bride, Maude Marwick, at Woodbury, three weeks ago, is now revived by the developments of the dead woman's will, which has now been probated.

Albert Williams, a convict who had been spending the past five years in Sing Sing Prison for a forgery committed in Buffalo, was discharged yesterday morning, having served his term. As he was about to walk away he was arrested by an officer from Boston, who had a warrant for him for a forgery committed there.

An attempt was made on Friday to poison the entire family of Jacob Schlopper, a farmer living near Flemington, N.J. During Thursday night some person entered the kitchen and placed a handful of Paris green in the coffee pot. The entire household, consisting of over a dozen persons, drank of the coffee made in the vessel.

BOSTON, Sept. 11.--Mason P. Helmbold, alias Drexel, alias G. Lanier, who was arrested at Albany on Wednesday for forgery, is wanted in this city for the same crime. He is a forger of the most clever description, the method of his work being well illustrated by an instance of his operations in Boston.

--Ancient chron iclers state that King Edgar attempted to extirpate the wolves in England by commuting the punishments for certain offenses into the acceptance of a certain number of wolves' tongues from each criminal, and in Wales by converting the tax of gold and silver into an annual tribute of 300 wolves' heads.

Natural conditions began to tell in Wallstreet this last week. Prosperity extending in every direction all over the land, stiffening every branch of trade, putting profits where losses have hitherto been felt--a prosperity that is no longer merely an optimistic theory, but a fact-- has made itself felt.

Two weeks ago "Nevada Ned," a vender of Indian specialties, opened a cheap imitation of Buffalo Bill's Wild West show at Oakland Park, on Jersey City Heights. He had not been there many days before some of the seats, arranged in amphitheatre style, gave way, and one or two persons were injured.

The annual Fall prize meeting of the National Rifle Association begins to-morrow at Creedmoor. Its programme is very nearly the same as that which has been familiar for years, and is perhaps about as useful as any that can be made up with the means at the association's disposal.

Vanbergen, in this city today, Mr. Vilas stated that President Cleveland had promised to make a tour of the West with him next Fall. Mr. Vilas said he intended bringing the President to this place to spend a week hunting and fishing.

LONDON, Sept. 11.--The European situation is still shrouded in a thick fog of falsehood and in speculation upon this fog. Trivial things throw colossal shadows and senseless rumors take on proportions of vital magnitude, while all the time really significant movements are cloaked from sight.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Sept. 12.--There was only one shock of earthquake here to-day. It came at 11 o'clock this morning, just about the time the church services began, but it was so slight that it did not create a panic or cause unusual excitement. In fact, the people are becoming accustomed to seismic disturbances, although they cannot be said to "hanker after them."

MONTREAL, Sept. 13.--The second day's play of the English Gentlemen and the Montreal Cricket Club began at 1 o'clock this afternoon. Rain had fallen heavily all day yesterday and the wickets were very soft.

The striking and locked-out plumbers felt much encouraged yesterday upon hearing the reports of their delegates who have just returned from the convention of the National Plumbers, Gas and Steam Fitters' Union that

CHARLESTON, S.C. Sept. 13--The sitation in Charleston remains unchanged. There has been no return of earthquake disturbances since 11 o'clock yesterday, and the people are making the best of it. The work of condemning damaged houses and removing the wreck from the streets is progressing rapidly.
The first annual meeting of the National Philatelic Society was held yesterday at the Metropolitan Assembly Rooms, No. 62 East Fourthstreet.

CONYERS, Ga., Sept.13. A death occurrod here on Saturday which has aroused the superstition of the negroes. Frank Thrasher had whipped his wife so that she had to leave the house. Returning a few minutes later she found him dead. Many negroes believe that it was punishment from on high, while others ascribe it to voodooism.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Sept. 13.-- Judge Hill, of the United States court at Oxford, Miss., granted an order on Saturday restraining the Railroad Commission of that State from interfering with the tariff of the Mississippi and Tennessee Railroad (Illinois Central) in so far as it relates to inter-State commerce. The case will be heard Sept. 22.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept.13.--John Leach's house, on Lawn-street, was burned this morning. and when the firemen broke into the kitchen they found the body of Leach's wife, shockingly charred, partly buried under a fallen chimney. Mrs. Leach was about 45 years old.

There were between 40 and 50 happy men after the races of the Broolklyn Jockey Club were over at Gravesend yesterday. They were bookmakers, and they had much cause for rejoicing, as they had a genuine good day, probably the best of the season.

Miss Lilian Olcott is rich and stage struck. To gratify her passion for acting she did Juliet for some time in Chatham Four Corners and other art centres. But Juliet becomes wearisome after a time even to the actress.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 13.--At the Coroner's inquest in the case of Robert Peaslee, who was shot at Sydney by Samuel P. Hill last Friday, Hill claimed that he shot Peaslee in selfdefense, stating that the latter attacked him.

The name of ex-Alderman Arthur J. McQuade, junk dealer and boodle Alderman, appears on the books of the Essex Market Police Court as surety for some twoscore delinquents who have thereby gained transient immunity from punishment.

Not the least noticeable feature of Secretary WHITNEY'S circular to shipbuilders and steel manufacturers is its invitation to supply the Navy Department with about 1,310 tons of steel gun forgings, of which more than two-thirds are to be used for 10-inch and 12-inch calibres.

PORT NORRIS, N.J., Sept. 13.--The body of Enoch Danzen Baker, 70 years of age, was discovered Iying on the floor of an old cabin at Long Reach this morning. He was dressed, and held some crackers in one hand and a piece of cheese in the other. Domestic and financial troubles caused him to seek the solitude of the cabin, where he met his death alone.

PARIS, Aug. 31,--I have just learned on unquestionable authority that the Duo d'Aumale, on the eve of his expulsion from France, was married morganatically to Mlle, de Clinchamp, the gouvernante, or, in plain English, the house keeper of the Chateau of Chantilly.

ALBANY, Sept. 13.--Incoming morning trains brought members of the State AntiMonopoly League from near and far, and at 3 o'clock this afternoon they were called together in the writing room in Stanwix Hall by Secretary Keogh.
The Catskills will be invaded by the Dutch to-day, It will be a peaceful invasion, so far as the members of the Holland Society of New-York, who are to constitute the invading party are concerned.

MARION, Ind., Sept. 13.--Malhala J. Calrert fatally shot her husband, Jeromo B. Calvert, on a public street in this city with a 32-calibre revolver last evening. The ball passed entirely through his body just above the heart.
The gross receipts of the concert in aid of the Charleston sufferers at Wallack's Theatre on Sunday evening were $1,509,50; its net proceeds will amount to $1,264.

The prosecution of the poolseilers and ra-- cing associations of Kings County under indict-- ments found by the July Grand Jury began yesterday, before Judge Walsh, in the Sessions Court in Brooklyn. The indictments included the Coney Island Jockey Club, the Brighton Beach ...

DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 13.--To-night, in spite of a drenching rain which began at 5 o'clock, the auditorium of White's new Grand Opera House was filled to its utmost capacity with the wealth and fashion of Detroit.

LITTLE ROCK, Sept. 13.--An Indian Territory special says: "The canvass for principal chief is attracting general interest. The Hons. Rabbit Bunch and Joel B. Mays, candidates of the national and Downing parties, respectively, are working quietly but effectively.
CHICAGO, Sept. 13.--A dispatch was received at Police Headquarters to-day from Philadelphia asking that one Meyer Breidenbach be apprehended and held until the arrival of an officer.
Mayor Grace is in Lenox, Mass., and will not return to this city for several days. President Nooney, of the Board of Aldermen, is acting Mayor.
The return cricket match between the Manhattan Club and the Trentons, of New-Jersey, was played yesterday in Prospect Park.

BALTIMORE, Md., Sept. 13.--The several posts of the Grand Army of the Republic to-day celebrated the anniversary of the battle of North Point by a parade in the city and a campfire at Darley Park, east of the city limits.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13.--The resignation of First Lieut. Philip C. Wales, Assistant Surgeon, has been accepted by the President, to take effect Nov. 8. Capt. R.H. Montgomery, Fifth Cavalry, has been granted one mouth's leave of absence.

LONG BRANCH, N.Y., Sept 13.--The dullness which prevails here after the big hotels have closed was broken to-day by an election for officials for the new Borough Government, for all of Long Branch cast of the New-York and Long Branch Railroad. The following were elected:
Kiralfy Brothers' spectacle, " Sieba," was produced at the Grand Opera House last evening, and the performance was witnessed by a large audience.
DOVER, Sept. 13.--The yacht Volta, propelled by electricity, started hence across the Channel to Calais on her trial trip to-day. She reached Calais in 3:51.

The Electrical Subway Commission will hold a meeting this afternoon, but will take no action relative to the Western Union Telegraph Company's attempt to evade the law by stringing its wires along the Third-avenue elevated railroad structure.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13.--A circular to naval architects has been issued by the Navy Department respecting the designs advertised last week for two armorod vessels of about 6,000 tons displacement. It embodies in detail the conditions to which those who submit designs must conform.
RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 13.--Ex-Congressman John S. Wise, a warm personal friend of Mahone's and a prominent Republican, will publish a letter to-morrow recommending his party

CHICAGO, Sept. 13.--Tho adjournment of Saturday's meeting of the managers of the Western roads without having been able to perfect the proposed pooling agreement when the day previous all points had virtually been settled and agreed upon caused much talk

DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 13,--At Panora last night Lew Apple, editor of the Gazette, shot himself through the head and died this morning. Last Summer his wife, who has since died, attached his property in connection with divorce proceedings Por adultery. He bought flowers at the State Fair and in a note directs them to be placed on his grave.
LONDON, Sept. 13.--A sculling match between George W. Lee, of New-Jersey, and Neil Matterson, the Australian oarsman, took place to-day on the Thames championship course, and was won by Lee.
Steamship Eros, (Br.,) Blankhorn, Hamburg 19 ds., with mdse, to Lawrence, Giles Co.

LONDON, Sept. 13.--The Parnell Land bill as redrafted suspends evictions on payment into court of half the rent due. Many Gladstoniaus disapprove of the amount, of the reduction. The Parneilites assert that the full values, justify

Ed Adams, a brother-in-law of Harry Wardwell, of the firm of MeIntyre Wardwell, is a frisky young broker on the floor of the Produce Exchange. So is Walter Munn, who has an office in the Produce Exchange Building with his brother.
The County Democracy Committee on Credentials, to which was referred the contests in the Fifth and Fourteenth Assembly Districts, met last evening in the New-Amsterdam. Club.

In the suit of Contractor James F. Gillen against Supervisor Wolfert, of the Twenty-sixth Ward of Brooklyn, to compel the payment of $27,000 for work done in the ward when it was the county town of New-Lots, prior to Aug. 1,
QUEENSTOWN, Sept. 13.--The Inman Line steamship City of Chester, Capt. Lewls, from New-York Sept. 4 for this port and Liverpool, was signaled off Brow Head at 6 o'clock this evening.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13.--Provisions were unsettled and higher to-day, with tho dealing in Lard very light, but large in other articles. Pork oponed 5c, higher, at $10 85 for October, sold up to $11 45, closing at $11.42 , with November at 32 c. discount, and January at 20c. premium. The year sold at $10 65@$10 92 . Lard was quiet.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 13.--It has leaked out that the two gas companies of this city, one manufacturing coal gas and the other water gas, have consolidated. The latter has been swallowed by tho old company.

AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 13.--The people living in the coal mining regions, embracing four towns and quite a large range of country, were awakened at 4 o'clock on Sunday morning by low rumbling sounds accompanied by shocks of earthquake so distinct that houses were terribly

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 13.--Particulars of the damage done by the cyclone in Burnside, in the town of East Hartford, could not be gathered last night, because of the bad working of the telegraph and telephone wires. The track of the cyclone extended over a distance of a mile, and was not over 12 rods wide at any point.
PARIS, Sept. 13.--The French authorities at Havre have just seized 11 English fishing boats for infringing the international maritime and fisheries laws in the channel.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept.18.--Henry Honsinger, aged, 12, living six miles south of this place, while bathing in a pond near his fathor's house, last evening, was seized with cramps. His brother William; aged 15, went to his assistance, when the struggling boy grasped his hand, and both were drowned.
It is quite certain that no "Obstruction Commission" prevented the Western Union Telegraph Company from stretching its wires along the Third-avenue elevated railroad ...

One of ex-Collector Hedden's proteges, Peter Neary, will no longer adorn the position or enjoy the emoluments of opener and packer at the Public Stores, Collector Magone having let the official axe do its work with him yesterday.

It seems to be generally assumed that the object of arresting GEORGE W. ALTER, under the indictment found against him last May, is not simply to secure his punishment for perjury, though that ought to be reason enough for the proceeding.

LONDON, Sept. 13.--Daly's company had an enthusiastic reception in Dublin to-night. They appeared at the Gaiety Theatre in "A Night Off." Although the prices had been increased to the operatic standard, the house was full.

NAUGATUCK, Conn., Sept. 13.--A melancholy youth named Squires walked into Kane's drug store yesterday afternoon and asked for an ounce of laudanum, saying that a stage driver had asked him to get if for use on the driver's horses. Squires secured the drug, and going to Culver's Grove swallowed a quantity of it.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13.--Mr. J. M. Thompson, a young man from the South, who has been in business in a cotton house in Memphis, and whose health was suffering in consequence of an uncongenial climate, came to Washington a short time ago, and, desiring to enter the Government ...

The New-Yorks lost another game yesterday, when the Bostons won by figures of 4 to 3. Both sides batted very poorly, only 10 hits--5 by each nine--being made throughout the contest. The heavy batters of the local club, including O'Rourke, Connor, Gillespie, and Dorgan, ...

Two hundred and fifth able-bodied men, the pride of the First Ward, composing the Greenwich Guard, started out at 9 o'clock yesterday morning to crowd as much enjoyment into the day as would ordinarily fall to their lot during a whole year.

LONDON Sept. 13.--The Mark-Lane Express, in its weekly review of the British grain trade, says: "Owing to the continued wet weather it will be impossible to make an early delivery of sound native wheats.
The cricket match between the West Indians and the Staten Island Club was begun on the grounds at Livingston, Staten Island, yesterday.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Sept. 13.--If the additional hands expected by the Augusta factory are here to-day they have not reported for duty, probably through fear. The weaving, carding, and spinning rooms are in operation. Late last night two of the "scabs" were cornered in a dark street and unmercifully beaten. Others escaped.

The heirs and next of kin of Miss Henrietta A. Lenox, who died a few months ago, were cited to appear before Surrogate Rollins yesterday to attend the probate of her will. The matter was adjourned, however, until Oct. 13.
WINCHESTER, Va., Sept. 13.--A large vote was polled here to-day. Much zeal is manifested on both sides.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14.--For Maine, NewHampshire, and Vermont, fair weathor, followed by local rains, slightly warmer winds, generally westerly.

The fourteenth annual prize meeting of the National Rifle Association was begun yesterday at Creedmoor. It will continue until Saturday. Lieut. E.L. Zalinski, of dynamite gun fame, is executive officer.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 13.--It is reported today that C.P. Huntington has proposed to Albert Netter, broker, representing Eastern men in the recent purchase at Forced sale of the Cincinnati and Eastern Railroad, to buy the road at a fair figure.
Railroad earnings were reported in Wallstreet yesterday as follows for the first week in September: Omana, $126,500, an increase of $5,100 over the corresponding week of last year;

CLEVELAND, Sept. 13--Much interest attaches to the Nickel Plate mortgage foreclosure suit, which will begin to-morrow before Judge Jones, of the Common Pleas Court in special session. SOME OF THE POINTS OF LAW THAT WILL COME BEFORE THE COURT AT CLEVELAND FOR DECISION.
NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 13.--Mrs. Catherine Atwood, the oldest resident of Port Jervis, died at the home of her son, Thomas Atwood, on John-street, in that village, on Saturday, aged 93 years.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Sept, 13,--Sight drafts on New-York, 12 telegraphic, 20.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Sept. 13.--Capt. Lawton was busily engaged yesterday in preparing his official report on the Apache campaign. He says he is not entitled to all the credit of capturing Geronimo, and that Lieut.
Mystery will take possession of St. Louis on Wednesday, Sept, 22, when Mecca Temple of the Nobles of the Mystic Shrine of this city visit Moolah Temple of St. Louis. Medinah ...

DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 13.--About 8 o'clock last evening a young man named Murdock, who has been employed as a workman on the State Fair Grounds all Summer, was fatally stabbed by a young colored man named Strader.

COLUMBUS, Sept. 13.--A political sensation was created to-day in the Court of Common Pleas, the September term of court opening today. After the usual formalities the Judge took an abrupt departure from the usual course, and made a most vigorous and sweeping charge.
CHICAGO, Ill., Sept. 13.--The following is the report of the visible supply of grain Sept. 11, as compiled by the Secretary of the Chicago Board of Trade: Wheat, 44,870,000 bushels; increase, ...

A secret conference of the Clan-na-Gael, the Irish ravolutionary organization, was held last evening in Irving Hall. About 300 delegates, representing the various camps in this vicinity, were present.

MARSHALL, Ill., Sept. 13.--George Powers, a telegraph operator and agent of the vandalia Road, stationed at a lonely spot about a mile from Marshall, was assassinated early on Sunday morning by some one who fired at him through a window as he was writing. The murderer robbed his victim of a watch and $15 in money. Bloodhounds have been sent for to trace the murderer.

Abort 40 workingmen assembled last evening at Washington Hall, at No. 220 Avenue A, to organize a Labor Party in the Fourteenth Assembly District, and began their meeting by excluding all who were not union men.

CONCORD. N.H., Sept. 13.--Delegates to the Republican State Convention, which meets in this city to-morrow, have been arriving all day, and nearly all are in town to-night. The two principal candidates for the Gubernatorial nomination

SOFIA, Sept. 13.--The National Assembly met to-day. The Russian agent has received the Czar's reply to Bulgaria's proposals. The Czar says Russia will recognize the Bulgarian regency and assist the union of Bulgaria and Eastern Roumelia on condition that no acts of violence be committed.

Henry Irving evidently went home with agreeable memories of his late pleasure visit here, and has come to the front in a way that will make him dearer than before to the Southern people, if not to the whole country, by cabling Wells, Fargo, Co. 100 for the Charleston sufferers.

Mr. Frederick Bryton entered upon a week's engagement at the Windsor Theatre last evening, and came forth in Mr. Clay Greene's drama entitled "Forgiven," which was referred to at some length in these columus last March. "Forgiven," which held the attention ...

NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 14.--The fortysixth annual fair of the Orange County Agricultural Society opened at the Benkard Grounds, in the southern part of this city, to-day, under more than ordinarily favorable auspices.

MONTREAL, Sept. 14.--If a citizen of NewYork City were asked how he thought John Keenan and the 1884 Aldermanic exiles stood their retirement to a safe retreat across the border he would, no doubt, picture them as worn out by worry and anxiety, and as longing for a chance to return to the city the principal thoroughfare of which they helped to turn over to ...
ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 14.--The State Senatorial District Convention which closed here to-day resulted in a victory for the Prohibitionists.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 14.--Speaker John G. Carlisle concludes an interview upon the economies of the present Administration with the following paragraphs on tariff reform: "In my opinion there is a reasonable prospect that the Democratic Party will become substantially united upon the tariff question.

Some of the public-spirited residents of that portion of Tarrytown made famous in the writings of Washington Irving as the "Sleepy Hollow" region have recently organized a committee, to be known as the Washington Irving ...

Mr. Lawrence Barrett as James Harebell in Mr. Wills's gracefully written version of the German "Lorbeerbaum and Bettelstadt," called "The Man o' Airlie," presents a characterization of remarkable beauty. His acting is natural and unaffected, but finished in every detail.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 14.--Ex-Lieut.Gov. Dorsheimer, of New-York, was the principal witness at to-day's hearing in the contest over Millionaire Tracy's will. He appeared on behalf of the estate, and his testimony was of a peculiarly interesting character.
JEFFERSON, Texas, Sept. 14.--A gentleman residing in this city has just received a letter from A.K. Cutting, which runs thus:

ST. CONCORD, N.H., Sept. 14.--As indicated in these dispatches last night, Col. Charles H. Sawyer had a walkover for the Gubernatorial nomination of the New-Hampshire Republicans to-day. He was nominated on the first ballot, receiving more than three-fourths of all the ballots cast.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 14.--At a meeting of the Philadelphia Iron Trade Association held here to-day the price of bar iron was advanced 1-10th cent per pound.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 14.--Medical Examiner Eliot, has made his return to Coroner Mix on the death of Ella Matthews's child, whose body was found floating in the Quinnipiac River.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14.--James Seymour McFarland was to-day expelled from the Chicago Live Stock Exchange, of which he has for some time been a member, for having made false returns to his country customers. McFarland was tried before a jury of his fellow-members, and the trial was held with closed doors.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Sept. 14.--The Maroons did themselves credit to-day, beating Chicago in one of the most exciting contests of the season. Clarkson was batted hard and the Maroons bunched their hits at the right time.
A number of other union men engaged in the clothing manufacturing trades took action yesterday in sympathy with the cutters' strike.

Mr. Lester Wallack had a consultation with his staff on Monday and finally decided to open the regular season at Wallack's on Monday evening, Oct. 11, with Mr. Henry Hamilton's new play of "Harvest." The piece has not yet been produced, but will be presented for the first time in London at the Princess's Theatre on Monday evening next.

Although three of the six favorites won at the Sheepshead Bay track yesterday it may be accounted a day of surprises, and the bookmakers had much the best of it. In the three first races the favorites came to grief, and speculators were in a quandary.

Theodore H. Rudolph, a bookkeeper at Edgar Farmer Co.'s trunk factory, in Newark, has disappeared. He left the factory Monday morning to get his breakfast. Since then nothing has been heard from him. His books are being examined.
LONDON, Ontario, Sept. 14.--The Supreme Council of the Catholic Mutual Benefit Association held its sixth biennial session to-day in this city.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14.--Mr. Thomas E. Benedict, the new Public Printer, took charge of the Government Printing Office to-day, after having been sworn in by Judge Lawrenson, of the Post Office Department, who has administered the oath of office to all the Public Printers and to nearly all the Postmaster-Generals who have ever held office.

ST. PAUL, Sept. 14.--The Democratic State Convention met at noon to-day at the Exposition Hall to nominate a full State ticket. The convention was called to order by the Hon. Michael Doran, who introduced the Hon. J.F. Meagher as temporary Chairman, and J. McHale as Secretary.
Albert Hansen, a laborer, 22 years of age, living at No. 66 Lafayette-street, Brooklyn, rode upon the big bridge in a truck yesterday afternoon from the Brooklyn end.

PORTLAND, Sept. 14.--Later returns do not change the result materially from that telegraphed last night. It will be a week, at least, before the whole vote is in. Returns from the First Congressional District are complete, and show a plurality of 1,350 for Mr. Reed, which is about 400 larger than two year ago.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 14.--The yacht Mayflower arrived here at 11 o'clock this morning, ready for the race of Saturday. Most of the other yachts entered for the race are expected to-day.

A special cable dispatch to THE TIMES from Paris two months or more ago announced the matrimonial engagement of Millionaire Jay Gould's oldest son, George, to the handsome and accomplished Miss Edith Kingdon, of Daiy's Theatre company. Many folks constituted themselves critics of the dispatch, and denials [of the most sweeping sort were volunteered from a variety of sources.

MONTREAL, Sept. 14.--The third and last day's play of the cricket match between the English Gentlemen and the Montreal Club commenced at 12 o'clock to-day, the Montreals following in their second inning.
NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 14.--The fiftieth anniversary of the marriage of Mr. and Mrs. Hector Moore was celebrated at their home on Roberts-street, Middletown, on Sunday.

ALBANY, Sept. 14.--The anti-Manning Democrats who voted for Blaine in 1884, and have been threatening to reorganize the local Democracy here ever since the Kelly bolt in 1879, took steps to-day to carry out their scheme of revenge.

The press throughout the country has made itself merry of late over the failure of the city of New-York promptly to build the pedestal for the statue of Liberty and the monument over the tomb of Gen. GRANT.

LAREDO, Texas, Sept. 14.--Prominent men of Mexican lineage in this city, who have reliable means of knowing, claim that a concentration of the revolutionary forces is now going on along the borders, and that preparations are ...

CINCINNATI, Sept. 14.--The jury in the case of J.B. Mannix, late Assignee of the Archbishop Purcell estate charged with embezzlement, was discharged late this afternoon without having agreed upon a verdict. It is said 10 were for conviction throughout the 24 hours of deliberation and 2 for acquittal.

Two artists, John R. Strickler, of Brooklyn, and Thomas L. Palmer, of Boston, studied art together in Carlos Duran's studio in Paris. They were almost like brothers, and Palmer was a great ladies' man.

ERIE, Penn., Sept. 14.--The train arrived in Erie this evening from the scene of the frightful accident at Silver Creek, on the New-York, Chicago and St. Louis Railroad. Henry Hayck, of Sterrettania, whose legs were ground to a pulp and which were amputated while the train was en route for Erie, died as he was being taken from the train here.

NYACK, Sept. 14.--Another elopement in Rockland County, breaking up a happy home, is the result of the infatuation of a woman with a traveling minstrel, named John White, who claims in past years to have belonged to Haverley's troupe.
An attempt was made in the law authorizing the repavement of Fifth-avenue to secure for that great thoroughfare as perfect and durable a pavement as could be laid.
INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 14.--An important decision was made by the Probate Court here today.

Peter Mitchell, the lawyer, has just returned from a seven weeks' pleasure trip through Europe and has declared himself a candidate for Congress in the district now represented by Nicholas Muller. Mr. Mitchell expects to secure the Tammany nomination, and among those who believe that he will be the wigwam's candidate is Civil Justice Michael Thunderbolt Norton.

LOUISVILLE, Sept. 14.--The Louisville Presbytery adjourned to-day to reconvene on the second Tuesday in November, when the trial of the Revs. T.E. and F.B. Converse will be resumed as a special order.

LONDON, Sept. 14.--A dispatch from Vienna to the Times says there are rumors in diplomatic circles at the Austrian capital that recent negotiations between the three Emperors have restated favorably, and that there are now good prospects for an agreement between Russia, Germany, and Austria relative to common action in Bulgaria.

Father Thomas J. Ducey, of St. Leo's Roman Catholic Church, in East Twenty-eighthstreet, yesterday filled with Dr. Nagle, the Deputy Registrar of Records of the Health Department, the certificate of the marriage solemnized ...

OSWEGO, N.Y., Sept. 14.--Senator Warner Miller, who was born in Oswego County, delivered the annual address before the Oswego County Agricultural Society at Mexico to-day. His presence was the occasion of an unusually large attendance, and the address is generally regarded as one of the most valuable ever delivered before the society.

DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 14.--Last evening Dr. C.W. Paine, a physician supposed to be in good circumstances, committed suicide at Grand Rapids by taking morphine. He was proprietor of what he termed a medical and surgical institute and had rooms fitted up elegantly in one of the business blocks of the city, where he cared for patients, in which he ...
Yesterday's play by the West Indian and Staten Island Cricket Clubs, on the grounds of the latter, was in marked contrast to that of the first day of the match.

Excitement reigned in yachting circles yesterday. An early rising member of the NewYork Yacht Club dropped into the cozy little clubhouse, No. 67 Madison-avenue, on his way down town and looked at the bulletin of the entries for the Newport races. At first he could not quite believe his eyes.
The trial of the Coney Island Jockey Club for permitting gambling on its track at Sheepshead Bay was continued yesterday in the Brooklyn Court of Sessions.
James McCrudin, who, in a fight in Robert Walsh's saloon on Box-street, Greenpoint, was kicked in the abdomen by Walsh, died yesterday at his home, No. 49 Jackson-avenue, Long Island City.
PROSPECT HOUSE, N.Y., Sept. 14.--The second attempt at a deer hunt having proved a failure on account of a storm of unusual violence, President Cleveland betook himself to fishing once more to-day.
Important railroad extensions were reported on Wall-street yesterday as having been settled upon. The Bee Line Road is to be extended to Kansas City from Indianapolis, in accordance ...

There was no place down town, until yesterday, where a merchant could retire or take business friends for a quiet lunch, or with any certainty that his company and surroundings would be congenial.

The Sub-Executive Committee of the Irish Parliamentary Fund Association held a special meeting yesterday afternoon at the Nassaustreet office of the fund. HUDSON, N.Y., Sept. 14.--Gov. Hill arrived in this city at 11 o'clock this morning and was received at the station by a committee of the Agricultural Association and the Municipal Government.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Sept. 14.--On the morning of Sept. 4 General Superintendent Clowry, of the Western Union Company, in Chicago, telegraphed E.H. Brown, the Manager of that company in this city, asking him why he had failed to forward his usual monthly statement regarding the condition of affairs in his office; also, ...
GREENWICH, N.Y., Sept. 14.--J.W. Fort, of South Easton, was nominated by acclamation for member of Assembly this afternoon by the Republican Convention in the First District of Washington County.

The second day of the Fall prize meeting of the National Ride Association, at Creedmoor, was ushered in yesterday with a breeze which would have filled a yachtsman's heart with joy, but which was regarded with great disfavor by the marksmen.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 14.--George Dunn and Joseph Brown, colored boys under 16 years of age, employed by Farmer Symmes Bergen, of East Windsor, are in the county jail here for assaulting Elizabeth Thompson, a white girl 12 years old. They pleaded guilty to-day, and will be sentenced on Friday.

TOPEKA, Kan., Sept. 14.--In the United States court the opinion of Judge Brewer was filed this morning in a case of great importance, involving the powers of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad Company to extend its line into other States and Territories outside of Kansas.
PARIS, Sept. 14.--A Cherbourg paper reports the arrest near here of several German spies, who were traveling disguised as priests.
There was a mile foot race yesterday afternoon at Mott Haven, on the grounds of the New-York Athletic Club, for the bronze figure of Atalanta given by A.V. De Bernales.
CHICAGO, Sept. 14.--Twenty Postmasters met here to-day in response to a call for a general Postmasters' Convention to consider the formation of a benevolent mutual aid association.

The motion on behalf of the District Attorney to vacate the order of Judge Churchill allowing the Commissioner of Jurors to be examined as to the method of the drawing of the Grand Jurors who found the indictment against Squire and Flynn was argued in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday.

The popularity of Mr. Poole's new theatre on Eighth-street is already firmly established. Mr. W.J. Scanlan is still seen there nightly in "Shane-na-Lawn."
As has been anticipated, the coal managers advanced prices yesterday 15 cents a ton for chestnut coal and 10 cents for all other sizes.

ELBERON, N.J., Sept. 14.--The first social event of note that has occurred at this charming seaside resort since the Chandon-Garrison wedding, about two years ago, was the marriage at the pretty little St. James's Church to-day of Anthony Drexel, Jr., son of Banker Drexel, of the well known firm of Drexel, Morgan Co., to Miss ...

SYRACUSE, Sept. 14.--The political branch of the State Trades Assembly met in annual convention in the City Hall at 12 o'clock to-day. There were 79 accredited delegates present who were entitled to vote, but the attendance upon the convention numbered about 150.

MONMOUTH, Ill., Sept. 14.--The Democrats today renominated W.H. Neece for Congress.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Sept. 14.--Government has notified counsel for the United States in the fishery cases that the prosecution will be ready to proceed with the case against the schooner David J. Adams on the 28d inst.
The last Baltimore Plenary Council directed that in each diocese ecclesiastical conferences should be held four times a year.

Trouble of an aggressive nature is in store for the Western Union Telegraph Company. CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 14.--The suit of the Union Trust Company, of New-York, Trustee, to foreclose the second mortgage of $10,000,000 on the Nickel Plate, was placed on hearing this morning before Judges Jones and Hamilton, of the Common Pleas Court.

SCRANTON, Penn., Sept. 14.--The most intense anxiety regarding the fate of the seven miners who were overwhelmed in the Marvine Colliery by the disaster of yesterday morning still prevails in this city. The search was conducted all night long by brave gangs of workmen who literally took their own lives in their ...

ELIZABETHTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 14.--A party, consisting of Cornelius A. Hart, County Clerk of Staten Island; his brother, P. Albert Hart, John N. Nichols, and three guides killed a 4-year-old stag to-day in Bouquet River, at the foot of Cobble Mountain, three miles from this place. This is the second deer killed here this season. Two more hunting parties start for the mountains to-morrow.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 14.--The circular emanating from half a dozen prominent Democrats, calling for the nomination of candidates for public office at a primary election, instead of in conventions, has been circulated for signatures today, and it is stated that several thousand names have already been appended to it.
The reports of railroad earnings that reached here yesterday continue to be encouraging.

HOTEL KAATERSKILL, N.Y., Sept. 14.--The fellow who hasn't a pedigree as long as one's arm and who cannot name as an ancestor one of the original Dutchmen who assisted in the building of Noah's centreboard yacht, vulgarly known as the ark, doesn't amount to much up here to-night.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14.--The rumored loss of the steamer Gracie Barker was found to be false through a dispatch received late last evening stating that she had run into Petoskey, where she was awaiting the subsidence of the storm. Another rumor current last night was that the little steamer Dewar, which was afterward found to have left Saugatuck last night for Grand Haven, had foundered in the afternoon.

CUSTER, Montana, Sept. 14.--The Piegan Indians made another raid on the horses belonging to a camp of Crows on Saturday, on the Big Horn near the mouth of the Rotten Grass River, and succeeded in making away with nearly 60 of them.

The admirers of John L. Sullivan, now of New-York, and Frank Herald, of Nicetown, Penn., have long been anxious to see those distinguished gentlemen within a 24-foot ring. Several attempts to bring about such a meeting have been frustrated by the authorities of NewYork and New-Jersey.

The prediction just made in Laredo that the 16th of September, the anniversary of Mexican independence, will witness "a demonstration that will shake the Mexican Government to its foundations," has the merit of being one for whose verification we shall not have long to wait.

Engineer Balch, who was engaged by the Commissioners of Accounts to examine the work of Contractor Matthew Baird on the repavement of Fifth-avenue, has made a second report, covering the work completed to July 24, representing in value over $100,000.

The returns from Maine tell their own story and confirm the interpretation which we were forced to make of them yesterday. No sensible and patriotic man, not carried away by partisan feeling, can deny that the Republicans are likely to give the State a better Government on the whole than the Democrats would have given it.

WILMINGTON, Sept. 14.--As a natural sequence to Saturday's delegate election the Bayard faction captured the convention of Kent County Democrats to-day, but through a lack of leadership they were unable to enforce the terms of a cast-iron programme mapped out, and gained less than their dictatorial position warranted.
NYACK, N.Y., Sept. 14.--The Rev. Mr. Laukenheimer, of Bergen, N.J., has been called to the pastorate of the Brick Reformed Church at West New-Hempstead, Rockland County.
Coroner Eidman was summoned yesterday to Bellevue Hospital to take the ante-mortem deposition of John J. Degnan, a liquor dealer at No. 414 East Eleventh-street, who is a patient ...

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 14.--A strong effort is being made to induce President Cleveland to pardon James A. Hedden, the wrecker of the First National Bank of Newark. Hedden's seven years term in the State prison will expire on Sept. 27.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14.--An army court-martial has been appointed to meet at West Point, N.Y., for the trial of Private J.B. Correa, Company E, Battalion of Engineers.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14.--Gordon S. Hubbard, the oldest settler of Chicago, died at his home in this city to-day. Mr. Hubbard had been ailing for some years, and his death was not unexpected. He was born at Windsor, Vt., in August, 1802, and when 13 years old went with his family to live in Montreal, Canada.

LONDON, Sept. 14.--It is stated in the lobby of the House of Commons that the alterations made at the last moment in Mr. Parnell's Land bill have only served to increase the Government's dislike of the measure; also, that all the members of the Conservative Party and about a dozen Liberal Unionists who still remain in town will oppose the second reading of the bill.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Sept. 14.--It is two weeks to-night since the great earthquake of Aug. 31, and there is some uneasiness among nervous people who believe that earthquakes run in series of sevens, like chills, lest there may be another "visitation" to-night. There have been no disturbances for the past 48 hours, however, and the worst is over.

When the Democratic State Committee meets on Tuesday next, at the United States Hotel, Saratoga, the members will in all probability vote not to hold a State Convention. John O'Brien will in all likelihood not resign from the committee, although this point has not yet been hor oughly determined.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 14.--At 11 o'clock this morning an east-bound excursion train on the New-York, Chicago and St. Louis Railway collided with a west-bound freight in a deep cut one mile east of Silver Creek.

A Texan whose name, for some unexplained reason, was not given, visited the District Attorney's office yesterday and said that T. J. Hill, who was the companion of James T. Holland, the murderer of Tom Davis a year ago, ...
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Sept. 14.--Sight drafts on New-York, 12 ; telegraphic, 20.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14.--The managers of the Western roads were again in session today without being able to perfect the proposed pool on freight traffic between Chicago, St. Louis, Omaha, Council Bluffs, and Nebraska points.

ERIE, Penn., Sept. 15.--All the bodies of the Erie victims, so far as they have been identified, have been sent here for interment, and this evening crape fluttered from a dozen homes of sorrow. The churches will hold funeral services, and requiem masses will be said to-morrow for the repose of the dead in all the Catholic churches, ...

The report that the Consumers' Gas Company is negotiating for the purchase of $1,000,000 of the securities of the New-York Mutual Gas Company and a representation in the directory of the latter has started speculation as to the object of this move.
PARIS, Sept. 15.--The Defense says that the Pope, in deference to the wishes of French Catholics, has postponed the dispatch of a Legate to China.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 15.--Information is received of a serious cave of the river bank in St. Charles, Bourbon Parish. Near the lower end of the star or plantation in front of the Catholic church on the west bank of the river, 32 miles above New-Orleans, a front width of about three acres, extending back several hundred feet, went into the river, carrying the levee with it.

Upon the opening of the Sessions Court in Brooklyn yesterday, in which the Coney Island Jockey Club has been on trial for alleged violation of the gambling laws prohibiting the registering and recording of bets, Judge Henry A. Moore delivered his charge to the jury. He called their attention to the terms of the indictment and then said:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15.--The Acting Secretary of the Treasury this afternoon issued the one hundred and forty-second call for the redemption of bonds. The call is for $15,000,000 of the 3 per cent. loan of 1882. Notice is given that the principal and accrued interest of the bonds designated will be paid ...

It was currently reported in theatrical circles that Edward E. Rice had peremptorily ordered the earth to stop revolving on its axis yesterday. The energetic manager expected Henry E. Dixey and company to arrive from England on the steamship Nevada, and as he had ...

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 15.--The damage suit brought by Edward E. Nisewander against John McBride, Democratic candidate for Secretary of State, charging him with alienating the affections of his wife, and claiming $10,000 damages, has been set for trial on the 27th inst.

Members of the Brooklyn Library, at Montague and Court streets, will be glad to learn that the new card catalogue, upon the preparation of which a vast amount of labor has been expended, is at last ready for use.
A certain number of the rank and file of the Thirteenth Regiment, Brooklyn, have issued circulars stating that a meeting is to be held in the armory to-morrow night to protest against ...
"The Minute Men" will be next week's play at the Grand Opera House. The Lyceum Theatre will open on Saturday evening with "The Main Line," for which the sale of seats has now begun.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 15.--About a month ago circulars were sent out from this city by leading Knights of Labor addressed to Western delegates to the Richmond Convention, inviting them to stop over in Pittsburg on their way South and hold a caucus and map out a line of policy to be pursued in the convention.

The subcommittee of the Executive Committee of the County Democracy met last evening in the New-Amsterdam Club rooms, in Twenty-fourth-street. Senator Michael C. Murphy presided. The following resolutions, offered by Fire Commissioner Henry D. Purroy, were unanimously adopted:
NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 15.--The man who died in the Middletown lockup last Saturday has been identified as Peter Haviland, who was a half brother of Mrs. Jane C. Hunt, of Fishkill.
A great deal has been printed in the newspapers as to who shall take the leadership of the Tammany organization and try to fill the vacancy caused by the death of John Kelly.

Chief of Police McKane, of Coney Island, said yesterday that he would do all in his power to prevent the proposed glove contest that is announced to take place in Paul Bauer's Casino tomorrow evening between Sullivan and Herald.

PARIS, Sept. 15.--The Republique Francaise publishes a telegram from London which states that "England meditates a grand coup d'etat and will probably proclaim Egypt a British possession. She will, however," adds the Republique Francaise, "do nothing until she has a sufficient force at Alexandria."
Railroad earnings reported yesterday continue to show an increase over the corresponding period of last year.
"Agnes."--It is not. Bayne's Sixty-ninth Regiment Band will give a concert this evening at Paradise Park.

Although the clouds were dark and lowering there was a very large attendance of people at the track of the Brooklyn Jockey Club, and some fine sport was witnessed. The horses, however, continue to run very cunning, and the spectators were in a quandary after the first race, which resulted in a genuine surprise.
