The Vanderbilts have extended their coal interests by the purchase of the Clearfield Coal Company's property of 33,000 acres, out of which they will no doubt take large quantities of soft coal. The company will be reorganized for this purpose. The Beech Creek Railroad Company that operates in that region has been ...

ROCK ISLAND, Ill., Sept. 15.--The Society of the Army of the Tennessee met at Harper's Theatre at 10 A.M. to-day and held a brief business session at which committees were appointed to report to-morrow. In the afternoon the society went to Van Druff's Island, where the County Veterans' Association was in camp.

The marksmen contesting for the National Rifle Association prizes at Creedmoor, who had begun to think they were to have nothing but cross-range and "fish-tail" winds throughout the meeting, were agreeably surprised at the improved shooting weather of yesterday. At no time did the wind blow more than six miles an hour, and it was a tired sort of wind, ...

BOSTON, sept. 15.--The irrepressible Parson Downs had a field day at Reading to-day on the occasion of the annual meeting of the Boston North Baptist Association. The little church was packed with those interested, all wearing that mysterious air of expectancy which denotes ...

PITTSBURG Penn., Sept. 15.--Capt. Lew Clark, manager of Geneva Park, a Summer resort six miles below the city, received a telegram from John L. Sullivan to-day asking if he could arrange to have his six-round contest with Frank Herald in Pittsburg or vicinity. Capt. Clark wired back that the match could take place in Geneva Park, either Friday, the 17th, or Monday, the 20th. It is probable that the fight will take place on Friday.

Gen. John Newton, the Commissioner of Public Works, yesterday succeeded, with the aid of Messrs. Spencer, Dowd, and Baldwin, of the Aqueduct Commission, and against the senile absurdities put forth by Adolescent Minnow Fish, Jr., and the adroit moves of Messrs. BOSTON, Sept. 15.--There was a hot and acrimonious debate to-day in the colored men's convention over a motion to reconsider resolutions adopted yesterday which had been construed as indorsing President Cleveland. The motion was carried.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 15.--Mack Clark, one of a party of masked men who attempted to assassinate D.W. Purdam, at Manchester last Spring, for guiding internal revenue officers to illicit distilleries, has been acquitted. Clark, who was dangerously shot during the fight which ensued, was freed on the ground of insanity. There is much indignation over the verdict of the jury.

TORONTO, Sept. 15.--The Trades Congress of labor delegates from different parts of Canada at present in session here, which is the most important labor gathering ever held in this country, to-day passed resolutions declaring for manhood suffrage, for grouped constituencies, with ...

CHICAGO, Sept. 15.--A report is current here that the Rev. Dr. O'Reilly, of Detroit, is about to resign the Treasurership of the Irish National League, and that the Rev. Maurice J. Dorney, of St. Gabriel's Church, at the Stock Yards, will be selected by the Executive Committee of the League to succeed him.
LAS VEGAS, New-Mexico, Sept. 15.--Today a train of coaches came from the south bearing the Chiricahua and Warm Spring Indians from the San Carlos Reservation, in Arizona, to Florida.

HARRISBURG, Sept. 15.--Chairman Isaiah Rynders, of the Greenback State Committee, says there will be from 100 to 125 delegates in the convention of that party, which will meet in this city to-morrow at 10 o'clock.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 15.--Rumors circulated in Wall-street and elsewhere that the Bee Line is to be extended from St. Louis to Kansas City, that it is backing the St. Louis and Chicago, and also projects a branch to tap the Chicago and Alton at Roodhouse are distinctly denied by Bee Line officials here, one of whom said to-day:

A motion for the payment of alimony in an action for limited divorce or separation, instituted by Kate N. Spraker against George Spraker, was argued yesterday before Justice Andrews by Counselor Myer J. Stein, of ex-Recorder James M. Smith's office. The defendant did not appear.
DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 15.--The State Board of Equalization, which meets once in five years, has just closed its prescribed work.
Judge Smith had the nomination of both parties for Judge of Probate in Caledonia County, and received the entire vote of the county--a rare compliment.

Coroner M.J.B. Messemer hopes to secure the Tammany nomination for Mayor. The Coroner was a candidate two years ago, but stepped aside to give Hugh J. Grant a chance. It is doubtful whether he will step aside to please anybody this year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15.--A plan of promotion has been prepared by the Civil Service Commissioners, and will probably be submitted to the President for his approval soon after his return from the Adirondacks. It contemplates the formation of Boards of Promotion in each department in Washington, to be assisted by an auxiliary number from each bureau, to whom ...

SYRACUSE, Sept. 15.--The Labor Conventioa met at 10:30 o'clock this morning. Various resolutions were presented.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Sept. 15.--August is a flush month among the milk producers, and the consumption of the article in the New-York City markets reaches the highest figures of the year. A statement of the quantity handled during the month, in the aggregate and in detail of the several sources of supply, compared with ...

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 15.--There is a difference of opinion among the miners of the country as to the forms of organization that will best serve their interests. The federation which recently met here favors open work, and that free from any connection with organizations not strictly confined to mines and miners.

LONDON, Sept. 15.--This was the second day of the Lancaster September meeting. The race for the St. Leger Stakes was won by the Duke of Westminster's b. c. Ormonde. Mr. Manton's br. c. St. Mirin was second, and T. Jenning's b.c. Exmoor third. There were seven starters.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 15.--In the Nickel Plate case today Ashley Pond offered in evidence a copy of the deed, in behalf of the Fort Wayne Road, transferring the roadbed to the Nickel Plate, to show the time the Nickel Plate acquired the title to the roadbed. He also read from the Secretary's books minutes of the proceedings of meetings of stockholders from the ...

MADISON, Sept. 15.--The Democratic State Convention assembled in the State House at noon to-day. Every district was represented, but there was less than the usual number expected from the different sections of the State. The convention, however, was notable for embracing the most distinguished wheel ...

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 15.--A picnic given by the Independent Sons of Honor at the Woodland Garden broke up in a very serious row at an early hour yesterday morning. About 1 o'clock Alexander Shorts and Pete Shorts, who had been at the picnic, started to force their way into the dance hall.

President Huntington is now in San Francisco looking over the ground and considering whether it is worth while to settle the transcontinental fight now. He can do so whenever he pleases, for the Pacific Mail has been the greatest sufferer by the cut in rates and the Southern Pacific has gained a large number of the waterroute customers, who will be slow to return to ...

AUGUSTA, Ga., Sept. 15.--Two boys are in jail here for drugging, garroting, and robbing a burly horse drover. Frankie McGinn and Tommy Mulaney, both just embarking in their teens, met a horse trader named Guest at a wagon yard, and after a short consultation determined to rob him.

LONDON, Sept. 15.--Mr. J.J. Clancy, (Parnellite,) member for North Dublin, arose in his place in the House of Commons this evening and charged the Government with refusing to pay the slightest attention to the Irish members when they urged remedies for the local grievances of the people of Ireland.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Sept. 15.--A lively scene was witnessed yesterday at the State Line Hotel, about eight miles south of this city, between the proprietor, John W. Kohn, and Henry Russell, a farmer. It appears that the proprietor had a note past due against Russell, and the latter, in company with a friend, John Armstrong, went to the hotel for the purpose, as Kohn believed, of paying the note.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 15.--Herman Koch, aged 17, quarreled with an older brotlier yesterday about a pigeon, and when his mother sided with the brother he got a revolver and shot himself in the back of the head, inflicting a mortal wound. The lad had an ungovernable temper. and had been perversely contrary from infancy.
P.S. Gilmore, whose band has been increased to 75 performers, is to have a benefit at Manhattan Beach this afternoon and evening, and a select and varied programme has been arranged for the occasion.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 15.--For more than six months letters containing money addressed to corporations and individuals in this city have failed to reach their destination, and it was considered reasonably certain that some one in the Hartford Post Office was carrying on a systematic scheme of robbery. From external evidence there was ground for suspicion that the ...

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 15.--Capt. J. V. Albertson, 50 years old and a former member of the City Council, has disappeared. He left his residence yesterday morning and was last seen at Newfield. He was a member of the Twenty-fifth New-Jersey Volunteers and contracted disease during the Fredericksburg campaign which has since caused him much trouble mentally.
Speaker Carlisle's letter thanking the Republican Congressmen who gave him a silver service at the close of the last session roads as follows:

QUEBEC, Sept. 15.--Advices just received from Labrador say that the herring fishermen there have been very successful. Several schooners filled at Bras d'Or and at Red Bay by a single cast of the seine. The fish are of superior quality. The cod fishing, on the other hand, is poor.

A score or more of the veterans of the Ninth Regiment left Jersey City last night at 8:15 o'clock by the Pennsylvania Railroad to visit their old battlefields at Antietam, South Mountain and Gettysburg.

CHICAGO, Ill., Sept. 15.--B. Sunfield Co., grocers, had to answer to a charge of selling spurious butter for the genuine article before Justice Hawkinson yesterday. The defense asked for proof of the nature of the article sold, and also for a trial by jury, but the Justice refused to entertain any motion for delay and fined the firm $50.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 15.--Senator Harrison opened the Indiana Republican campaign to-night before a large audience in the Grand Opera House. It was a notable gathering, representing in some measure the Republican Party of the State. In arranging for the meeting it was the intention of the State Committee ...

CHICAGO, Sept. 15.--Assistant State Veterinarian Walker thinks he has discovered a small outbreak of pleuro-pneumonia on the farm of John Carne, near Austin, in this county, and has served a notice of quarantine on Mr. Carne. Mr. Carne keeps four Jersey cows on his place.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 15.--Issac Stephenson was yesterday renominated for Congress by the Republicans of the Ninth District.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15.--"You are the man that insulted me and this is how I get even!" A rather good looking, well dressed, and muscular young woman accompanied this declaration with a straight-from-the-shoulder hit that knocked a dude up against the Pennsylvania Railroad ticket office, at Broad and Chestnut streets, about 11 o'clock last night.

WATERBURY, Conn., Sept. 15.--George I. McDonald, of No. 9 French-street, an employe at Matthews Willard's factory, set to work this morning to slip a belt upon a pulley. In some way his clothing was caught and he was whirled several times around the shaft before the machinery could be stopped. McDonald was found to be terribly bruised about the head and several of his ribs were broken. His chances to recover are very slight.

The delegates held an informal meeting at the Grand Pacific this evening to discuss the preliminaries of the ...

The eagerness of its yearning to please the public by putting it wires under ground has got the Western Union Telegraph Company into trouble, poor thing. Such at least is the view officially taken by the Executive Committee of that long-suffering and public-spirited corporation.
The British bark Avoca, commanded by Capt. Mitchener, was anchored off Tompkinsville, Staten Island, yesterday afternoon bound for London with a cargo of oil.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Sept. 15.--The Northwestern Miller says: "The water power was good throughout the week, and the mills running did a comparatively heavy week's work. The product was 142,780 barrels, averaging 23,797 barrels daily, against 141,200 barrels the preceding week, and 72,620 the corresponding time in 1885.
OMAHA, Neb., Sept. 15.--Private Mallon, of Company C, Ninth United States Infantry, gardener at Fort Robinson, was found murdered at his post yesterday. There is no clue to the murderer.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15.--A New-York policeman named De Koven was a prisoner at the Armory Police Court yesterday. De Koven has been west on a vacation, and on his way back stopped here and has been enjoying life at a great rate. Yesterday, while he was waiting at the station for a train which he was about to take to New-York, a spry young man lured him out into the street.

The probate of the will of Samuel J. Tilden, which was set down for yesterday, at White Plains, was adjourned one week, in consequence of the absence of Mrs. Caroline B. Whittlessey, who resides in Wisconsin. She is one of the heirs and must be present or be represented by counsel.

HAVANA, Sept. 15.--Advices from San Domingo of the 22d ult. say that the revolution there had lost ground; that the advantage was all with the Government, and unless something extraordinary happened the revolution would soon be crushed.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 15.--Mr. Hubert Wilke, who takes the leading part of the Pied Piper of Hamelin in "The Rat Catcher," was taken sick at the Galt House with typhoid fever. He was ailing when he came to the city, and was compelled to go to bed Monday on account of his illness. Mr. Wilke was sent to the Morton Infirmary yesterday afternoon for treatment.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 15.--Hannah D. Meidenbauer and John P. Brauer, composing the firm of Meidenbauer Co., maltsters, at No. 992 Michigan-street, have assigned to George L. Kingston. The preferred creditors include the German Bank of Buffalo, $31,600.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 15.--For some time past the citizens of this city have been exasperated over the frequent crimes committed in Black Bottom, Hell's Half Acre, Rolling Mill Hill, and other portions of the city.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Sept. 15.--Collector Bourinot, of Port Hawkesbury, has three more cases against the schooner Mora Castle since first seizing her for smuggling. She is charged with getting barrels, salt, and supplies, and with other violations of the law.
The turnstile master at the New-Jersey State Fair at Waverly reported last evening that 17,000 people passed into the fair grounds during yesterday.
It is announced that Pierre Lorillard has determined to give up the breeding of race horses and will sell all the thoroughbred stock on his great stud farm near Jobstown, N.J.

PRINCETOWN, N.J., Sept. 15.--The College of New-Jersey reopened to-day with the regular exercises in Marquand Chapel. There was a good attendance. President McCosh and Dean Murray officiated.

SARANAC INN, N.Y., Sept. 15.--A third attempt at a deer hunt proved successful this morning. No rain had fallen during the night, and as the conditions were favorable for the scent lying on the ground the dogs were put out about 8 o'clock.
CHICAGO, Sept. 15.--The Canadian Pacific, which at present reaches Chicago over the Michigan Central, is reported to be making arrangements for an independent line of its own into this city.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 15.--Col. G.W. McFarlane, who arrived here on the last steamer from Honolulu, will proceed to New-York and London in a few days to negotiate a loan for the Hawaiian Government.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 15.--A mild form of boycott has been discovered here. Cards are being distributed asking that patronage be refused those merchants who are named as having refused to join the early closing movement. The Clerks' Early Closing Association denies all responsibility for the boycott and attribute it to the Knights of Labor.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 15.--Goshen was last night the scene of an affray which is likely to prove a tragedy. Two colored men named David Huff and Charles Crawford had planted some potatoes on shares, and now that they were marketed engaged in a dispute as to the division of the proceeds.

One of the most gratifying results of the removal from office of ROLLIN M. SQUIRE and the appointment of Gen. NEWTON as Commissioner of Public Works is the defeat of the corrupt scheme for placing the Aqueduct Commission in control of a political combination.

MONTREAL, Sept. 15.--The Provincial Synod discussed some live questions to-day. The Rev. Dr. Carry began by moving that the use of unfermented wine at sacrament be forbidden. He held that the physical effect of the wine taken in communion could not be injurious while the moral effect of both fermented and unfermented wine might be detrimental.

Quinn, Corps of Engineers; First Lieut. William M. Medcalfe, ordered from the New-York Arsenal to East Lyme, Conn., on public business.

In an interview on Monday at Cincinnati Mr. Speaker CARLISLE spoke with his accustomed earnestness and with his accustomed cheerfulness regarding the chances of tariff reform legislation within the next two years. That, of course, means by the present Congress or the next one.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 15.--The second day of the Orange County Fair, at Newburg, was attended by over 20,000 people. In the afternoon 3,500 Newburg public school children attended the fair in a body, headed by their teachers and the Montgomery Cornet Band. The wages to-day began the work of awarding the premiums in the various classes of exhibits.

LOUISVILLE, Sept. 15.--The Diurnal, a packet steamer running between Louisville and Cannellton, struck a snag near Alta, Ind., yesterday and sank. Her passengers and freight were all removed without accident. The freight was considerably damaged by water. The loss is estimated at $5,000; insurance, $3,000. The Diurnal will be taken out of the water at once.

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 16.--The Political action of the State for 1886 is already settled. The Governor has been designated, twothirds of the Legislature fixed upon, and the reelection of Mr. Gray to the United States Senate assured. The real battle is over, leaving to November simply the formal recording of the result.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 16.--John Wyatt and Demps Loftin are neighbors in Marshall County, Ky., who have not spoken for years Loftin spoke to Wyatt yesterday at a funeral and the latter knocked him down with a stone. Loftin then drew a knife and killed Wyatt, stabbing him seven times.

The Queens County Grand Jury yesterday indicted Mrs. Elizabeth Singer for murder in the second degree in having killed her husband, Bernard Singer, with a crowbar in their home at Ridgewood on the morning of Aug 29. Mrs. ger, who is in jail, will be in court to-day.

BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 16.--The Sixth District Democratic Congressional Convention today, after 16 ballots, nominated E.W. Robertson, of this city, for congress, vice A.B. Irlon, sitting member.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Sept. 16.--The first evidence in the David J. Adams seizure case was taken this afternoon by Commissioner McClellan.

The steamship Parthia, which formerly belonged to the Canard Line, is the pioneer veseel of a new line which will run between this port and China. Carter, Macy Co., of No. 142 Pearl-street, are the agents.
CHICAGO, Sept. 16.--A.T. Parsons was seen at the county jail last night and shown the St. Louis dispatch from Waco concerning himself and wife. Parsons denied the whole story.

MANSFIELD, Ohio, Sept. 16.--A freight train on the Baltimore and Ohio Rail road at Independence to-day struck a horse on the bridge.

Capt. Chester S. Cole, the Chairman of the Republican State Committee, and Charles W. Hackett, the Chairman of the Republican State Executive Committee, conferred yesterday and issued a call for a meeting of the Republican State Committee on Sept. 29, at the Gilsey House, at which time a nomination for the office of Judge of the Court of Appeals will be made.

Public Works Commissioner Newton yesterday ordered Contractor Matthew Baird to suspend the work of repaying Fifth-avenue pending an examination into the charges made in the second report of Col. George T. Balch to the Commissioners of Accounts.

A. Howell, formerly Secretary of the Joint Price Committee of Milk Dealers of this city, and now editor of the Milk Reporter, in conversation with a TIMES reporter yesterday, corrected some of the statistics of the milk traffic for August, as published in a Middletown dispatch yesterday. President Reall called the body to order at 10:30 A. M. and called for a report from the Committee on Resolutions. It came in the following shape, from Mr. Rice, of Minnesota.

DANBURY, Conn., Sept. 16.--Edward Light, a farmer, drove upon the track of the Danbury and Norwalk Railroad at Bethel last night and was struck by a passing train. Light was instantly killed. The engine knocked the wagon into anlinters and the horse was killed.

LONDON, Sept. 16.--The Parnellite members of Parliament, at an informal meeting today, agreed to abate their obstructive tactics after a full debate on the vote for the Irish police and permit the Government to conclude the consideration of the estimates. The object of this decision is to enable Mr. Parnell's Land...

ERIE, Penn., Sept. 16.--Mrs. Mary Godfrey, wife of Rufus Godfrey, a wealthy farmer, of Girard, left her husband's bed last night and, dressing herself, cautiously crept from the house and went to the high bridge on the Nickel Plate over Elk Creek and threw herself from the dizzy height, a distance of upward of 125 feet, and was dashed to death.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16.--The presence of the Republican and Democratic candidates for Governor in this city to-day, created quite a stir at the headquarters of the State committees. ST. LOUIS, Mo., Sept. 16.--What was known as the Rhodes pension trial, which has occupied the time of the United States court in Jefferson City four days, concluded this morning.

Collector Magone had a busy day yesterday, a small part of which was given to County Clerk Flack and Fire Commissioner Croker, who Balled socially, but with the evident view of seeing what sort of timber they would have to deal with in whooping up city politics.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 16.--A circular has been issued by Chairman John Franey, of the Workingmen's Assembly, regarding the incipient bolt of four delegates from the late session of that organization.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Sept. 16.--The Relief Committee have distributed 1,200 blank forms of applications for money to aid in rebuilding houses damaged by the earthquake, but so far only 150 of the forms have been filled out.

SEA GIRT, N.J., Sept. 16.--The great contest that has been going on at the State rifle range at this place for months past for a handsome marksman's badge to be presented by Gov. Leon Abbett to the best marksman in the National Guard of New-Jersey ended to-day.

Ex-Judge Dennis Quinn, an old-time Tammany brave, who knows every man, woman, and child from the Battery to Chambers-street, and many beyond those boundaries, has just returned from a journey through Ireland and Italy.
The election of a successor to Mayor GRACE in November is a matter of supreme importance to the taxpayers of this city, who directly or indirectly constitute the whole body of the people.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17.--That the Anarchist organization in Chicago has not been broken up yet is admitted by the police officers who secured the conviction of Spies and his gang. The groups continue intact.

Those people who study racing form and back horses on it were sadly at fault at the Brooklyn Jockey Club races yesterday. Only two favorites out of the six finished in front, and consequently the bookmakers had another remunerative inning.

In granting an injunction against the defendants Judge Larremore says: "It does not satisfactorily appear that any person by the name of Dr. Warren had any connection with defendants' business, and the use of that name, so similar to plaintiffs', [Dr. Warner,] without special authority is not consistent with good faith and fair dealing; the injunction should be granted."
BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 17.--To-day occurred the fifth incineration at the Buffalo Crematory, and, like those which preceded it, was successful in every particular.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 17.--The total vote of this State in the September election foots up 143,000. Democratic majority, 37,000. The Legislature stands: House--Democrats, 67; Republicans and Wheelers, 23; Senate--Democrats, 27; Republicans and Wheelers, 5.
BUCHAREST, Sept. 17.--M. Bratiano, Roumanian Prime Minister, was shot at last evening by an assassin. M. Bratiano perceived the man's intention in time to spring out of the path of his aim.

Thomas F. Hali, an engineer on the Second-avenue elevated railroad, looked out of the window of his cab at Sixty-first-street last evening, and was badly injured by his head coming in contact with the switch shanty there. He was taken to the Presbyterian Hospital.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17.--As a result of a movement upon the part of the Chief Magistrates of the 13 original States, seven Governors of as many commonwealths met here today to arrange for a fitting observance of the centennial of the promulgation of the Constitution of the United States.

LYONS, N.Y. Sept. 17.--This was the second day of the Wayne County Agricultural Society's fair, and Lyons has never had such great crowds. At 3 o'clock over 15,000 visitors were here from all parts of this region.
The names of the Rev. Dr. Abbott Kittredge, the new Pastor of the Madison-Avenue Reformed Church, and John I. Davenport were ...

VINCENNES, Ind., Sept. 17.--John Schyrock, a wealthy farmer, living near Olney, Ill., was murdered last night by unknown men, who secured $3,000 hidden in the farmer's house. After committing the double crime of murder and robbery, they added a third to the list by burning down the house.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17.--Senator Don Cameron was in this city to-day. In conversation with a Philadelphia Times reporter he said: "I expect to get to Harrisburg in about two or three weeks and shall then remain during the campaign. It is a central place, convenient for our friends."

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17.--The annual cricket match between Gentlemen and Players was begun to-day at Nicetown, the day's play, contrary to all expectations, resulting in giving the professional men a commanding lead.

OMAHA, Neb., Sept. 17.--Two Union Pacific trains came into collision at Gilmore yesterday, demolishing both engines and several freight cars, two of which took fire and burned up. E.M. Jones, a fireman, was instantly killed. Engineer Meely had his arm broken. Engineer Bollon, who overlooked his orders, has been placed under arrest.
A play by the notorious Henri Rochefort is to be produced at the Fourteenth-street Theatre the latter part of October. It is entitled "An Irish Girl, or A Daughter of Erin."
OTTAWA, Sept. 17.--Prof. Wiggins is daily receiving letters from persons in the South regarding earthquakes there. The Professor says the worst has not yet been experienced.

LONDON, Sept. 17.--This was the fourth day of the Doncaster September meeting. The race for the Park Hill Stakes, of 15 each, with 300 added, for 3-year-old fillies, was won by the Duke of Hamilton's Miss Jummy by a neck, with Prince Soltykoff's Argo Navis second, and Sir R. Jardine's Daydream, by Adventurer, out of Fanny Day, a bad third. Six ran.

NEWPORT, Sept. 17.--Yachts have been coming into the harbor all day as thick as the proverbial Newburg fog. Big yachts and little yachts, wide yachts and narrow ones, skimming dishes and deep keels, are lying in a picturesque tangle, with their clean spars and trim rigging ...

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept.17.--The following additional candidates have passed a successful examination and been admitted as Cadets in the Naval Academy: John H. Dayton, at large; John Jherhorn, of New-York; Urban T. Holmes, of Arkansas; Thomas J. Mason, of New-Mexico; Wendell C. Neville, of Virginia.

For several months complaints have been made to the Brooklyn Post Office that letters addressed to certain large business houses were not delivered.
INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 17.--The Portland (Me.) Savings Bank began suit yesterday in the Federal Court against the city of Evansville for $100,000. The suit grows out of the repudiated bonds of 1869.
LONDON, Sept. 18.--A rumor is current that a plot has been discovered to assassinate Prince Alexander, and that two men have been found who were paid to commit the crime.

BUTLER, Ga., Sept. 17.--Hundreds of colored people gathered here to-day to witness the execution of one of their race, the Rev. Jesse Cook, who has just paid the death penalty for the murder of his wife, formerly Mrs. Dehlia Fowler.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 17.--The Central Committee of the United Labor Party, composed of members of the Knights of Labor, the Central Labor Union, and the Trades Assembly, have issued a call for a convention to be held on Oct. 7 to nominate a full city ticket.

RUSHTON, La., Sept. 17.--After a session of three days, in which 64 ballots were had, the opponents of Gen. J. Floyd King concentrated their votes on the Hon. C. Newton, of Moorehouse, and he received the nomination, Mr. King's friends voting with the rest to make it unanimous.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Sept. 17.--Two years ago Bartlett, Tenn., was a flourishing town and a shipping point of no mean importance. The saloon business, like other things, was brisk.
MEMPHIS, Tenn. Sept. 17.--The nomination by acclamation at noon to-day of James Phelan as Democratic candidate for Congress of this (the Tenth) district had more than local significance.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Sept. 17.--Julius Baum Co., wholesale clothiers at No. 9 Sansome-street, assigned to Solomon Sweet today for the benefit of creditors.
NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 17.--The annual fair of the Orange County Agricultural Society at Newburg closed to-day.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 17.--The towboat Lulu Woods and two barges belonging to John A. Woods Sons, coal operators, ware burned to the water's edge in the Monongahela River at 11 o'olock to-night. The crew escaped by jumping into the river and swimming ashore. Loss, $12,000; fully insured.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 17.--Drafts on New-York--Sight, 12 cents; telegraphic, 20.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 17.--Local sporting men are in something of a quandary concerning the Sullivan-Herald boxing match set for to-morrow night. Final arrangements, such as procuring a license, erecting a stage in the Casino building, and other details were completed to-day and the contest will probably take place.

It was a New-York National Guard day at Creedmoor yesterday. There were three matches open only to teams of 12 from each regiment, battalion, or separate company of infantry of the National Guard of New-York.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 17.--The legal proceedings growing out of the elopement of the heiress, Mrs. Frank E. Hill and J.T. Marchand, of Greensburg, have been compromised.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 17.--George Dunn, age 18 years, and Joseph Brown, age 15 years, both colored, were sentenced in the Mercer Court to-day to 15 years in the State prison.
TROY, N.Y., Sept. 17.--The Wine, Liquor and Beer Dealers' Association met this afternoon to make preparations for the convention to be held here Oct. 5.
Rumors that have lately agitated Wallstreet over a projected compromise to put the affairs of the Reading Railroad Company on an improved basis were proved yesterday to be true.

NYACK, N.Y., Sept. 17.--Considerable interest is being manifested in the coming retrial of the Rev. Dr. George R. Bristor, formerly Pastor of the Spring Valley Methodist Episcopal Church, but at present Pastor of the new Congregational flock of that place.

LONDON, Sept. 17.--The Parnellites indignantly deny that they as a party adopted an organized system of obstruction in the House of Commons. They say that the members accused of obstruction acted on their own responsibility.

"Phil" McDowell's presence of mind probably prevented a tragedy at Twenty-third-street and Ninth-avenue about noon yesterday. He succeeded in restraining Policeman Engehausen, of the Twentieth Precinct, from trying to empty his revolver into a runaway bull.
The Executive Committee of the Journeymen Plumbers' Union was in session the greater part of yesterday, considering the advisability of starting co-operative shops in this city.

It was the most uncomfortable, if not the hottest, day of the season yesterday. The rain of Thursday left the atmosphere very humid. At 7 o'clock in the morning the humidity was 96, and at 3 o'clock in the afternoon it was 75.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17.--Col. Charles S. Stewart, Corps of Engineers, was yesterday afternoon, by direction of the President and at his own request, placed upon the retired list. He was the senior officer of the Engineer Corps when Gen. Newton was retired, but his ill health took him out at the list of eligibles for the office of Chief of Engineers.
DANBURY, Conn., Sept. 17.--Three young tramps tried to steal a ride on the midnight freight train from Norwalk over the Danbury and Norwalk Railroad last night.
A meeting of the Mississippi River Commission was held yesterday in the Army Building, in Houston-street. Gen. C.B. Comstock presided.

A Citizens' Association, under the auspices of the Citizens' Committhe of One Hundred, was formed last evening at No. 1,212 Broadway, of the Thirteenth Assembly District, with 182 members. John G. Hyatt was elected Chairman and John C. Casey Secretary.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Sept. 17.--The Second District Republican Convention has renominated D.E. Ainsworth, of Sandy Creek, for the Assembly. The Congressional delegates were instructed to favor N.W. Nutting for Congress.
CHICAGO, Sept. 17.--The Western Export Association at its meeting to-day adjusted all difficulties and every member signed the general agreement.

GALVESTON, Texas, Sept. 17.--A special to the News from Laredo, Texas, says: "A telegram has been received stating that the famous rebel chief, El Coyote, with his lieutenants, Manuel Vela and Pena, and six followers were killed in an engagement with national troops under Col. Valdez near Santo Domingo Ranch, a short distance from Lampasas, Mexico, yesterday.
The Manhattan Temperance Association will begin its Fall work at 3 P.M. to-morrow in Masonic Temple.
CHICAGO, Sept. 17.--The National Committee of the Anti-Saloon Republicans held a meeting last night. Albert Griffin was chosen Chairman and J.C. Schaeffer Secretary.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 17.--This was the third day of the bicycle tournament at Hampden Park. To-day's races were largely attended, there being about 8,000 spectators. But one loafing race was run, and the two contestants in that were fined $10 each and made to run it over.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Sept. 17.--Three hundred and eighty-five Chiricahua Indians, 63 men, 175 squaws, and 147 children, arrived in this city this morning in 12 special cars over the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad in charge of Col. J.F. Wade, of the Tenth United States Cavalry, commanding the company of 85 guards.

PROSPECT HOUSE, N.Y., Sept. 17.--President Cleveland's party concluded, in spite of the threatening weather of this morning, to make the fishing and hunting expedition for which arrangements had been made.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 17.--The Parrott Iron Works, at Greenwood, Orange County, which suspended more than a year ago, were sold at foreclosure sale to-day by William Van Amee, at Goshen. The purchaser was E.W. Harriman, of New-York City, and the price paid $52,500. There were 46 plots of ground, comprising 10,000 acres, on which there was a mortgage of $150,000. The plaintiff in the action is James Paulding.

Drescher, of Buffalo, N.Y.; Supreme First Vice-President-- Thomas Coffey, London, Ontario; Supreme Second Vice-President--Charles Fernicorn, Meadville, ...

BELLEVILLE, Ontario, Sept. 17.--The heirs of Samuel Peck and Rachel Slater, numbering about 100, assembled here to-day from Prince Edward and Hastings Counties and organized to establish their claim to an interest in the Harlem Commons estate, New York City. A President, Vice-President, and Advisory Board were appointed.

When Mrs. Koehl, who claims Albert Hahn as her husband, appeared in the Tombs Police Court yesterday, she was accompanied by Harry Hain, of No. 123 East Thirteenth-street, a boy 14 years of age. She said that on Thursday afternoon she met him accidentally in Centre-street.
BOSTON, Sept. 17.--A 2-year-old babe was the victim to-day of a most brutal assault at the hands of a burly and rum-crazed negro named Sylvester Fletcher.
Collector Magone is making headway with his investigation into the accounts of Douglas Smith, who was dismissed during the last days of Collector Hedden's term.

FREDERICK, Md., Sept. 17.--The veterans of the Ninth New-York Regiment held their reunion on the battlefield of Antietam, at Sharpsburg, Md., to-day. They were met on their arrival by the citizens. An address of welcome was made and replied to. The veterans then presented resolutions to the town in appreciation of the patriotic welcome they received 25 years ago.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 17.--Henry Rogers, keeper of the toll bridge at Saratoga Lake, was accidentally shot and killed this morning by William B. Pettite, of No. 444 west Thirtyfourth-street, New-York. The lad had a shotgun and was loading it, when it was discharged in some way and the load entered Rogers's stomach. He died almost instantly.
BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 17.--The cricket match between the Gentlemen of England and the Longwoods, postponed from yesterday, was continued to-day.
The proposal to celebrate the hundredth anniversary of the formal adoption of our Federal Constitution in the Convention of Delegates assembled to frame it is one of much interest.
Dr. Philip E. Donlin, the new leader of the County Democracy organization in the Fifth Assembly District, is beginning to understand that his leadership is not the fat prize he hoped to find it.
OTTAWA, Sept. 17.--The statement of the Government savings banks shows that at the end of the fiscal year deposits amounted to $20,014,457, an increase over the amount on deposit ...
MADRID, Sept. 17.--Three officers belonging to the Spanish army at Barcelona have been arrested and imprisoned for leading a band of soldiers to join the Carlists.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 17.--The increased earnings of the Cincinnati, Indianapolis, St. Louis and Chicago Railroad (Big Four) insure an increase in the dividend for the coming quarter from 4 to 5, and quite likely to 6, per cent.

Mr. PARNELL'S bill is very well contrived to strengthen the position of its sponsor in Ireland. For that purpose it may be superfluous, since Ireland has never had a leader so generally acknowledged and so unquestioningly obeyed.

When the boycotters of Mrs. Landgraf were on trial Bohemian Bakers' Union No. 22 wanted Pawlick Max, one of its members, to make certain statements. Max refused to do this, claiming that he could not swear to them.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17.--"Big George" Fix, a faro dealer in Jordan's gambling rooms, over the Turf Exchange in Clark-street, was shot and probably fatally wounded this afternoon by Capt. James M. Bailey, a watchman in the employ of the Merchants' Police.
CHICAGO, Sept. 17.--During the severe storm of yesterday several carpenters who were working on some frame buildings at Hermosa took shelter in one of the structures.

MONTREAL, Sept. 17.--The trial of John N. Walter, charged with attempting to bribe Customs Officer Brosseau to steal the books of J.C. Ayer Co., at present held by the customs authorities as evidence against the firm, was opened to-day in the Court of Queen's Bench. Mr. Donald MacMaster, Queen's Counsel, member of Paliament, counsel for Messrs. ...

The Republican Assembly district leaders met in caucus yesterday afternoon to select a cancandidate for Chairmanship of the County Committee, which convenes on Thuesday evening next. Col. S.V.R. Cruger presided.
OMAHA, Neb., Sept. 17.--Second Lieut. John F. McBlain, Ninth Regiment of Cavalry, was tried by the court-martial recently in session at Cheyenne, Wyoming.

HAMILTON, Ontario, Sept. 17.--In 1883 Fred Cooper, a married man, son of Ezra Cooper, a millionaire, of Union City, Penn., became enamored of a woman named Victoria Bender, and the pair fled to Canada, where they have ever since at different places lived together as man and wife.

On the New-York Athletic Club's grounds at Mott Haven this afternoon will take place the much-talked-of contest for the amateur athletic championship of America.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 17.--The Central Trust Company of New-York is interested in another railway case here, which occupied the attention of Judges Jackson and Welker, of the United States Circuit Court, all day to-day and until late to-night.

Since the return of the New-York Baseball Club Master Preston, the mascot of the team, had not put in an appearance on the Polo Grounds. Some of the patrons and players were superstitious enough to believe that this was the cause of the club's poor playing.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 17.--The police to-day arrested a young woman who gave her name as B.T. Redmond, and who for the past few weeks has been in the city soliciting subscriptions for what she called the Ladies' Art Union of New-York City.

LOWELL, Mass., Sept. 17.--At the Police Court this afternoon Charles Weldy was put under $10,000 bail to answer for assaulting James Henry Forbes late last night and inflicting on him a serious wound, which penetrated the lower portion of the left lung.

LONDON, Sept. 17.--In Mincing-lane the prices of coffee at the auction sales advanced 1s.@2s. per hundred weight. Teas are inactive. Congou is easier. Good to fine Ceylon and Indian sell readily. The sales of spice have gone flatly. Pimento and cloves are cheaper. Pepper on the spot is quiet. White Singapore closes firmer.
NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 17.--Cecilia Butler, a pretty girl of 17, who lives at No. 213 Congress-avenue, for a long time has been inclined to doubtful ways and companions.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 17.--At Cornwall yesterday a squad of West Point cavalry were in search of Jerome A. Correa, who had deserted from the post. Correa, with two others, was working in a sand bank at West Point when he made a break for liberty.
CHICAGO, Sept. 17.--A notice was posted with the Directory of the Chicago Board of Trade Sept. 12 asking that action be taken relative to a change of hours.
BUFFALO, Sept. 17.--The Tracy will case was continued to-day, both morning and afternoon, before Surrogate Stern.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 17.--The town of Hartford, in recognition of the soldiers and sailors who participated in the war of the rebellion, made a few years ago an appropriation of $60,000 for a memorial arch which has been erected at the Ford-street bridge, the leading entrance to Bushnell Park.

About a week ago the water in the City Hall Park fountain was started, but stopped the next day. Yesterday, at 5 o'clock in the afternoon, the water was set running again, to the great delight of the loungers in the park.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17.--It occurred to me while on my way through Charleston's ruined streets some days ago that no more striking way of illustrating the extent of the damage done there could be suggested than an application of the earthquake shock to NewYork.

The Tammany Hall Committee on Organization met last night and referred to the General Committee, which meets next Friday evening, a blank call for the primaries and the various local conventions.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 17.--Judge Hoadly resumed his argument in the Nickel Plate foreclosure proceedings this morning, seeking to fortify the points previously noted. T.E. Stillman, of New-York, followed for the Central Trust Company.

WINCHESTER, Va., Sept. 17.--Twenty members of the League of American Wheelmen arrived here this evening after a delightful spin from Woodstock. A number of local wheelmen met them a few miles from the city and escorted them to their quarters. They were serenaded to-night and will leave for Harper's Ferry, vin Berryville, in the morning, where the party will separate.
ELMIRA, N.Y., Sept. 17.--The Supreme Lodge of the United States, Knights of Columbia, closed its annual session here to-night.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18.--Passenger train No. 3, outbound on the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Road, was ditched by a misplaced switch tonight about 11 P.M. It is reported several lives were lost. Primary meetings to elect delegates to the Gubernatorial Convention, which is to be held at Trenton on Sept. 28, were held in Newark last night.
LONDON, Sept. 22.--Gen. Kaulbars bears with him to Sofia an ultimatum from Russia to the Bulgarian Government.

The organization of the sleeping car porters "for mutual aid and protection" seems rather queer. An association for mutual aid and protection generally has for its object more wages or less work or both, and it is hard to see how the porters can accomplish those objects by association.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Sept. 22.--Despite the severe earthquake shock yesterday morning, which unsettled many nerves, this has been one of the quietest class since the great shake of of Aug. 31.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22.--Dr. D.E. Salmon, head of the United States Bureau of Animal Industry, says that the disease from which the cattle in the distillery stables of this city are suffering is pleuro-pneumonia, and State Veterinarian Dr. D.V. Atkinson, of Wisconsin, and Dr. A.J. Murray, of Detroit, agree with him.
NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 22.--Loomis's Temple of Music was the scene of a big rally of Connecticut Prohibitionists to-day, and also of several conventions to nominate candidates for the coming election.

This company paid its hands higher wages than any other manufactory in town, and its closing will throw nearly 150 men and women out of employment.

The paymaster of the road was on his way to Albany with a locomotive and one car. Just after leaving the State line he stopped to pay off a gang of men at work along the track.

It is said upon the authority of one of the most important members of the Republican Central Committee that the organization will support ex-Mayor Edward Cooper for the Mayoralty if the County Democracy will agree to accept a Republican Register and make other conditions.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23.--The Managers of the various roads in the Northwest met again this morning to try and form a gross money pool on Northwestern freight traffic. Section 1 of the proposed agreement, which provides for the business to be put in the pool, was again taken up for discussion, but no headway could be made.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 22.--Benjamine Noyes, President of the old American Mutual Life and Trust Company, has served notice upon W.J. Atwater, who yesterday bought the Insurance Building at public auction, and Receiver Talcott H. Russell, who sold the building, that he will contest the legality of the sale in the United States courts.

CHICACO, Sept. 22.--George A. Marshall, one of the stockholders in the Chester Boot and Shoe Manufacturing Company, which employs convict labor in the Chester Penitentiary, has applied to the Superior Court to have a Receiver appointed for the company.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Sept. 22.--Mail advices from Bermuda state that a slight shock of earthquake was felt by some people on the night of Aug. 31, but it seems not to have been felt at the lighthouse on Gibbs Hill, where the vibrations of the great earthquake and subsequent shocks a few years ago at St. Thomas were reported by the keeper to have been distinctly felt.

EAGLE PASS, Texas, Sept. 22.--A new law has just gone into effect in Mexico. Hereafter drummers from the United States will have to take a patent or license for one month, costing $25, which will have to be renewed each month.

LONG BRANCH, Sept. 22.--Theodore Joline, Postmaster at North Long Branch, was arrested this morning on a warrant sworn out by Mrs. Elizabeth Rudolph, a domestic who has been employed in his family and who charges him with a criminal assault. Joline asserts his innocence. He offered the woman $50 in order to avoid the unpleasentnees of a trial. She demanded $500 to settle, and he preferred to stand trial.

WARSAW, N.Y., Sept. 22.--The Wyoming County Prohibitionists assembled to-day in county convention. There were 11 of the 16 towns represented by delegation.

Rumors industriously circulated to the effect that the New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad is to be reorganized by a consolidation of its divisions are stated by Vice-President Folton to be wholly without foundation. They appear to have grown out of the resignation of Superintendent Cable of the Susquehanna Division.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 22.--A 5-yearold daughter of Albert Schaef, of East Bridgeport, accidentally set fire to her clothing last night, and received fatal burns. Her cries brought her mother to her side, and in her efforts to extinguish the flames the woman received severe and painful burns.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 22--While hunting on the Oswegatchie Inlet, Adirondacks, on Monday, Fletcher Caulkins, of Brooklyn, was shot by the accidental discharge of his rifle. He died Monday night. His father, W.D. Caulkins, of Nunda, N.Y., was with him at the time. Caulkins leaves a widow and two children in Brooklyn. He was 31 years old.

Bartholomew, President of the Charter Oak Life Insurance Company and one of the best known business men of the city, was a defaulter to a great amount; that he had fled the city, and that his whereabouts was unknown to the Directors of the company.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22.--The Superintendent of the General Recruiting Service has been directed to send 50 recruits to Fort Snelling, Minn., for the Twentieth Infantry. Adams and other American fishermen were captured by Canadian cruisers, the Dominion Government has been trying to make some arrangement to settle the matter and thus live on friendly terms with their Yankee cousins.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 23.--A terrific thunderstorm, accompanied by hail, swept over the city about 7:30 o'clock this morning. The rainfall was very heavy during the prevalence of the storm. The house of Robert J. Arthur, in the western part of the city, was badly wrecked by a thunderbolt and Mrs. Arthur was dangerously injured.

ROME, Sept. 23.--In all Italy since the last report 25 persons have died from cholera and 28 new cases of the disease have been reported.

The least successful and most slimly attended of all of the clambakes held under the auspices of the Fat Men's Association was that held at Roton Point, near South Norwalk, Conn., yesterday.

A very large number of letters posted in Canada and bearing the United States postage stamps continue to be received at the Dead Letter Office here, as well as United States postal cards posted in this country. The trouble is caused by tourists, who do not seem to under stand that foreign stamps and cards should not be used.

LIMA, Ohio, Sept. 23.--This morning at 7 o'clock the city was startled by a terrific clap of thunder. In a few moments black clouds of smoke were seen rolling up from one of the oil wells on the Brotherton land. The fire at once communicated with the tank and in a few minutes all was on fire.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 23.--Yale College began its academic year to-day, President Dwight for the first time conducting the chapel service and receiving the Seniors' traditional bow to the head of the university.

The announcement made by Sir J. FERGUSON in the House of Commons that negotiations were proceeding in London for the removal of the fishery troubles "arising out of the defects of the present treaties" is gratifying as far as it goes, because it seems to admit that the existing treaty does not cover all the equities of the case.

When the racing began yesterday at Gravesend the track was heavy, but it dried during the afternoon, and when the last race was run the pattering hoofs raised the dust. Except in the last race the fields were small, yet the speculators had no easy task in picking the winners, as only one favorite was successful during the day.

PORT HAWKESBURY, Cape Breton, Sept. 23.--The $1,600 ordered by the Customs Department on the 17th inst. to be paid before the schooner Morro Castle should be released, has not yet been paid, and as the parties interested show no disposition to pay the money the Collector here is having the vessel stripped of her sails, , and will have her in every way secured. The Captain and crew leave to-morrow for Gloucester; via Boston.

State Treasurer Edward C. McFetridge, who was nominated for Congress Wednesday by the Republicans of the Second District, has declined to serve. He is of the firm opinion, his friends say, that the Republicans of the district would have better success with some one from another county, the Democrats having already put in the field a Dodge County man. His declination is authoritatively stated to be peremptory.

LONDON, Sept. 23.--A committee of the Cabinet consisting of Lord Sailsbury, Lord Randolph Churchill, sir Michael Hicks-Beach, Mr. Matthews and Mr. Smith discussed the Irish question for two hours to-day. Unless some unforeseen necessity arises the Cabinet will not meet again for several weeks. Sir Michael HicksBeach will start for Ireland early next week.

Two hundred years ago yesterday the Dutch settlers of the Hackensack Valley met together and formed the First Reformed Church of Hackensack. Ten years later they built a little redstone church building in a cluster of big elm trees in what is now the centre of Hackensack village.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 23.--The convention of Sovereign Grand Lodge, I.O.O.F., was called to order at 9 o'clock this morning, Grand Sire Garey in the chair. Past Grand Sire Stokes offered a resolution permitting lodges to omit their weekly meetings when they occur on legal and generally recognized holidays, which was adopted.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 23.--There is one thing talked about in Hartford to-day, and just onething,the Bartholomew defalcation. Nothing in all the history of the city has so shaken the confidence of the people in human honesty, and the effects of yesterday's revelations will be experienced for many a day to come.
UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 23.--The New-York State fair in this city opened to-day with the largest number of entries ever before received.
ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, Sept. 23.--In a terrific northwest gale Tuesday last a Newfoundland fishing vessel collapsed in Trepassey Bay. Fortunately only one life was lost.

Mr. George Miller, who keeps a gentlemen's furnishing goods store on Sixth-avenue, was surprised yesterday when a wagon backed up to the sidewalk in front of his store and a young man, dumping down, seized the showcase, put it in the cart, and drove away.

BELVIDERE, N.J., Sept. 23.--The boarders at the Cramer House, a private boarding house, were poisoned by eating boiled ham in which arsenic had been placed in some unaccountable manner. A number of the guests were made very sick, but none of them died. Members of Col. Yard's family were among those who ate and suffered severely.

BAIRD, Texas, Sept. 23.--On Tuesday night as the east-bound passenger train on the Texas and Pacific was about two miles west of this place it was announced by the Pullman porter that a passenger had fallen overboard from the platform. TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 23.--The primaries for the election of delegates to the Democratic Gubernatorial Convention were held in this city to-day. The city is entitled to 20 delegates, and although the anti-Green men made herculcan efforts they succeeded in electing only four men, the representatives of the First and Second Wards. The excitement at the polls was intense, carriages being run for voters, the same as on Presidential and Gubernatorial election days.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 24.--Peter Denny, of Ridgefield, noticed that the water in his well had a fishy taste. He cleaned the well out yesterday and found 60 trout in the bottom. Then he remembered that he had put a trout in the water three years ago because he had heard that it was a good scheme. The trout was a female and had spawned, with the result of making the well a fish pond.

MARSHALL, Texas, Sept. 24.--George M. Fabler, City Marshal of Longview, was killed at the Capital Hotel this morning in a difficulty with L.L. and L.W. Teague, father and son, of Gregg County. MILLEDGEVILLE, Ga., Sept. 24.--On the 4th of March last two respectable white girls-- Carrie Raines and Ella Humphreys--were murdered.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 24.--Wright Weldon, colored, was to have been hanged at Edgefield Jail to-day for the murder of John Lagrone, white, in November, 1884, but upon a petition Gov. Sheppard granted him a respite until Oct. 8.

MARBLEHEAD, Sept. 24.--There was no race between the Mayflower and the Galatea today. Early in the morning there was a light breeze from the westward, working from northwest to southwest, but it was so light that there was no prospect of a race.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 24.--A party of revenue officers returned to-day from a raid in Sumner, Overton, Jackson, and Putnam Counties, where they arrested Matt Keith, Ben Chaflin, Bud Brizendine, and 12 other men for violation of the revenue laws. The distilleries of Keith, Chafflin, and William Hodges were destroyed, together with several hundred gallons of whisky, beer, and brandy.
SALEM, Mass., Sept. 24.--A new element has been introduced into the labor troubles of this city and Peabody, and it is one that fills the law-abiding citizen with terror.

ERIE, Penn., Sept. 24.--Willis Phelps, son of the Rev. W.H. Phelps, of Edenborough, went out with William Woodward, a student, duck hunting on Lake Conneaute. Woodward fired at some ducks and capsized the boat. The boat being too light to sustain both, Phelps was drowned, and his companion when rescued was almost dead.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 24.--The Louisiana orange crop is usually marketed about this time. Reports from Calicarren, St. Bernard, St. Mary, Cameron, La Fourche, and other parishes in which the oranges are principally grown, report that the crop is a complete failure this year.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Sept. 24.--Charles Diltzer, of Pittston, for the past 20 years in the employ of the Pennsylvania Coal Company as foreman in the live stock department, committed suicide this morning by hanging himself in a barn.

DUBLIN, Sept. 24.--The police last night ran down and surprised a party of moonlighters at Feale Bridge, County Kerry. The police, who had concealed themselves, on seeing the moonlighters approach ordered them to "Halt in the Queen's name!"

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 24.--Great excitement prevails in Hope County over the abduction of Miss Maggie Bashier by Edward Bowman and a companion. A posse pursued the abductors and captured them. There is talk of lynching them.

CLAYTON, Ga., Sept. 25.--Gus Scruggs was to-day sentenced to 15 years in the peniten tiary for the murder of his brother, Mills Scruggs. The murder took place last Tuesday night at a colored dance. The murderer escaped and was found yesterday, in a thicket where he was hiding.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27.--California seems to have been short of ice, as this is the only way in which the fact can be explained that lately heavy quantities of ice have been shipped from Chicago by the San Francisco dealers.
TORONTO, Ontario, Sept. 27.--The man named Hand, arrested is Sarnia for plotting and attempting to destroy the families of several temperance men with dynamite, was committed for trial to-day.

SOFIA, Sept. 27.--M. Stambuloff, President of the Regency, is negotiating with M. Zankoff, the leader of the Russian party in Bulgaria, with a view to arranging for a cessation of Internal strife. M. Zankoff promises to recognize the Regency on condition that some of the foreign portfolios are allotted to the Zankoff party.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27.--At a conference here to-day between the window glass manufacturers and a committee of employes the wage question was settled, and the fires will be started at once. This settlement affects all factories in New-Jersey, Maryland, New-York, and Pennsylvania east or the Alleghanies.
The regular meeting of the New-York County Medical Society was held last evening in the Academy of Medicine, No.12 West Thirtyfirst-street.
The Bishop of Ely has written to the papers from Venice to say that there is nothing to fear about cholera there, and to urge tourists to hie thither, "as it will be rally an act of charity to come."
OTTAWA, Sept. 27.--Sir Charles Tupper, the Hon. Thomas White, and the General Manager of the Canadian Pacific Railroad, who have been visiting the Sudbury copper mines, returned to-day.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 27.--In the United States Circuit Court to-day, the report of the intervening petition of the Chicago, Burlington and Quiney Railroad Company was confirmed.

Miss Genevieve Ward, after a long absence from New-York, during which she has made a professional tour of Australia, reappeared at the Star Theatre last evening. She was cordially welcomed. Her audience was small, however, and the theatre was uncomfortably warm.

SEDAN, Kan., Sept. 27.--In a Sunday school here yesterday Simon Smith, who had a grudge against William Andrews, both colored, opened fire, wounding Andrews twice and killing Benjamin Williams, an aged negro. The murderer was captured and brought here. The guard evaded a mob of colored people and lodged their prisoner in jail.

BUFFALO, Sept. 27.--Conductor Harrison and Engineer Brewer, of the excursion train in collision at Silver Creek, have both been indicted for manslaughter by the Grand Jury at Mayville. They are held in $3,000 bail each. Their cases may be tried next months.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 27--Two unknown men, supposed to be commercial travelers, were drowned from the Big Sandy wharf boat at 10 o'clock last night.

Foraker, showing the extravagances of the Democratic management and the loss sustained by the State during the Hoadly regime.

BROWNSVILLE, Texas, Sept. 28.--Advices from Santa Maria are to the effect that Col. Hernandez is dangerously wounded, having two bullet wounds in his left side, received in the recent fight with revolutionists at Tinojas Del Trangino; also, that he hanged the prisoners captured there. It is stated that the revolutionists are gathering forces up the river and will attempt to capture Reynosa or Camargo to get supplies.

LONDON, Sept. 28.--The Foreign Office and the United States Legation authorize the statement that the report telegraphed from Ottawa that a new fishery treaty had been effected between the United States and Canada is an entire fabrication, and that no such treaty has beon proposod by either Government.

The year 5647 of the Jewish calendar begins to-morrow. The day is designated in the ritual as Rosh Hashono, or the New Year. The celebration of this important and generally observed festival commences this evening and among orthodox Jews lasts until Friday.

The steamboat Plymouth Rock has been bought by the firm of Butler, Clancy Co., of Boston, and it is their intention to break her up and sell her for old junk. The old boat was put up at auction on Sept. 22 and the firm mentioned bid $5,100 for her.

The Republican League of Brooklyn held a meeting last night to discuss the expediency of voting this Fall in favor of holding a Constitutional Convention. John Winslow presided over the meeting, which was not a very large one.

HINSDALE, Ill., Sept. 28.--The Sterling passenger train on the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad, while running east this morning at about the rate of 30 miles an hour, broke a rail just east of a little station called Greggs, and the entire train, except the engine and tender, was thrown from the track and rolled down a 15-foot embankment.

LYONS, N.Y., Sept. 28.--The Republican Congressional Convention for the Twenty-seventh District, composed of Wayne, Oswego, and Cayuga Counties, was held in this village this afternoon. By good batting at opportune moments and clever base running the New-Yorks won an other game from the Kansas City men yesterday. King, a Western twirler, pitched for the visitors, and he created a very favorable impression.

OTTAWA, Sept. 28.--The War Claims Commission is still in session here. Eighteen hundred claims, including those of the Hudson's Bay Company and the Canadian Pacific Railway for $1,500,000 and $700,000 respectively, have been adjusted.
There has been trouble brewing in the ranks of the County Democrats of the Fourteenth District ever since Maurice B. Flynn resigned his position as Chairman of the district organization.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 28.--In the Supreme Court this morning the divorce suit of Ella C. Hurlburt against Henry A. Hurlburt, Jr., of New-York, was heard and a decree was granted, no one appearing for the defendant. The charges were neglect to provide, extreme cruelty, intemperance and desertion.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 28.--The race between the sloop yachts Mayflower and Galatea, which is so anxiously looked forward to by all interested in the success of either yacht, will not absorb all the attention in yachting circles this week.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 28.--Three children of a respectable family, near Andalusia, ranging from 2 to 6 years old, went out Sunday afternoon to play near the house. A large pine tree had been blown down and they were playing around in the hole made by the roots of the tree being torn up.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 28.--The men employed in Philip Goerres's cooper's shop have been locked out for several days past. The question at issue is of general interest to manufacturers and one that is attracting widespread attention.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 28.--The sale of horses by the National Horse Exchange here today was, owing to inclement weather, almost a failure, 35 head being sold for $6,445. The best price was $530, for a black filly, 2 years old, by Voltaire, out of Tullahoma, by Almont. The prospects are good for a large attendance and better prices to-morrow.

Brooklyn has never had a warmer day for registration of voters than yesterday. Many came to the registry places in straw hats. It is an off year, and the first day shows a slight falling off in the number of those registering.
NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 28.--John R. Shields Co., hardware merchants, made an assignment to-day. Their liabilities are estimated at $30,000; assets, $20,000.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Sept. 28.--Wiggins is patiently awaiting the approach of to-morrow's storm, which is to blow him into fame. A heavy downpour of rain kept him from sleep last night, so he informed THE TIMES'S correspondent; but although the storm roared with dangerous howls it required something more convincing to assure him that his great, his only, his original disturbance had arrived ahead of time.
MANCHESTER, Sept. 28.--The Roach Mills at Heywood, 8 miles northwest from here in Lancaster County, were destroyed by fire to-day. The mills employed 45,000 spindles.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 28.--The large side-wheel steamer Saratoga, of the Citizens' Line of Troy, was stranded at an early hour this morning near Tivoli. She left Troy last evening with 230 passengers and 80 tons of freight.

DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 28.--A big iron mine suit has just reached an important stage in the progress toward a final settlement. Years ago Capt. N.D. Moore gave information as to the probable value of a tract of land on which the great Colby iron mine in the Lake Superior region is now situated. The land was purchased by a company, and for his services Capt. Moore was given one-third interest.
PARIS, Sept. 28.--A riot took place to-day during the unveiling and dedication of the statue of Armand Barbes, the Red Republican colleague of Blanqui, at Carcassonne, in the department of Aude.
CHICAGO, Sept. 28.--The written motion for a new trial in behalf of the doomed Anarchists and the several affidavits in support of it were taken to the State Attorney to-day.

No one who is familiar with the manner in which property in New-York County has been assessed by the State Assessors for State taxes heretofore will be surprised to learn that the protests and carefully prepared statements recently submitted to the board by the authorities of this city have been disregarded.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28.--The Superintendent of the Mounted Recruiting Service has been directed to send 23 recruits to Fort Snelling, Minn., for the First Cavalry. Leaves of absence have been granted as follows: To Post Chaplain John W. Jackson, three months; Second Lieut. H.A. Leonhaeuser, Twenty-fifth Infantry, three months.

LONDON, Sept. 28.--This was the first day of the Newmarket first October meeting. The race for the Hopeful Stakes was won by Mr. Abington's bay filly St. Mary, with the Duke of Hamilton's gray filly Cornalba second, and M. Lupin's chestnut filly Alida third.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28.--The Public Printer dismissed 210 persons to-day, about 100 of whom were women employed in the folding room.
BOSTON, Sept. 28.--Among the Democratic leaders, says the Post, there is a strong drift toward young John F. Andrew as the Democratic standard bearer in the coming election.
The Irving Hall Executive Committee last night adopted resolutions favoring union and harmony among the local Democratic factions.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 28.--The First District Democratic Congressional Convention met yesterday noon. The Hon. Thomas J. Ford, Chairman of the district committee, did not call the convention to order, being unavoidably detained at Baton Rouge, where he is serving a 20 years' term for the famous Murphy murder.

MERIDEN, Conn., Sept. 28.--In common with the rest of Connecticut Meriden experienced very unpleasant weather yesterday. It was hot, it was close, it was muggy. Good citizens sweltered and thought what reckless citizens said out loud, and both thoughts and words were theological.

"Marita," produced by Mlle. Aimee at the Union-Square Theatre last evening, is an adaptation of "Piccolino," a vaudeville by Victorien Sardou.

FORT SHAW, Montana, Sept. 28.--Troops have been ordered out in the direction of the Judith Gap, it is understood, to intercept the movements of some Indians from the south suspected to be Crows.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 28.--The Grand Jury of the Hustings Court to-day found indictments against the Boycott Committee of the Richmond Typographical Union and editors, proprietors, and publishers of the Labor Herald. The firm boycotted by these parties is Boughman Brothers, wholesale stationers and job printers.
Henry E. Abbey was married in Boston yesterday, so runs a dispatch received by a friend of the happy manager in this city last evening.

FORT WORTH, Texas, Sept. 29.--An impromptu duel took place on the Dallas road, nine miles east of Fort Worth, this afternoon, between Bob Jordan, stockman, of Ellis County, and Alfred Masters, lately from near Hope, Ark.

TROY,N. Y., Sept. 29.--After three days' work a jury has been obtained for the trial of Bartholomew Mahoney on the charge of murdering Michael Lyons Sunday, April 11, last. Mahoney in company with a friend started out for a walk.
Justin McCarthy and his literary associatie, Mrs. Campbell-Praed, did their daily quota of work yesterday on "The Ladies' Gallery," the novel on which they are collaborating.

A new departure in the matter of counterfeiting money was brought to light at the United States Sub-Treasury in Baltimore a few days ago. A somewhat worn ten-dollar Government bill was presented at the cashier's window with a request for change, which was given.
RALEIGH, N.C., Sept. 29.--W.P. Bynum, of Charlotte, who was nominated for the Supreme Court by the Republican State Convention last week, declines to accept the nomination.

CHERRY VALLEY, N.Y., Sept. 29.--At the afternoon session of the Democratic Congressional Convention for the Twenty-fourth District, held here to-day, 20 ballots were taken without a decision being reached. The balloting is going on to-night with like results.

The quiet-loving people of the village of Woodlawn, which takes its name from that still city perched high above the sleepy Bronx Valley, were, rudely disturbed yesterday morning by a story that despoilers of graves had been at work in the cemetery.

SOFIA, Sept. 29.--The Regency has posted notices of the elections for the Grand Sobranje which is to elect a successor to Prince Alexander, Gen. Kaulbars, the Russian special agent, threatents to have the notices removed.

BOSTON, Sept. 29.--If the testimony of Henry L. Jones and his piece of clapboard can be substantiated, the investigation of the East Boston Ferry Board of Directors promises to develop a first-class sensation and fully substantiate the charges of corruption brought by Alderman Barr.

DENVER, Sept. 29.--The Republican State Convention to-day nominated the Hon. William H. Meyer for Governor on the third ballot. Other nominations were made as follows: For Lieutenant-Governor--The Hon. N. H. Meldrum; Congressman--Judge G. G. Syms; State Treasurer--P. W. Breen; Secretary of State--Capt. James Rice.

The hubbub that has been made about the prediction by WIGGINS that a great storm would occur on the 29th of September is a melancholy illustration how little the spread of education, of which we boast, has done toward diminishing the gullibility of human nature.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Sept. 29.--The editor of the Fort MacLeod Gazette wires the Manitobian that no massacre by the Indians has occurred in the Northwest as reported in special dispatches from Ottawa, Ontario. Everything is quiet there, the Bloods being on their reserve. He added that the rumor probably originated from the killing of a few Bloods in Montana some time ago.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 29.--It looks tonight as if John F. Andrew would receive the Democratic nomination for Governor tomorrow by an almost unanimous vote and, strange as this may appear, possibly without even the formality of a ballot.

One of our best known Boston families has been severely afflicted during the past week by the death of its youngest child, undoubtedly from arsenic inhaled from wall paper at their Summer residence at Swampscott.

The New-Yorks won another game from the Kansas City men on the Polo Grounds yesterday. Although defeated, the visitors played strongly, and contested the game with rare vim and determination from start to finish.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 29.--Reports to the New-England Homestead from the principal onion-growing sections of the country indicate a short crop and higher prices.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 29.--The employes in Sargent's lock factory, numbering 250, struck work to-day because 27 hours had been declared a week's work. The employes want 40 hours to be a week's work.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 29.--There is considerable excitement at the Custom House over a recent hostile encounter between Mr. H.P. Kernochan. United States Naval Officer, and Mr. Wash Marks, Superintendent of the Warehouse Department.

The Franklin-Avenue Presbyterian Church was crowded yesterday afternoon when the trial of the Rev. Benjamin Staunton, of Fort Greene Church, was resumed. The fact that Mrs. Staunton was to testify against her husband attracted a large number of ladies to the church.

A fashionable wedding took place last evening in St. John's Episcopal Church, Yonkers, the contracting parties being the Hon. Joseph Fitch, of Flushing, Long Island, and Miss Annie Lorainc, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Levi P. Rose.

The Aqueduct Commissioners yesterday afternoon sat on their raised platform in their offices in the Stewart Building. Ex-Judge James C. Spencer presided. At his left was Commissioner Baldwin. At his right were Commissioners Dowd, Ridgway, and Fish. Gen. John Newton.
TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 29.--John S. Carey, proprietor of the United States Hotel, of this city, was indicted in Wilkesbarre, Penn., some time ago, for forcible entry and detainer.
George Albert, senior member of the firm of Albert Heilbrunn, dealers in pork, has disappeared from his home and place of business.

The American Institute Fair was opened at the Institute Building yesterday afternoon at 2 o'clock. A brief address was made by Robert Rutter, the band played, and some vocal selections were given.

MARQUETTE, Mich., Sept. 29.--This forenoon three miners were buried under a mass of falling rock at the Winthrop Mine, near Ishpeming, and instantly killed. Their bodies were recovered this evening. Their names are Mauritz Shellman, Paul Brazzo, and Peter Poppa. Two of them were married, and leave families.
PARIS, Sept. 29.--China intends to issue a loan of $50,000,000 for the construction of rail ways in the empire.
The entertainment now to be seen nightly at Dockstader's is excellent of its kind, and the popularity of the new place of amusement seems to be permanently established.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29.--Pleuro-pneumonia was to-day discovered on three farms near the Harvey farm, where John Carns bought his Jersey two months ago, and through the illness of which the evidence of the disease was first disclosed.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 29.--A west-bound passenger train on the Chicao, Milwaukee and St. Paul Road was run into by a wild freight at Ixonia station last evening.
POTTSVILLE, Penn., Sept. 29.--The advances made by the coal companies in the price of anthracite within the past few months have made the miners anxious to participate in the profits.
