MARBLEHEAD, Sept. 29.--Another fizzle was added to-day to the already long list of unsatisfactory attempts on the part of the Galatca to have a contest with the Mayflower in a regular cutter wind.

Not a stone was touched on the second section of the subway on Sixth-avenue below Twenty-third-street yesterday. This was hardly on account of underground obstructions, because D. Lowber Smith said yesterday that there was no doubt that the permit from the Department of Public Works would be changed so as to admit of digging five feet from the curb.
A very fine programme is offered by the American Jockey Club to-day, the six races having filled largely with a high class of horses, and the races promise to be hotly contested.

BOSTON, Sept. 29.--Howard Snelling Co., coal dealers, have failed, and will settle in insolvency. Liabilities and assets unknown, Charles E. Kelly, boot and shoe dealer at Haverhill, Mass., has failed. His liabilities are stated at over $40,000. Assets unknown.

BELFAST, Sept. 29.--There was desperate fighting to-day between Protestant and Catholic workmen at Barbour's foundry in this city. The police interfered, when the fighters joined forces and stoned and routed the police. Cavalry were then summoned, who charged upon and dispersed the mob. Scores of rioters and several policemen were injured.
A party of gentlemen connected with the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad and Staten Island terminal facilities yesterday inspected various parts of the harbor.

BELVIDERE, N.J., Sept. 29.--This was the second day of the trail of James J. Titus for the outrage and murder of Tillie Smith at the Centenary Collegiate Institute, at Hackettstown. The morning opened bright and clear, and visitors were early on the street seeking relief from the close, stifling air of the overcrowded hotels.

LONDON, Sept. 29.--Sir Reginald Hanson has been elected Lord Mayor of London.
CHICAGO, Sept. 29.--The passenger department of the Central Traffic Association, in the course of a meeting here to-day, took up the question of pooling the traffic between Chicago and New-York.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 29.--In the Spring of 1882 Miss Missouri Watkins, or "Zou," as she was familiarly known, came to St. Louis from Denver,Col., with her sister Lillie. They were on their way to New-Orleans, and while in the city were the guests of Mr. Isaac Martin, No. 2,215 Gamble-avenue.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 29.--For two weeks Coroner Mix, of this city, has been somewhere outside of the State, and the fact has caused a great deal of discussion, especially as it was known that he had by no means given up his investigation of the Wallingford shoe-box mystery.

OTTAWA,Ontario,Sept.29.--Wiggins feels as confident as ever that his storm will prove the greatest blow of the century. He worked away all day counting up long rows of figures in his office in the Finance Department and was besieged with callers.

The taking of testimony in the trial of Daniel Driscoll for murder in the Court of General Sessions was finished yesterday.

John F. Smith, who has won golden opinions as pitcher of the Newark Club, recently signed a contract with Manager Mutrie, of the New-Yorks, agreeing to become a member of his club after the present season. A salary of $2,800 was agreed upon and Smith accepted $800 advance money.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29.--Col. E. C. Mason, Fourth Infantry, has been relieved from duty as Acting Inspector-General, Department of Dakota, and assigned to similar duty in the Department of Arizona, to relieve Major William F. Drum, Fourteeth...

I hear that Mr. Gladstone is diverting himself during his stay at Tegern See by writing a theological pamphlet, which, however, will not be published before the Winter. It is probable that Mr. and Mrs. Gladstone will go to Italy for two or three months about Christmas. Mr. Gladstone has been greatly annoyed and irritated by the Radical revolt against Mr. Arnold Morley.

MONTREAL, Sept. 29.--Crowfoot, the Blackfoot chief, who was loyal to the Dominion Government during the recent rebellion, arrived here to-day accompanied by his brother, Three Bulls, and was presented with an address by Mayor Beaugrand to-night.
BOSTON, Sept. 29.--It looked very much as though the "old guard," of the Republican Party had left Henry Cabot Lodge to run the Republican State Convention alone to-day.

SAULT STE. MARIE, Ontario, Sept. 29.-- The steamer Francis Smith, of the Collingwood Line,has been released by the customs officials on giving bonds to the amount of $16,000. The seizure caused the steamer a week's loss of time.

The large safe of the branch Post Office in the Produce Exchange Building was opened on Tuesday night by some unknown person and stamps and cash to the amount of $2,300 were stolen. Watchman Tappey discovered the burglary.

The eagerly expected volume of the late Mr. Hayward's correspondence will be published early next month by Murray. The letteis in it extend over a period of 50 years--1834 to 1884. I will venture to predict that this book will produce a rich crop of denials, corrections, and expostulations; for, with all his cleverness and shrewdness, there never lived a more spiteful, jealous, and selfish man than Mr. Hayward.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29.--By an order of the Civil Service Commissioners a new method of dealing with soldier applicants for office has been adopted.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 29.--The large sloop yacht Florida, built for H. C. Kingsland, of New-York, was launched to-day from Gessner Marr's ship yard, in West Haven. The yacht cost $13,500.

Dr. Aveling and Herr Liebknecht, the Socialist leaders, were taken to the Manhattan Club on Tuesday by Willard Brown, a new member, who got them tickets giving them the privileges of the club for 10 days. During the evening Dr. Aveling was recognized as the Socialist...

There is not much doubt that if the Democratic State Committee had been agreed at its Saratoga meeting in presenting RUFUS W. PECKHAM as its candidate for Judge of the Court of Appeals, he would have been accepted by the Republican Committee.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 29.--The second day's sale of horses at the National Horse Exchange brought the aggregate to $13,000. The best price to-day was for the bay stallion Egwood, foaled 1885, by Egbert, dam by Blackwood, $1,100. Other sales ranged from $100 to $1,000.

CENTREVILLE, Md., Sept. 29.--The Rev. J.H.D. Wingfield, Missionary Bishop of Northern California, was to-day elected Bishop of the Diocese of Easton, to succeed the late Bishop Lay. Dr. Wingfield is the fifth selection that has been made, the others having declined to accept.

Gen. James Bowen died of malarial fever at his residence in Hastings-on-the-Hudson yesterday. He had been ill only about a fortnight. He was born in this city in 1808, and his father being a well-to-do merchant no pains or expense was spared in his education.

John and Louisa Wolf, who are charged with brutally abusing their 7-year-old daughter Annie, were arraigned before Justice Welde in the Yorkville Court yesterday. Annie and her 11-year-old sister Lizzie are Wolf's daughters by his first wife.

The steamer Kaaterskill has taken the place of the Saratoga on the Troy Line. Boats for Troy will therefore leave as usual daily, except Saturday.

HANOVER, N. H., Sept. 29.--The Rev. M. D. Bisbee, of Cambridgeport, Mass., a graduate of Dartmouth College, Class of '7l, and of the Chicago Theological Seminary of the Class of '74, and who was recently connected with the Congregationalist, has been elected librarian of Dartmouth College.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29.--Mr. E.P. Wilson, arbitrator for the passenger department of the Central Traffic Association, submitted to Assist ant Commissioner George H. Daniels to-day his decision in regard to differentials from Cincinnati to New-York by the NewYork, Pennsylvania and Ohio Railroad, (Erie Railway.)

PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 29.--Patsey Feeney, aged 16, shot his mother this afternoon. She cannot live. He recently escaped from a reform school and had written to his sister for money to join her, but the mother would not give it to him. He ran away after the shooting and has not been arrested.
It is a notorious fact that there are many places of vile resort in this city which have been denied excise licenses but in which the sale of liquor goes on almost without interruption.

John Hugg, the Tea Neck burglar who shot George Coe, was sentenced by Judge Skinner yesterday, at Hackensack, N. J., to serve 15 years at hard labor in State prison. Ten years --the full legal limit--of the sentence is for the shooting with intent to kill, and five years was added by the Judge for "breaking and entering in the nighttime."

The following are the results of other games played yesterday: Detroit, 6; Boston, 4. Philadelphia, 8; Chicago, 5. Washington, 9; St. Louis, O. W.P.Allen, clerk to Chief Charles Oscar Shay, sent to the Fire Commissioners yesterday $1,216, collected from the uniformed force in aid of the firemen of Charleston. The collection is not ended.
HOUSTON, Texas Sept. 29.--At 11 o'clock to-night Capt. Mike Hennessey, Chief of the Houston Detective Agency, was brutally assassinated by some unknown person within half a square of his residence.

DENVER, Sept. 30.--At last night's session of the State Republican Convention the Hon. D. P. Kinsley was nominated for Auditor of State, Judge Alvin Marsh for Attorney-General, S.B. Cornell for Superintendent of Public Instruction, and Gen. W. Hammill for member of the National Committee to fill the vacancy caused by the death of the Hon. Jerome B. Chaffee.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 30.--The third day's offering of horse stock by the National Horse and Cattle Exchange took place to-day. Thirty-two head passed under the hammer, bringing a total of $6,455, an average of a little over $200.
The Grand Jury filed into the Court of Sessions yesterday afternoon, interrupting Mr. Howe's appeal to the jury in the Driscoll case, and handed up a big batch of indictments to Recorder Smyth.
Major F.S. Bond, General Manager of the Erlanger system of railways, was elected VicePresident of the St. Paul Railroad Company yesterday.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 30.--There were 7,000 people at the Dutchess County Fair to-day. The annual address was delivered by Prof. De Garmo. The one mile race for the 2:45 class was won by R.D. Hicks's Alexander. Time --2:52 ; 2:45; 2:44. The 5-year-old contest was won by P. Grote's Dick. Time--3:08 ; 3:04; 3:09 ; 3:02.

The striking derrickmen who are assisting the stone rubbers reported yesterday that a general strike had been ordered at the building at Sixtieth-street and Tenth-avenue because no union derrickmen had been employed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30.--The President has the proposed changes in the civil service rules, which were outlined some time ago in these dispatches, under consideration, and it will probably be several weeks before they are approved. The changes will be slight.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 30.--The 108 delegates to the Third Congressional District Democratic Convention spent three hours this afternoon in a wrangle which may result in the defeat of the candidate, though this is a strong Democratic district.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30.--It is estimated at the Treasury Department to-day that there has been a decrease of nearly $11,000,000 in the public debt during September. The receipts during the month were about $32,000,000 and the expenditures about $18,000,000, making an excess of about $14,000,000.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 30.--The Blaine Club took possession of its new clubhouse, on Eighthstreet, to-night, and celebrated the occasion with a big meeting. All the Republican clubs of this city and the clubs in Dayton, Columbus, and Portsmouth were in attendance.

William T. Wardwell, who was nominated for Mayor at the recent Prohibition Convention, has written a letter to the officers of the convention expressing his hearty indorsement of the platform it adopted and accepting the nomination.

NYACK, N.Y., Sept. 30.--The senior single scull race for the silver cup and the champion-_ ship of the Nyack Rowing Association was rowed last evening, with Benjamin A. Jessup and Julian O. Davidson as starters. Jessup got off with a slight lead, but on the way home Davidson gained a decided lead, crossing the line two lengths ahead. Distance, two miles. Time --15:00.
MARQUETTE, Mich., Sept. 30.--A snowstorm prevails here. The wind and sea on Lake Superior are very heavy and vessels are seeking shelter.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30--Mrs. Cleveland and Mrs. Folsom have gone to Buffalo for a visit of about 10 days.
The case before the Arbitration Committee of the New-York Mercantile Exchange of J. H. Seymour Co. against Samuel H. Hilton has been decided in favor of the plaintiff.

The anthracite coal companies agreed yesterday to put up the price of coal still further, and 15 cents a ton was added to the price of stove coal, other advances being 10 cents on egg and chestnut and 5 cents on broken.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Sept. 30.--Wiggins is loth to admit that he has blundered. His customary coolness has deserted him, and all day he has patiently awaited tidings from the South. He was seen by THE TIMES'S correspondent this evening. "Your storm is late," the correspondent suggested.

Congressman William G. Stahlnecker had a walkover yesterday in the Democratic Convention of the Fourteenth Congressional District, at which he was nominated for another term at Washington with every appearance of harmony. There had been a good deal of talk about a contest.

The season at the Thalia will be entered upon this evening, when Lortzing's "Undine," the libretto of which is founded on La Motte Fouque's well known romance, will be brought out for the first time in this country.

NYACK, N.Y., Sept. 30.--The Tasman divorce suit, which has occupied two whole days in the Oyer and Terminer Court at New City, this week, before Judge Bartlett, was ended to-day, the jury returning a verdict for T.F. Tasman, thus denying Mrs. Tasman the absolute divorce which she so earnestly sought.

BUDA-PESTH, Sept. 30.--The Unterhaus presented a lively appearance to-day. The day had been looked forward to as an eventful one, Premier Tisza having several days ago announced his intention of publicly declaring the attitude decided upon by the empire toward the threatened aggressions of Russia in the Balkans. Every seat in the Chamber was occupied and the galleries were crowded.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 30.--The Secretary of the Nashville branches of the Liberia Colonizatton Society announces that 4,000 negroes will leave this city April 15 next for Liberia.

The nominations for Governor made by the two parties in Massachusetts may be taken as illustrating certain tendencies in the politics of the present time.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Sept. 30.--At 9:30 o'clock this morning the signal of "No race" was sent to the masthead of the flagship Fortuna, and with this announcement all hopes for another contest this season between the Galatea and Mayflower had expired.

PARIS, Sept. 30.--The Budget Committee, at the instance of the Government, has reduced the recidivist credit by 4,000,000f. Henceforth the number of criminals from France will not exceed 300 annually. The committee wishes that criminals be deported to Guiana because New-Caledonia is now overfull.
WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Sept. 30.--United States Consul Taylor was thrown from a stage at Neche, Dakota, yesterday, and had his right leg fractured in two places.

MANASQUAN, N.J., Sept. 30.--One of the most disgraceful scenes that has been witnessed in the usually quiet town of Manasquan for some time took place this evening, two of the sons of the late ex-Judge Remson figuring prominently. About 5 o'clock the two Remson boys, the...

DUBLIN, Sept. 30.--At Milltown-Malbay, County Clare, to-day, while the Sheriffs were employed in distraining on the property of a man named Kelly, the married women of the neighborhood attacked, overpowered, and imprisoned all the officers engaged, while their husbands secured the cattle and removed them from the locality.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 30.--At a singing school at Perkins's Schoolhouse, in the Sixth District of Williamson County, last night, Dr. John Sledge and William Todd became involved in a difficulty, during which Sledge shot and killed Todd. Sledge was arrested.

NYACK, Sept. 30.--The Prohibitionists of Rockland County are already beginning their work for the Fall campaign, and to-day their call for a County Convention, to be held at Haverstraw on Thursday, Oct. 7, at 2 o' clock, is issued.

The action recently taken by the new Public Printer at Washington shows that a party majority in the House of Representatives may sometimes overreach itself while cutting down appropriations for political effect.
SING SING, N.Y., Sept. 30.--The earnings at Sing Sing Prison for the month of September were $19,049 16; expenditures, $12,049 13. The profit for the month is $7,000 03.

SAN JOSE, Cal., Sept. 30.--The 2-year-old colt C.H. Todd, which broke the best 2-year-old mile record at Stockton on the 22d inst., made seven-eighths of a mile here yesterday afternoon in 1:28 , beating the record by second.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30.--The prospects of bringing about the formation of a gross money pool on passenger traffic between Chicago, St. Louis, and Southwestern Missouri River points are gradually diminishing.

BUFFALO, Sept. 30.--The Courier Company has brought suit against Bartley Campbell, the demented playwright, for show printing done in 1884 and 1885. The case was prepared last July, but through somo misunderstanding the papers were never served. The necessary order was obtained to-day for proper service.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30.--Leaves of absence have been granted as follows: To Second Lieut. D.D. Gaillard, United States Engineers, 1 month and 15 days; to Major James A. Gibson, Surgeon, two months.

The Tammany Hall organization held primary elections last night in every Assembly district for the election of delegates to the various local conventions. The polls were open from 7:30 to 9 P.M. There were no contests.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30.--The expected happened when A.S. Gage Co., the big wholesale and retail Wabash-avenue dry goods house, made an assignment to-day, with assets of not more than $650,000 and liabilities of nearly $900,000. Nevertheless there was a great scramble...

WATERBURY, Conn., Sept. 30.--A social event to which all Waterbury has been looking forward for weeks took place this afternoon in the marriage of the Hon. Lynde Harrison, of New-Haven, and Miss Harriet T. White, daughter of Luther C. White, of this city.
Mr. James Baillie Hamilton, the inventor of the vocalion organ, is visiting friends in Worcester, where he has established the principal factory for his instruments.
PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 30.--William E. Gould, the defaulting Cashier, was brought into court to-night and arraigned on three indictments--all for embezzlement.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 30.--Gov. Foraker is in receipt of information from not less than a dozen points in the State fully confirming each and every charge against the penitentiary management under the Hoadly Administration.

LONDON, Sept. 30.--This was the third day of the Newmarket first October meeting. The race for the Grand Duke Michael Stakes was won by Mr. Manton's br. c. St. Mirin, Prince soltykoff's ch. c. Mephisto was second, and Gen...

The City of Chester, of the Inman Line, which arrived last evening, brought Rosina Vokes, fair and plump, and Wilson Barrett, the English actor, author, and manager.
The trial of the Rev. Benjamin Staunton, of the Fort Greene Church, Brooklyn, charged with unministerial conduct, was continued at the Franklin-Avenue Presbyterian Church yesterday.

CHERRY VALLEY, N.Y., Sept. 30.--The Democratic Congressional Convention of the Twentyfourth District has as yet been unable to settle upon a candidate, Herkimer, Otsego, and Schoharie each demanding the honor of furnishing one.
The owner of the Galatea has undoubtedly had bad luck since he arrived in these waters. He has sailed four races, or, rather, has started in four races.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30.--The Star to-night says: "Gen. Miles did not make a special report regarding the capture of the Apaches, as was expected, out embodied an account of the campaign and its termination in his annual report.

The Liberal Club, of which Horace Greeley was the first President and long presided over by the renowned James Parton, will hold the first of its Winter meetings at the rooms of the club, No. 220 East Fifteenth-street, this evening. The President of the club, Mr. T.B. Wakeman, will deliver the opening address. On the 29th of October Mr. James Redpath is to read an essay before the club.

HOUSTON, Texas, Sept. 30.--The daring assassination of Capt. Michael Hennessy, Chief of the Houston detectives, last night, almost in front of his own residence, has been the theme of conversation in this city to-day.

OGDENSBURG, Sept. 30.--The First St. Lawrence County Assembly District Republican Convention, held at Gouverneur to-day, nominated Gen. N.M. Curtis, of Ogdensburg, for member of Assembly. Delegates to the Congressional Convention were elected favorable to the renomination of Congressman A.X. Parker.
A few minutes before 10 o'clock yesterday morning there was a terrible explosion at the Ditmar Powder Works, at Baychester, Westchester County, by which four men and one building were blown to atoms.
CHICAGO, Sept. 30.--The deliberations of the Central Traffic Association, passenger department, were satisfactorily concluded this evening.
The five football clubs which at present constitute the American Football Union were represented at the Fall meeting yesterday, at No. 243 Broadway.
The members of the Society of Medical Jurisprudence and State Medicine held a meeting last night at No. 12 West Thirty-first-street in memory of Dr. Frank Hastings Hamilton.

OTTAWA. Sept. 30.--Robert Evan Sproule, the American prospector, under sentence of death for murder, will be executed to-morrow at Victoria, British Columbia. His counsel and Mr. Hotchkiss, American Consul here, made every effort to obtain a reprieve. They have now abandoned all hopes, as Mr. Thompson, Minister of Justice, has refused to interfere.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 30.--Messrs. Robson and Crane tried "The Merry Wives of Windsor" here to-night for the first time.

The timely illustrated paper of the month is Franklin H. North's account of the fishermen of Gloucester and their life of arduous work and laziness, in alternation, on and off the Banks.

The news from London that the Foreign Office was lighted last evening and business apparently going on within does not seem to have much importance. It is, however, significant at least of the feverish condition of public sentiment which could make such an occurrence seem remarkable.
Dr. Howard Crosby has written a letter to Mayor Grace, which he refuses to furnish for publication, urging the Mayor to accept a renomination.

The trial of Daniel Driscoll, a leader of the "Why-oh" gang, for the murder of Bridget Garrity, at No. 163 Hester-street, on June 26, was finished before Recorder Smyth yesterday, with a verdict of guilty of murder in the first degree. With the exception of Dr, Davin, of St. Vincent's...

LONDON, Sept.30.--Lights are burning in the Foreign Office long after midnight and the papers will all have leaders in the morning declaring that the situation is more serious than it has been at any time since the abduction of Prince Alexander.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 30.--William Tanner, a saloon keeper of Alliance, petitioned the United States Circuit Court for an injunction restraining that city from enforcing its prohibition ordinance, under the local option feat ure of the Dow law. To-day Judge Walker refused the restraining order, holding that the...

WILMINGTON, Sept. 29.--The Harlan Hollingsworth Company has just finished for Mr. William K. Vanderbilt the steel yacht Alva, the finest pleasure ship afloat, at a cost of $650,000, and she will be launched at Wilmington next Saturday if conditions and circumstances are propitious.

The concert given by Col. McCaull for the relief of the Charleston sufferers netted $1,265.50, and the entertainment by Prof. Herrmann on Sunday evening last $1,267. Wallack's Theatre was furnished free of charge by Mr. Wallack on both occasions, and the total amount $2,532.50, has been turned over to Mayor Grace to be forwarded to Charleston.

BUTTE, Montana, Sept. 30.--Recent movements of Union Pacific engineers on the west side tend to confirm rumors concerning the intentions of that company with regard to future railway developments in this territory.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 30.--Col. Ingersoll is in Cincinnati on business in the United States Court in connection with the Toledo, Cincinnati and St. Louis Railroad. When asked by a reporter what he thought the predominating issue in the next Presidential campaign would be he replied: "I don't know that there is any.

The Executive Committee of the Republican County Committee held a special meeting at Grand Opera House Hall last night, to which were invited about 50 prominent Republicans outside the pale of the local party organization.
BERLIN, Sept. 30.--It is rumored that a plot to blow up a train on which the Czar was traveling has been discovered at St. Petersburg.

Inspector Thomas Byrnes, not content with making life miserable for criminals of all kinds by his untiring efforts in their pursuit, has a scheme for enabling the public at large to keep track of professional criminals without the intervention of special police aid.
One of the most stubbornly contested games that has been played here this season took place on the Polo Grounds yesterday, when the New-York and Detroit teams crossed bats.
LANCASTER, Penn., Sept. 30.--Hayden H. Tshudy, dry goods merchant, of Litiz, this county, made an assignment to-day. His liabilities are $20,000; assets, $15,000.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30.--The order of the Secretary of the Navy changing the Washington Navy Yard into an ordnance foundry goes into effect after to-day.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Sept. 30.--The schoolers Mystery and Landseer have arrived here from Iceland after a rough passage, bringing 130,000 pounds of Fletcher halibut each. The Landseer brought home an Icelandic family of five persons, who attract much attention, being the first Icelanders over to arrive at this port.

"Phenomenal" Smith, the left-handed pitcher, who agreed to play with the New-Yorks, and who broke his contract to accept an engagement from the Detroits, was on the field ready to play against the New-Yorks yesterday. Shortly before the time announced for the game to begin a gentleman walked...

The number of business failures for the quarter ending with Sept. 30, as reported to R. G. Dun Co., of the Mercantile Agency, is 1,932, as compared with 2,173 for the third quarter of 1885, showing a decrease of 241 failures. The liabilities, however, show a considerable in crease, amounting in the quarter just closed to $27,500,000, as against $23,874,000 in the corresponding quarter in 1885.
The Committee of the American Ornithological Union met last night at the residence of their Chairman, Mr. George B. Sennett, to discuss the form of a general law for the protection of song birds.

At a recent audience the Very Rev. Dr. Denis J. O'Connell, the Rector of the North American College, laid at the feet of the Pope 1,800, the contribution for the schools in the East from the Archdiocese of Boston.

BELVIDERE, N.J., Sept. 30,--Janitor Titus appeared in court this morning after passing an almost sleepless night, and he looked careworn and depressed, but during the day he showed no indications of a return of yesterday's nervous prostration.

The Convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Diocese of New-York reassembled at 9 o'clock yesterday morning in St. Augustine's Chapel.

It was a busy day at the Grand Central Station yesterday. All the Vanderbilt railroad companies held formal meetings. No dividends were declared on Lake Shore, Canada Southern, or Michigan Central. No business of special interest to the public was transacted, so said one...
BUFFALO, Sept. 30.--To-day occurred the seventh cremation at the Buffalo Crematory, and in its attendant circumstances it was the most noteworthy yet performed in this city.

BOSTON, Sept. 30.--Very quiet was the wedding this evening of Abbott F. Graves, the Boston artist, and Miss Montie Mayo Aldrich, daughter of Louis Aldrich, the actor, which was solemnized in a private parlor at the Parker...
There is rejoicing among the Commissioners of Emigration, and Elder Hart, the great Mogul of the Mormons, who looks after their interests here in New-York, is the cause of it.

The Rev. Dr. Charles S. Vedder, Pastor of the Huguenot Church, in Charleston, is at the St. Denis Hotel, in this city. He arrived there Thursday night. Dr. Vedder has come to the metropolis in the interests of his church, which was very much damaged by the recent earthquakes, as were the other churches in Charleston.

Lortzing's "Undine," first brought forth 40 years ago in Germany, was performed at the Thalia Theatre last evening. NEWPORT, Oct. 1.--The best race of the year was sailed off this place to-day. The contest was between the English-built schooner Miranda, Mr. G.H.B. Hill, owner, and the Burgess designed schooner Sachem, owned by Messrs. Metcalf and Owen. The race resulted in a substantial victory for the Sachem, which beat her competitor 8 minutes and 44 seconds.

DETROIT, Oct. 1.--Charles Conklin, alias Morgan, alias Andrews, a most desirable man to keep locked up and a most desperate character, has just succeeded in successfully escaping from the jail at Grand Rapids.

There will be music by the Seventh Regiment Band at 4 o'clock this afternoon on the West Drive, Central Park.

BOSTON, Oct. 1.--Judge Julius Rockwell, of Lenox, who has served ae Justice of the Superior Court since 1859, has resigned. Gov. Robinson, in replying to Judge Rockwell's letter or resignation, expresses recognition and appreciation of Judge Rockwells "high, honorable, able, just, and courteous administration of justice for so long a period of years."

The blood-red ribbon of the Socialist was conspicuous on the lapels of many coats in Clarendon Hall last evening, when Dr. Edward Aveling and Mrs. Eleanor Marx Aveling, of London, spoke on the meaning and methods of Socialism.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1.--An omnibus bill for the benefit of all the creditors of A.S. Gage Co. was filed this afternoon in the Superior Court against the insolvent firm and the First National Bank by Abegg, Darniker Co. The complainants are wholesale dealers in silks and dry goods in New-York City, and contract creditors of the bankrupt firm to the amount of $3,611.
Eugene P. Peyser, who already has a store at No. 123 Fulton-street, will open to-day a branch at No. 383 Broadway, in the very heart of the dry goods district.
Miss Davenport will bring out "Much Ado" at the Union-Square on Tuesday evening, Oct. 12.

It is not to be assumed that the financial policy of the National Government is an' issue in the State politics of Massachusetts and it is not probable that many votes will be cast for either Mr. ANDREW or Mr. AMES because of the declarations on that subject...
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1.--The second grand cricket match between picked men of Philadelphia and the English visitors was begun to-day on the Germantown Club grounds at Nicetown.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 1.--The Kentucky Trotting Horse Breeders' Association had cool and fine weather and a good track for to-day's trotting.

STEELEVILLE, Mo., Oct. 1.--Ever since P. F. Wallace was brought here under arrest for the murder of the Logan family, there have been threats of lynching him. At 11 o'clock last night an organized body of masked men marched...

BOSTON, Oct. 1.--Impure gas very nearly caused the suffocation of many persons in Dedham last night. The chief sufferers were in and around the Court House, where a jury of the Superior Civil Court were held under lock and key pending agreement on a verdict in a case under consideration. Of course the gas was lighted. while the jury sat about discussing the evidence.

CHERRY VALLEY, N.Y., Oct. 1.--No progress has apparently been made toward breaking the deadlock in the Twenty-fourth District Congressional Convention, which has been in session here since Wednesday. The vote still stands: Smith, of Herkimer, Il; Davenport, of Otsego, 15, and Pindar, of Schoharie, 11.

Margaret Maher, a confirmed inebriate, was found dead yesterday afternoon in her room at No. 413 West Forty-first-street, where she also kept a grocery. Her husband hanged himself in November, 1884, on account of her...

The jewelry trade has recently been excited over announcements of the discovery of an alleged new gem called beryl. This stone was described as one of great brilliancy and beauty, and also of exceeding hardness.
Christ Church, at Oyster Bay, Long Island, has made a handsome gift to the fund in aid of the sufferers by the earthquake at Charleston.
A number of the Hon. Abram s. Hewitt's friends met last night in the Park-Avenue Hotel and organized "The Tariff Reform Association...

PROVINCETOWN, Mass., Oct. 1.--Senators Saulsbury, Edmunds, and Frye, of the Senate Fishery Committee, arrived here at noon on the revenue cutter Gallatin, and took testimony this afternoon regarding the effects of reciprocity in fish on Cape Cod's interests. Capt. Kemp, of the schooner Pearl Nelson, was one of the winesses. Senators Frye and Saulsbury returned to Boston on the cutter at the conclusion of the hearing.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1.--Surgeon William H. Gardner has been relieved from duty in the Department of Texas and ordered to duty in the Department of the East. First Lieut. Sibley, Second Cavalry, has been granted one month's leave of absence. The leave of Second Lieut. Frank F. Eastman, Fourteenth Infantry, has been extended two months.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Oct. 1.--Charles Edwards, (colored,) alias Charles Gorham, who killed his mistress, Hettic Refuge, in Algiers, on June 20, was hanged to-day in the grounds of the parish prison in presence of the 15 witnesses allowed by law.
In the course of winding up its work the Episcopal Convention yesterday morning took decided action in a matter of greater public interest than any of its previous proceedings.

SCRANTON, Penn., Oct. 1.--Clara Morris played an engagement at Erie last night and left for this city on othe 1:40 A.M. train. It was not discovered until to-night that a diamond brooch, valued at $3,000, was missing. A telegram was sent to night to the Chief of Police at Erie, by the actress's husband, F.C. Harriott, to place the matter in the hands of the detectives of that city.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Oct. 1.--The colors of another English cutter were lowered to-day by a typical American centreboard sloop, when George W. Warren's crack Stranger finished behind Henry Bryant's Thetis, after one of the prettiest races seen in these waters this year.
The third day's play in the New-York Club's lawn tennis tournament was largely attended, although the wind was very cold and made both spectators and players shiver.

CHARLESTON, Oct. 1.--The first day of October came in with an earthquake overture about 1 o'clock this morning. The shock was very slight; in fact, few persons felt it, but it was here all the same. The day has been exceedingly quiet, and there have been no indications of a return of the disturbances.

Henry George took off his coat for yesterday's work, and received visitors, high and low alike, without cuffs and with his undershirt in sight beneath the foldings of his upturned shirt sleeves. But however informal his office and reception methods, the callers who filed all day into his quarters at the Colonnade Hotel had no trouble in seeing him, and came away pleased.

BOSTON, Oct. 1.--The nomination of Andrew by the Democrats was almost the sole topic of discussion among politicians to-day. The Democratic leaders reported at headquarters that they found his nomination well received by every one.

The inquiry into the cause of the collision of the ferryboats Wyoming and Flushing was finished before Steamboat Inspectors Fairchild and Marsland yesterday afternoon, and a decision will be given in about a week.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1.--The weather was cold and the attendance quite small at the Gentlemen's Driving Park races to-day:
David De Bensaude, the husband of "Miss" Violet Cameron, was arraigned at 10 o'clock yesterday morning before Justice Smith, in the Court of Special Sessions, at the Tombs.

Giovanni Danesi, an Italian gentleman, 50 years of age and living at the Shelburne Hotel, Fifth-avenue and Thirty-sixth-street, was arraigned at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday to answer a charge of disorderly conduct, preferred by Charles C. Delmonico.

In the maze of political discussion over the Mayoralty question it should not be forgotten that a new set of Aldermen are to be chosen. The President of the board will be chosen by the people at large.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1.--The Star to-night says: "At the Treasury Department there seems to be no importance attached to the report that the President had offered the Secretaryship of the Treasury to Senator McPherson. It may be stated with certainty that Secretary Manning is going back to the Treasury.

A stiff and chilly breeze from the northwest made the cyclers move slower than usual yesterday at Roseville, N.J., where the second day's racing of the New-Jersey Cycling and Athletic Association came off before a fair-sized audience.

Calls for the ambulances of the Manhattan and Ninety-ninth-Street Hospitals came from One Hundred and Eighty-first-street and the Harlem River, on the New-York side, at 5:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

READING, Penn., Oct. 1.--Hog cholera has made its appearance on the eastern frontier of this county, and is proving unusually fatal. U. G. Houck, of New-Berlinville, recently bought 13 hogs, all of which died of the disease. A number of farmers in the same vicinity have lost from three to five head each.

The striking stonerubbers were informed yesterday that an employment agent by the name of Fitzgerald had gone to Castle Garden and had taken 14 immigrants thence to some of the stoneyards up town where the rubbers are on strike.

LAREDO, Texas, Oct. 1.--Parties who have visited El Coyote's last battlefield in Mexico report finding several bodies of whites, confirming all other reports in regard to the killing of El Coyote and his men. Since that trouble there have been no indications of revolutionary movements in Mexico.
BOSTON, Oct. 1.--The Kansas City Club put King in to pitch to-day. He was very wild and was poorly supported.
STEVENS POINT, Wis., Oct. 1.--One of the most notable murder trials which have over taken place in Wisconsin is on the calendar for the term of the Circuit Court, which sits here next week.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1.--One of the most deliberate wholesale robberies that has been commited in this city for years occurred last Saturday night in the brownstone buildings Nos. 8 and 10 Park-row, and has just been made public.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 1.--James A. Hedden, who, while Cashier of the First National Bank of Newark, wrecked the institution, was to-day pardoned by President Cleveland.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1.--The Secretary of State is officially informed that the Canadian authorities, having learned that further representations in behalf of Sproule, the American convicted of murder in British Columbia, were on their way from the Department of State to London, have again respited him until Oct. 29. He was to have been executed to-day.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1.--The annual report of Gen. Miles is still in the hands of the President, and has been the subject of a brief conference to-day between himself and Secretary Endicott, but it is understood that no line of action has yet been decided upon in regard to that portion relating to the surrender of Geronimo.

The article on Keely's motor in the September Lippincott by Mrs. Bloomfield Moore is answered very good humoredly, but decidedly, by W.H. Babcock in the October number. NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 1.--The inter-State croquet tournament between NewYrok, New-Jersey, and Pennsylvania, which began here to-day, was marked by some fine plays.

BELVIDERE, N.J., Oct. 1.--On coming into court this morning Mrs. Titus was seized with a fainting attack, and had to be led to an anteroom. She was followed by the counsel for the prisoner, and they held a consultation for 20 minutes. Mrs. Titus came in about an hour later, looking very pale and depressed. The prisoner showed no signs of emotion during his wife's absence, and his condition was the same as yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1.--The General Grand Chapter of Royal Arch Masons at its meeting today completed the election of officers andc selected Atlanta, Ga., as its next place of meeting.

If a meeting were to be gauged by the number of people it gathers together, the citizens' meeting at Chickering Hall last night to favor Henry George's nomintion for Mayor was a thorough success at least a half hour before any one appeared on the platform to speak. Every seat, up stairs and down, was filled at 7:30.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 1.--The offerings to-day by the National Horse and Cattle Exchange consisted of 34 head, and the sums received aggregated $8,085, an averagve of $238. Earnestine, by Red Wilkes, dam by Banner Boy, was sold to D.A. Smith, of Lawrence, Kan., for $2,000. The balance brought low prices.

He did not undertake to defend himself. Without delay he pleaded guilty, and was sentenced to be confined for ten years in the State prison.

A young man named Holland, employed by the proprietor of the St. Nicholas Hotel as cashier, was sent to a bank on Tuesday with money and a check payable to bearer amounting to about $350. Holland cashed the check, appropriated the money, and disappeared. Central Office detectives were placed on the case, and they believe he has not left New-York.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 1.--The remains of the late Chief-Justice Chase will be removed from Washington to Cincinnati on Oct. 14, when the services will be held in the rotunda of the Capitol in this city.
ALBANY, Oct. 1.--One of the most skillful counterfeiters in the country was captured here to-day while at work by Detectives James Scanlan and Clarence R. Eaves, of the Secret Service Bureau.

DUTY--FEELING AMONG POLITICIANS. Mayor Grace looked cheerful and happy yesterday when a TIMES reporter asked him what he thought of the action of the County Democracy in proposing him for renomination.

PARIS, Oct. 1.--The will of the Duc d'Aumale, bequeathing his great estates at Chantilly, with all their appurtenances, works of art, books, and revenues, to the French Institute, in trust for the people of France forever,is dated in 1884.
COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 1.--The Democrats of this Assembly district renominated Lowell S. Henry for member of Assembly at their convention held here to-day.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 1.--Charlie Rose, the noted murderer and pay car robber, has escaped from the Dade Coal Mines by climbing a flue 100 feet high. He had made several des perate efforts previously.

PARIS, Oct. 1.--The French Chambers have been summoned to assemble on Oct. 14.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1.--The hearing of the motion for a new trial, in the case of the seven Anarchists under sentence of death for their participation in the Haymarket slaughter, was commenced before Judge Gary in the Criminal Court this morning.
Anthony Comstock entered the rooms of the Young Men's Christian Association, at No. 502 Fulton-street, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, and took his place among a number of clergymen there assembled.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1.--Dispatches from NewYork to-day brought a report that President Roberts, of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company had given notice that his company would withdraw from the trunk line pool Dec. 31 next, unless the present war on express rates is brought to an end and the disputes and difficulties in the pool settled.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 1.--The first day of the Latonia Jockey Club Fall meeting was cold and disagreeable, although the weather was fair. The attendance was light. The track was dusty, but the time was good and remarkably even.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1.--Commissioner Coleman, of the Department of Agriculture, has received a report from Dr. C.K. Dyer, the veterinary surgeon who was sent to ascertain what disease had broken out in the Counties of London, Fauquier, and Prince William, in Virginia, communicated by cattle obtained from Chicago, in which he says the disease is Texas fever and not pleuro-pneumonia.

Ex-Alderman Thomas P. Walsh, otherwise known as "Fatty" Walsh, recently announced that he would be the County Democracy candidate for Congress in the Seventh District, to succeed John J. Adams, otherwise known as "Jack" Adams.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Oct. 1.--A dispatch received here states that Blood Indians are daily growing bolder and are likely to put on their paint in a few days. Settlers in the vicinity of their reserve are fleeing from their homes, well knowing that soon the redskins will plunder every house and murder all whites they find.

LYNN, Mass., Oct. 1.--Five boys were out in the harbor in a small boat to-day, when the wind capsized the boat and three of them were drowned. Two, George Roberts and John Coakley, were rescued. The drowned boys were Henry Sears, Michael O'Nell, and Darhy Green.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 1.--The Knights of Labor of the Southwest will be but slimly represented at the Richmond convention of the order. They were thoroughly disorganized by the strike of last Spring on the Gould Southwestern system of railroads, and even under the most favorable circumstances a long time will elapse before they can regain their old strength.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Oct. 1.--Drafts on New-York--Sight, 12 cents; telegraphic, 20.

VIENNA, Oct. 1.--It is stated positively that Gen. Kaulbars, in consequence of hints from St. Petersburg, has moderated his attitude equally with the Regency and has become more conciliatory. An immediate relaxation of the tension between Russia and Bulgaria is, therefore, considered probable.

EL PASO, Texas, Oct. 1.--Two Mexican policemen to-day pursued a native whom they wanted to arrest across the Rio Grande into the United States, fired at him, and wounded him seriously. They then seized tha disabled man and dragged him back to Mexican territory, fording the river to do so. Great indignation is expressed here over the affair.

LONDON, Oct. 1.--This was the fourth day of the Newmarket first October meeting. The race for the Rous Memorial Stakes was won by J. Winteringham's ch. f. Caller Herrin.
LANCASTER, Penn., Oct. 1.--Harry Keys, a freight brakeman on the Pennsylvania Railroad, was instantly killed at Mountville this evening.

LONDON, Oct. 1.--Mr. Gladstone has received a proof copy of a manifesto to be issued by the Scottish Liberal Federation advocating home rule for both the Scotch and the Irish. Mr. Gladstone, in reply, assures the Federation that if he feels grateful for Scotland's action in the Irish question, he feels yet more confident concerning the efficiency of that action in the future.

MONTREAL, Oct. 1.--The Canadian Pacific Railway to-day took possession of the telegraph lines throughout British Columbia. This newly acquired system includes all the lines west of Winnipeg. HARRODSBURG, Ky., Oct. 1.--When the store of Col. H.W. Hawkins was opened by his clerk this morning a terrible sight met his vision. On the floor near the bed, which was in the rear part of the store, surrounded by several pools of blood, lay Col. Hawkins' body, in which were four ghastly shot wounds.

ERIE, Penn., Oct. 2.--When the curtain fell after Clara Morris's last act on Thursday evening she found her three-thousand-dollar diamond brooch missing. All search for the missing jewel was unavailing until this evening. A heavy reward was offered. This evening it was learned that a stage hand picked up the article, and supposing it was only a stage ornament put it in his pocket. The brooch will be forwarded at once.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 2.--A young man named E. Roe went out coon hunting last night. His dogs got into a quarrel, and he endeavored to hit one of them with the butt end of his gun. The trigger of the gun hit a tree and it was discharged. The contents entered Roe's abdomen, killing him instantly.

WATERBURY, Conn., Oct. 2.--This city is to have a hospital as soon as funds enough can be raised.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Oct. 2.--This afternoon Mrs. Yellig went to Rondout Creek for water. Arriving there she noticed the body of a child floating in the creek, and, pulling it ashore, found it to be that of her own 4-year-old son Charlie.

The Fall games of the New-York Athletic Club took place yesterday afternoon on the club grounds in the presence of an assemblage of spectators that was large, considering the coolness of the weather. A raw wind swept across the grounds and made the athletes dance about to keep warm.

The Detroits won another game from the New-Yorks on the Polo Grounds yesterday. The Giants led in the work at the bat, but they lost the game by unsteady fielding and the poor judgment displayed by base runners. A remarkably fine catch by Dorgan was the only feature of the game.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 2.--Admiral Porter is quite ill at the Hodges Cottage, on Catherinestreet, where he arrived from Milford Springs on Monday night. He had been indisposed for some time, but no one believed that he was seriously ill.
CHARLESTON, S.C., Oct. 2.--There have been no shocks here to-day, and the Summerville people have only been troubled with two or three slight tremors in the last 24 hours.

BUFFALO, Oct. 3.--On Saturday last several heavily loaded drays took all of the personal possessions of President Cleveland from his late bachelor quarters in the Weed Block to the Lehigh Valley freight station, where they were shipped to Washington.

LANCASTER, Penn., Oct. 3.--St. Joseph's, new Catholic Church, a handsome structure, was consecrated to-day, the Right Rev. John Conroy, Bishop of Albany, N.Y., officiating. The sermon was delivered by the Rev. Peter Kauffman, of Allegheny City. Over 200 persons, principally children, were confirmed.

The last of the Oregon, a lifeboat saved from the wreck, was lost in a gale encountered by the Etruria during the second day of the trip that ended yesterday. The boat lay on deck for emergency service, under one of the Etruria's lifeboats. While the steamship was pitching heavily a wave displaced the Oregon's boat, and at the next lurch it went overboard.

Pattison's latter to Attorney-General Cassidy regarding the anthracite combination and the trunk line pool when found by a representative of the Philadelphia Times in the library of his beautiful country seat near Bala Station this afternoon.
The Rev. Melville Y. Bovard has been nominated for Congress by the Prohibitionists of the Tenth District.

WILLIAMSPORT, Penn., Oct. 3.--James Arbuckle, freight agent of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad at Allenwood, was assaulted and robbed of $300 and a silver watch, and then left for dead in a secluded place in this city about 1 o'clock this morning.

'That "Billy" Moloney, although gone, is not forgotten, was proved yesterday when the countenance of ex-Senator John Hogan beamed upon the Etruria, as she swung into her dock. There are evidences in the political world that the undercurrent of feeling among a number of local Republican leaders and not a few Democratic business men is running in favor of ex-Sub-Treasurer Thomas C. Acton as a Mayoralty candidate.

Owners of property in the neighborhood of Madison-avenue and Fifty-eighth-street have begun to consider measures whereby the NewYork Steam Heating Company shall be prevented from building a boiler house on the vacant lots in Fifty-eighth-street, just east of ...

Summer is over, the vacation season is ended, and the benevolent but thrifty persons who manufacture great estates in England for deluded heirs in America have resumed work. The Washington Post publishes an advertisement, filling a column, beginning as follows:

The transformation of the Washington Navy Yard into a great ordnance factory, which was formally begun on the 1st of October, is the anticipation by Secretary WHITNEY of a step which Congress would probably sooner or later have specifically authorized and directed.
LONDON, Oct. 4.--The steamship Parthia, from New-York Sept. 19 for Hong-Kong, which is coaling at Elizabeth, will be surveyed in consequence of an explosion among the cargo.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Oct. 3.--For some weeks past a section of the Salvation Army, led by Capt. John Atkin, of New-York, has been parading through the streets here with drums, flags and tambourines, singing and shouting.

Husband De Bensaude was inconspicuous yesterday. It was reported that he had left town, but one who ought to know said that he was simply under the surveillance of his bondsman, and would appear at Lawyer Jacobs's office this morning to put his diminutive shoulder to the big suit he has undertaken.

Mr. Hamilton Willcox, Chairman of the Executive Committee of the New-York State Committee of the Woman Suffrage Party, wrote in November last to the Hon. Anson S. Wood, then Deputy Secretary of State, in regard to the "Election Code" formulated under his supervision, and under which many Inspectors at the last election refused to receive the votes of women.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 3--Knights of Labor tumbled into town to-day by boat and rail to the number of about 700. The colored citizen enjoyed the Knightly influx immensely, but was rather disappointed that each assembly was not headed by a brass band.

SOFIA, Oct. 3.--Gen. Kaulbars having again asked for a reply to Russia's ultimatum, the Ministry to-day, (Sunday,) after a long discussion, drafted a reply to the effect that the Bulgarian Government would comply with the demands of Russia to the extent that the Constitution and laws would permit.

LOUISIVLLE, Ky., Oct. 3.--The CourierJournal's specials report frosts all over the State. About half of the tobacco crop is uncut, and so much has been injured that one-half to three-quarters of it will make only frosted lugs.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Oct. 3.--Startling stories are told here to-day concerning the depredations of the Blood Indians. It is said that they have gone on the warpath, which means another Indian rebellion. The military are awaiting orders. It is possible, however, that the stories are exaggerated.

Mr. Streeter, of Bond-street, has a primrose-colored diamond 10 carats heavier than the Koh-i-Noor. Here is a fine opportunity for the Primrose League. They should buy it, and the dame who has talked the greatest amount of nonsense during the previous year should be allowed to wear it for a twelvemonth.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Oct. 3.--The Republicans of the Second Assembly District of Steuben County yesterday by acclamation renominated for the fourth time the Hon. Charles D. Baker, of Corning, for Assemblyman. The delegates to the Congressional Convention, to be held at Penn Yan Oct. 11, favor the renomination Of Ira Davenport, of Bath, late candidate for Governor.
Conjugal bliss has never been a feature in the private life of the Hohenzollerns, but the various "distinguished couples" have always managed to preserve a decent appearance of amity in public.

LONDON, Oct. 3.--A terrible explosion occurred on Saturday at Altoft's colliery, near Wakefield, Yorkshire. Seven men have been found dead, eight have been rescued, and seventeen are missing. In all probability the missing 17 lost their lives.

BOSTON, Oct. 3.--Clarence Hendrick, a young lawyer of this city, has disappeared and it is charged that he has misappropriated between $5,000 and $10,000 belonging to a young lady for whom he was settling up an estate.

BOSTON, Oct. 3.--Henry E. Dixey and his "Adonis" company arrived here late this afternoon on a special train. He was met at the station by a crowd numbering 500 or more, including Louis Aldrich, John J. Braham, Dexter Smith, Mrs. Dixey, the comedian's mother; Isaac Rich, and others in the profession.

At yesterday's meeting of the Central Labor Union a letter was received from the NewHaven Woodworkers' Union complaining against T.W. Porter, of that place, who, they said, employed non-union men in his wood factory, and then sent on the products of their work to this city, where they were put together by union men.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3.--The shipments of dead freight of all kinds from this city during the last week by the regular pool lines, including 2,596 tons taken by the Cincinnati, Indianapolis, St. Louis and Chicago, (Big Four,) amounted to only 36,122 tons, while for the corresponding ...

BRIDGETON, N.J., Oct. 3.--Charles G. Myers, Justice of the Peace, and general merchant here, died suddenly of apoplexy while sitting in his chair this morning. He weighed over 300 pounds and was about 60 years of age.

BOSTON, Oct. 3.--This evening, in Appleton Chapel, Cambridge, the first exercises under the new religious system at Harvard College were held before a large audience, composed in great part of Harvard students.

The complaint of difficulty in obtaining good servants is bocoming more frequent and more widespread in the south every day. There is one remedy which the white people can apply and which in the end they will be compelled to adopt.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 3.--Yesterday afternoon Mrs. Knight, living near the Camden and Atlantic station, noticed that Charles Clark was watching her house. This aroused her suspicions, and as she was going to a literary entertainment last night she had Lincoln Jones and a friend stay at the house during her absence.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Oct. 3.--A report reached here this evening that the Canadian Pacific Railroad steamer Athabasca went down last night on Lake Superior, with all on board. All efforts to get authentic news failed. The rumor causes much consternation.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Oct. 3.--One of the remarkable features of the wool market here the past week is the high price prevailing. While the highest price paid last Spring was 19 cents for the best wool the Fall clip thus far has been as high as 21 cents, with a strong tendency toward another upward move.

The church of St. Mary the Virgin, in West Forty-fifth-street, was crowded last night when the dedication and exhibition of the new organ took place. The service, which was entirely of a musical character, was very elaborate.
The Cracow Czas describes how the Czar of Russia travels: It announces the Emperor's recent call at Wysoko-Litewsk, and adds:

KINGSTON, N.Y., Oct. 2.--The Rev. Father Slegelack is the chief priest in charge of St. Peter's German Roman Catholic Church, in this city. A year or so ago a sensation was caused in church circles by Mr. Siegelack being charged with drinking beer in saloons and breweries here, and also having one of his servant girls "work the growler" between the parsonage and ...

It is reported that Gov. Henry Lloyd is to wed on Monday, Oct. 10, one of Cambridge's pretty daughters. The young lady is Miss Bettie Staplefoot. She is a blonde, and is very popular. A relative of the young lady is authority for the report. The event has long been looked for by people in Cambridge.

John Herreshoff's steam yacht Stiletto, which on Saturday afternoon again proved her title to the distinction of being the fastest steam vessel afloat by defeating the Mary Powell, "the grayhound of the Hudson," was tied up all day yesterday at Col. Franklin Brandreth's dock at Sing Sing.

Last evening's concert at the Casino enlisted the services of the Armaninis, of Miss Belle Colo, and of Mr. J. Levy. The performances of the Armaninis, although one can easily have a surfeit of mandolin music, were by far the most interesting and striking incidents of the entertainment:

At St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday solemn high mass was celebrated by the Rev. William J. Daly, assisted by the Rev. Michael J. Mulhern, the Rev. Joseph H. McMahon, and the Rev. James W. Kelly. The sermon was delivered by Archbishop Corrigan.

LONDON, Oct. 3.--Discount during the past week was quoted at 2 @2. There was an increased demand for money. The stock settlement was unusually heavy. Values advanced, but speculators cheerfully paid the higher rates. A large amount borrowed from the Bank of England and put upon the market restored rates to their former level.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 3.--Mrs. Craig Alexander, the wife of a formerly very wealthy commission merchant and a man of great local prominence socially, committed suicide this morning at 6 o'clock by jumping from the roof of her son-inlaw's house, No. 3,535 Lindell-avenue.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 3.--In the 30 suits against the insolvent banking firm of Wilkinson Co., notices of appeal were served yesterday from the recent decision of Justice Williams, of Watertown, setting aside the transfer of property before the failure to John Wilkinson, of Chicago, a brother of the Assignors; the one-hundred-and-twenty-thousand-dollar ...

Henry George yesterday discovered that Sunday is no day of rest for politicians. At his headquarters at the Colonnade Hotel, during the afternoon, he received a great number of local labor leaders, chatted with some, and from all received assurances of support in his contest for ...
NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 3.--The schooner Sachem left here for Providence to-day.

Mr. Francis R. Brooks, son of Dr. Almon Brooks, residing at No. 2, 548 Indiana-avenue, a student in Harvard College, was seriously injured on the 29th of March while performing a required chemical course.

ERIE, Penn., Oct. 3.--Philip Ackerman, of Summit, who had his residence and other buildings heavily insured, came home yesterday and applied the torch to them. His son August became so incensed because of his mother's narrow escape from cremation that he had his father arrested to-day.

BOSTON, Oct. 3.--L.M. Tebbetts, a prosperous fruit dealer on City Hall-avenue, has been missing since Friday under suspicious circumstances. His place of business was broken open this morning by the police, and a letter addressed to his wife found on the counter in which he states, that he will surely return home: The officers suspect suicide.
NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 3.--Admiral Porter passed a very comfortable night, and his general condition is somewhat improved. He has been suffering from intestinal pains of the most agonizing character.

AUBURN, N.Y., Oct. 3.--People in this city have not yet got over the surprise caused by the announcement, some three weeks ago, that John H. Little, a local canvasser for portraits, had fallen heir to a large estate in England.

ICY BAY, Alaska, July 19, 1886. The early morning of the 17th of July was a cold, damp, disagreeable one, with great banks of fog chasing each other rapidly over the waters of Icy Bay as the Pinta let drop her anchor in about seven fathoms of water, hardly knowing where she was till ...
These two volumes of the Badminton Library complete the collection of works on sporting, the first two treating of the horse and the turf and fishing.

BUFFALO, Oct. 3.--This morning, shortly after 9 o'clock, about 75 Knights of Labor gathered at the Central Station in this city. About an hour and a quarter earlier the body of John H. Heine, a painter of East Saginaw, had arrived, and ...

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 3.--The Hon. Thomas C. Manning, the recently appointed Minister to Mexico, left this morning for New-York, accompanied by Mrs. Manning and his widowed daughter, Mrs. Johnson. He will take the steamer from there to Vera Cruz, while his family will return to their home in Alexandria, in this State. A month later they will join him at the Mexican capital.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 3.--The nomination of Mr. Lagan yesterday by the Second District Democrats completes the list of this State's candidates. The Republicans have put a candidate in the Second District who, in case a free vote and fair count is vouchsafed, will probably be elected.

Mr. HENRY GEORGE gave to the public yesterday through the columns of the Sun an extended statement of why he wishes to be Mayor.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark, Oct. 3.--Advices from the Indian Territory say the Choctaw Legislature will convene to-morrow at Tuscahomma, the capital of the Choctaw country.

BERLIN, Oct. 4.--The newspapers announce that the Reichstag will, meet on Nov. 18. An exciting session is expected over the government's demand that the credit for the military shall be effective in times of peace for an indefinite period instead of, as hitherto ...

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4.--The general distribution of the new one-dollar silver certificates began to-day and will be continued until the demand, which is very great, has been entirely supplied. The notes are now being printed at the rate of 80,000 a day. The new twodollar silver certificates will not be ready for issue for two weeks yet.

Since Judge John R. Brady's white dog Puggy disappeared, last Friday afternoon, Capt. William H. Ricketts, the Supreme Court crier, and Capt. Alexander S. Williams have been very much interested in the search for the pet.
CHARLESTON, S.C., Oct. 4.--President Cleveland has sent $20 to the Confederate Home accompanied by a sympathetic letter.

SAN JUAN DEL SUR, Nicaragua, Oct. 4, via Galveston.--Telegraphic communication via the lines of the Central and South American Telegraph Company was re-establiahed yesterday, having been interrupted since, Sept. 15. The shore ends of the cables at this place were washed out by a mountain torrent, and the...

SANDWICK, Mass., Oct. 4.--The inland cranberry bogs suffered more on Saturday and last night by frost than any time this season. At 9 o'clock last night the thermometer registered 30 , gradually falling until midnight. It was the coldest night this season.

An anti-saloon Republican temperance mass meeting was held last night in the Palace Rink in Olermont-avenue, Brooklyn. The attendance was not particularly encouraging, although it had been announced that the Hon. William Windom, the Hon. Noah Davis ...

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4.--The English cricketers completed their conquest of America to-day when their second match against the local team terminated in their favor by six wickets. It took but a short time this morning to finish the game, as the Philadelphians, who were 37 runs to the good, with one wicket to fall, were only able to increase their score by 2 runs.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 4.--No man ever dropped more completely from public sight than Mgr. Capel since coming to California. He came here with a flouish of trumpets and for a little while appeared frequently in public, and his name was often mentioned in the papers.

Old Tim Connolly, who many years ago was a ward politician, was brought up short in the Court of General Sessions yesterday with a prompt conviction of assault. Tim, who is 64 years old, until very recently peddled Bibles, scapule, c., and about six weeks ago assaulted Rechel Harris in Washington Market and blackened her eyes.
Preparations for the registration of voters for the coming election, which begins this morn ing, have all been completed by Chief O'Brien, of the Bureau of Elections.

Miss Genevieve Ward revived at the Star Theatre last evening that admirable three-act drama by Messrs. F.C. Grove and Herman Merrivale called "Forget-Me-Not," portraying once more the woman, Stephanie, in whose character the fury and pitilessness of the tigress are...

A great number of men and boys visited the London and Liverpool Clothing Company's store at Nos. 86 and 88 Bowery, corner of Hester-street, and inspected the large assortment of Autumn clothes which are now on exhibition ...

BUFFALO, Oct. 4.--Mrs. Grover Cleveland attended the last entertainment given in her honor during her brief stay in the city this afternoon, it being a luncheon given by Mrs. George J. Sicard. To-morrow morning Mrs. Cleveland and her mother will leave Buffalo for Washington. The private car of the President of the Lehigh Valley arrived here to-night for Mrs. Cleveland's use on her return trip.

The friends of Henry George were hard at work yesterday and the literary and naturalization bureaus were in full blast. Mr. George was busily engaged in the preparation of the opening speech of the campaign, to be delivered by him in the large hall of the Cooper Union this evening.

BUFFALO, Oct. 4.--The investigation into the Engineer's Department by Mayor Becker has resulted in the death of the Deputy, the removal of two clerks, and the attempted suspension of the engineer prior to his trial on formal charges of misconduct in office. To-day Mayor Becker ordered Engineer Krause to appoint a Deputy ...

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Oct. 4.--On Dec. 31, 1870, Thomas H. Shollenberger, Richard Purcell, and Augustus Bartholomew leased from the Manhattan Coal Company Taylorsville colliery. It had been worked some time prior to that, but when Shollenberger Co. took charge the...

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 4.--William K. Vanderbilt's new steel yacht Alva will be launched by the Harlan Hollingsworth Company on Saturday, Oct. 16, at 2 P.M. The hull was ready for launching on Saturday last, and all preparations were made for the event, but her owner ordered her baptism to be staid until...

The Paying Tellers at the Union Dime Savings Bank, at Broadway and Thirty-secondstreet, had $100,000 on their desks yesterday to pay out to any depositors who might wish to close their accounts because Receiving Teller Otto Baumann ran off with $19,000. This fund remained untouched all day, and the bank closed with more money on hand than when it opened. There was about the average daily withdrawal and 40 new accounts were opened.
BOSTON, Oct. 4.--Merrill S. Holway, City Treasurer of Chelsea, committed suicide this evening by shooting himself in the toilet room connected with the Treasurer's office in the City Hall.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 4.--An old log house at City Point owned by Dr. Richard Epps, known as Gen. Grant's headquarters, was purchased today by Capt. Thomas E. Halleck, of New-York. This is a historic house, being the place where...

An experiment was made on the Thirdavenue elevated road yesterday morning with a new hydro-carbon fuel burner, patented by H. A. Barclay and managed by Charles F. Jacobsen, both of this city. The road had placed engine No. 128 at their service.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 4.--August Belmont, of New-York, has sold his beautiful and well known farm called "Oakland," containing about 126 acres, to Cornelius Vanderbilt, of that city. This is one of the most valuable farms on the island, and has been occupied for some time by O.H.P. Belmont, son of the late owner.

John Haggerty was driving some steers to a slaughter house in Brooklyn, Eastern District, yesterday afternoon, when two of them ran away. One started down Grand-street, while the other explored Bushwick-avenue.
