PAILADELPHIA, Oct. 4.--Fire broke out late to-night in the cotton and woolen mill of John Greer Co., at Sixteenth and Reed streets, and the flames spread so rapidly that the entire building was gutted before they could be conquered by the firemen.

Alderman Patrick Divver, of the Second Assembly District, in broadcloth and fine linen, and topped with a brand-new silk hat, strode out of his cafe in Park-row at noon yesterday, and the diamond as large as a chestnut in the snowy bosom of his shirt nearly blinded ex-Alderman...
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4.--There was a small attendance at the Gentlemen's Driving Park races to-day. Following are summaries:
Mr. Harrigan has postponed the first performance of "The O'Reagans" until Oct. 11, next Monday.
In his address to the students at the opening of the Columbia College sessions yesterday. President Barnard gave them some excellent advice as to their studies and obedience to college rules.

CITY OF MEXICO, Oct. 4, via Galveston.-- A curious phenomenon has occurred at Chimapla, in the State of Mexico. Within a few days past tremendous subterranean reports were heard, though at the time the meteorological conditions were perfect, there being no unusual aspect of the sky nor the slightest rain.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4.--The Controller of the Currency to-day received a preliminary report from the Bank Examiner at Portland, Me., which shows that the First National Bank of that place has suffered no impairment of capital by the recent defalcation of Cashier Gould, and still has more than $100,000 of surplus and undivided profits over and above all losses as yet ascertained.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 4.--The law regarding the taxation of insurance companies passed by the last Legislature is causing a good deal of trouble and loss of revenue to the State. Attorney-General O'Brien to-day rendered the following:
SEDALIA, Mo., Oct. 4.--An attempt was made early yesterday morning to wreck the eastbound passenger train on the Missouri Pacific Railroad at Greenwood, 30 miles east of Kansas City.

The audience at the Union-Square Theatre last evening was quite large and the number of ladies present was particularly noticeable. The play presented was "Miss Multon," with Clara Morris in the title role.

DANVILLE, Va., Oct. 4.--A daring attempt was made to-night to murder J.J. McIntyre, a wealthy merchant engaged in business in Norfolk and this city, who was here on a business visit. He was struck on the back of the head ...

"The Irish Minstrel," Mr. Frederick Marsden's new Irish play, was produced for the first time in New-York by Mr. W.J. Scanlan at Poole's Theatre last night, and if the applause of his audience goes for anything that young comedian gained a new triumph.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 4.--Atkisson held the champions down to two hits to-day and won the game. The Athletics, on the other hand, batted Hudson's pitching very freely. The fielding on the part of both teams was remarkably brilliant. The score by innings follows:
TRENTON, Oct 4.--When ex-Congressman John Hart Brewer goes to bed to-night it will be with the expectation that to-morrow night will find him the Republican candidate for Governor of New-Jersey.

We took note yesterday of Mr. HENRY GEORGE'S plans, of the portion of his propositions which his election as Mayor would give him immediate opportunity to carry ont, and we called attention to the fact...

District Attorney Martine, up to a late hour yesterday afternoon, had heard nothing definite as to the decision of the Court of Appeals in the Jaehne case, and he decided to send Mr. Nicoll, his assistant, to Albany. Mr. Nicoll went on the 6 o'clock train.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 4.--The third day of the Latonia Jockey Club races had a fair attendance and a very dusty track. It was an extra day, with purse races. There were 24 starters for the first contest and it was made into two races, an extra purse being offered.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 4.--Judge James Buchanan, of this city, was nominated by acclamation for Congress to-day by the Republican Congressional Convention of the Second District. Congressman Phelps, of the Fifth New-Jersey District, and Boutelle, of Maine, made speeches at the convention. As the district has a Republican majority of 2,000, Judge Buchanan is certain of re-election.
WAY STOCK, WITH SOME FIGURES. Wall-street's head was sent spinning again yesterday. Up went New-England Railway stock a half dozen points, and Western Union Telegraph stock kept pace.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 4.--To-day's LouisvilleBrooklyn game was a pitchers' battle, and although Ramsey was rapped safely five times, while the home nine hit Porter safely six times, the latter did the better work, as Browning alone seemed able to size him up with any degree of safety.
OF THE CONSPIRATORS RELEASED. BUCHAREST, Oct. 4.--It is reported here that a revolution has broken out in Sofia and Tinova.

A low-hulled steam yacht, less than a hundred feet in length and scudding down the Hudson with great velocity, attracted the attention of all the villagers between Sing Sing and this city early yesterday morning, and it was saluted time and again by the cannon of yachts and the whistles of steamers.

The French residents of this city gave a reception last evening to Gabriel Dumont, the leader of the Metis and the first of Riel's lieutenants during the Northwest rebellion. The reception was held in the hall at No. 21 South Fifth-avenue, which was decorated with French and American flags, and Dumont was given a...
DETROIT, Oct. 4.--The State University at Ann Arbor has just opened its new year and the attendance bids fair to be the largest, in the history of the institution.

Mayor Grace was yesterday waited upon by State Factories Inspector James Connolly, Arbitration Commissioner George Blair, Joel W. Hopper, and Thomas Bernhard, who asked him to sign a petition to Gov. Hill for the pardon of the Theiss boycotters.
The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company yesterday opened its new all-rail freight route to the West and Southwest, which is to be known as the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad and Continental Line.

PITTSBURG, Oct. 4.--Josiah Cohen filed papers to-day in behalf of H.B. Claflin Co., of New-York, against A.S. Gage Co., of Chicago, for $39,000. A partner of the defendant firm was served while taking breakfast this morning at the Union Station. The suit is to recover to goods bought of the Claflins.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 4.--The Court of Appeals opened to-day without any formality, all the Judges being present. The following causes mere argued. No. 749--People; respondent, vs. Oscar F. Beckwith, appellant.--Argned by L.F. Longley for appellant, A.B. Gardenier, District Attorney, for respondent.

MONTREAL, Oct. 4.--Alderman Beausoleil writes to La Presec that Mr. Helbrouner, who has charge of the labor column in that paper, never submitted the constitution or the Knights of Labor to Archbishop Fabre, as ordered by his superior, Mr. Blumhart.

LONDON, Oct. 4.--The Mark-Lane Express, in its weekly review of the British grain trade, says; "Trade is dull and despondent, with no prospect of relief. The sales of English wheat during the past week were 60,431 quarters at 30s. 3d., against 72,403 quarters at 30s. 6d, during the corresponding week last year.

The New-Yorks sustained another defeat yesterday, when the Chicago men won a game by 9 to 7. It was a poor contest, and the 2,500 persons who witnessed it gave evidence of their feelings by the manner in which they received the plays made.

There was a curious sort of gymnastic exhibition in Wood's Gymnasium yesterday, when 154 men were physically tested to ascertain their fitness for the police service. There were four applicants for positions on the Park Police and the remainder wanted to be patrolmen.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Oct. 4.--The Metropolitans beat the Cincinnatis today in a close and well played game. The visitors were more lucky in their hitting. The batting of Meister, Reilly, and Fennelly was the chief feature. About 300 people attended. The score follows:

CHICAGO, Oct. 4.--Drexel Boulevard was the scene of great excitement last evening. A span of powerful horses attached to an open carriage containing two gentlemen became unmanageable and tore down the crowded drive at a frightful rate of speed.

CORTLAND, N.Y., Oct. 4.--The Republican County Convention to-day made an unusually strong nomination for member of Assembly by placing in the field Wayland D. Tisdale, Treasurer of the Cortland Wagon Company, of which State Treasurer L. J. Fitzgerald, is President. Mr. Tisdale has been President of Cortland Village, and is one of the best known and most popular business men in the county. His election is certain.

TROY, N.Y., Oct. 4.--Bartholomew Mahoney, aged 17, who last week convicted of murder in the second degree for causing the death of Michael Lyons, was brought before Judge Parker in the Court of Oyer and Terminer to-day and sentenced to imprisonment for life.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Oct. 4.--The United States Senate Sub-Committee on the Foreign Fisheries arrived here to-day and will consider questions relating to the treaty obligations between the American and British Governments in regard to the Dominion fisheries.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Oct. 4.--Several parties from the Ninety-six section, in town to-day, stated that a small vocano had been discovered some 20 miles above here. They state that the land has fissures in it, and that smoke comes out of it.
NYACK, N.Y., Oct. 4.--Dwight B. Moody began a series of religious meetings in this place to-day, which will be continued for a week. At the first service a large audience was present in the rink.

As Eighth avenue car No. 133 was going down town at 6:15 o'clock last evening, two men jumped on at Seventy-fifth-street. They acted like ordinary passengers until Fiftyninth-street was reached, when, as if by a preconcerted signal, they sprang on the conductor and dragged him from the platform to the ground.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 4.--The McCaull Opera Company commenced a week's engagement here last evening at Coate's Opera House, opening with "Do nCaesar" to a crowded house. The company was well received and encores were numerous.

MANASQUAN, N.J., Oct. 4.--Although the Reform Club at this place has labored untiringly for a year past to find and close up the various beer depots and liquor saloons of the town its members were still confident that the laws were being infringed upon, and the unlawful sellers flourishing.

DUBLIN, Oct. 4.--The Freeman's Journal warns Lord Randolph Churchill that if he really believes his statements that the Irish difficulty is solely agrarian "he will flounder from mistakes into crimes."

The steamship Anchoria, which was due here a week ago yesterday, has not yet arrived, and some anxiety is beginning to be felt by those who have friends on board. Frequent inquiries were made at the office of the Anchor Line yesterday, but nothing was known there about the steamship's whereabouts or what was causing the delay.
The Subway Commission will have a meeting this afternoon, and the form of conduit for section No. 3, from Cortlandt-street to the Battery, along Broadway, will be one of the chief topics.
COPENHAGEN, Oct. 4.--The Rigsdag met to-day. Both chambers re-elected their Presidents and Vice-Presidents.
L.Z. Leiter, of Chicago, is at the Murray Hill Hotel.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4.--Good to fancy Cattle advanced 10c.@20c. to-day, while poor to fair natives remained unchanged. Native butchers stock sold at about former quotations. Local buyers were the principal operators. Competition from Dressed Beef men was too heavy for Eastern dealers.

Tenth-street in the vicinity of Broadway was crowded yesterday forenoon with old volunteer firemen. They were dressed in their regulation uniform of blue coat and pantaloons, black belts, red shirt, and leather service hats, and they attracted the attention of the large number of pedestrians passing up and down the thoroughfare.

Senator Daly was elected Chairman of the County Democrats of the Fourteenth District last night by the members who bolted after Frank Lowe was elected to fill the position made vacant by the resignation of Maurice B. Flynn.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4.--Darkness put an end to the game between the Washingtons and Detroits today when the former in the ninth inning had tied the score. The score was then reverted to even innings --the eighth--which left the visitors victorious by a score of 4 to 3.

PORT HAWKESBURY, Cape Breton, Oct. 4. --Customs Collector Bourinot, of this port, has been for sometime endeavoring to get his eye on several American schooners which had violated the Canadian customs laws.

An audience in numbers worthy of any orator and Mr. Justin McCarthy, an orator who would delight any audience, met in the Academy of Music last evening and Ireland's wrongs and prospects were told for the benefit of Charleston.

DETROIT, Oct. 4.--The log house of Judge Moran, grandfather of Controller Moran, the oldest building in the present city of Detroit, was torn down to-day. The house was built in 1734, a little over 152 years ago, the raising being followed by a jumping and wrestling match, with hard cider and eatables.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Oct. 4.--The schooner Garibaldi, Capt. Morton, of Gloucester, Mass., with about 16,000 pounds of fish, lying at anchor off Murder Island Saturday night, caught fire in the forecastle.

BUFFALO, Oct. 4.--The forces of the Republican Parts in the First Assembly District of Chautauqua County are in a bad condition and truly need mending. Capt. Chester Cole, Clerk Vrooman, and E.W. Hatch, of the State Committee, are going to Jamestown...

LITTLE FALLS, N.Y., Oct. 4.--Cheese--Sales to-day, 70 bxs, at 11c,; 220 bxs, at 11 c., 3,000 bxs. at 11 c., 2,200 bxs. at 11 c., 350 bxs, at 12c., 700 bxs, on commission and 700 bxs. Farm Dairy at l0 c.@12c.; bulk at 11 c.; no change in prices since last week. Butter--Sales, 150 pks, at 23c.@ 28c.; bulk at 25c, for Dairy and 27c. for Creamery.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 4.--A cable message from Europe announces the discovery of a new asteroid by Dr. Paliza. Its position Oct. 3 was, 4 hours 8 minutes 3 seconds Greenwich mean time, right ascension 23 hours, 3 minutes, 17.4 seconds; declination south 6 , 42', 46". It is of the fourteenth magnitude and is No. 260. Dr. Paliza has discovered this year five asteroids.

BELVIDERE, N.J., Oct. 4.--The court room was but partially filled this morning on the assembling of the Titus tribunal. The jury, looking sleepy and worn, filed into court escorted by the two special deputies who have them under constant surveillance.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct.4.--The trial of George W. Liming, charged with the attempted murder of George Lahue, of South Amboy, began here this morning. Liming shot Lahue in the back one afternoon in the presence of half a dozen witnesses.

GALVESTON, Texas, Oct. 4.--Ever since the great storm of Aug. 20, which swept over South Texas and did such extensive damage at Galveston, San Antonio, Indianola, and other points, reports have been constantly arriving telling of damage to the cotton plant through the belt lying between Galveston and San Antonio, a distance of 260 miles.

The ex-New-York Turner Cadets' Association has sent Mayor Courtenay, of Charleston, $100 for the relief of the earthquake sufferers.

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 4.--Town elections throughout the State, except in New-Haven and Bridgeport, were held to-day. Returns from this county show that in general there was a light vote. In Naugatuck and Branford the Knights of Labor tested their strength. In the former place they carried the town and elected their whole ticket by a majority of 60.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4.--It is stated officially at the War Department that nothing has been determined upon in regard to the surrender of Geronimo, and that the department is still lacking the information upon which to base any action.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4.--Edwin Booth opened his engagement at the Chicago Opera House this evening, playing Richelieu before a very large and brilliant audience. Mr. Booth was called once before the curtain at the end of the first act, and twice at the end of the third act.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4.--Mr. W.P. Rend is one of the most prominent of anti-pool dealers in the Chicago coal trade. He has extensive interests in all the bituminous fields of Pennsylvania and Ohio, and is one of the largest buyers of anthracite known on the Buffalo market.

Hanlon, of Medina. Collector Pierce was appointed by President Arthur after a very long contest over the place by the friends of several candidates.

KEYPORT, N.J., Oct. 4.--The sloop Argus, Capt. Kipp, of Perth Amboy, N.J., sank off Port Monmouth yesterday afternoon. The Captain and mate, Clarence Walling, were rescued in an exhausted condition by a passing sloop.

TORONTO, Ontario, Oct. 4.--The conference of State Boards of Health of the United States was in session here all day to-day, considering matters of interest to the different States of the Union.

Capt. William C. Casey yesterday celebrated the twenty-fifth anniversary of his joining the Seventh Regiment by entertaining his company, the Ninth, at his residence, "Hillcrest," at Tarrytown. There were about 50 files present, with some invited guests.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct.4.--The general plan of the Poughkeepsie bridge has been materially changed. Instead of three truss and two cantilever spans there will be three cantilever spans and two trusses, the spans to be nearest the shore on each side and the middle one being cantilevers.

MONTREAL, Oct. 4.--The exiled ex-Reading Clerk of New-York, "Billy" Moloney, returned to this city to-day after a trip to Europe. He has put up at the St. Lawrence Hall and is looking much better after his voyage.

George S. Scott, the capitalist, is one of the most popular men in Wall-street. Everybody knows him; everybody likes him. Yesterday, though, his hand was shaken with even unusual earnestness by friend after friend who called at his office. And there was a good cause, too, for the congratulations that were showered upon him.

Again the Equitable Life Assurance Society comes to the front in progress in life insurance methods. This sound, stable, and always progressive company was the first not only to issue Tontine policies, but the first to make its policies incontestable after three years from the date of issue.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 5.--In the inter-State croquet tournament to-day a number of ties were played, and the series has finally been reduced to a tie between Bush and Germond, each having three games won and two lost. The tie will be played off this week.

MELBOURNE, Oct. 5.--A volcanic eruption has occurred on the Island of Niapu, one of the Tonga group of the Friendly Islands. The whole island is now covered with 20 feet of volcanic dust. Niapu has a population of about 500.

Luke Lukens, a miller of Santa Cruz, filed a petition in insolvency, claiming to be a merchant under the act of June, 1880. The Superior Court sustained the petitioner, but on appeal the Supreme Court reversed the case, holding that a miller is not a merchant under the act.

PHELPS, N.Y., Oct. 7.--Prof. Brooks, of the Red House Observatory, secured observations this morning of the new comet in the constellation Leo. It is moderately bright for a telescopic comet, with considerable condensation on the side of the comet toward the sun. It can only be seen just before daybreak in the eastern heavens.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7.--The number of fresh and "stale" Cattle on sale to-day reached 14,200 head. The general market was 5c.@10c. lower than yesterday. Real choice offerings, however, commanded full previous quotations, and in some instances "handy" natives sold a shade higher.

SHAMOKIN, Penn., Oct. 7.--The miners of the Philadelphia and Reading Peerless Colliery struck to-day on account of a scarcity of cars. The breaker cannot prepare coal steadily and several miners demanded that the time be allowed them which was thus lost. Their request was refused and the committee was ordered from the mines. The rest then struck for their reinstatement. Three hundred persons are thus made idle.

LAREDO, Texas, Oct. 7.--The arrest of an officer of the Mexican Army was made here today that is likely to cause a good deal of trouble before the matter is settled. The officer in question is Capt. Rafael Pinale, of the regular army.

The White Star pier yesterday looked like a meeting place for cricketers. The English eleven, who have been on a visit here for the last month, were departing for their homes, and besides a large delegation from the Staten Island Cricket Club several members of other clubs were there to bid them good-bye.

Henry George had a host of visitors at his headquarters in the Colonnade Hotel yesterday, but the most welcome were brought by the letter carrier. CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 7.--A tramp known as "Black Hills" committed suicide at 8 o'clock this morning by lying down in front of a train near Edgewater Park, on the Amboy Division of the Pennsylvania Railroad. His left arm and head were severed from the body. He had always been crazy, but was regarded as harmless.

The news of the nomination of Judge Dahiels by the Republican State Committee as candidate for a Judgeship in the Court of Appeals was received by him yesterday afternoon at his private office at the City Hall. BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 7.--Castile, a little town in Wyoming County, was much excited this morning by the shooting of a young man in cold blood by Robert E. Van Brunt, a tailor. The scene of the tragedy was the residence of Simon Roy, and it was his son, Will E. Roy, aged 20 years, who was the victim. Van Brunt is a Canadian by birth, and boarded with the Roys.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7.--News has just been received in this city from Nicaragua of the sudden and tragic death of Dr. Constantine Guzman, one of the most noted and popular men in the country, who was well known in Philadelphia, where he studied medicine.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Oct. 7.--James Mullen a thrasher, of the town of Stafford, came to Batavia this morning. On his way home, about 10 o'clock, he was struck by an Erie excursion train bound for Niagara Falls, at a crossing in the outskirts of this village, and instantly killed, his neck being broken. His wagon was wrecked, but his horse was uninjured. Mullen was 50 years old, and leaves a widow and 11 children.
LONDON, Oct. 7.--The steamship Kovno, (Br.,) Capt. Neill, from New-York Sept. 19 for Gothenburg, Copenhagen, and Stettin, passed Dunnet Head to-day.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 7.--Jay Gould, Mr. and Mrs. George Gould, and Mr. A.L. Hopkins, Vice-President of the Missouri Pacific, passed through here at 2 o'clock this afternoon in Gould's private car, bound west on the Lake Shore Road, but refused information as to their destination, saying they had no plans and really did not know where they should stop.

From sunset this evening until to-morrow at sunset there will be observed by some seven or eight million Israelites, scattered all over this globe, the so-called solemn festival of "Yom Kippur" or day of atonement. This fast day has done more to bring Jews together in their ancient faith than all of the rest of the holidays.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 7.--New-Orleans parties have sent an offer to the St. Louis American Club and the Chicago League Club to play three of the baseball championship games here. The offer comprises a guarantee of $5,000 and all expenses paid. Baseball here is on a boom.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 7.--The case against Soldier Kerns, of the Salvation Army, who is charged with gross immoralities, and with whom half a dozen other Salvationists are involved, was closed to-day with a verdict declaring Kerns guilty, but refusing to punish him, as the woman who made the complaint is a notorious character and was involved with other soldiers. Despite the exposures, the Salvation Army held a grand jubilee to-night.

BOSTON, Oct. 7.--The first meeting of the Freshman Class of Harvard College was held this afternoon in Boylston Hall, Cambridge. To prevent any rush or disturbance between the Sophomores and Freshmen the Faculty had ordered the latter to meet in the afternoon, and not, as has been the custom invariably, in the evening.

LONDON, Oct. 7.--The Anchor Line steamer Ethiopia, which arrived at Glasgow to-day from New-York, reports that on Sept. 29 she passed another steamer of the same line. The latter was probably the steamer Anchoria, which left Glasgow Sept. 16 for New-York, and has not yet reached her destination.

COBLESKILL, N.Y., Oct. 7.--"Did you ever hear of such a thing as a man hiring pasture for bees?" asked a gentleman from Cherry Valley, who was waiting here for a train. THE TIMES'S reporter, of whom the question was asked, had certainly never heard of anything of the kind, and so informed his questioner.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Oct. 7.--William G. Wilber died today from the effects of a wound received last Sunday from a target gun in the hands of a companion named William Gubb. They were shooting at a mark, and while Gubb was loading the weapon Wilber stepped in front of it, and it was accidentally discharged, the ball entering Wilber's body at the groin. Wilber was 18 years old and Gubb is 30.

BELVIDERE, N.J., Oct. 7.--The opening of the eighth day of the trial of Janitor Titus was not marked with any particular incident. The 12 "good and true" men were photographed in front of the Court House before they marched to their seats. They now keep in line nicely, and look like a small body of militia on undress parade when promenading the streets.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 7.--An unknown man fell over the Genesee Falls this evening. He was well dressed, but there was nothing about his person which could lead to identification. Whether it was suicide or a casualty is not known.

SOFIA, Oct. 7.--M. Karaveloff has resigned as Regent. The new newspaper Independent Bulgaira stigmatizes Gen. Kaulbars as "a rebel fomenting rebellion among the people and army." It also urges the Government to "bind Gen. Kaulbars and send him across the frontier."
ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 7.--The Women's Christian Temperance Union of this State has re-elected Mrs. Mary T. Burt President. In 39 counties there are 383 auxiliary branches with a membership of 9,459.

The address of welcome will be delivered by Eminent Sir John B. Stanchfield, Commander of St. Omer's.

DELHI, Oct. 8.--The ill feeling recently aroused between the Hindus and Mohammedans here over mutual violations of their respective religious principles culminated in a riot last night. Several persons were killed.

BRIDGETON, Me., Oct. 8.--Owen B. Gibbs, a prominent citizen, largely interested in manufacturing industries, was thrown from his carriage to-day and very badly injured. Mr. Gibbs is a member of the New-York firm of Deering, Milliken Co., and Treasurer of the Pondicherry Mills Company, and is widely known in business circles.

NATCHEZ, Miss., Oct. 8.--Ex-Sheriff Chase, of Concordia Pariah, La., has disappeared pending an investigation of his embezzlement case. His friends says he is in Canada. His official bondsmen prevented his arrest some time ago as they thought he would remain to atone for his crime.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 8.--Wright Weldon was hanged in Edgefield to-day for murder. His neck was broken and and he died almost without a struggle. He made a full confession before going upon the gallows.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 8.--The two factions in the General Assembly of the Knights of Labor indulged in a bitter contest on the floor of the convention to-day, and the debate became so acrimonious that Mr. Powderly felt compelled to desert the chair to champion the imperiled Home Club.
LOWVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 8.--The Democrats of Lewis County to-day nominated Thomas B. Phelps, of Lowville, for Assemblyman.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8.--Christian Anderson, a Swede, living with Conrad Nelson, at No. 478 West Erie-street, was caught by the latter in a room with Mrs. Nelson at 1:30 o'clock this morning, and shot in the stomach. He was taken to the County Hospital, where he died. Nelson was locked up at the West Chicago-Avenue Station.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8.--Lieut. Albert G. Berry has been ordered to ordnance duty at the Washington Navy Yard. Ensign Charles N. Atwater to the Naval Academy, 20th inst.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8.--Mrs. Griffin, residing at No. 2,623 Anthracite-street, left her 14-month-old babe in care of a 8-year-old daughter this evening during a brief absence from home, and when she returned she found the babe's clothing in flames. The little one was so badly burned that it died in a few minutes.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Oct. 8.--The American schooner Marion Grimes, Laudery, Master, has been seized at Shelburn for violation of the customs law. She put into Port Shelburn last evening for shelter, as a heavy gale was blowing outside at the time.

James Pringle, pitcher of the home nine, while in the act act of delivering a swift curve liner, broke his right arm near the elbow and at the same time dislocated his shoulder. Pringle is heavily built and pitches a very swift ball.

Mrs. Mary Eliza Metz, of Catonsville, Baltimore County, through Thomas R. Clendenin, yesterday docketed suit in the Superior Court against the Board of Managers of the Maryland Hospital for the Insane to recover $10,000 damages for injuries suffered from the locating of the asylum adjoining her grounds, which, she claims, has depreciated the value of her property.
CARLISLE, Ky., Oct. 11.--Last Friday night a party of men went to the house of Jack Taylor, in Robertson County, bent on murder or kukluxing.

George Curran is a Calais lawyer, famed for his wit and talents all through Eastern Maine. Not long ago a banquet of some kind was given in St. Stephens, New-Brunswick, opposite Calais, at which Mr. Curran was one of the invited guests and speakers.

From some information given in the Liverpool Consistory Court yesterday, one of two conclusions is inevitable--either that the parish church of North Meols has had an extremely small door to its pulpit or a clergyman of most portly proportions on temporary duty.

LONDON, Oct.11.--Lord Randolph Chnchill has arrived at Vienna. The Rev. Henry Ward Beecher's closing lecture was attentively listened to by 2,000 persons. Mr. Beecher contended that evolution, the handmaid of religion, was the greatest blessing Christianity ever had.

BOSTON, Oct. 11.--At a meeting of the Harvard Boat Club, held this evening in Holden Chapel, Cambridge, the following officers were elected: President--F.S. Coolidge, '87, of Boston; Vice-President--C.F. Adams, 3d, '88, of Quincy, Mass.; Secretary--Copley Amory, '88, of Boston; Treasurer--F.G. Balch, '88, of Boston.

Mme. Julia Yalda, the leading soprano of Signor Angelo's new Italian opera company, arrived yesterday by the steamer Arizona, and went at once to apartments which had been secured for her at the Victoria Hotel. Mme. Valda came over earlier in the seasom by the Umbria, but returned on the same steamer. She came then to make arrangements for the season now about to begin.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 11.--At the opening of McCaull's Opera House to-night "Josephine Sold by her Sisters" made an immense hit. It was not a success of estime or of first night enthusiasm, or of any other of the elements which come so often to the assistance of initial performances, but a pronounced popular verdict.

LONDON, Oct. 11.--The Conservative newspapers avoid direct mention of the Daily News's statement that the Government will introduce a bill giving four Provincial Councils to Ireland. The Standard refers to "big gooseberry revelations of important Cabinet secrets before the Ministers themselves have arrived at any decision."

The officers of the New-York and NewEngland Road still continue to attract the attention of the speculative New-Yorkers. To-day's story on Wall-street was that President Watrous and Vice-President Reed of the NewYork, New-Haven and Hartford Road were making a tour of inspection over the New-England Road.

Ex-Warden of the Tombs Jonn Stacom, now a lawyer with a large practice at the criminal bar, is Irving Hall's candidate for the Assembly in the Second District. He expects to secure the Tammany and Irving Hall indorsements.
ELMIRA, N.Y., Oct. 11.--Ira Davenport was renominated for Congress by the Republican Convention of the Twenty-ninth District, held at Penn Yan, this afternoon. The vote was unanimous.
FREEHOLD, N.J., Oct.11.--Mary Ann, the 10-year-old daughter of Farmer Willett, living about five miles from this place, was assaulted yesterday by an unknown negro.

Capt. James Garvey, of the canalboat James Field, lying at Pier No. 3 East River, heard a cry for help from the water shortly before 10 o'clock Sunday night and discovored a man struggling in the water.

An application for a commission to determine the mental condition of "Blind Tom," the pianist, and for the appointment of committees of his person and estate, was denied by Judge Donohue, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday.
Miss Clara Morris appeared in "Article 49" before a crowded house at the Windsor Theatre last night, the beginning of a week's engagement.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 11.--The Beck Marshal Carpet Company, doing business on Washington-avenue, made an assignment this afternoon to Percival S. Hill. N. H. Beck, the President of the company, places the vulue of the stock at $50,000, and the open accounts and bills receivable at $20,000.

The band of office holders and office seekers dignified by the title of a County Convention met in Tammany Hall last night and nominated Congressman Abram S. Hewitt for Mayor of the city. A conference committee was appointed to meet similar committees from the County Democracy on filling the other places on the local ticket.

The British ship Dunnottar Castle, bound from Sydney, New-South Wales, for Wilmington, this State, Capt. H. A. Martin, Iaden with coal, went ashore at about midnight on Cure or Ocean Island, July 15, between two reefs on a coral bottom, and became a total loss.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Oct. 11.--The NewEngland yachting season closed to-day, when the cutter Stranger defeated Mr. Bryant's Thetis. Early in the morning there was a dead calm, but at 10 o'clock a light breeze from the southward sprang up.

MOUNT CARMEL, Penn., Oct. 11.--Another seam of excellent coal, eight feet thick and of fine quality, has been struck at the Shamokin Neilson shaft at a depth of 720 feet. Gangways will at once be opened, and the completion of the large breaker, which is now partly erected will be hastened. When the mine is fully opened 1,000 hands will find employment.

Representatives of the so-called Andover school in the Congregational Church were beaten by a vote of two to one at the annual meeting of the great missions board in Des Moines last week, when the resolution approving the work of the board's officers was adopted.

John B. Sargent, one of the largest manufacturers of builders' hardware in the United States, will preside at the meeting of merchants and manufacturers who are agitating for tariff reform, which meeting is to be held at 2 o'clock this afternoon at Room F. Stewart Building, No. 280 Broadway.

Judge Hall, who lives at Boston-avenue and One Hundred and Sixty-sixth-street, was awakened at 1 o'clock on Sunday morning by his burglar alarm. Hastily putting on his coat he hurried out of his room and heard retreating footsteps.

Rusk, which is generally conceded. The question of plurality, however, is what puzzles the politicians. There are four tickets in the field-Republican, Democratic, Prohibition, and Labor.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11.--Gen. Miles's annual report, as commander of the Military Department of Arizona and New-Mexico, which has been received at the War Department, is a voluminous document, containing a full history of his operations against Geronimo and his band, together with a statement of his position in regard to the terms of surrender.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 11.--Ever since the nomination of candidates by the Republican City Convention there has been internal strife and dissensions in the party. In view of this state of affairs the Republican City Central Committee called a convention for the purpose of reconstructing the ticket.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 11.--Judge Brown, of the United States court, this morning handed down his decision in the case of the United States against John Craig on the action brought to recover a penalty of $1,000 provided for in the "Assisted Immigration act" of Feb. 26, 1886.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 11.--David Carpenter, the Postmaster of the little town of Woodbridge, owns a row of buildings on Mainstreet and the Post Office is at the other end of the town.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 11.--Frank Hamilton, aged 7 years, of Waynesburg, Stark County, an inmate of the Ohio Institute for the Deaf and Dumb, died a horrible death yesterday after three days suffering of a most intense nature.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11.--At the founding of the Andover Theological Seminary the donors of the funds drew up a very clear and sharp creed. CHICAGO, Oct. 11.--The House of Deputies of the Protestant Episcopal Church resumed its sitting this morning at Central Music Hall. The galleries were crowded with ladies and gentlemen. Prayer was offered by the Rev. Dr. Barbee, of Easton, Penn., and the benediction was given by Bishop Brewer, of Minnesota.

LONDON, Oct. 11.--At Newmarket to-day the Clearwell Stakes, of 30 each, with 200 added, for 2-year-olds, distance about five and two-thirds furlongs, (34 subscribers,) was won by Mr. Manton's br. c. Lourdes by one length.

DANVILLE, Va., Oct. 11.--Late Saturday night a number of the university students at Chapel Hill, N.C., were out on a lark, and a disturbance took place between them and a number of negroes who reside at the place.
The first anniversary mass for the repose of the late Cardinal McCloskey was celebrated in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning by the Most Rev. Dr. Corrigan, Archbishop of NewYork.

ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, Oct. 11.--The steamer Anchoria, Capt. Small, left Glasgow on Sept. 18 bound for New-York. She had 700 persons on board, including passengers and crew. On Sept. 22, four days after the steamer had cleared from Glasgow, a strong gale sprang up, and during this blow a heavy sea struck the ship. In the lurch which she made the shaft of the propeller was suddenly broken.
As Senator Evarts walks about town-- and he walks a good deal--there is a suspicious little limp in his gait suggesting that his accident up in Vermont was not altogether a matter of one day.

OTTAWA, Oct. 11.--Preliminary arrangements have been made for the formation of a company to establish a line of steamships between Port Nelson and England as soon as the Hudson's Bay Railway is finished. The com pany will be composed of a large number of English capitalists.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 11.--General Superintendent Shaler met the committee of dissatisfied brakemen at Meadville to-day for conference. He said he could not grant the advance in wages, and at 6 o'clock this evening the brakemen and switchmen of the first and second divisions, from Kent to Salamanca, stopped work. The engines were run into the roundhouses and affairs seem to be arranged on both sides for a long strike.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Oct. 11.--An incident occurred at Shelburne to-day, that threatens to give rise to more serious complications than those which have occurred since the abrogation of the treaty.

The people of New-York have a warm place in their hearts for Edward Harrigan, and whenever he produces a new play they crowd his theatre to see what new combinations he has made of the heterogeneous materials that breezes from all points of the compass waft together in this most cosmopolitan of cities.

Prof. Oscar R. Gleason, the horse educator, had a large, enthusiastic, and apparently well pleased audience at the Cosmopolitan Theatre last evening, where he began his second season in this city after a very successful tour of the country.

Patrick Burns, who said that he was also known by the name of "Jerry O'Brien," was charged in the Essex Market Police Court yesterday with having assaulted two little girls Sunday night in front of the Church of the Nativity, in Second-avenue.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11.--Thomas B. Atkins, Henry K. McKarg, Jacob Short, and Stephen H. Thayer, bondholders of the Wabash, St. Louis and Pacific Railway east of the Mississippi, presented a petition to Judge Gresham to-day for leave to file a bill to foreclose the mortgaged property of the road, and for a Reneiver.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11.--An interesting case to the commercial world was decided today by Judge Gresham in the United States Court. For some years prior to 1885 Harris Burton did a fair business as a wholesale cigar dealer at Peoria, with a stock worth $4,000. In July, 1885, he ordered $14,000 worth of goods on four months' time.

VICKSBURG, Miss., Oct. 11.--The Vicksburg Water Works Company, recently organized in this city under a charter granted by the last Legislature, made a proposition to the Mayor and Council at the meeting of that body held tonight ...
TORONTO, Oct. 11.--It is reported that defaulter Neeld, of Chicago, is in this city with his wife. He has, it is said, been seen and recognized by an old Chicago acquaintance.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Oct. 11.--Col. McCaull's Opera Company made their first appearance in Wilkesbarre this evening, presenting Millocker's opera, "The Black Hussar," before one of the largest audiences ever assembled in Music Hall.

The Democrats dissatisfied with the renomination of Congressman McAdoo met at Odd Fellow's Hall, Hoboken, last night, and nominated Mayor Kerr, of that city, as the candidate of the Independent Democrats for Congress.

BOSTON, Oct. 11.--The dissatisfied conductors and drivers of the consolidated horse railroad kept their own counsel well, and when they presented to Prosident Powers to-day a formal list of grievances as a result of their secret midnight meeting of Sunday they anticipated by several days the expected denouement.
CHICAGO, Oct. 11.--The committee of railroad managers which was to have met today to agree upon a plan to pool Southwestern passenger business refused to come together on a point of etiquette.

Some 200 Chinese laundrymen met Sunday evening in their temple on Chatham-square. Their object was to devise means to limit the number of laundries, and thus prevent a further reduction of the price for washing, which those now established regard as already too low.

The Subway Commissioners begin to believe that they foresee harmonious relations with the electrical companies. President R. P. Flower said yesterday that Superintendent Smith had applied for room for the fire alarm wires, and the Metropolitan Telephone Company has completed a satisfactory negotiation, ...

The new main reception room of the Union Club, which has recently been refurnished and redecorated, was thrown opon to the members of the club last evening. The new room is said to exceed in magnificence the reception room of millionaire Flood, which has heretofore been regarded as the finest in America.

FORT VALLEY, Ga., Oct. 11.--Last night, in Henderson, Mattie Barren and Lucy King were quarreling about their lovers. They finally came to blows, when Marietta Jones, a friend of the girls, stepped up and stabbed Lucy to the heart, killing her instantly.

FORT VALLEY, Ga., Oct. 11.--Last night, in Henderson, Mattie Barren and Lucy King were quarreling about their lovers. They finally came to blows, when Marietta Jones, a friend of the girls, stepped up and stabbed Lucy to the heart, killing her instantly.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 11.--Ex-Speaker Samuel J. Randall was found to-day at his residence on Paoli Heights sitting up, but still showing in his face signs of his recent severe illness.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 11.--The steamer George Appold, Capt. Warren, left this port Saturday at 7 P.M. for Baltimore. About midnight of the same day she broke the outward section of her shaft.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 11.--Col. James A. Grinstead, the well known turfman, who has been prominently connected with race horses and their breeding in Kentucky for 40 years, died Saturday night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11.--The dispatch printed in a New-York paper this morning purporting to come from Chicago and giving particulars about the flooding of that city with counterfeits of the new ten-dollar certificates, so good that even expert handlers of money can scarcely distinguish them from the genuine, was news to the Treasury Department.
WALLINGFORD, Conn., Oct. 11.--Thomas Wallace created a sensation here to-day by telling Constable Austin that he knew where the head of the man whose body was found in the famous shoe box was buried.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12.--The House of Deputies of the Protestant Episcopal Church began its sixth day's session this morning. The Committee on Consecration of Bishops reported in favor of the consecration of the Rev. Mahlon Norris Gilbert as Assistant Bishop of Minnesota.

There was a large and disappointed crowd of people at the Gravesend track yesterday. There was no betting of any kind, as it was reported that several members of the Grand Jury were present. All the well known bookmakers were present and occupied seats on the grand stand.

ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, Oct. 12.--The officers of the Anchoria and Sir Ambrose Shea. the agent of the Anchor Line here, have decided to keep the passengers on board the steamer until arrangements have been made for sending them to their destination.

The best Mayor that the city has had for a long time is Mayor Grace. SHENANDOAH, Penn., Oct. 12.--This town and the entire Mahanoy Valley is threatened with a water famine which must result in serious loss to business.

A New-York paper says that grapes are very cheap and abundant in that city, the common varieties selling at from 10 to 30 cents a pound. That does not sound like cheapness and abundance to one accustomed to Cleveland prices for fruit, grapes being sold here at 2 cents per pound.

The price of wheat at Chicago on Monday last was lower than it had been for twentyfour years, the month of December, 1884, excepted. The extremely low price on Monday was 69 cents a bushel. In December, 1884, the price fell to 69 3/8 cents.
Last night the Hairdressers' Guild of London met in solemn conclave, and Mr. Osborn delivered to them an eloquent lecture upon the place of the hairdressers' trade in literature.
Nothing has been heard yet by the creditors of the whereabouts of Stevens Voisin, the exporter, of No. 85 Leonard-street, who fled last Thursday.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 12.--The result of the election here to-day is as follows: Aldermen --First Ward, Kane, (Rep.,) 387 majority; Second Ward, Ufford, (Dem.,) 42 majority; Third Ward, Parker, (Rep.,) 324 majority; Fourth Ward, Duryea and Roth, (Dem.,) 117 and 82 ...

FRANKLIN, N. H., Oct. 12.--The funeral of Senator Austin F. Pike this afternoon was largely attended. At 1:30 P.M. prayers were offered at the residence of the late Senator by the Rev. J. H. Bliss, after which the remains were taken to the Congregational Church.

GALVESTON, Texas, Oct. 12.--The storm which was reported by the Signal Service as entering the Gulf of Mexico last Saturday night reached Galveston to-day, and at this time, 8 P. M., a furious gale is blowing from the north.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Oct. 12.--The seventythird annual session of the Grand Commandery of Knights Templar of the State of New-York began here this morning at 10 o'clock. Right Eminent Grand Commander Peter Forester opened the conclave in the asylum of St. Omer's Commandery, in the Masonic ...

An oil lamp in Ames Co.'s iron foundry, No. 96 steuben-street, Jersey City, exploded at 9 o'clock last evening and set fire to the building. The entire building, which was a onestory frame structure, running through to Morgan-street was ablaze, when the Fire Department arrived.
TORONTO, Oct. 12.--Smallpox has broken out again at Trenton, a small town on the line of the railway between Toronto and Montreal.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Oct. 12.--The Burlington Coasting Club, under whose auspices the carnival was held here last Winter, held its annual meeting last night and elected the Hon. Henry Ballard President. It was unanimously dedided to hold another week of sports next Winter, probably the middle of February. The membership of this club is 800.

The Kings County Republican General Committee met last night at Everett Hall to determine the dates for holding the conventions. The report of the Executive Committee in regard to the conventions was adopted after a short discussion.

One day last week while the tug steamer Seth Low was around at St. Augustine about 150 of the Apache Indians, with their squaws, were treated to a short ride out to sea on her. They seemed to enjoy the trip hugely, the sensation of riding over the surging billows being new to them. The boat returned about dark, when they disembarked and again reoccupied their quarters in the old fort.

Henry and Edward Kohout were taken from the Tombs to the Court of General Sessions yesterday, to testify in the trial of John Kylian, who was supposed to have been concerned with them in the tenement house arson case, for which they had been sentenced to imprisonment in Sing Sing Prison for life.

The Emigration Commissioners have now on their hands four American Indians, who arrived by a Hamburg steamer on Monday. He Crow, the head of the party, is a dignified-looking man who wears a stovepipe hat.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 12.--At the Republican Congressional Convention for the Sixteenth District, held to-day, the Hon. John H. Ketcham was unanimously renominated for Congress. Strong speeches were made by representative men from Columbia, Dutchess, and Putnam Counties, and Gen. Ketcham also made an address accepting the nomination.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12.--Among the scientific papers which will appear in the appendix of one of the forthcoming reports of the Geological Survey is one by Prof. Joseph P. Iddings upon the obsidian cliff of Yellowstone Park.

ALBANY, Oct. 12.--The following Assembly nominations were made by the Meegan Democrats in Albany County this afternoon: First District, Philip J. Henzel; Second, Meredith Burke; Third, John McCullough; Fourth, John T. Hill, of West Troy. The others live in Albany.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Oct. 12.--A great sensation was created in this city to-night by the discovery that W.H.H. Murray, better known as "Adirondack Murray," was quietly married at his residence at 8 o'clock last Monday evening to Miss Frances M. Rivers, of Montreal.

About 50 laborers from Shafts Nos. 2 and 3 of the new aqueduct went to Shaft No. 4 on Monday night and entered the saloon kept by an Italian known only by the name of "Joe." They were negroes, Italians, and Irishmen.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 12.--Late to-night word comes from Meadville that at a conference this evening between Superintendent Shaler and the strikers an agreement was reached by which the brakemen return to work to-morrow on the first and second divisions of the main line of the New-York, Pennsylvania and Ohio Railroad.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct.12.--Wales Doolittle, of Bethany, was tried to-day for killing his hired man, William Ford, last February. The principal witnesses against Doolittle were his two young sons, but they gave their testimony directly, making no effort to shield their father.

LONDON, Oct. 13.--The comments of the whole European press on the Eastern question evince increasing uneasiness. From St. Petersburg little news is received, but a feeling of anxiety prevails there. Rubles have fallen to a lower point than was reached on the announcement of the Plevna disaster.

At its meeting last night the Bar Association refused to pass a resolution, presented by Charles Lydecker, approving the holding of a convention to revise the State Constitution.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 12.--A German named Dyihtel was found hanging in his room at the boarding house of Rudolph Zwingley, No. 46 Richmond-street, this evening. He came here about two weeks ago from Boston, and unsuccessfully sought work at his trade of shoemaking. He had worked for some time at Hartford, Conn.

ERIE, Penn., Oct. 12.--The Hon. William L. Scott has shipped 80 of his brood mares and colts to the blue grass region of Kentucky. The colts go to be sold, while the mares are sent for the benefit of the blue grass. The protracted dry weather which prevailed here for several weeks killed the grass and made the change absolutely necessary. Extensive improvements are about to be made in the home of Rayon d'Or.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12.--It is understood that the promotion of Col. James C. Duane to be Brigadier-General and Chief of Engineers, to succeed Gen. John Newton, has been decided upon at the War Department, and only remains to be approved by the President.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 12.--The rear section of a coal train on the Camden and Amboy Railroad ran into the other section, near South Amboy, this morning, and badly wrecked it. Conductor Burchern was dangerously injured about the head, but the other trainmen escaped by jumping. The track was not cleared until late in the afternoon.

ALEXANDRIA, Minn., Oct. 12.--Congressman Knute Nelson was picked up unconscious in the lake last night, but revived this morning and is now able to walk about. He was out fishing, hooked a big pickerel, and in his efforts to land him lost his balance and fell overboard. The water chilled him thoroughly, and it was several hours before he regained consciousness. No serious results are apprehended.

Congressional district, Representative Willis, who has been defeated for the Democratic nomination, will be taken up and re-elected, notwithstanding his committal of the high crime and misdemeanor of getting President Cleveland to reappoint Mrs. Thompson, the thoroughly efficient Postmistress of that city.

PORTLAND, Me., Oct. 12.--The affairs of the David Cowan Co.'s woolen mill, at Lewiston, have been placed in the hands of John T. Scruton who is the Assignee. The business will be conducted as heretofore. The liabilities are about $100,000. It is thought that the obnoxious second hand, about whom the hands went on strike, will be dropped if the hands return to work.

Mrs. Sophia Twitchell, who had announced that she would register at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon in Brooklyn, did not appear at the place of registering at Albany-avenue and Deanstreet. No ladies registered in Brooklyn.

READING, Penn., Oct. 12.--Nathaniel C. Barr, of Hamburg, this county, who recently failed for nearly $30,000, was Treasurer of the Hamburg Building Association, and it was discovered to-day that he was short in his accounts with the association nearly $5,000. A committee of stockholders has been appointed to either collect the amount or institute criminal proceedings.
NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 12.--British Consul De Fonblanque, aided by two British shipmasters, completed to-day an investigation of the matter of the bark Montreal and her rescue by Capt. Suttalora.

The feature of the meeting of business men yesterday to discuss the question of revenue reform was the speech of the Hon. ABRAM S. HEWITT. It was, in effect, a declaration of war. He recounted his experiences in the House during the last twelve years.

The President of the Third-avenue street railroad, who went to Baltimore yesterday, will inspect while there the working of a new electric motor, which has been in use for some time in Cleveland and has recently been employed to some extent on a Baltimore surface road.

BOSTON, Oct. 12.--The election of Class Day Officers of the Senior Class of Harvard College took place this evening, and, as is generally the case, the contests over some of the offices were long and protracted.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12.--The Collector of Customs at San Francisco has informed the Treasury Department of difficulties encountered in the enforcement of the Chinese restriction law.

CHICAGO, Oct.3.--Freeman Fearnley has disappeared from his usual place of business at No.141 South Water-street, and it is said that he has gone to Canada.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 13.--Yale's Fall regatta was rowed on Lake Saltonstall this afternoon and drew out a big crowd of spectators, who traveled to the lake in all sorts of conveyances from a special train to a lumber box wagon.

CHARLESTON, West Va., Oct.13.--The thirty-third annual Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church South met in this city this morning and was called to order by Bishop W. W. Duncan, of South Carolina. J.H. Black was elected Secretary and J.M. Carter Assistant Secretary. This Conference includes West Virginia, a portion of Virginia, Kentucky, and South Carolina.
A collision occurred yesterday in the East River between two floats loaded with railway cars.

The appointments of Col. J.C. DUANE to be Chief of Engineers' and of Col. O.B. WILLCOX to be Brigadier-General, made yesterday, add two more to the unusually long list of appointments of General officers which President CLEVELAND has had to make this year.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct.13.--The sale of blooded trotters at the Glenview Farm was continued to-day. The attendance was much larger than yesterday, and the bidding was spirited, although the prices paid were not so high as the first offered some of the finest of the stock being sold yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct.13.--The postponed game played off to-day by the Athletic and Brooklyn Clubs resulted in a draw, darkness putting a stop to the play at the end of the eighth inning, when each club had scored 3 runs.

WASHINGTON, Oct.23.--The body of ChiefJustice Chase left Washington by a special train, which preceded the regular 3:30 train, this afternoon, for Cincinnati, where it will arrive at 7:30 to-morrow morning.

The Carriage Builders' National Association is holding its fourteenth annual meeting in the Germanic Assembly Rooms, No. 291 Bowery. About 300 members, representing a majority of the States, are present.
WILMINGTON, Del., Oct.13.--The palatial steam yacht Alva will be launched to-morrow morning at the yards of the Harlan Hollingsworth Company.

MONTREAL, Oct.13.--Nathan M.Neeld, the partner of J.C. Ferguson Co., the pork packers of Chicago, who defrauded several banks, among them the British North America, arrived at the Balmoral Hotel Saturday evening with his wife, and registered under his own name.

One hundred and twenty-five gentlemen, representing 75 of the 155 railroads which are in the National Time Convention, met at the Hotel Brunswick yesterday and discussed a plan which has been presented for uniform train rules.

EMINENCE, Ky., Oct.13.--An armed mob of about 50 masked men rode to the jail in NewCastle about 3 o'clock this morning and demanded the delivery of two negro prisoners, one charged with an attempted assault on a white woman, the other with the murder of his 2-yearold child.

Degraaf Taylor exhibited at their furniture warerooms in West Fourteenth-street, near Sixth-avenue, yesterday, several novelties which they have introduced this Fall, and which already are assured successes.

Preparations for the ceremonies at the unveiling of the Bartholdi statue are going forward smoothly. The parade promises to be one of the greatest displays ever seen in this city. Gen. C.P. Stone, the Grand Marshal, was busy all day yesterday looking over letters and documents relating to the procession and issuing directions.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct.13.--Joseph Frese, a German, 55 years old, living on Williston-street, West Stratford, tried to murder his wife, aged 33, and then ended his own life, early this morning.

SHENANDOAH, Penn., Oct.13.--About 8 o'clook this morning a girl named Hennessy, residing with her parents on West Coal-street, this borough, went into the basement of the family residence, and seeing at the foot of the stairway what appeared to be a bar of iron she attempted to pick it up.

HUDSON, N.Y., Oct.13.--To-day another judgment was filed in the County Clerk's office against George H. and Samuel J. Tilden, Jr., in favor of the National Bank of Kinderhook for $125,000. The claim is for notes given in 1885.
WASHINGTON, Oct.13.--The Post says: "United States Marshal McMahon, of New-York, is in town to make war on First Controller Durham for cutting down his bills.

BOSTON, Oct.13.--A meeting of the stockholders of the Atlantic Cotton Mills, of which the late William Gray, Jr., was Treasurer, was held to-day to hear the report of the Directors. Several important recommendations were made and adopted.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct.13.--William M. Rowe, of Lynn, broke the two, four, and five mile bicycle records of the world at the Hampden Park track to-day, riding against time. His time was as follows: Mile, 2:37 1-5; two miles, 5:14; three miles, 8:02 1-5; four miles, 10:45; five miles, 13:27 2-5.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13.--The President has appointed Col. James C. Duane to be Chief of Engineers, with the rank of Brigadier-General, vice Gen. Newton, retired. Gen. Duane is now on duty in New-York as Engineer of the Third Lighthouse District, and has been ordered to Washington to assume the duties of Chief of Engineers.
ALBANY, Oct.13.--All dispute as to the exact age of Judge Charles Danieis would seem to be set at rest by the following certificate, now on file in the office of the Secretary of State.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct.13.--The American Academy of Medicine finished up its business to-day and adjourned shortly after noon to meet in Washington, D.C., the Friday and Saturday preceding the International Medical Congress which convenes in that city on Sept.1, 1887.

TORONTO, Oct.13.--The interesting ceremony of unveiling the Brant statue at Brantford was performod to-day. The statue was erected by the Six Nation Indians of the Mohawk village, near Brantford, Ontario, in memory of Joseph Brant, the greatest chief of the Mohawks, whose name is so bloodily prominent in American history.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct.13.--Private advices state that a company of teachers under the direction of Dr.Sheldon Jackson reached Kodiak Sept.23 on the steam schooner Leo, 19 days from Seattle, en-route to the Aleutian Islands and Western Alaska.

CHICAGO, Oct.13.--The packers at the stock yards seem to be playing fast and loose with the Knights of Labor committee which are trying to settle the big strike, and the men are getting restive. Not a progressive step was taken in the stock yards strike to-day, and everything was as quiet as ever.

CHICAGO, Oct.13.--The triennial Council of the Congregational ministers assembled at the Union Park Church this morning. There was a large attendance of delegates from various States, among whom were the following:

CHICAGO, Oct.13.--Any day within the near future may witness the arrest of one or more of forty man who are to-day walking the streets of Chicago unconscious that the charge of writing and indicting menacing messages to the officers of the law will soon be proved against them.

It was predicted by open enemies of the Knights of Labor before the convention now in session at Richmond opened that the result of that convention would be the practical disintegration of the order, and the prediction seems in a fair way to be verified.

Indian Chief, a stallion, known as "the Connecticut man eater," although belonging to Dr. E.W. Miller, of Springfield, Mass., took a preliminary lesson in obedience at Cosmopolitan Hall last evening from Prof. Gleason, the horse educator.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct.13.--Lew Simmons and James Scott, an insurance broker of this city, returned from Havana to-day.

The National Committee appointed at the Chicago Anti-Saloon Republican Conference has issued through its Executive Committee an address to the Republican Party of the country urging it to take the position defined at that conference in regard to dealing with the liquor traffic.

VINCENNES, Ind., Oct.13.--The experts, Messrs. Allen and Fleener, reported on the investigation of County Treasurer Hollingsworth's books last evening, and find that he owes the county a balance of $76,897. The report created a great sensation.

Schedules filed by Assignee Francis T. Sargent, in the Court of Common Pleas, yesterday, show that the insolveut firm of J. De Riviera Co., whose head, Henry C. De Rivera, fled to Canada last July, owes $1,412,245 81 outright, and has contingent liabilities to the amount of $73,O86 54.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct.13.--A catboat race was sailed here to-day, the entries being the AEtna, sailed by George Gordon King; the Princess Ida, by Woodbury Kane; the Alice, by W. R. Hunter, and the Dove, by S. Whitney Warren. The AEtna won, leading the others by a long distance. The course was about 12 miles and the AEtna's time was a few minutes less than three hours.

Surrogate Rollins heard testimony yesterday in the case of James Henry Paine, who was known as a miser and musical critic, and who died at his home, No. 177 Bleecker-street, on Dec. 23, 1885, from the efeects of being knocked down by a horse on Broadway on Dec. 15. Paine was said to possess several hundred thousand dollars, but after his death no trace of the fortune could be found.

Congressman John J.Adams has retired from the race for a renomination in the Seventh Congressional District. This leaves the field clear for Thomas P.Walsh, who is a County Democracy man, and will undoubtedly be the union candidate for the place.

JAMESTOWN, Oct.13.--Certain innovations upon the methods of conducting a political convention in the southwestern corner of the state are shaking the old-time politicians out of control in a manner painful for them to contemplate.

Mr.HEWITT will have the profound sympathy of his fellow-citizens during the laborious process of making up his mind what to do about the nomination for Mayor which was tendered to him yesterday by seven solemn sachems from Tammany Hall. Whether Mr.HEWITT shall go back to Congress and reform the tariff laws or take his ...

BERLIN, Oct.13.--The Government has received a long dispatch from Herr Thielman, the German agent at Sofia. He describes the position of affairs as extremely critical. It is reported that Russia has informed the powers that the immediate occupation of Bulgaria is necessary.

The final proceedings in the case of the Rev. Benjamin Staunton drew a big crowd to the Franklin-Avenue Presbyterian Church yesterday, though none of the parties' in the case, with the exception of the defendant himself, were present. The Rev. Newell Woolsey Wells summed up for the prosecution.

The Baltimore and Ohio Railway's business hitherto given to the Ohio and Mississippi Railroad Company for St. Louis is to go hereafter to the Cincinnati, Indianapolis, St. Louis and Chicago Railroad, known as the "Big Four."

PITTSBURG, Oct.13.--One of the most important deals in oil-producing property in many years is that agreed to in yesterday and to-day's conferences. This consists of the absorption by the Standard Oil Company of the property of the Raccoon Oil Company at Shannopin, consisting of 7,000 acres of promising oil and gas territory.

LONDON, Oct.3.--The Attorney-General, in a speech at Sandown,'Isle of Wight, this evening, said that the Government would not be deterred from suppressing Irish crime and outrage and the wicked oppression of the weak by the strong with the aid of gold from other countries. The Government, he said, was determined to maintain the existing laws.

The news that the Manhattan Railway Company had ordered all electric light wires to be removed from the structures of the elevated roads created a breeze in subway circles yesterday. It was surmised that the Western Union Telegraph Company was behind the order.

SUMTER, S.G., Oct.13.--The cotton-picking machine invented by C.T. Mason, of this place, was tested to-day in the field in the presence of committees from the New-York Cotton Exchange and the Charleston Exchanges and ...

MACON, Ga., Oct.13.--Albert Thomas and Thomas Basemore, two well-to-do colored men, who had been enemies, had a reconciliation during the earthquake excitement and concluded to be fraternal hereafter. Night before last the men were sleeping together.

OTTAWA, Oct.13.--The Government, yielding to the pressure exercised by the imperial authorities, has consented to appoint a medical commission to inquire into the mental condition of Sproule, the American citizen, now under sentence of death for murder at Victoria, British Columbia.
LONDON, Oct.13.--The Times publishes a leader commenting on the Henry George movement and on the torpor which it says has fallen upon American politics, and which it pronounces unexampled.

The Brooklyn Republican League held a meeting last night in the Brooklyn Rink, in Clermont-avenue, near Myrtle-avenue. Col. Winslow presided, and on the platform and among the audience, which numbered about 700, were Gen. B.F. Tracy, C.D. Mosserop, Jesse Johnson, Foster ...
CHICAGO, Oct.13.--The managers of the Northwestern roads have hit upon a plan for surmounting obstacles in the way of forming pools which deserves to be patented.

BELVIDERE, N.J., Oct. 13.--This has been a clear day for the defense in the Titus trial. All day the jury have endured a flow of eloquence, but by no sign indicating the impression it may have made. This morning, headed by their soldierly-looking foreman, the jurymen marched to their cane-bottomed, high-backed seats and settled down as if to stay.

Car No. 1 of the Newark-avenue line drove up to the Newark-avenue crossing of the Pennsylvania Railroad in Jersey City on Tuesday evening. The seats were crowded and some passengers were hanging to the straps.

Mr.McPHERSON, the talented and experienced Secretary of the Republican Congressional Committee, is reported to have made the prediction that the Republicans will elect a majority of the House of Representatives in the next Congress.

Queens County Republicans assembled in good force in Jamaica yesterday, where they held three conventions--one for the nomination of officers for Queens County and the other two for Assembly nominations.
LONDON, Oct.13.--The race for the Middle Park Plate of 500 sovereigns, added to a sweepstakes of 30 sovereigns each, for 2-year-olds, the second horse to receive 200 sovereigns and ...
NEW-ORLEANS, Oct.13.--The storm on the Lower Mississippi proves to have been much more serious than was at first supposed.

A dark, shaggy cloak covered up the gaudy red and blue stripes in the tight-fitting dress which Miss Mary Alice Almont Livingston wore when she appeared before Justice Murray in the Court of Special Sessions yesterday to listen to what Lawyer Henry R. Willis should say.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 14.--To-day's play has been the best seen on the intercollegiate tennis tournament, and the most interesting event of all was the match in the doubles between Knapp and Thacher, of Yale, and Brinley and Paddock of Trinity.

The Citizens' Committee of One Hundred met last night at No. 1,212 Broadway and, after an executive session of over two hours, nominated Theodore Roosevelt for Mayor, J. Hampden Robb for President of the Board of Aldermen, Daniel G. Rollins for Justice of the Supreme Court, Edward Patterson for Judge of ...

GALVESTON, Texas, Oct. 14.--The Government steam tugboat Penrose left Galveston at 1 o'clock to-day for the scene of the Sabine Pass disaster with a life-saving crew on board. The village of Sabine Pass was settled in 1832.

Mr. Reinhard, who keeps a cigar store in the basement of No. 165 Broadway, and who has beeh entirely deaf for many years, joyfully informed his brother, about 10 o'clock yesterday morning, that he was regaining his lost sense.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 14.--The Congressional contests in Pennsylvania present some interesting features. There will be numerous changes in the delegation, and several districts usually regarded as perfectly safe for one or the other party are now more than uncertain.

The County Convention of the Anti-Monopoly League met last evening at the Tremont House. Several of the delegates came instructed for Henry George, others preferred Abram S. Hewitt, and still others wanted to wait until all the parties had completed their nominations.

DUBLIN, Oct. 14.--Archbishop Croke writes to the newspapers that it would be deplorable if the temperance societies in Ireland, under a pretext of political neutrality, should succeed in impeding the progress and retarding the triumph of the national cause.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 14.--This was the seventh day of the Fall meeting of the Latonia Jockey Club. The weather was windy and the track was heavy from last night's rain. Following were the events:
The County Democracy's County Convention in the large hall of the Cooper Union last evening was one of the most memorable events in the history of that organization.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14.--The Protestant Episcopal Convention began its eighth day's proceedings as usual with religious services. The Committee on the State of the Church reported back favorably the resolution of the Rev. Mr. Statsenberg urging international arbitration as a means of obviating war. The report was placed on the calendar.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Oct. 14.--Jacob Weller, doing business as J. Weller Co., wholesale dealers in peanuts and pickles at Vine and Water streets, made an assignment to-day to Charles E. Wilson. Mr. Weller was the largest dealer in peanuts in the country.

A few days ago Dr. Nagle, of the Bureau of Vital Statistics, received a letter from MrS. Edith Turner, of Sydney, Australia, asking him to search the records of the department to ascertain whether one Isaac Putnam Smith, formerly of this city, but now resident in Sydney, where he is known as "Col. Ike Austin, the American sharpshooter," had been married over 20 years ago to one Julia Barclay.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 14.--All this afternoon passengers were carried about the city free on the street cars. The railroad was opened to-day and this was a part of the celebration.
The New-Orleans Picayune prints the following open letter addressed to the Rev. Dr. W. H. Milburn:
The Republicans of Westchester County met in Moran's Hall, White Plains, yesterday, to nominate candidates for county offices to be filled at the ensuing election.
The belief is said to prevail at the War Department that the Chiricahua captives now at San Antonio will soon be sent to join the remainder of their band at Fort Marion, Florida.
Miss Edith May, daughter of Mr. I.E. Wright, was married yesterday to Charles Edgar Storey at the bride's residence, No. 1,983 Madison-avenue.
SOFIA, Oct 14.--Gen. Kaulbars, the Russian military agent, has been ordered by his Government to abandon his proposed journey to Roumelia.

BALTIMORE Oct. 14.--The Baltimore Manufacturers' Record, in its quarterly review of the South's industrial growth, to be published to-morrow, says that "even the West, in the days of its greatest progress, probably never saw such tremendous strides of progress as some portions of the South are now making."
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 14.--In the trial of Peter Correicola, of Woodbridge, in the Middlesex courts to-day a story equal to any of Dickens's was told.

District Attorney Martine and his chief assistant, De Lancey Nicoll, had a comparatively easy day of it yesterday so far as boodledom was concerned. Only one Alderman, William H. Miller, had failed to secure $40,000 bail up to the time the office was closed for the day.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 14.--The hearing of the Carrie J. Welton will case was resumed in the Superior Court to-day. The testimony was principally corroborative of what had gone before to show that Miss Welton was of unsound mind.

Dissatisfaction with the results of some speculative enterprises engaged in by him under the tutelage of Mr. A.R. Hammond, who maintains what is termed a "bucket shop" at No. 51 New-street, has led Edward B. Ketchum, of No. 55 Broadway, to resort to litigation.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 14.--Miss Van Goon, a young girl at Knoxville, who had been betrayed by a prominent man, committed suiside with morphine to-day, her mother having driven her from home.
Capt. Baker on his last trip from Liverpool to New-Orleans met with an exciting experience. It was on the forenoon of Sept. 24 as his ship, the British steamer Red Sea, was off the Azores.
Gen. John Newton, Commissioner of Public Works, has transmitted to the Mayor his report of the transactions of the Department of Public Works for the quarter ending Sept. 30, 1886.

Elihu Root, John J. O'Brien, John D. Lawson, and Police Justices Smith and Patterson, composing the Ways and Means Committee of the Republican Executive Committee, met in the Lincoln Club yesterday ostensibly for the purpose of considering the condition of local politics.
BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 14.--Neither of the two races on to-day's programme at Mystic Park was finished, four heats being run in each. Following are summaries:

BERLIN, Oct. 14.--An official statement issued to-day shows that the value of exports from Germany to America during the fiscal year ending in September was $20,000,000 more than for the preceding fiscal year.

The Universalist Club held its first meeting of the season last night at Clark's, in West Twenty-third-street. The Rev. Dr. W.S. Crowe presided, and among those present were the Rev. Dr. C.H. Eaton, S.A. Briggs, George H. Robinson, ...
LONDON, Oct. 14.--This was the fourth day of the Newmarket Second October meeting. The race for the Champion Stakes was won by the Duke of Westminster's 3-year-old b.c. Ormonde.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14.--The Collector of Customs at New-York informs the Treasury Department that steamship companies which obtain the privilege of allowing their cargoes to remain on the wharf for 48 hours pile the goods in masses upon the dock much to the detriment of the Government and the importers, and he ...
There is the usual story of the law's delay from the United States Supreme Court, which began its session on Monday last.
B. Altman Co. have now in stock for the Fall trade one of the most extended importations of French underclothing and garments for negligee wear ever received in this city.
