CHICAGO, Oct. 19.--N.M. Neeld, the defaulting manager of the packing firm of J.C. Ferguson Co., was formally expelled from membership on the Board of Trade by the Directors at their regular meeting to-day, and an election to fill the place in the Directory left vacant by the absconder was ordered for next Tuesday.
AMSTERDAM, N.Y., Oct. 19.--At the convention of Montgomery County Republicans held at Fonda this afternoon the Hon. Thomas Liddle, of Amsterdam, was renominated for member of Assembly.

The committee appointed by property owners to see what could be done to prevent the building of a boiler house by the New-York Steam Heating Company at Madison-avenue and Fifty-eighth-street met at the Madison Avenue Hotel last evening.

DUNSVEITH, Dakota, Oct. 19.--A terrible fire has been raging for the last 10 days in the mountains and on the prairies. Careful estimates place the amount of prairie and timber land burned at 192,000 acres.

The fight over the possession of the boy Ludlow Valentine, who was taken from his grandmother, Mrs. Schoonmaker, by Judge Bartlett, of Brooklyn, and placed in the care of Dr. M.Y. Young, a Professor in the Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute, was renewed yesterday by Mrs. Valentine.

A very clever game was played yesterday on the Staten Island cricket ground at Livingston between a team of the home club and a mixed team from New-York and its vicinity. The St. George's, Kings County, Manhattan, and Riverside were represented against Staten Island, and won on the score of the first inning by 14 runs.

PARIS, Oct. 19.--M. de Freycinet, the Prime Minister, at the cabinet meeting held today to consider yesterday's defeat of the Government in the Chamber of Deputies, on the question of the Vierzon strike, explained that the adverse vote of the chamber affected the responsibility of the whole ministry.
PACIFIC, Mo., Oct. 19.--The Dephflander farm, near this city, was the scene last evening of a deplorable tragedy.

LEWISTOWN, Penn., Oct. 19.--Mr. Blaine and party left Harrisburg this morning at 8 o'clock and reached here at 10, an hour before the people expected them, but there was a crowd of several thousand gathered in front of the Court House in the public square.

Reserved seats for the six concerts of the Brooklyn Philharmonic Society will be sold at auction to the subscribers at 8 o'clock to-morrow evening in the hall of the Art Association, adjoining the Academy of Music, Brooklyn.

Three months ago Jacob Thomas was arrested in Jersey City, charged with complicity in the murder of Patrick Cronin two years ago on Barren Island. Thomas was taken to Brooklyn, indicted for manslaughter, and lodged in Raymond-Street Jail.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Oct. 19.--Since Sept. 1, 1885, 26 vessels belonging to the Gloucester district fleet, aggregating 1,761,000 tons, valued at $164,000, and insured for $118,460, have been lost. The lives of 104 men have been lost, leaving 22 widows and 50 fatherless children.

Post, Executrix of John Earl, respondent, vs. William B. Dinsmore, President of Adams Express Company, appellant; judgment affirmed, with costs.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 19.--The eleventh annual convention of the Mutual Benefit Life Associations of America held its first session at 10:30 o'clock to-day at the Lindell Hotel.

BOSTON, Oct. 19.--The third annual meeting of the New-England Meteorological Society was held in the Institute of Technology here today, when questions concerning rainfalls formed the chief element of discussion.

BOSTON, Oct. 19.--Another poisoning case has come to light, but several of the parties supposed to be connected with the crime have disappeared. Abram Lamb, for many years had been a grocer on Harrison-avenue and a well known ward politician. Last week, Tuesday, his wife gave birth to a male child, which was somewhat deformed, but was apparently healthy.

SOUTH NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 19.--Patrick McGowen, a laborer living in Hawleyville, but employed in Danbury, was run over by the New-England train last evening while on his way home, and seriously injured. One of his legs was so badly mangled that amputation was necessary. McGowen is 25 years old and unmarried. His recovery is doubtful.
BERLIN, Oct. 19.--The Boerse to-day showed increased strength. Russian and other international stocks were per cent. higher, and rubles improved to 193.90 and St. Petersburg exchange to 191.60.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 19.--At 7:30 o'clock this morning Mrs. Mary Haverkamp, wife of Herman Haverkamp, who keeps a shoe store at No. 3,341 Manchester road, ended her life and troubles by shooting herself through the head.

KEYPORT, N.J., Oct. 19.--The Democratic convention for the nomination of an Assemblyman for the Third Assembly District was held here to-day, and resulted in the nomination of William Pintard, of Shrewsbury Township.
SOFIA, Oct. 19.--Gadban Effendi's interview with the Bulgarian Ministers to-day disclosed the fact that a complete agreement has been arrived at between Turkey and Russia.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 19.--This afternoon William Kaufman, Phil Lutz, Frank Debo, Phil Zeffa, J.W. Peck, and William Crist attempted to cross the river from the foot of Miller-street in a small rowboat.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 19.--The annual "cane spree" between the Freshman and Sophomore Classes took place last night on the campus in front of Witherspoon Hall. The classes began to assemble at about 10 o'clock, and by 11:30 every one was on the grounds.

MONTREAL, Oct. 19.--A round robin is being signed by the members of the Quebec Legislature calling upon the Lieutenant Governor to authorize Mr. Mercier, the leader of the Liberal Party, to form a Government.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn,, Oct. 19.--Hundreds of people who are interested in the work of the American Missionary Association have been arriving in this city to-day to attend the annual meeting of the society.
CHICAGO, Oct. 19.--Prince Napoleon and party, of France, arrived in the city this afternoon from San Francisco. The party went to the Grand Pacific Hotel.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 19.--Patrick H. McCarron, who on Aug. 18 killed James Crosby by cutting his throat while shaving him, was today acquitted on the ground of insanity, but was remanded to await the appointment of a commission in lunacy.

The Commissioners of the Sinking Fund yesterday opened bids for $500,000 of registered dock bonds bearing interest at the rate of 3 per cent. per annum and payable Nov. 1, 1916.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19.--The war of rates that has been waged between the express companies since the Erie Express was established will, according to the representative of the Erie here, lead to a law suit.
BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 19.--The Democrats of the Twenty-sixth District to-day unanimously nominated Frank W. Downs, of Binghamton, for Congress.
Through the efforts of the Board of Finance $100,000 was paid into the Jersey City Treasury yesterday by the State on account of railroad taxes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19.--Minister Cox called on the President to-day and afterward had an interview with Secretary Bayard in regard to the Turkish mission. It is understood that the Minister is willing to return to Turkey to close up some diplomatic matters left unsettled at his departure if Mr. Bayard thinks it necessary. Otherwise he will resign and again enter political life.

BUFFALO, Oct. 19.--The familiar faces of the counsel, chief witnesses, members of the Bar, and other spectators who have been in attendance at the previous sessions of the Tracy will controversy were seen again at the City Hall this morning, where, at 10 o'clock, the proceedings were resumed.

ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, Oct. 19.--The surveying schooner Annie was lost on Sunday night on the reefs near Ireland Harbor, Bona vista Bay. All on board were saved except one man named Ligresly, a servant of Mr. Mutche, the mining explorer.

MILLEN, Ga., Oct. 19.--Last night at Ederfield Broggs's turpentine still Sam Simmons shot and instantly killed Charlie Johnson. Johnson was quietly passing the night in a shanty. About 10 o'clock Simmons approached the shanty, and with one heave with a young pine tree burst the door open, and as Johnson made an effort to get out of bed Simmons fired, killing him instantly. Simmons then robbed Johnson's body of $25, and fled.
BOSTON, Oct. 19.--Parson Downs is not quite ready yet to have the cases against him tried.

NYACK, Oct, 19.--The long-continued drought has assumed a serious form in some parts of Rockland County, and farmers particularly are complaining deeply of the lack of water.

The troubles of the First Reformed Church of Brooklyn, which was recently sold to a cyclorama company for $250,000, were the chief subject of discussion at the semi-annual meeting of the South Classis of Long Island, which took place yesterday in the Reformed Church on New-Jersey-avenue, Brooklyn.

CATTSKILL, Oct. 18.--The brazen attempt of certain miserable Connecticut persons to steal the sea serpent from our midst and transfer him to Long Island Sound, in the demoralizing vicinity of Norwalk, has excited deep indignation ...

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19.--About three weeks ago $3,897, the savings of a lifetime, was stolen from Charles Caughlin, of No. 1,240 North Twenty-sixth-street. Mr. Caughlin, who is over 70 years old, and his wife, wife's brother, who is also very old, and a hired man, are the only occupants of the house.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Oct. 19.--One of the leading lights among the colored Knights of Labor in Augusta approached the President of one of the largest cotton mills this forenoon and asked him about putting negroes to work in the mills.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19.--Second Controller Maynard and Third Auditor Williams have just concluded a critical re-examination of the accounts of the Signal Service from Sept. 1, 1880, to July 1, 1886.

A practical result of the French invasion of Anam has just come to hand in the shape of a mass of gold and silver treasure captured at Hue.
NOGALES, Arizona Territory, Oct. 19.--A revolution in Mexico of no mean proportions is considered by many who are in a position to know the facts as imminent.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20.--A neatly dressed artilleryman named Martin, the sole white survivor of Custer's command, was among Gen. Sheridan's callers to-day. He is an applicant for a messenger's place in the War Department and, in view of his good record at the time of Custer's fatal engagement and since, Gen. Sheridan promised to further his application as far as it lay in his power to do so.
HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 20.--The Grand Jury in the Bartholomew case has been in session all day taking testimony.

A rumor was circulated yesterday that all the surface and elevated roads in the city would be tied up on election day and most of the shops and factories closed in order that the laboring men might show their power.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 20.--The fourteenth annual session of the National Association for the Advancement of Women began with a private meeting of the officers in this city at 9 o'clock this morning.

Henry George has written a letter to Mr. Hewitt in answer to the latter's letter declining to hold a discussion, in which he strongly intimates that Hewitt is afraid. Mr. George does not believe that the real issue is as laid down by Mr. Hewitt, and he claims that he can show to the contrary so conclusively, should Mr. Hewitt engage in debate with him, that the latter dare not risk the encounter.

On the morning of Tuesday, Oct. 20, 1880, Truth, a comparatively unknown journal then published in this city, printed in type a letter which it claimed had been written in January of that year by Gen. James A. Garfield to one Henry L. Morey, of Lynn, Mass., upon the subject of Chinese labor.
HOUSTON, Texas, Oct. 20.--The report of Special Master of the bankrupt savings bank has been considered by Judge Masters, of the District Court.
NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 20.--William E. Quintard was run over and killed last evening in attempting to jump from the Boston limited express that passes South Norwalk about 9:30.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20.--The following business was transacted in the Supreme Court of the United States to-day: No. 1028--The Continental Life Insurance Company of Hartford, Conn., plaintiff in error, vs. Thomas W. Pumphrey.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20.--A rumor was current to-day that Anarchists Spies and Parsons had attempted suicide in their cells. A reporter hurried to the jail, where he found both of the men alive and apparently happy.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Oct. 20.--The proposed settlement with ex-Gov. Hoadly of this liability upon the bond of the embezzling Assignee of Archbishop Purcell, was to-day authorized by Probate Judge Goebel.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20.--A.G. Angier, proprietor of the London-China Express, is at the Grand Pacific. He is just from Japan, and carries with him to England semi-official information to the effect that the treaty revision between the various nations and Japan is now about consummated.

The first block of electric cable went under ground on Sixth-avenue yesterday, between Thirty-seventh and Thirty-eighth streets. It was a Waring Six-wire cable made for the fire alarm service, each wire being separately sheathed in lead and the whole cable being insulated with lead.

LONDON, Oct. 20.--The Steamship Kovno, (Br.,) Capt. Neill, sld. from Stettin for New-York to-day. The steamship Kate, (Br.,) Capt. Durkee, from Savannah Sept. 29, arr. at Liverpool today.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 20.--In the Court at Appeals to-day the following business was transacted: No. 950--The People, respondent, vs. Charles A. Buddensiek, appellant.--Argued by William F. Howe for appellant,...

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 20.--The Hon. P.C. Lounsbury, Republican candidate for Governor, was given a reception to-night at the Republican League Clubhouse.

With an unbroken record of victories this season the Yale College football team yesterday made its first appearance on the St. George Ground, Hoboken, since last year, to play the annual match with Stevens Institute.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20.--G.A. Mason, an expert accountant, who has been studying the books of A.S. Gage Co., and William Oliver, the firm's bookkeeper, were to-day examined by some of the creditors of the firm.

The big statue of Liberty held its giant arm skyward yesterday while a number of workmen, who looked like mosquitoes settled on the statue's neck, adjusted the torch in the enormous hand. Other workmen labored at the base of the figure, looking absurdly small as their heads were seen reaching hardly higher than the hem of the majestic statue's robe.
READING, Penn., Oct. 20.--The Municipal Convention, composed of representatives from cities of the third, fourth, and fifth classes of this State, has assembled in this city for the purpose...
LONDON, Oct. 20.--The Most Rev. Thomas Nulty, Roman Catholic Bishop of Meath, preached a powerful sermon in Dublin Sunday against moonlighters.
The Hon. Theodore Roosevelt had a most enthusiastic reception by the Republican Club at its clubhouse, in West Twenty-eighth-street, last evening.

Dr. Philip E. Donlin, who was elected at a previous meeting of the Board of Aldermen to succeed Henry W. Jachns as Alderman from the Fifth Assembly District, resigned at yesterday's meeting of the board and William Von Blaricom was chosen in his place.

MONTPELIER, Vt., Oct. 20.--The election of supreme Court Judges took place in joint assembly of the Legislature this afternoon. The greatest interest centred in the election of a Chief Justice to succeed Chief-Justice Homer E. Royce.

A meeting of the Executive Committee of the Independent Labor Party was held last evening at No. 139 Fourth-avenue, and it was voted to hold a County Convention at Clarendon Hall to-morrow evening, at which a county and city ticket will be nominated in opposition to Henry George, whose candidature was vigorously denounced at the meeting on account of his Social istic and free trade opinions.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 20.--At a quiet meeting of Directors of the Hocking Valley Railway, held here, J.H. Wade resigned, and J. Lee Humphreville, of New-York, was elected a Director and then chosen Second vice-President.

The friends of Edward J. Kerr, Mayor of Hoboken, who claim that he is the regular Democratic candidate for Congress in the Hudson County district, held a mass meeting on Tuesday night. Only about 50 persons attended.

MONTPELIER, Vt., Oct. 20.--At noon today the two houses of the Legislature met in joint assembly and proceeded to cast a formal vote for United States Senator to succeed Senator Edmunds. In the informal ballot which was cast in each house yesterday the vote stood...

CHICAGO, Ill., Oct. 20.--Dr. Chalmers M. C. Prentice, of Norwalk, Ohio, was arrested Oct. 12 on a train of the Lake Shore and Michigan Southern Railway when it arrived at South Chicago, charged with disorderly conduct.
RONDOUT, N.Y., Oct. 20.--The Republicans of the Second Assembly District of Ulster County nominated Willett Vandemark, of the town of Rosendale, for member of Assembly in Rondout this afternoon.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Oct. 20.--Exchange --Sight drafts on New-York yesterday 17 ; telegraphic, 25.

SANDUSKY, Ohio. Oct. 20.--Emmet Fowler, aged 14, was instantly killed near his home at Berlin Heights, this county, to-day, by the bursting of an overloaded shotgun, the entire right side of his head being blown off.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 20.--Louis Webster was twice sentenced to death for the murder of Perry Harrington at Montva, but on the third trial was acquitted.

Coroner Mitchell, of Yonkers, held an inquest yesterday over the bodies of John Skahill, Charles Zedek, and James Martin, who were killed the previous afternoon at Shaft No. 16 of the new Croton aqueduct by an explosion at the dynamite cartridge house.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 20.--A contractor who had secured the contract for building a large lake vessel the coming Winter, and who had leased one of the local ship yards for the purpose, hired 30 ship carpenters in Maine whom he knew to be skilled men.

The long convention of the Knights of Labor at Richmond came to a close yesterday. Owing to the exclusion of reporters and the nominal secrecy of the proceedings it has been a very difficult matter to obtain...

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 20.--The tariff demonstration to-day in honor of James G. Blaine was not as large as was anticipated, but the city was filled with strangers who had been attracted by the announcement that both Mr. Blaine and Gen. Beaver would speak.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 20.--The trial of John Patterson, which began here today, marks the beginning of the end of a remarkable career of crime. Patterson is the son of Ezekiel Patterson, one of the wealthiest citizens of this place, and the nephew of ex-Judge Patterson, who owns a large part of the town of Perth Amboy.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 20.--Some time ago the most prominent merchants of St. Louis decided to determine whether or not there were evidences of natural gas in this vicinity, with the end in view of forming a company to supply the manufactories in this city with that kind of fuel.

A well dressed stranger walked into S. W. McKenzie's office, at No. 202 Broadway, sev eral weeks ago, and said he wanted to hypothecate his month's salary, amounting to $60. He said he was George Lutterlein, an employe of Lorillard's tobacco factory, in Jersey City.

The Fall opening of Lord Taylor's store at Grand and Chrystie streets attracted a large number of visitors yesterday. Two large floral pieces, representing the statue of Liberty and the steamship Anchoria were much admired.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 20.--The Central Labor Union of Rochester yesterday declared a boycott on beer from Miller's brewery. the brewery was burned to the ground some time ago, and difficulty arose over the employment of non-union men in rebuilding. A bitter fight is anticipated.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 20.--W.F. Norton, Sr., the banker, died this morning at 9 o'clock at his residence, No. 517 Fourth-street, aged 67. His death resulted from chronic Bright's disease.

WASHINGTON, Oct.20.--Civil Service Commissioners Oberly and Lyman have decided that hereafter the examinations of applicants, whether for appointment or promotion, shall be carried on under the supervision of the Civil Service Commissioners at Washington, and not be left to the discretion of the local Board of Examiners.

The Pastor of the First Baptist Church at Hackensack, N.J., announced on Sunday that in a vision he had been told by God that a certain brother, prominent in the church, had never been converted, that he would die within six months, and unless converted would go to hell.

SOFIA, Oct. 20.--Gadban Effendi, the Turkish representative, has informed the Bulgarian Ministry that he has been instructed to act in concert with Gen. Kaulbars, the Russian agent, whose arrival at Sofia, Gadban Effendi says, he will await before making for Turkey definite proposals to Bulgaria, strongly advising the Ministry, however, in the meantime to concede...

CHICAGO, Oct. 20.--Packingtown in the stock yards is once more resuming its wonted appearance. While out of the large number who quit but 3,500 wore at work to-day, those out of work are no longer called strikers, except about 1,500 coopers, who still refuse to return under the 10-hour system.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 20.--Larry Donovan, the bridge jumper, is going back to NewYork. He applied for permission to jump the Genesee Falls and was refused by the mayor. He says he will join a circus and so a high jumping act.
TROY, N.Y., Oct. 20.--This morning Michael W. Byron was employed with other men in repairing the roof of Fitzgerald Brothers' brewery.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 20.--At 10 o'clock this morning the argument of Counselor Parsons in the Tracy will case was continued. "If," said he, "you accept the idea that Mr. Tracy was not influenced by delusion, then you an only believe him a man of most malignant purpose.
A peddler of diamonds dropped into the Produce Exchange yesterday. Business has lately been so dull there that most members were inclined to twist the visit into a bit of practical sarcasm.
The members of the Produce Exchange will vote to-day upon the question of making Bartholdi day a holiday.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 20.--At to-day's meeting of the Ohio Grand Lodge of Masons S. Hacker Williams, of Newark, was elected for the third time Grand Master, and J.D. Caldwell, of Cincinnati, was elected Grand secretary for the thirty-seventh time.

TAHLEQUAH, Indian Territory, Oct 20.-- Sheriff Saunders, of Coowescoowee District, Cherokee Nation, who rounded up 1,200 head of cattle near the Kansas line in the vicinity of Coffeyville that were trespassing on lands belonging to non-citizens, reported to the department...
There is one lady on the registry lists of Brooklyn. She is Mrs. Emma Beck, living at No. 310 Adams-street, in the Fourth Ward. She registered at the Fifth District polling place.

The Bedford Farmers' Club met yesterday at Mount Kisco at the house of James Wood, who was nominated last Saturday by the Republicans of the Fourteenth Congressional District to reduce Congressman Stahlnecker's last year's majority of 2,300 in this year's Congressional race.

ALBANY, Oct. 20.--Bank Superintendent Willis S. Paine has granted authority to the Richmond County Savings Bank of the town of Castleton to open an office for the deposit of savings, subject to the provisions of the State banking laws.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 20.--The Rev. Dr. William C. Roberts, a graduate of Princeton, Class of '55 and a Trustee of the College of NewJersey since 1866, has accepted the Presidency of Lake Forest University, near chicago.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20.--It does not seem to make any difference to Second Controller Maynard that the House Committee on Expenditures in the War Department last Winter regarded Gen. Hazen's irregularities more leniently than he did. In a "memorandum" covering several large pages he had noted his suspension of accounts of the Signal Service Office amounting to more than $1,000,000.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 20.--Suit was brought to-day in the Common Pleas Court by the Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton Railroad Company against Thomas and J.J. Emery to enjoin the levying of further executions upon the plaintiff company's cars found in the State of New-York.
MANCHESTER, Oct. 20.--The Guardian, in its commercial article, says: "Although business is nowhere really active, many departments have been moderately busy.

OTTAWA, Oct. 20.--Prof. Low, of the Geological Survey, returned to-day from an exploratory trip to Hudson's Bay. He left Ottawa on May 10, and started on his journey overland from Winnipeg. A great portion of the distance was accomplished in bark canoes steered by Indian guides.

Assembly and Aldermanic Conventions were held by Republicans and Democrats in all of the city Assembly districts last evening. In 19 districts the Republicans adjourned without reaching a nomination for either Assemblyman or Alderman.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 20.--Dr. C.R. Montgomery, late physician at the penitentiary, arrived from St. Louis and surrendered to the authorities to-day, a warrant for his arrest for complicity in the tally-sheet forgeries having been issued.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20.--The following communication, touching the disposition of Ge ronimo and his fellow-captives, was this after noon addressed to Lieut.-Gen. Sheridan by the Secretary of War:

BOSTON, Oct. 20.--Lawyer James A.L. Whittier, who as Trustee of the estate of Miss Harriet D. Reed, managed to dissipate the bulk of her generous fortune, was this afternoon sentenced to State prison for four years and three months, at hard labor, with one day's solitary confinement.
The fourth annual contest for the crosscountry championship of America, under the management of the New-York Athletic Club, will take place on election day.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Oct. 20.--The Northwestern Miller says: "Notwithstanding the fact that the operation of the mills was seriously interfered with by the switchmen's strike, a very respectable amount of flour was turned out last week.

ASHEVILLE. N.C., Oct. 20.--A wreck occurred on the Asheville and Spartanburg Railroad at 8 o'clook this morning four miles out from this city.

Ex-Alderman Francis McCabe, who was committed without bail on Monday last and locked up in Ludlow-Street Jail,is to be arraigned for trial before Justice Cowing in the Court of General Sessions this morning.
ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 20.--The biggest sale of the season in the lumber market occurred today. Three million feet of better grades were sold for export to New-York firms.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20.--Minister Cox had a second interview with Secretary Bayard this morning and indicated a desire to be relieved of his duties as United States Minister to Turkey.

The ink used to complete the probate of Samuel J. Tilden's will, at White Plains, yesterday was hardly dry when notice was served upon the Executor's attorneys that George H. Tilden intended to bring suit in the Supreme Court of this courts against "the Executors, Trustees, and all the legatees under the will."
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 20.--The Republican Congressional Convention for the Thirtieth District met this morning and unanimously renominated Charles S. Baker on the first ballot.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 20.--The Grand Lodge of Kentucky, F. and A.M., resumed its session at the Mason's Temple this morning.

LONDON, Oct. 20.--Gen. Lord Wolsely, Adjutant-General, has issued a circular to the English Army intimating that the Duck of Cambridge, Commander-in-Chief, is dissatisfied over the small progress made in their military training.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20.--The report of the Commission of Post Office Inspectors assigned to the duty of making an examination of the Post Office at Philadelphia was made public this afternoon. PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 20.--A telegram was received from Cresson to-day, stating that Andrew Carnegie had been ordered to keep his bed for few days.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 20.--Notwithstanding the unanimity of the office holding physicians in declaring that the present sickness at Biloxi is the genuine yellow fever, the private physicians having the cases in charge assert to the contrary. Dr. Gerardin, who has treated 14 cases and lost none, pronounces the disease malarial fever.

The sermon delivered by the Bishop of Meath last Sunday in Dublin may or may not have the effect of closing the breach which a year or two ago was visibly widening between the religious traditions and the political aspirations of the Irish people.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 20.--The little son of W.J. Duval, of Argenta, who was bitten by a mad puppy some three weeks ago, died today. His sufferings were terrible. The little girl that was bitten at the same time has as yet shown no symptoms of hydrophobia. Much alarm is felt, as several children in the city have been bitten by rabid dogs.

BERLIN, Oct. 20.--The German East African Company is to be converted into a corporation. Dr. William C.H.Peters is to be elected President for a term of 15 years, and the company's capital is to be at the start 3,800,000 marks.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 20.--There was a large attendance and a fast track for the races to-day. Following were the events:

Mrs. Mary B. Wheaton was arraigned before Justice White, in the Tombs Police Court, yesterday, on a charge of having conspired to murder the infant son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Lamb. of No. 4 Decatur-street, Boston.

The Italian colony dwelling in "Little Italy," the territory extending from One Hundred and Tenth to One Hundred and Twelfth street and from First to Second avenues, was greatly excited yesterday over the filling of Antonio Cignarale, a stonemason, by his wife,...
Miss Yates, a granddaughter of ex-Judge Rosworth and daughter of the late Charles Yates, was married to Mr. Guert Gansevoort Jackson yesterday in the Calvary Episcopal Church.

The political bosses who say that they expect to elect Abram S. Hewitt Mayor of the city were busily engaged yesterday in trying to refute injurious statements made in reference to their candidate's antipathy to butchers and foreign-born citizens.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 20.--The Commandery-in-chief of the Military Order of the Loyal Legion held its annual encampment in the hall of the Pennsylvania Historical Society today.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Oct. 20.--The Grand Jury of Monmouth County brought in 67 indictments to-day, which were handed down to the Court of Quarter Sessions for charge and trial. No indictments were found against the bookmakers or the proprietors of the Monmouth Park race course. It is rumored that indictments were found against some of the Long Branch gamblers.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 20.--E.H. Grecley, a nephew of the late Horace Greeley, died today. A fortnight ago he fell in a barn and broke his back, paralyzing his lower limbs. The flesh finally began shaving off, and his last days were full of extreme suffering. To his widow and daughter he leaves a fine property.

BORDENTOWN, N.J., Oct. 20.--While walking from Georgetown to Bordentown last evening to attend a show, William, Shinn, a respectable young farmer, was shot in the thigh by some person lying in ambush. The bullet made an ugly wound. Shinn thinks he was mistaken for another person.
Miss Effie Ellsler is filling a profitable engagement at the Theatre Comique, in Harlem, in "Woman Against Woman."
We are indebted to the Evening Post for the publication, without charge, of a valuable standing advertisement of THE TIMES.

PHILADELPHI, Oct.20.--About 175 Superintendents and other representatives of gas companies in the United States and Canada are in attendance at the forteenth annual meeting of the American Gaslight Association which convened in the Academy of Music this morning.

The City Convention of Brooklyn Republicans, which was adjourned on Saturday, after City Judge Reynolds had been nominated, reconvened last night, and completed the city ticket by making these nominations: For Controller-- Police Justice Charles Naeher; for City Auditor --Richard H. Poillon.
ELIMIRA, N.Y., Oct. 20.--The Presbyterian Synod of New-York began the work of its session this morning.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20.--After religious services this forenoon the General Convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church listened to a report from the Committee on Canons, recommending concurrence in that portion of the message from the House of Bishops which authorized...
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 20.--Max Edelmuth, the cigar manufacturer and dealer at No. 332 West Jefferson-street, made an assignment this morning to Sol Isenberg for the benefit of his creditors.
NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 20.--The boys of the training squadron were treated to a substantial dinner to-day by Paymaster Simpson.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 20.--So many delegates are here attending the annual meeting of the American Missionary Association, and so many New-Haven people are interested in the society's doings, that both the Centre and United churches have been opened for the meetings.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 20.--The Yale Athletic Association held a very successful Fall meeting this afternoon at the Athletic Field. In spite of a sharp wind which swept down the track two Yale records were broken.

The meeting of the Country Club at Pelham will begin to-day. Special interest is centred about the pony race, in which Buckshot, the fastest pony ever bred in this country, is to come in competition with A. Belmont, Jr.'s, imported pony Spinster, who is reputed to be very fast.
RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 20.--Such a blast of melody as could be produced by no other body terminated the proceedings of the tenth annual General Assembly of the Knights of Labor.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 20.--The second day of the races of the Maryland Jockey Club, at Pimlico, was quite as successful as the first. The weather was fine, and though there was some delay in getting the horses off in some of the races, the result was entirely satisfactory to the large throng in attendance.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 20.--The most brilliant of the Autumn weddings occurred at St. Peter's Episcopal Church at noon to-day, when Mr. Charles L. Pruyn, son of the late Robert H. Pruyn, was married to Miss Sarah Gibson Talcott, youngest daughter of Gen. S.V. Talcott.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20.--Col. J.N.C. Whistler, Fifteenth Infantry, has been placed on the retired list and ordered home. First Lieut. Rufus P.Brown, Fourth Infantry, having completed his duty in this city, has been ordered to Columbus Barracks.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 21.--The Republicans held their Congressional conventions today. In the Second District the present incumbent, Major W.A. Pirce, the "war horse" of the party, whose present seat is being contested by Charles A. Page, his Democratic opponent, was overwhelmingly defeated by Nathan F. Dixon, the son of a distinguished Rhode Islander of the ...

The Sun and the Evening Post, unmindful of recent acerbities, work merrily together for the Hewitt and Slevin ticket. The Post no longer trains its deadly parallel column upon the Sun, and every megalomaniac paragraph upon the Sun's standing galleys is marked "Waits for orders."

CHICAGO, Oct. 21.--The creditors of A.S. Gage Co. held another meeting to-day, at which George H. Hovey, for 10 years confidential secretary of the firm, was examined. Hovey admitted that since Jan. 1, 1883, but one inventory showing a profit had been taken.

TROY, N.Y., Oct. 21.--The committee appointed by the Democratic Assembly Convention of the Second District of Rensselaer County to find a candidate met to-day and nominated M.V.B. Peters, of Hoosic Falls, for the Assembly. Mr. Peters has accepted the nomination. A workingmen's convention will meet on Saturday and will indorse the nomination.

CRESSON, Penn., Oct. 21.--Andrew Carnegie, who is lying ill at Cresson, passed a very comfortable day, and all the symptoms of his illness appear at present favorable. His physician from New-York sees no ground for present apprehension, though his illness will probably be a tedious one.

Two Deputy Collectors were suspended yesterday by Collector Magone, and S. Ascher, of No. 48 Pine-street, had his privileges as a Custom House broker taken away for participation in their irregularity. The case in which the broker was involved came to light through Deputy Collector C.O. Rockwell.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 21.--Jay Gould, who is on a tour of inspection of his railroad lines in the Southwest, arrived this forenoon from St. Louis. At 3 o'clock he appeared on 'Change, where he was formally introduced by Judge R. J. Morgan.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21.--Miss Minnie Roesch, daughter of Frank Roesch, a prominent north side German, living at No.194 North State-street, was to have been married at 7 o'olock this evening to Julius Lefer, manager for Schmidt Laves, wholesale liquor dealers. The wedding supper was spread and the invited guests arrived, but Lefer did not appear.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 21.--The races today were largely attended and the track was in very fine condition. The favorites were defeated in three out of the four races. Following were the events:

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21.--The annual session of the military order of the Loyal Legion was concluded to-day with the ceremony of installing Lieut.-Gen. Philip H. Sheridan in the office of Commander-in-Chief of the order.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 21.--Clarkson, after pitching against the Browns yesterday in Chicago, at tempted to do so against them in St. Louis this afternoon in the fourth game of the world's championpionship series, but he met with little success.

LANCASTER, Penn., Oct. 21.--Though pleuro-pneumonia was supposed to have been stamped out in this county the disease is reported among a herd of 18 cattle, the property of a farmer named Heiss, on Thomas Ambler's farm, near McCall's Ferry. One of the animals died a few weeks ago and another yesterday. State Veterinary Surgeon Bridge, of Philadelphia, will visit the herd to-morrow.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 21.--The Democrats of the Thirtieth Congressional District to-day nominated Theodore Bacon. He is one of the most prominent attorneys of Rochester, and has always been a Republican, but joined the independents in 1884 and supported Cleveland. His nomination was unanimous on the first ballot. He is said to have been selected by the Hon. George Raines, the local Democratic leader.

Looks of hatred were exchanged by Cecilia Ressler and her husband, Charles H. Ressler, as they sat in the presence of Judge Barrett in the Supreme Court, Special Term, yesterday. Mrs. Ressler is a dark, vivacious little woman, with big black eyes. She is a teacher of music and languages.

DUBLIN, Oct. 21.--United Ireland states that Gen. Buller declines the appeals of Sheriff's for police protection while engaged in the work of eviction until he has personally inquired into the nature and justice of the case. The paper urges tenants to organize and by combined action resist the collection of rents.

Boss Croker, of Tammany Hall, and Boss Power, of the County Democracy, yesterday managed to obtain the signatures of a few of the Tammany men to a statement certifying that said Tammany men did not hear Abram S. Hewitt decline to consider "Nooney, the butcher," as a candidate for the Presidency of the Board of Aldermen on the "Bosses' ticket."
ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, Oct. 21.--The British schooner Phillip, Capt. Taylor, has towed into Catalina the wrecked schooner Annie, which was found derelict. There is no account of her crew.

When Theodore Thomas brought Felix Bour from France, about a year ago, to play the oboe in his orchestra, the Musical Union, to which he and all his other players belonged, objected to Bour's presence. He was not a member of the union, and its members were forbidden to play with non-members.
GALVESTON, Texas, Oct. 21.--President Cleveland has sent $100 to the sufferers at Sabine Pass, Texas, as the following correspondence shows:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21.--It is to-day learned that the District Attorney of Arizona recently represented to the Attorney-General that sufficient evidence was obtainable to convict Geronimo and his braves of murder before a civil tribunal, and that in view of that fact Gov. Zulick, of Arizona, had requested the President ...

The new convent and chapel at Madisonavenue and East Eighty-first-street, adjoining the St. Joseph's Industrial Home, has been completed, and the consecration of the elaborately constructed white marble altar was performed Wednesday evening and yesterday morning by Archbishop Corrigan, assisted by numerous priests.

The Ladies' Suffrage Committee held a private session last night at No. 61 West Fifteenth-street, with a large attendance. Their organization was made permanent, and instructed to work vigorously and spread their ideas on the subject of women voting.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21.--Frank J. Bradley, who, as manager of the Pullman Works at Pullman, found a chance to steal at least $500, and who has been in custody at the Palmer House for a week, was to-day railroaded through two courts, induced to plead guilty, and sentenced to five years' imprisonment, and before sunset was labeled as prisoner No. 7,893 in the Joliet Penitentiary.

Thoroughly convinced, as is every one else who has taken the pains to inform himself of the condition of affairs, that Theodore Roosevelt will in all probability be the next Mayor of NewYork, a hundred or more young business men met at No. 47 Broadway yesterday afternoon and took measures to form a down-town business men's Roosevelt campaign club.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 21.--Elbridge T. Gerry, of New-York, was the principal witness in the Carrie J. Welton will case, in the Superior Court, to-day. He testified that in 1878 he drew up a will at Miss Welton's request in which she left the bulk of her property to the Society for ...

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21.--President Cleveland has made his first visit to the State of Virginia, has listened to the shrill cheers of thousands of her sons, who gathered to greet him along the road to Richmond and at the State Fair Grounds, has grasped the hands of many of the toiling sons and fair daughters of the old Commonwealth, and has come back to ...

One of the recently arrived steamships brought two New-York ladies home from Europe who are well known in New-York society, one of whom has figured in a rather remarkable experience since she sailed away with her friends last Spring to enjoy excursions in Great Britain and on the Continent.

Ex-Senator Thomas F. Grady received the independent nomination for Congress in the Eighth Congressional District last evening, and he will oppose Congressman Timothy J. Campbell, who has the united Democratic nomination. Ever since the rosy-cheeked orator from the Fourth District shook the dust of the Senate Chamber from his feet he has been aching to re-enter the political arena.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Oct. 21.--Senator John Sherman arrived here about noon to-day and was met by a committee of 100 leading Republicans. There was no formal reception at the railway station and the Senator was driven immediately to the residence of ...

CHICAGO, Oct. 21.--The National Council of the Evangelical Lutheran Church began its sessions to-day. The Council is held in the Trinity English Lutheran Church, on La Salle-avenue. The introductory sermon was preached by the Rev. A. Spaeth D.D., of Philadelphia. The discourse was of a historical nature, touching on the life of Luther and the establishment of the church.

MOBILE, Ala., Oct. 21.--Yesterday afternoon William C. Carrell, a well known young business man, drove down the Shell road, accompanied by his sister, and paid a visit to Mrs. Barry and her daughter, Mrs. Lee Fordney.

When the Liars' Club assembled for its last weekly meeting every one noticed that Prof. Snodgrass, the worthy Secretary, wore a disturbed appearance. He glanced about the room nervously, as if looking for some avenue of escape. There was perspiration on his brow and he mopped it off occasionally with his red silk handkerchief.

The annual tournament of the New-York University Lawn Tennis Club was commenced yesterday on the lower tennis courts in Central Park. A large number of students and friends were present. The first round of singles were finished. The doubles will be played to-day and the finals to-morrow. The following is the result of yesterday's play:
PITTSBURG, Oct. 21.--Preliminary steps have been taken by the window glass manufacturers to establish a national syndicate, the object being to advance and maintain prices.
LONDON, Oct. 21.--Lord Randolph Churchill has arrived in London. He is stronger and stouter than he was before he started on his Continental Trip.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Oct. 21.--Drafts on New-York, sight, 17 cents; telegraphic, 25 cents.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21.--The American Gaslight Association began its second day's work this morning. The first paper read was by N.H. Deninston, Superintendent of the East End Gas Company, of Pittsburg, entitled, "Some Further Remarks on Natural Gas."

ALBANY, Oct. 21.--There was an extraordinary gathering of lawyers in the Court of Appeals to-day to argue the case of the NewYork Cable Railway Company. The Hon. W.M. Evarts, who made his first public appearance since the runaway accident at his Vermont farm last Summer; Robert Sewell, Everett P. Wheeler, and Charles P. Shaw appeared for the Cable ...

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 21.--The Patterson trial is developing a family skeleton that is viewed with astonished eyes by the people who attend court. The lawyer defending the wayward son, John, is making the defense that he was driven from home by family quarreling, his sister being not only an agnostic but John's bitter enemy.

Signor Pietro Saltini, an Italian artist who is well known in Florence, is at present in this city on a brief visit, and is staying at the house of Mr. W.J. Ehrich, No. 306 Next Fiftyeighth-street. Signor Saltini has 10 pictures in this country. They are scattered about in Philadelphia, Chicago, Milwaukee, Colorado Springs, and this city. They are all figure works, to which Signor Saltini devotes himself.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 21.--The National Association for the Advancement of Women held its second session to-day. This morning at 10 o'clock a private executive meeting was held, with a good attendance of ladies present. "Industrial Education," a paper by Dr. Anna French, was a full and exhaustive report on this branch of education as taught in this and foreign countries.

Nominating conventions were held last evening by Republicans and Democrats in various Congressional and Assembly districts. The Republicans of the Thirteenth Congressional District unanimously nominated Ashbel P. Fitch for Congress.
A young man named Pelletier, of St. Leon, in the county of Maskinonge, while attempting to lift a heavy weight on Saturday, burst a blood vessel and died immediately.

Two or three days after the bitter contest in this city between the cigarmakers and District Assembly No. 49, Knights of Labor, ended in a victory for the former, Mr. POWDERLY caused to be published a long statement concerning the order over which he presided, in the course of which he said: ...

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 21.--This morning was the beginning of the end in the Tracy will controversy. Mr. Rogers resumed his summing up of the proponent's side of the case, taking up the thread of his argument at the point where he had broken off the day previous--the description of the physical characteristics of Mr. Tracy.

ST. PETERSBURG, Oct. 21.--The Czar has summoned Gen. Gourkho, military commander of Warsaw, to proceed to the imperial palace at Gatschina to receive instructions preparatory to replacing Gen. Kaulbars as Russian military agent in Bulgaria.

MONTREAL, Oct., 21.--Judge Desnoyers, the Government counsel, and several detectives have gone to Three Rivers to make investigations, on behalf of the Government, into the brutal assault made on the Hon. Mr. Mathist on the eve of the elections.

There is blood on the face of the moon which shines on the colored Republicans of the Seventh Assembly District. The McKeever Brothers, who have a saloon at Sixth-avenue and Fourteenth-street, have refused, so the colored men say, to dispense liquors or cigars to would-be customers of their race.

LONDON, Oct. 22.--Rumors are current that a terrible state of confusion and alarm exists in the Czar's household owing to hallucinations of imaginary dangers to which the Czar is subject. It is said that on seeing an Adjutant walking rapidly toward him recently, the Czar seized a revolver and shot the Adjutant dead. Other accounts say that the Adjutant made an attempt to kill the Czar, and the latter fired in self-defense.

A syndicate, of which C.R. Cummings, President of the Union National Bank of Chicago; Calvin S. Brice and F.P. Olcott, of this city; James McMillan, of Detroit; Norman B. Ream, of Chicago; President Samuel Thomas, of the East Tennessee, Virginia and Georgia Railroad; George I. Seney, and A.D. Juilliard ...

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21.--"For the first time since the opening of the campaign," said Chairman Hensel at the rooms of the Democratic State Committee this evening, "I feel that the State is entirely safe, and from this time on our ticket will grow in strength, and nothing can prevent its election.

DENISON, Texas, Oct. 21.--News has just reached here of the killing of John Ingram, alias John Ward, in the Cherokee Nation. Ingram had been living with his uncle near Tahlequah. He was wanted in Charleston, Swain County, N.C., for the cold blooded murder of Samuel Welch about a year ago, and $500 reward was offered for his capture.

BERLIN, Oct. 21.--Emperor William arrived here to-day. He was received at the railway station by the Governor of the city, the Chief of Police, and other officials. He rested for two hours, and afterward gave audience to Gen. Bronsart von Schellendorf, the Imperial Secretary for War, and Count Herbert Bismarck, Imperial Secretary for Foreign Affairs.

The French wheat growers, depressed by a poor crop and by the low price at which imported wheat that has paid a duty can be sold in their markets, have caused the Government to introduce a bill raising the duty on foreign wheat from 3f. to 5f., and they now ask that the Government shall declare urgency for this bill.

HEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 21.--There were not so many delegates at the meeting of the American Missionary Association at the Center Church this morning as on the previous days, but the church was well filled, New-Haveners taking the absentees' places.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Oct. 21.--Mr. James G. Blaine in his speech at Pittsburg yesterday referred to Chattanooga as a point in the South where colored laborers are paid 60 and 70 cents a day. The Daily Times, commenting on this speech, says: "Careful investigation here ...

CHICAGO, Oct. 21.--When the Convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church was called to order this forenoon President Dix submitted two communications from the National Council of the Congregational Church, recently in session, in this city, one relating to Mormonism, and the other to the subject of family and divorce.

SLATINGTON, Penn., Oct. 21.--While David Evans, aged 50 years, and his son William, 14, of Millport, Carbon County, employed at the Sterling Slate Quarry, near here, were crossing a tunnel this morning it caved in, carrying them down 100 feet and burying them under a mountain of earth. It will take months to recover their bodies.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Oct. 21.--The times are surely out of joint. A correspondent writing from Cheraw, Chesterfield County, says that for several weeks past a number of trustworthy persons in that place have discovered that at certain hours of the day, between 9 and 1 o'clock, rain has fallen from a perfectly cloudless sky.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21.--The following business was transacted in the Supreme Court of the United States today: No. 239--The New-York Mutual Gaslight Company, plaintiff in error, vs. Albert G. Thorp.--In error to the Circuit Court for the Southern District of New-York.--On motion of C.W. Homer, in behalf of counsel, dismissed per stipulation.

PANAMA, Oct. 21, via Galveston, Texas.-- In consequence of bail being refused for Conductor Noye, who has been imprisoned for shooting a man on a train on Sunday last, the conductors and engineers employed on the Panama Railroad have gone on strike. Affairs look very serious, and all transit across the isthmus has been stopped.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21.--The revenues so far this month have averaged over $1,000,000 a day and are now about $12,000,000 in excess of the expenditures during the same period. The financial situation is regarded at the Treasury Department as favorable for another call for 3 per cent. bonds, and it is probable that one will be issued in a few days.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 21.--A committee of the Louisville and Nashville switchmen from the yards of both the main stem and Louisville, Cincinnati and Lexington Division presented to General Manager Harahan this morning a request for an increase in pay.

BLOOMINGTON, Ill., Oct. 21.--Coffman Brothers, breeders of hogs at Danvers, have made an assignment for the benefit of their creditors. They schedule their assets at $13,600 and their liabilities at $13,015.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 21.--A special reports that a mob of masked men in Pickens County went to the jail, overpowered the jailer, took out three negroes charged with arson, and hanged them to the limb of a neighboring tree.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 21.--The residents of North Haven to-day celebrated the centennial of the town's incorporation. Bells were rung and a salute fired at sunrise, and during the day there was a procession. Speeches were made by ex-Gov. Bigelow and Mayor Holcomb, of New-Haven, and the Rev. W.T. Reynolds, of North Haven made a historical address.

Commissioners Taintor, Olwell, Ulrich, and Brunn, of the Ward's Island Board of the Emigration Commission, continued yesterday afternoon at the island the investigation of the charges that dead immigrants had been indecently mutilated by the house staff. Commissioner Stephenson acted as prosecutor. Dr. Wheelock, of the Board of Consulting Physicians, was present.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21.--The looked-for meeting of the Central Traffic Association began here yesterday. Every road in the association was represented. The Chicago and Atlantic, which, although not a member, was invited to be present, failed to accept the invitation, and the inference is that it intends to maintain its independent position.

AUGUSTA, Me., Oct. 21.--The Law Court has given a unanimous decision in the Soldiers' Home beer case, holding that beer intended for sale upon the grounds of the National Soldiers' Home is not liable to seizure by the State officers while in transit through the State.

BOSTON, Oct. 21.--Early this evening Henry H. Fowle, a bookkeeper for Frenyear Razee, Washington-street dealers in electric supplies, attempted to commit suicide by shooting. He had completed his work for the day and stepped into a washroom and in a few minutes three shots in quick succession were heard.

The consideration of the estimates of the heads of the various city departments for the expenses of the city government during 1887, was begun yesterday by the Board of Estimate and Apportionment. The estimates of the Corporation Counsel's office were first taken up. Mr. Lacombe asked for $188,560, an increase of $17,560 over the amount allowed last year.

Mrs. Fithian, wife of the late Judge Fithian, of the Superior Court, appeared before Surrogate Rollins yesterday with her counsel, Lawyer Secor, to compel Mrs. L.B. Clark, widow of L.B. Clark, who was Executor of the Fithian estate, to give an accounting of the property of her late husband.
LONDON, Oct. 20.--The steamship Mississippi, (Br.,) Capt. Hunter, sld. from Avonmouth for Montreal yesterday. Arr. 21, Village Belle.

For some time past ex-Senator John C. Jacobs has been seen a good deal in the neighborhood of Fifth-first-street and Fifth-avenue, and his friends have wondered what it was all about. It was explained by the publication of this notice yesterday:

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 21.--The Grand Jury in the Bartholomew and Plunkett cases returned to court at noon to-day having failed to find sufficient evidence to indict Bartholomew for forgery. This result was anticipated.

SHERMAN, Texas, Oct. 21.--About 3 o'clock this morning the Binkley House, one of the best known hotels in the Southwest, was destroyed by fire. The fire was the work of incendiaries, as it was discovered simultaneously in the second and third stories.

Samuel S. Cox last night accepted the united Democratic nomination for Congress from the Ninth District. Committees from the Tammany Hall, County Democracy, and GermanAmerican independent organizations tendered the nomination on behalf of their respective organizations, and each had a pleasant word to say of the unanimity of the nomination and the sure prospect of election.

We published yesterday some statements of opinion made by Mr. A.S. HEWITT in 1880, and printed in the Brooklyn Eagle of Nov. 26 of that year. They relate to a subject of urgent interest at the present time, one, in fact, which Mr. HEWITT himself regards as of supreme and exclusive importance in the pending canvass for the office of Mayor of the city of New-York.

The spectator on the simple grand stand at Bartow-on-Sound yesterday afternoon during the Pelham steeplechases, under the auspices of the Country Club, could easily have imagined himself in the big back yard of the estate of some British landed proprietor.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 21.--After a light rain in the forenoon the third day of the Fall meeting of the Maryland Jockey Club was even a greater success than the two preceding days. The track was in perfect condition, and the only incident to mar the pleasure of those present was the failure of the Vestal Stakes, for which the Dwyer Brothers' filly Millie had a walk-over. Following were the events:

Mr. Joseph Murphy, who is this week filling a very successful engagement at the Third-Avenue Theatre, was seen there last night in "Shaun Rhue," a drama by Mr. Frederick Marsden, which is scarcely less popular with Mr. Murphy's admirers than "The Kerry Gow." The theatre was crowded with a sympathetic audience, and there were tears in abundance for the pathos, and laughter, hearty and long continued, for the humor of the play.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 21.--The cornerstone of the new temple of the Hebrew congregation Aushe Chesed was laid here to-day with impressive ceremonies, made the more memorable because, in addition to the simple Jewish services, consisting of addresses by two Rabbis and one layman, the Ohio Grand Lodge of Masons laid the cornerstone with the ancient rites of the order.
Theodore Roosevelt as Mayor of NewYork would be worth several hundred thousand dollars a year to that overtaxed city.

LOWELL, Mass., Oct. 21.--Col. J.M.G. Parker, a very wealthy resident of this city, and a brother-in-law of Gen. B.F. Butler, is missing. For several years he has been subject to temporary fits of insanity, although at no time has he been violent.

The advance guard of the homewardbound TIMES expedition to Alaska, in the person of William Libbey, Jr., Professor of Physical Geography in Princeton College, and scientist of the party, arrived in New-York on Monday morning, and, after a few hours passed in his father's home in Fort Washington, left the city for his own home in New-Jersey.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Oct. 21.--The Presbyterian Synod of New-York, in session to-day, adopted a new plan for sustaining weak churches within the State. The work was formerly carried on by the Home Mission Board. The New-England States were exempted from the action of the plan, by the provisions of which New-York is divided into two districts ...

The union of Russia and Turkey on a Balkan policy, several times rumored of late, and as often regarded with a skepticism akin to that of a reported coalition between oil and water, seems to have been, in part at least, effected.

LONDON, Oct. 21.--At Sandown Park today the Great Sapling Plate of 1,000 for 2-yearolds, the second to receive 50 out of the plate, was won by a head by Lord Hastings's ch.f. Mirage, by Speculum, out of Euonyma, J. Hammond's b.c. Aintree, by Sefton, out of Electric, and Capt. C. Bowling's bay colt by Speculum, out of Baroness, ran a dead heat for second place. There were five starters.

The members of the Xavier Union received the Rectors of the Catholic churches of the city at their clubhouse, No. 20 West Twenty-seventhstreet, last evening. The guests were welcomed by the Moderator, the Rev. Patrick F. Dealy, S.J., Mr. J.F. Mosher, the President, and other officers of the union.

At 11 o'clock yesterday morning the machinery of justice in the Court of General Sessions, Part I., City Judge Rufus B. Cowing presiding, was ready to make short work of exAlderman Francis McCabe, indicted upon a charge of receiving a bribe of $20,000 for his vote in favor of the Broadway Surface Railroad franchise.

VALPARAISO, Oct. 21.--Sarah Bernhardt made her first appearance here in the play of "Fedora" on Tuesday night. The theatre was crowded and the actress scored a complete triumph. The receipts amounted to $6,984.

With the experience gained Wednesday in drawing the six-wire cable through the subway conduit running from Thirty-seventh to Thirty-eighth street Superintendent J. Elliot Smith, of the fire alarm telegraph, and a corps of a dozen assistants, resumed work yesterday morning with a feeling of confidence.
MACON, Ga., Oct. 21.--The Macon and Athens Railroad Company began work yesterday on their proposed extension to Florida, starting in 10 miles below Perry, Ga., with 15 laborers.

LAREDO, Texas, Oct. 21.--There is imminent danger here of a repetition of the disastrous political riot of last April. Party feeling among the Mexicans is now at fever heat, and some trifling incident or insult may again set the Botas to killing the Guaraches.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 21.--A fire occurred at the Ohio Penitentiary at an early hour this morning. It began in the northern portion of the inclosure in the middle row of shops. The fire had its origin in the shop of the Columbus Wheel and Bending Company, owned by Eberly, Killiam Co., most of the firm being residents of Pennsylvania.

Henry George spoke yesterday afternoon from the steps of the Sub-Treasury Building before what was called the Journalists' Henry George Campaign Club. As a matter of fact there were hardly a dozen journalists present, including those who were on hand to report what was done.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 21.--The inspection party of Pennsylvania Directors and officials arrived here late this afternoon from Alliance, having come from Chicago over the Fort Wayne. The examination here was limited to half an hour's drive among freight houses and docks, after which the gentlemen resumed their ...
FORT LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Oct. 21.--The order of Gen. Miles announcing to his troops the close of the Indian campaign in Arizona has just been made public, and is an interesting document.

The acceptance by the Mount Vernon Trustees of the water works built by the NewYork and Mount Vernon Water Company does not give satisfaction, and all but one of the practicing physicians of the place have sent a communication to the State Board of Health stating that it is their belief that the water furnished by this company is dangerous to health ...

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21.--Leave of absence for two months has been granted Lieut.-Col. William E. Merrill, Corps of Engineers. On account of sickness the leave already granted Major Warren Webster has been further extended one year. Leave of absence for one month and 15 days has been granted Second Lieut. Hiram M. Chittenden, Corps of Engineers.

At the Union League Club one of the largest and most enthusiastic meetings to take action on a political matter of late years was held last evening. Mr. Theodore Roosevelt's candidacy for Mayor was indorsed in the most enthusiastic manner, and practical effect was given to the resolutions adopted by the appointment of a committee of 150 gentlemen to take part in the active work of the campaign.

GODINAH, Ontario, Oct. 21.--The schooner E.W. Rathbun, with a cargo of coal, went ashore near this place during a heavy gale last night. The Captain and crew clung to the rigging until daylight, when they were rescued by a Government lifeboat. The vessel went to pieces shortly afterward.

CHICAGO, Ill., Oct. 21.--George Holland, Jr., who was clerk in the St. Nicholas Hotel, New-York, up to Sept. 29 last, was arrested yesterday on a charge of embezzling about $300 from J.A. Robinson, proprietor of that hotel. He will be taken to New-York to-day.
BOSTON, Oct. 21.--In the United States Circuit Court to-day the Grand Jury reported four additional indictments against Richmond J. Lane, the defaulting President of the Abington National Bank.

Richmond County Republicans met yesterday in Tynan's Hall, Stapleton, Staten Island. John L. Dailey, a real estate broker, of No. 36 Pine-street, who lives at Tottenville, was nominated for the Assembly by acclamation. Judge Lott C. Alston, of Port Richmond, was nominated for District Attorney, and W.W. Corbitt, of West Brighton, for Judge of Sessions. Drs. A.G. Martindale, of Northfield, and T.J. Thompson, of Westfield, were named for Coroners.

ERIE, Penn., Oct. 21.--William Kryer, a carpenter, was instantly killed to-day while at work with a gang of men on the new Jarecki foundry building. Kryer and his men were holding up a truss, which fell, killing him and injuring John Schmell so badly that he will die. Three other men escaped with slight injuries.

James Wood, the Republican nominee for member of Congress in the Fourteenth Congressional District, opened his campaign last evening at Yonkers, the home of his Democratic opponent, William G. Stahlnecker. There was a mass meeting in Getty-square, attended by at least 2,000 persons, who stood in the cool atmosphere and listened to the speakers intently.

"We haven't had campaign headquarters that looked so much like business in this county since ex-President Arthur was Chairman of the County Committee and carried things with a rush," said an enthusiastic Republican as he watched the crowds pouring in and out of Mr. Roosevelt's headquarters in the Fifth-Avenue Hotel yesterday.

While preparations were making to test the 12-inch mortar at the ordnance station on Sandy Hook yesterday afternoon, a newly loaded shell exploded. Joseph King, a soldier, was literally blown to pieces, and Lieut. William M. Medcalfe was so frightfully mangled that he died soon after.
BOMBAY, Oct. 21.--Gen. Sir Frederick S. Roberts, Commander-in-Chief of the British forces in India, will succeed the late Gen. Sir H. T. Macpherson as commander of the army of occupation in Burmah.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 21.--In view of the fact that the training ships are under orders to sail for New-York to-morrow morning, the Custom House authorities collected to-day the sums due for duties on the articles purchased in foreign ports by the officers.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 22.--The latest reports from the arctic are to the effect that the whaling fleet had captured 86 whales to Sept. 26. The catch was about evenly divided between the San Francisco and New-Bedford fleets.

Col. A. Mordecai said yesterday that no military investigation into the circumstances which caused the death of Private Joseph King and Lieut. William M. Medcalfe at Sandy Hook on Thursday afternoon would be held. Coroner Van Woert, of Long Branch, who was called ...

The old wigwam trembled violently last evening; in fact, all of the big and little chiefs in it shook as though with the ague, and their red feathers became ghostly white over the candidacy of Henry George for Mayor. The spectacle was enough to make John Kelly turn over ...
VICKSBURG, Miss., Oct. 22.--The body of Dr. A.B. Sloan, who committed suicide near Greenville, Washington County, this State, on Monday night, reached Leota, his home, yesterday.
Congressional, Assembly, or Aldermanic nominations were made in a number of districts last evening. The selections were as follows:

FARMINGTON, Me., Oct. 23.--A great fire has raged here since 8 o'clock in the evening. At this hour, (1:50 A.M.,) the fire is sweeping down Main-street, and will probably consume everything on the west side of the street to Abbott Hill.
READING, Penn., Oct. 22.--The Municipal Convention, which adjourned to-day, agreed to ask the Legislature that there be no classification of property for purposes of taxation, and that there ...

CHICAGO, Oct. 22.--Henry Sewall, a solicitor of London, England, is at the Hotel Richelieu, having just returned from Mexico, where he has been examining into the management of the North Mexico Silver Mine, ...

MATAWAN, N.J., Oct. 22.--The people of this town are in great need of water, no rain having fallen for nearly two months. Almost every cistern and well in the town is dry, and the only way water can be procured is by bringing it from a distance in barrels. The country was never in such a dry condition as it now is, and rain is prayed for.
CHICAGO, Oct. 22.--Meetings of the St. Louis and Peoria committees of the Central Traffic Association were held to-day at the Commissioner's office.

PARIS, Oct. 9.--A reproach is frequently made to the French for their chilly reserve toward strangers, and often with a certain degree of justice. The travelers who sojourn in Paris a certain number of weeks, those who live abroad, now here, now ...

DETROIT, Oct. 22.--A singular turn in local politics has just developed. The fact has come to the surface that the Republican candidate for Sheriff, more than 20 years ago, served a term in Auburn State Prison for horse stealing.
Albert Polhemus, Jr., the partner of Jeremiah T. Story in the livery stable business at No. 106 Division-avenue, Brooklyn, left town last Saturday, and has not been seen by his friends since.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22.--The largest labor demonstration that has ever been witnessed in this city will take place to-morrow night in connection with the return of the Philadelphia delegates to the Richmond convention.
John H. Marr was in the Tombs a short time ago, charged with keeping a disorderly house. To him went Frank Whittaker, of No. 49 Delancey-street, who told him that for $100 he...

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 22.--Dr. W.E. Cyhert, of De Kalb County, who was convicted yesterday in the United States Circuit Court of collecting unlawful fees from a pensioner, was convicted to-day of forging the names of magistrates to pension claims.
NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 22.--Dominico Milchiondo, an Italian, who has during his year's residence in this city made for himself a reputation for general lawlessness, is a prisoner at the County Jail.

OTTAWA, Oct. 23.--James Fell, Mayor of Victoria, is expected here to-morrow. He is undertaking the trip with a view of inducing the Government to commute the sentence of death passed on R.E. Sproule, the American citizen. He will present a petition signed by a majority of the citizens of Victoria, requesting that clemency be extended to the condemned man.

NASHVILLE, Mich., Oct. 23.--A young man named Vickers, living seven miles south of here, yesterday accidentally discharged his gun. The load went through the heart of Mrs. Effingham, his mother-in-law, killing her instantly.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 23.--Geronimo, Natchez, and 13 bucks and 17 squaws and papooses, heavily guarded by United States troops, passed through this city this afternoon. The bucks will be sent to Fort Pickens, Pensacola Bay, and the squaws and papooses to St. Augustine, Florida. There was a large crowd at the station and ferry landing anxious to get a look at the savage.

LANCASTER, Penn., Oct. 23.--State Veterinary Surgeon Bridge, of Philadelphia, came to Lancaster this morning and visited the farm of Thomas E. Ambler, at Bethesda, where the herd of a farmer named Hess was reported to be infected with pieuro-pneumonia. He found that two of the herd had died from this disease and two more were past recovery. These were killed and the remainder of the herd, 17 in number were inoculated and the herd quarantined.

The canvass of the bosses' candidate for Mayor of New-York goes blunderingly along. Scarcely a day passes without revealing some new phase of Mr. Hewitt's campaign, which goes to show how little his backers, Boss Croker and Boss Power, understand the temper of the people of the city.

A few weeks ago a public statement was made by Gen. Howard that an Iowa soldier was, during the war, imprisoned by order of Gen. Halleck for freeing slaves. The name of the soldier was not then given, but he has responded for himself. He was Dr. Ransom L. Harris, of Tabor, Fremont County, a Lieutenant of the First Kansas Colored Volunteers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23.--Second Lieut. O.M. Lissack, Fourth Artillery, has been granted six months' leave of absence on account of disability. Capt. J.K. Corson, Assistant Surgeon, has been granted leave for one month.
ST. THOMAS, Ontario, Oct. 23.--Clessold, who pleaded guilty to manufacturing and passing counterfeit coin, was to-day sentenced to 10 years' imprisonment in the penitentiary.

CHASE, Mich., Oct. 23.--Wednesday afternoon Wilson Cone's residence was burned. Mrs. Cone and her baby were in the house. The family dog ran into the building, caught the child in its teeth, and carried it out in safety.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 23.--Hunters have been having unusually good sport this year, and game birds are far more plenty than in former seasons. Quail, especially, are so thick that if they were not so hard to hit everybody who owns a gun could try the experiment of eating one a day for 30 days. Besides, the birds are tame beyond precedent.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Oct. 23.--Advices from Aspy Bay, Cape North, state that a fleet of American vessels has been in that vicinity for a week fishing with seines and hooks clear to the Cape, and getting from 14 to 34 barrels daily.

SOFIA, Oct. 23.--Gen. Kaulbars has demanded of the Bulgarian Government the postponement of the meeting of the Sobranje. The Government have refused to accede to his demand and have started for Tirnova to attend the sessions of the Sobranje.

GARDINER, Me., Oct. 23.--Although the shipment of ice from Maine is going on at pres ent, the season will soon be closed. It appears from a careful estimate that 200,000 tons will be carried over this season, of which Kennebee will have 40,000 tons; Penobscot, 10,000, and the coast, 150,000.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23.--John T. Mullen, the clerk of election in the First Precinet of the First Ward, who was drunk on registration day, was before Judge Prendergast this morning charged with contempt of court. The Judge sent him to the county jail for 50 days.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23.--George W. Symonds who yesterday morning shot James H. Bunn, while the latter was making an assault on Symonds's wife, was taken to-day from the Twenty-second District Station House to Moyamensing Prison, where he will be kept in custody until the physicians determine Bunn's condition.

The other day a gentleman ate a lobster salad. He died shortly afterward in great agony. At a subsequent investigation the lobster (which was tinned) was found "not guilty." But the report of the analyst is not likely to increase the demand for tinned goods.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23.--The electric light that has been maintained at Hell Gate by the Lighthouse Board has been ordered discontinued. The light is 250 feet high, on an iron skeleton tower, is of about 50,000 candle-power, and is placed there for the purpose of making artificial daylight, so that vessels going through can avoid the rocks.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 23.--Prince Komatsu, of Japan, and suite, who arrived here from Japan on Oct. 20, left for New-York to-day. The party will visit Salt Lake City, Denver, and Chicago en route.

One of the results of the cyclone of "blue envelopes" which have been so frequent on the railroad recently is that the position of conductor is not considered as desirable as formerly. About a year ago all the conductors on the Central Road were removed and new men put in their places.

MANASQUAN, N.J., Oct. 23.--Hubert W. Brown, son of the Rev. Dr. Frederick T. Brown, of this place, has just returned home from Mexico, where he has been for a number of years as a missionary, bringing with him a bride, who was also a missionary when the two became acquainted. RONDOUT, N.Y., Oct. 23.--A bold highway robbery occurred on Union-avenue here early this morning. George Bowers, a baker, heard cries of "Murder!" and "Help!" He ran out of his shop to the sidewalk and found a young man named Henry Miller, of South Rondout, lying in the gutter insensible.

BERLIN, Oct. 23.--Emperor William received M. Herbette, the new French Ambassador, in formal audience at 2 o'clock to-day. Count Herbert Bismarck was present. M. Herbette, being unable to speak German, read an address in French expressing a desire to take his stand on the ground of the common interests of both nations.

Gen. C.P. Stone and his adjutants in the Washington Building were busily employed yesterday in answering letters from applicants for positions in the land and sea parades, and in receiving the numerous people who thought that they were entitled to tickets for the ceremonies ...

DANVILLE, Va., Oct. 23.--Late last night two white men, John C. Alderson and J.D. Ferguson, met at a store in Pittsylvania County, three miles from town, and renewed a quarrel which they had had during the day in the city. Ferguson shot and instantly killed Alderson. The murderer was arrested.

LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Oct. 23.--A horrible murder was committed here last night. Silas Laferty quarreled with his wife, and after knocking her down and beating her until she was unconscious poured half a gallon of coal oil over her clothing, set it on fire, and then left.

LONDON, Oct. 23.--Still uncertainty and apprehension reign in every capital of Europe. What with the see-sawing of correspondents, now running en masse toward the peace end of the plank, now rushing over each other to push the war end down, the general public has grown terribly weary of the long drawn-out crisis.

Those who are interested in the work of the Horticultural Society will be glad to know that the arrangements for the exhibition at Cosmopolitan Hall, at Broadway and Forty-first street, insure already the finest display of chrysanthemums ever seen in this country. There will no doubt be 1,000,000 flowers.

Stevens Institute and Lafayette College, of Pennsylvania, played a rather unsatisfactory football match on the Hoboken ground yesterday. In the first half of the game Lafayette scored a goal from the field by a kick of Camp's, scoring 5 points.

The Red Star steamship Waesland which sailed for Antwerp, Saturday afternoon,returned to port yesterday afternoon with her shaft out of order. Capt. Ueberweg reports that all went well until 8:30 o'clock Saturday evening when the Waesland was about 35 miles east of Sandy Hook.

HOUSTON, Texas, Oct. 24.--On Wednesday night last a young, wealthy, and highly connected Englishman named Albert Singleton, hailing from Manchester, England, attempted suicide by jumping into the bayou.
