Some 4,000 people witnessed the game played at Wallace's grounds, Ridgewood, yesterday, between the Metropolitans and the NewYorks. It resulted in a hard-earned victory for the Staten Islanders.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 24.--A passenger train on the Detroit, Grand Haven and Milwaukee Railroad, consisting of a baggage car, two coaches, and a sleeper, ran into an open switch at Royal Oak, about eight miles from here, late last night and collided with a heavily loaded freight train.
D.P. Wolff, whose experience with a would-be blackmailer was detailod in yesterday's TIMES, says he is not a gambler in any sense of the word.

BOSTON, Oct. 24.--The schooner J.P. Wallace, of Bristol, Capt. Bryant, from Damariscotta for this port with brick, struck on Devil's Back in Boston Harbor last night and sank. The crew climbed to the rigging and remained there until daylight this morning, when they were taken off by the crew of a fishing vessel and brought to this city.

The steamship La Bretagne, of the Compagnie Generale Transatlantique, arrived last evening from Havre. Among the passengers on board were the delegates sent to represent France at the celebration which on Thursday next will mark the completion of work on the Bartholdi statue of Liberty. SOFIA, Oct. 24.--The chiefs of the Sobranje have decided to send to the Czar a deputation, consisting of Slavikoff, Gueschoff, and Metropolitan Clement. They will be instructed to complain of the action of Gen. Kaulbars as Russian Agent in Bulgaria, and to ask the Czar to name a candidate for the Bulgarian throne. The Russian Consuls in Bulgaria have been ordered to refuse passports to the members of the proposed delegation.

The marriage of Mr. Samuel Hoar, son of Judge E. Rockwood Hoar, to Miss Helen Putnam Wadleigh, daughter of ex-Senator Bainbridge Wadleigh, of New-Hampshire, took place at the residence of Mr. and Mrs. W.B. Thomas, No. 285 Commonwealth-avenue, last evening.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 24.--The fifth game of the local championship series between the St. Louis League and American Association baseball teams to-day resulted in victory for the latter, the score being 6 to 5. This is the fifth successive defeat which the Maroons have suffered ...

PORTLAND, Me., Oct. 24.--Detectives Frue and Simpson, of this city, have arrested two men, Albert Teass, and Colby Moore, who have confessed to having blown up the office of Dr. C.C. Hall, in Monson, on the night of Aug. 27. They have also confessed to having started several fires.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24.--At a meeting of the Central Labor Union, held in the Anarchists' old headquarters, No.54 West Lake-street,this afternoon, a report was presented from a committee appointed last Sunday to have the speeches of the condemned Anarchists printed in book form.

Antonio Guisuald, an Italian 44 years old who kept a cobbler's shop in a shanty at No. 508 Second-street, Brooklyn, Eastern District, was arrested yesterday morning for enticing little girls into his place.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Oct. 24.--There has been absolutely nothing to disturb the quiet of Charleston since the earthquake shocks on Friday. The churches to-day have been filled with devout congregations, and the effect of the latest shakes is especially marked among the colored Christians.

The first premonition of coming Winter in Central Park was felt yesterday when it was announced that the big drove of elephants would start for their Winter quarters in Bridgeport, Conn., some time during the present week. The drove contains 13 animals of varying sizes. It is the property of P.T. Barnum and his partners ...

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24.--James H. Bunn, who had a big bullet shot into his leg on Friday morning last by George W. Symonds, was in an improved condition to-night. The surgeons say that it will not be necessary to amputate the injured leg. The bullet did not touch the bone, and the doctors believe that if sloughing of the wound can be prevented Bunn ...

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 24.--Eastern papers arrived to-day, containing a dispatch to the effect that Col. John M.G. Parker, of Lowell, Mass., a brother-in-law of Gen. Ben Butler, had become insane and disappeared from his home, and that it was generally thought he had made away with himself.

Henry Villard and his family were among the passengers on the North German steamship Saale, which arrived yesterday. Several friends were at the Hoboken pier to meet the ex-President of the Northern Pacific.

--Mr. Cable is said to be now busy with the compilation of a series of "True Stories of Louisiana," based on papers by the late Comtesse Francoise Bossier, a creole writer of whom Mr. Cable has an excellent opinion. These papers were found by a granddaughter of the lady among a mass of other writings. She has transferred them to Mr. Cable.

SANTA FE, New-Mexico, Oct. 19.--The statement made by Geronimo to Gen. Miles that the causes of his leaving the reservation were the tyranny and abuse of the officials in charge is generally believed by those who are acquainted with the system usually employed on these fiefs of the United States.

Mrs. Lucy A. Parsons, wife of the Chicago Anarchist, managed to create quite a sensation at Orange yesterday. She had determined to lecture in Central Hall, on Main-street, and there she lectured, although much against the will of the proprietor.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 24.--The bicycle races of the Camden wheelmen were run yesterday afternoon on their new track at Stockton Park in the presence of 1,000 spectators. The track, owing to the continued drought, was in poor condition, which accounts for the slow time made.

As Park Guard Thomas Wallace was pacing his beat on the east side of Harlem Lake at 1 o'clock yesterday morning He saw a man standing near a tree some distance away. He supposed the man to be some casual vagrant who had found the air of the Park too chilly for comfort. Wallace walked toward the man with the intention of warning him off the grounds.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 24.--Miss Sallie McGrath, a niece of the noted turfman, Price McGrath, was burned to death at Lexington, Ky., this morning. Her clothing caught fire from the grate, and before the flames could be extinguished she was horribly burned, and died after five hours of great suffering.

CORSICANA, Texas, Oct. 24.--Yesterday morning at about 3 o'clock William Smith, 28 years old, who came here from Virginia was run over by a freight train on the Houston and Texas Central Railroad, near Angus six miles south of here.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 24.--Jay Gould, after having made a thorough examination of his railroad property in the West, Southwest, and St. Louis, started to-night for New-York. He expresses himself as well satisfied with the condition of his roads and their terminal facilities excepting the latter in St. Louis.

Robert Todd is stage carpenter at Niblo's Garden. While he was passing along Thirtyninth-street Saturday night on his way home, and when near the Second Reformed Church, he was suddenly attacked by two or more footpads.

More ladies were driven over Jeromeavenue yesterday than on any other Sunday this year. The sharp air evidently tempted them out in search of a natural color, and perhaps the tempting little lunches at Judge Smith's and Gabe Case's offered an additional inducement.

ATLANTA, Oct. 24.--A large and brilliant meteor passed over Atlanta about midnight last night. Just before the darkness was more intense than at any other time during the night. About two minutes before 12 o'clock a brilliant, strong light appeared directly overhead.

NORTH ADAMS, Mass., Oct. 24.--James O'Brien, age 44 years, went into Welch Brothers' livery stable here this afternoon to hire a horse. While the animal was being harnessed O'Brien got into a dispute with Edward Potter, a stableman, both men evidently being some what intoxicated.

Leo Hartmann, who was charged with having planned and carried out the unsuccessful scheme to kill the Emperor Alexander II. of Russia, six years ago, by wrecking a railroad train in which he was expected to travel, was one of the last persons who were naturalized last week in time to vote at the approaching election.

The City Reform Club has done a useful work in compiling and publishing its "Record of Assemblymen and Senators of the City of NewYork in the Legislature of 1886." The record makes a bulky pamphlet of 72 pages, and by reference to it any voter can determine what kind of work was done at Albany by the representative of his district last Winter.

Peter J. Cahil keeps a saloon on Orchardstreet at Yonkers. Late Saturday night Timothy Sullivan and some friends entered tho place, and because Cahil refused them drinks, they started a row which ended in Cahil's putting the crowd out of the saloon.

MONTREAL, Oct. 24.--Four Cree chiefs, who have been taking a trip east at the expense of the Government, arrived here to-night in charge of Col. McDonald. Their names are Big Child, Star Blanket, Flying-in-the-Circle, and Back Fat.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 24.--The Dahlonega Signal is authority for the reported indictment of Judge James Brown, of the Blue Ridge Circuit, for removing blockade whisky. Judge Brown is a brother of Senator Brown.

Our London correspondent in his cable letter yesterday cited a curious instance of the scandalous mismanagement of the British Army. In this country the acceptance of 30,000 muskets, when a board of experts had reported against the arm on an examination of the first thousand, would unmistakably mean corruption. In England it may mean only stupidity.

Tennis will be extensively played by the Twenty-third Regiment this Winter in the armory in Brooklyn. The members are practicing diligently for the handicap (doubles) tournament to be held on election day.

PLYMOUTH, Wis., Oct. 24.--As people were going to church this morning they witnessed a most exciting and desperate struggle which Deputy Sheriff Gilman had with two notorious burglars, and in which several shots were fired. It is remarkable that none of the bystanders were injured.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24.--Charles Bradley, a boy whose skull was fractured yesterday afternoon at Roxborough by a stone thrown by John Lanagan, died at the Pennsylvania Hospital at 1 o'clock this morning. Bradley was 14 year old and his father being dead, he resided with his grandfather, William Bradley, of Roxborough.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 24.--Mrs. Sarah Jane Robinson, Dr. C.C. Beers, and Thomas R. Smith, the trio charged with poisoning William and Lizzie Robinson, in Somerville, have been indicted for murder by the Middlesex Grand Jury at Lowell.
PORTLAND, Me., Oct. 24--A dispatch received here to-night gives news of the total loss of the bark Dida E. Clark, of this port, in Matanzas Harbor. She was valued at $15,000, and insured for $4,000.

There is now a very great abundance of grapes in the market. It is the principal attraction in the fruit stores, and the supply is drawn from half around the world. It comes here from the Pacific slope and from along the shores of the Mediterranean.

BUFFALO, Oct. 24.--The Lehigh Valley Railroad seems to be making extensive preparations for a heavy Western trade, and if facilities will capture the business the Lehigh Valley will not be the last in the race.
The Staten Island Cricket Club has played its last match this season, which has been a most prosperous one. Although defeated by the English visitors the club has been very suc cessful.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 24.--About 7 o'clock to-night John McGowan, a baker by trade, in company with his wife and little boy 4 years old, called at the residence of Mrs. Eliza Lyons, No. 3 Fabius-street, and remained to supper.

GREENVILLE, Texas, Oct. 24.--A Brooklyn man was killed here yesterday. When the construction train, which is engaged in laying track on the Missouri Pacific from here to Dallas, was coming in from work, it ran over some spikes and bolts which had maliciously been placed on the track.

RED BANK, N.J., Oct. 24.--The elopement of Mrs. West and Mr. Rockwell yesterday was the sole topic of conversation to-day. Much sympathy is expressed with Mr. West and his family.

In a fight between Italians in a saloon atshaft No. 6 of the newaqueduct yesterday afternoon Louis Boradt was shot and killed by an unknown Italian, and Alberi Gromino was shot in the abdomen. The row occurred in a low groggery kept by Samuel Forefarrio.

At yesterday's meeting of the Central Labor Union a letter was received from George Blair, Prison Reform Commissioner, in reply to a report that had been made to the Central Labor Union to the effect that agents from the Sing Sing Prison laundry were in this city looking for new contracts.

Henry George walked down Broadway from Twenty-third-street yesterday afternoon to the Colonnade Hotel without attracting any special attention. It is doubtful whether many of the persons in that thoroughfare recognized him at all. Those who looked at him saw a quiet little man, with red beard and red hair.

VALPARAISO, Oct. 24, via Galveston Texas.--Sarah Bernhardt last night gave her third performance here. She was warmly received and gained much applause. To-night she appears in "Frou-Frou." It is reported that she will proceed to Iquique and Lima after visiting Talca.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 24.--The Republicans have nominated D.D. Leach, of Augusta, Ark., for Congress in the Second Congressional District. He will make the race against C.R. Breckinridge (Democrat) and Reuben Carllee, (Wheeler.)

CHICAGO, Oct. 24.--The list of entries in the Washington Park Club's 13 stakes for 1887 and 1888, which closed Oct. 15, will not be published until the end of the present week, and will show a decided falling off when compared with last year.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 24.--Two years ago Mr. J.P. Curran, of Charlestown, Mass., arrived in this city, and soon became a favorite with the ladies. Among others was Mrs. Louis Galvan, whose husband had recently died, leaving her a handsome fortune.

Mr. Roosevelt's campaign headquarters in the Fifth-Avenue Hotel were closed yesterday, and he and his Executive Committee had a needed day of rest from the hard labors of last week, and preparatory to a still livelier week's work to come.

Ryan, of the Rudolph, requested the steam barge Cleveland to sink his vessel, and the Cleveland crushed in the Rudolph's stern, causing the vessel to sink and driving the flames to the bow.

The blowing out of a cylinder head delayed the trains on the Third-avenue elevated railroad 40 minutes last night. The accident occurred at Seventy-sixth-street as the engine was about to start on its way down town. The trains going up town were stopped as soon as possible by telegraph, and passengers were notified at Chatham-square to take the Second-avenue line. The disabled engine was run down to Forty-second-street and switched off.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24.--William Holmgrau bookkeeper and cashier for Shourds, Storey Kasper, jewelers, is missing. It is reported today that his accounts are $10,000 short. Holmgrau had been with the firm eight years. He has not been seen since Tuesday. It is believed that he is in Canada.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 27.--A kangaroo rented from the New-York Central Park Museum escaped from a kangaroo show here tonight and jumped over the heads of a lot of boys and men who tried to catch him. A reward has been offered for his capture, and a body of men will hunt for him to-morrow.

VIENNA, Oct. 27.--The funeral of Count von Beust took place to-day. Archduke Charles Louis, representatives of the Emperor and royal family, Count von Taafe, Count Kalnoky, and a crowd of Ministers, Deputies, and distinguished persons filled the chamber in which the services were held. WASHINGTON, Oct. 27.--President Cleveland's suspension of two United States District Attorneys on one day and both for political ac tivity is the first official interpretation of his order of July 14 that he has furnished to office holders or the public.

BERLIN, Oct. 27.--Emperor William today received several military reports, worked three hours, received Count Herbert Bismarck at 4 o'clock, and gave a large dinner party at 5. The Emperor proposes to attend a hunt on Saturday at Hubertustock.

LYNCHBURG, Va., Oct. 27.--A fire at Pocahontas this morning destroyed 16 houes, including two hotels and several business houses, George Baber, of Lynchburg, perished in the flames. Waggaman, Eugene Kelly, and Michael Jenkins.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 27.--The Case School of Applied Science, founded by the late Leonard Case and endowed by him with property estimated to be worth $2,250,000, has been destroyed by a mysterious fire which broke out after midnight last night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27.--The President has undone the work he recently did when he revoked President Arthur's proclamation to carry out the reciprocal arrangement between Spain and the United States, by which vessels of both countries were to enjoy exemption from differentail duties.

The statue of Liberty yesterday was seen through a mist darkly. Piercing winds blew around Bedlow's Island, and the numerous workmen, who were not in any way protected from the weather, worked uncomfortably.

LONDON, Oct. 27.--The Standard announces that M. Waddington, French Ambassador at London, has made no demand respecting England's withdrawal from Egypt, and that he brought no instructions of such a character.

JOSEPH H. CHOATE hit the nail squarely on the head when he said in his Cooper Union speech last night that "HEWITT couldn't turn his back on his party and turn the rascals out."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27.--Two patents have been issued this week to Mr. Lucius J. Phelps, of New-York, on duplex telegraphy. Under these inventions it is claimed that the same wire used for telegraphing to or from trains may be worked "duplex," thereby enabling it to be used as an ordinary Morse wire between stations, and simultaneously used for telegraphing to and from moving trains.
ATLANTA, Oct. 27.--In the recent State election two amendments to the Constitution, provided for by acts of the Legislature, were submitted to a vote of the people.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 27.--Chief of Police Williams, of Chester, Penn., appeared before Gov. Harrison to-day with requisition papers for Domincio Milchrondo, the Italian held at the county jail on a charge of murdering Crampi Nuociante, another Italian, in Chester two years ago. The papers were found to be correct, and Milchrondo was delivered to Chief Will iams, who, with his prisoner, left New-Haven on an afternoon train.
CHICAGO, Oct. 27.--Ex-Judge Walter B. Scates died at his residence in Evanston, a suburb of Chicago, on Tuesday, of paralysis. Judge Scates was 78 years old.
The Grand Jury was discharged yesterday by Judge Cowing sitting in Part I. of the Court of General Sessions.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 27.--The dissatisfied Democratic conferrees of the Twenty-first-Congressional District met here to-day and nominated Dr. H.L. Donnelly, of Latrobe, Penn., in opposition to Gilbert T. Rafferty, the regular nominee of the party.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 27.--At the meeting of the Board of Trustees of Cornell University this morning there were present President Adams and the following Trustees: George W. Schuyler, William R. Humphrey, Amasa J. Parker.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 27.--A private letter received here to-day gives the particulars of an attempt upon the life of President Barillas, of Guatemala, who succeeded to the control of the Government upon the death in battle of Rufino Barrios a few years ago.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 27.--The Women's Board of Missions of the Interior began its eighteenth annual session in Plymouth Church today, Mrs. Moses Smith, of Detroit, presiding.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 27.--Lieut. John Sehon, of the United States Army, arrived in the city to-day from Dakota, the occasion of his coming being his approaching marriage with Miss Marie Allen, of Dickson Springs, Tenn.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 27.--The semiannual meeting of the American Oriental Society was held at the Yale Divinity School this afternoon, and was largely attended by members of the society.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27.--J.H. McVicker, the proprietor of McVicker's Theatre, has begun a suit against Wesley Sission, Clara Morris's manager, for $70,000 damages. As nearly as can be learned the suit is brought for alleged violation of contract, Mr. Sission having decided to take Miss Morris to the Chicago Opera House for her engagement, which begins next week, instead of to McVicker's Theatre.
LONDON, Oct. 27.--King Otto, of Bavaria, is suffering from violent attacks of insanity. The worst is expected.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 27.--Jacob J. Hart, of Rochester, was to-night nominated for the Assembly from the Second Monroe District by the Democrats. He is a prominent local politician and an ex-Alderman.

Buttz, Executor, , appellant, vs. the Northern Pacific Railway Company.--Argument continued by W.P. Clough for appellee, and concluded by Henry E. Davis for appellant. No. 19--The Consolidated Safety Valve Company, appellant, vs. Erastus B. Kunkle.--Argument begun by Thomas William Clark for appellant, and continued by J.H. Raymond for appellee.

McCaul, a maple sugar dealer, with a store in Hudson-street, this city, and a home in Brooklyn, applied to Judge Van Wyck in Brooklyn yesterday for the custody of his two children, aged 1 and 3 years respectively, who were unlawfully detained, he alleged, by their maternal grandparents, Mr and Mrs. Matthew Keenan, of No. 392 Myrtle-avenue.

OTTAWA, Oct. 27.--The fate of Robert Evan Sproule, the American prospector whose reprieve expires on Friday morning, still hangs in the balance.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 27.--John Guy Vassar has purchased all the well known College Hill property from the New-York Mutual Life Insurance Company for $26,000. It originally cost $100,000. It is not yet known what Mr. Vassar intends to do with the property, but he says that "whatever is done will be for the good of the public."
The local members of the State Committee of the National Greenback Labor Party met at the Gilsey House last night, and authorized Chairman George O. Jones to issue an address to the people.

MANCHESTER, Oct. 27.--The Guardian in its commercial article says: "The market is inactive. Only a few sellers yesterday made the average Tuesday's sales, although the general tone was firm. Producers, many of whom are under engagement, hold firmly to last week's best prices, and a few are asking a small advance.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27.--Capt. George B. Rodney, Fourth Artillery, has been transferred from Battery D to Light Battery F, and Capt. F.G. Smith from Light Battery F to Battery D.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 27.--Mr. B. Powel, son of John Hare Powel, Mayor of Newport, is to be married to Miss Whipple, eldest daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Whipple, formerly of NewYork. Miss Whipple is a granddaughter of the late Gov. Thomas Swann, of Maryland.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Oct. 27.--One hundred adult negroes, besides a large number of children, have started out on a pilgrimage to Liberia. For some time the Rev. R.A. Massay, a plausible colored preacher, has been preaching up Liberia in the two Carolinas, representing it as a land of milk and honey.

MONTREAL, Oct. 27.--The city was startled to-day by the death of Mrs. Fannie Ward, a wealthy widow, under very mysterious circumstances. It appears that Mrs. Ward had disposed of her property on the death of her husband, and gone with her daughter to live at the Turkish Bath Institute.

The Albany Argus, which has taken the lead in opposing a constitutional convention, favors the appointment of a commission to do the work of revising the Constitution, mainly on the ground that it will be less expensive.

The candidacy of Ashbel P. Fitch anainst Congressman Egbert L. Viele has assumed formidable proportions, especially in the Twentythird Assembly District. Non-partisan clubs have been organized with no other purpose than to aid his election.
LONDON, Oct. 27.--Garibaldi's youngest son has been baptized a Catholic through the persuasion of his schoolmates.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 27.--A rumor that the wholesale dry goods house of Shipley, Dorsey Co. was cramped, and had been compelled to ask for an extension of time from their creditors was the talk of the afternoon in business circles.

In the Harlem Police Court, yesterday morning, John McGrath was held without bail for further examination, on a charge of killing John McKegney, an old man, who lived at No. 139 East Eighty-eighth-street, in a saloon kept by Martin Godfrey, at Eighty-ninth-street and Third-avenue, on Monday night.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 27.--The attendance at the Baptist State Pastors' Conference was larger to-day than yesterday.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 27.--John Patterson, son of the millionaire, who was ac quitted this week of a charge of robbing and assaulting his sister, has been released, the prosecutor entering a nolle pros in the other cases against him.

The body of Robert H. Thompson, who flied in Paris on Sept. 22, will be buried from his father's house at No. 493 Third-street, Brooklyn, on Saturday. Mr. Thompson was 22 year's of age, and was the eldest son of Robert H. Thompson, a wealthy wall paper manufacturer.

CHADWICK, N.J., Oct. 27.--For the last 24 hours a severe northeast storm has raged along the whole length of the Jersey coast, and the life-saving men, who have had a comparatively easy time during the Fall, found it difficult last night to beat their way against the wind and the rain that fell in blinding sheets.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 27.--Private advice from Desare, Ark., states that the County Treasurer of Prairie County was robbed this morning between the hours of 12 and 2 of about $11,000. Active measures are being taken to capture the robbers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27.--There has sprung up within the last few months an unprecedented demand for minor coin in the form of five-cent and one-cent pieces, the stock of which up to the time this demand began was in the several United States depositories redundant.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Oct. 27.--The Northwestern Miller says: "Toward the close of the week most of the mills which had been idle on account of the switchmen's strike started up. Eighteen recorded outputs. some were not at work before Friday or Saturday.

KEYPORT, N.J., Oct. 27.--Mr. and Mrs. Garrett Stout, of this place, celebrated their golden wedding this evening. Over 200 relatives and friends were present, including many grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Mr. Stout is 76 years of age, and has never used glasses. His wife is 69, and hale and hearty. The presents received were numerous and handsome.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 27.--The people of Englishtown, Monmouth County, have organized a Vigilance Committee, and will prosecute some roughs who have been making life miserable to the town people. The roughs have instituted a reign of terror.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 27.--The corporation of Yale College held a meeting in this city to-day.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 27.--Although the Democrats have a majority of 1,200 the Republicans expect to carry the Third Assembly District of this county.

The independent voters of the Fourth Ward held an enthusiastic meeting last evening at No. 404 Pearl-street in support of Lewis S. Goebel for Register. Stirring speeches were made by James Lane, Daniel Dougherty, John Miller, and others.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 27.--Burglars attempted to enter the dwelling of Samuel Whitehead at South River last night.
The Fall reception of the New-York Press Club, in the Press Club Building, at 120 Nassaustreet, last evening, was a big thing.

SOFIA, Oct. 27.--M. Karaveloff refuses to go to Tirnova because of a fear of being insulted or assaulted. He argues that it is useless to convoke the Sobranje in the face of the Russian opposition. The Sobranje, he says, has no right to depose him from the Regency, and declares that if it does he will retire under protest.
Ex-Senator Grady continued his work yesterday to defeat "Tim" Campbell for Congressional honors in the Eight District.
Edward T. McLaughlin was nominated by the Democrats of the First District, Jersey City, for the Assembly on Tuesday night.

The Jackson Association, composed chiefly of cigarette makers formerly employed by Goodwin Co., whose factory is at the foot of Grandstreet, East River, held a mass meeting last evening at Pythagoras Hall, in Canal-street, to take action concerning the treatment they have received from the firm. Goodwin Co. put machines in their factory last December and discharged nearly all the cigarette hands.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 27.--Dr. Allan Hamilton, of New-York, testified to-day as an expert on insanity for the defense in the Welton will case. He declared that while Miss Welton may have been eccentric she was not, in his belief, insane. The hearing will be continued tomorrow.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 27.--George Liming, who shot George Lohue at Perth Amboy for betraying his wife, was sentenced to-day to pay $50 fine. One of the jurymen, who were obliged by the evidence to convict him, paid the fine.

Rain did not damp the Roosevelt boom yesterday apparently, for from early morning until late at night the headquarters in the FifthAvenue Hotel were thronged with the friends and workers of the energetic Republican candidate, who met many hundreds during the day, and received scores of letters containing assurances of support for him.

The General Missionary Conference of the Reformed Church of America, which has been in session in the Twelfth-Street Church, Brooklyn, for two days, adjourned yesterday. Several interesting addresses in regard to the work of the church in foreign lands were read by the Rev. D. Jacob West, Mrs. Edmund B. Horton, and the Rev. Dr. James Demarest, Jr.
Though the Empress of Austria is no longer allowed to take horse exercise, she is using her returning strength to make extensive pedestrian excursions in the neighborhood of Ischi.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 28.--A conference of Archbishops was hold to-day at the Cardinal's residence, and the subject under discussion was the attitude of the Catholic Church toward the Knights of Labor.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 28.--The bodies of Paul Kupler and Patrick Sweeney were found floating near the harbor to-day and brought ashore. Both men have been missing for some time. No suspicions of foul play are entertained.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 28.--The Freshmen ashletic sports at Harvard took place this afternoon in a drizzling rain, on Holmes Fields, before a fair number of spectators.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 28.--It was nearly 6:30 o'clock this evening when the Chicago "limited" arrived, direct from the wreck at Rio, Wis., brining most of the passengers who were saved. The first person to appear from the train was the venerable Bishop Whipple, accompanied by his wife.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 28.--John Glynn, of Sixteenth and Federal streets, Philadelphia, tonight identified the body of the man found drowned at Cape May yesterday as that of his father, Michael M. Glynn. The Coroner's jury rendered a verdict of accidental drowning.
Allan Thorndyke Rice, the nominee of the Tenth Congressional District Republicans, was indorsed by Irving Hall last night.
PARIS, Oct. 28.--The Customs Committee of the Chamber of Deputies have decided in favor of the bill raising the duty on foreign wheat from 3f. to 5f.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 28.--The boiler in the ginhouse on H.L. Fletcher's plantation, near this city, exploded this morning, blowing the engine house to atoms and killing Frank Waters and fatally wounding his wife.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 28.--Jacob Gawney, a totally blind mountaineer, was yesterday sentenced to imprisonment in the Albany (N.Y.) Penitentiary for one year, having been convicted by the United States Circuit Court of selling moonshine whisky.

Mr. Roosevelt had a zigzag route to travel last night to fulfill the campaign engagements made for him by the Republican County Committee. So he entered a hansom which was in waiting at the entrance to his headquarters in the Fifth-Avenue Hotel and directed the driver to hurry down to the Grand Opera House Hall, at Eighth-avenue and Twenty-third-street.

Happy were they who had the forethought to provide themselves with passes to Governor's Island yesterday. There were a good many such persons. They kept the little tug, which has a surprising carrying capacity when a crowd wants to ride, making half-hourly trips from noon until the guns of Castle Williams were belching forth the national salute.

ANSONIA, Conn., Oct. 28.--Joseph L. Hakes was called to his door about midnight last night and struck down by a man who was armed with a heavy club. Hakes's skull was fractured, and he received other serious wounds.

The friends of Theodore Bronson, whose death by shooting at Fairfield, Conn., on Wednesday morning was attributed to suicide in a published dispatch from that city, state that the occurrence was accidental.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 28.--There was a peculiar case before the Holston Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church South to-day. The Rev. J.F. Austin was on trial for baptizing the body of a dead woman. He claims that it was done at the request of the woman's relatives, but the Conference charges that he has some cranky notions on the subject. The matter was referred to a committee.

After 26 years of litigation the contest over the Jackson Hollow estates has been settled. Stephen Jackson owned 70 lots in Brooklyn, and allowed his taxes to remain unpaid, until finally the property was sold to meat the arrears.
The Irving Hall delegation of the Second Assembly District held a convention last evening at Peter Seaman's saloon, No. 116 Centrestreet, to tender to the Hon. "Jimmy" Oliver the Assembly nomination.

LONDON, Oct. 28.--The British steamer Borderer, Capt. Manley, from Boston, Oct. 16, for London, was in collision to-day with the Minerva in the Thames. The latter vessel sunk and seven persons were drowned. The Borderer was damaged.

READING, Penn., Oct. 28.--At Coffrode Saylor's iron works, Pottstown, this afternoon, while a gang of laborers, in charge of William Betz, foreman, were handling angle iron, a piece caught in the flywheel, striking Mr. Betz on the forehead and crushing his brains. He died in half an hour. Another of the gang was also injured.
CHICAGO, Oct. 28.--The owners of quarantined distillery cattle continued killing their healthy animals to-day under the inspection of the State Veterinarian.

HAZLETON, Penn., Oct. 28.--The Blaine party was sent off from Pottsville this morning in the rain. Mr. Blaine, after his three-hundredmile ride and eight speeches of yesterday, said he felt first rate and looked that way.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 28.--Drafts on NewYork--Sight, 20; telegraphic, 27 .

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28.--Secretary Manning will resume actual control of the Treasury Department to-morrow, and Mr. Fairchild will be relieved of his duties as Acting Secretary, which office he has held from the time Mr. Manning was taken sick up to date. Orders have been issued to have the Treasury mail to-morrow prepared for the signature of Mr. Manning.

NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 28.--The British steamship Willisden arrived here to-day for coal, having on board the Captain and crew of the schooner Charles A. Campbell, wrecked in the Gulf of Mexico. The wrecked schooner was bound from Ship's Island to Aspinwall with lumber, and when two days out was struck by a hurricane, which carried away the sails and threw the vessel on her beam end.

Congressman Timothy J. Campbell, since his return from Washington, has been carefully looking after his worm-eaten fences in the Eighth Congressional District, which, notwithstanding his plurality of indorsements, are sadly in need of repair.

Capt. Malet, of the steamship Buffalo, which arrived yesterday from Hull, reports that at 6:30 P.M. on Oct. 23, when in latitude 45 47' and longitude 47 25', he exchanged night signals with a Bremen Line steamship which was slowly proceeding eastward, apparently under sail only.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 28.--The children of the late Alfred Smith, Newport's real estate king, state that there is no will. It is estimated that each of the four children will receive between $900,000 and $1,000,000 as their part.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 28.--The 28 members of the City Republican Central Committee to-day found themselves defendants in a mandamus petition brought before the Supreme Court of the State by J.P. Vastein, one of the Republican...

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct. 28.--The large building known as the Salvation Army Barrack, which has been in litigation for some time past, has been purchased by James A. Bradley, the founder of Asbury Park. He is having it fitted up as a first-class opera house. Electric lights and other improvements will be introduced.

A very pretty youthful wedding took place at Maplegrove, the residence of Mr. Sheridan Shook, near Barrytown, yesterday afternoon. Miss Louise Weed Shook, his eldest daughter, a charming girl of 19, was united in the bonds of matrimony with Mr. Horace A. Hoffman, of Red Hook, who is just a year past his majority.
BELFAST, Oct. 28.--The Land Commission opened its session here to-day, Earl Cowper presiding.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28.--The convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church adjourned this afternoon. The Rev. CHICAGO, Oct. 28.--A special dispatch from Springfield, Ill., says: "United States Master in Chancery Bluford Wilson, under decree of the court, sold the Havana, Rantoul and Eastern Railway yesterday for $100,000, to satisfy the demands of the creditors.
When Catherine E. White died at Brooklyn in 1883 her heirs, Sarah A. Foster and Emma E. Jarvis, retained Lawyer Frederick K. Clark, of this city, to prevent a Mrs. Scarles from having it revoked.

For hours before the procession started the line of march was thronged with people. Early comers exercised the squatter claim privilege, and occupied all the available elevations. Some of them had remained at their posts since early morning.

The scene on Bedlow's Island was one of enthusiasm that would not be dampened by mist or rain. David H. Krig, Jr., had charge of all the arrangements on the island preparatory to the unveiling. He was assisted by a staff consisting of Bruce Price, E.F. Choate, Charles W. Clinton, G.R.A. Ricketts, Clarence Carey, W. Butler, Jr., and George A. Glaenzer.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 28.--Albert Netter, a broker representing unknown parties, defaulted to-day on the second payment of $60,000 for the Cincinnati and Eastern Railroad. He bought the road for $900,050 at judicial sale.

The citizens of New-York who believe that the only true issue in the municipal canvass is reform in the administration of city affairs ought to be convinced that the only hope of advancing that cause at the coming election lies in the choice of ROOSEVELT for Mayor.

Norman B. Ream, the big Chicago operator; Alfred Sidman, for 18 years with the old firm of Dater Timpson, and now junior partner of Timpson Co., their successor, and Edward L. Norton, of Henry Allen Co., were admitted to membership in the Stock Exchange yesterday.
NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 28.--Yesterday afternoon the Evening News published an article saying that Frank Long, a married man, and Miss Placid Reid, a young lady well connected, had eloped.

KEYPORT, N.J., Oct. 28.--Charles Morris, of this place, recently did some work for Mrs. Borhauser, a widow, and had a quarrel with her because she refused to pay him what she considered as extortionate price. A few days later a dozen of Mrs. Borhauser's pigs were poisoned. Morris was suspected, and hearing that the police were looking for him he has fled the town.

A fair and festival is to be held by the Sisters of Peace at St. Joseph's Home, in Jersey City, beginning at 8 o'clock to-morrow evening. The proceeds are to be devoted to charitable purposes connected with the organization.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 28.--Two hundred soldiers and sailors of the late war he buried in St. Bernard's Cemetery, and to-day a monument erected to their memory by the State of Connecticut was dedicated with impressive services.
The Fall opening of the Central Park Riding Academy took place last evening, when a reception was given to a large company of gentlemen and ladies, the friends and patrons of the establishment.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 28.--Henry S. Ives, of New-York, was asked to-day as to the truth of the report that his syndicate has been offered an advance of $2,000,000 on the purchase price for a controlling share of the stock of the Cincinnati.
PITTSBURG, Oct. 28.--An ore bank owned by D.W. Cox, at Dillsburg, York County, caved in this morning, killing two men and seriously injuring several others.

Irving Hall was last night given over to revelry and high living, a banquet being given there by the Veteran Firemen's Association to the visiting Bremen from other cities. Seven hundred people, of whom about half were visitors, sat down at long tables running down the big room, and brawny, red-shirted men they were.

PARIS, Oct. 28.--La Republique Francaise, speaking of the relations between France and England concerning the latter's occupation of Egypt, says: "We are not enemies of England. We should be greatly blamed if we attempted to revive the hatred which formerly existed between the two nations.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28.--Mayor Harrison this afternoon sent a letter to the Chairman of the Third District Democratic Congressional Committee declining to be a candidate for Congress in that district.

LINCOLN, Ill., Oct. 28.--A sensation was caused this morning by the failure, for over $125,000, of the banking house of William M. Dustin Co., of this city. The bank was over 30 years old and was so well established that it enjoyed the confidence of the community, and until lately did a large business.

Twenty-one men and thirty boys assembled in Apollo Hall, No. 126 Clinton-street, last evening, to attend what was termed "a monster Hewitt and Campbell meeting." The speakers waited in vain for the promised crowds to pour into the hall, but they were disappointed and had to speak to the empty benches.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 28.--In the tallysheet forgery trial to-day John Francis, the convict, was again placed upon the stand. Upon being cross-examined by Mr. Converse for the defense, Francis was asked if it was not a part of the Republican scheme that he was to escape.

Many Democratic newspapers in other States and other cities call Mr. ABRAM S. HEWITT "the Administration candidate," "the Cleveland candidate," and so on. The Wilmington Star, among others, says that Mr. HEWITT "represents Mr. CLEVELAND, and yet THE TIMES attacks the Cleveland candidate."

Lord Lonsdale has returned to the land where Earls are more appreciated than they are in this country. He left silently, almost surreptitiously, on the Britannic yesterday, with his valet, but, like Rienzi, he left word that he went but to return.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 28.--The Democrats in Passaic County are in a quandary. In the strongly Democratic Assembly district they nominated a straight-out Democrat for the Legislature, although there was a labor candidate in the field.

"M.C."--The "society was organized" is the preferable expression. The Tenth Ward Republican Club will hold a meeting this evening in Telephone Hall, No. 131 Allen-street, to indorse the Republican candidate for Congress.

SOFIA, Oct. 28.--At a private meeting at Tirnova, of Deputies belonging to the Government parts, it was unanimously decided to adhere to the Government's policy toward Russia. Gen. Kaulbars telegraphed to the Regency advising the raising of the state of siege at Sofia and Varna.

LONDON, Oct. 29.--The Daily News, commenting on the dedication of Bartholdi's Statue of Liberty says: "It is a great mistake to think the statue will increase the friendship between the two countries. America did not want the statue. She took it because it was offered to her. When the last cannon boomed New-York was richer by a remarkable statue, and that is about all."

The first of the afternoon Popular concerts at the Metropolitan Opera House took place yesterday afternoon. A programme of 10 numbers was interpreted. The nomination of Theodore Roosevelt as the Republican candidate for Mayor of NewYork City is something in which Dakota people have even greater interest than the desire that the Nation's metropolis should have clean and efficient government.

LONDON, Oct. 28.--This was the fourth day of the Newmarket Houghton meeting. The race for the frog handicap sweepstakes for 3year-olds was won by the Duke of Westminster's b.c. Ormonde. Prince Soltykoff's ch.c. Mcphisto was second, and A. Sassoon's b.c. Theodore third.
There died here this morning Dr. F.G.P. Abbot, an American dentist, who has long stood at the head of his profession in this capital, and was the oldest member of the American colony in Berlin.
LONDON, Oct. 28.--The steamship Jan Breydel, (Belg.,) Capt. Meyer, from New-York Oct. 16 for Antwerp, passed the Lizard to-day.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 28.--There was a marked increase in the attendance at the races, which was the third day of the regular Fall meeting of the new Memphis Jockey Club. The weather was clear and bright, and the track a little heavy from dust. Following were the events:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28.--Acting Sectetary Fairchild to-day gave orders for the extinguishment of the electric light in the tower at Hell Gate, New-York Harbor, from and after Dec. 1.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Oct. 28.--The steamer San Pablo, from Hong-Kong and Yokohama, which arrived here to-day, brings Hong Kong advices to Oct. 2 and Yokohama advices to Oct. 13. Although the cholera a epidemic in Japan is abating somewhat, the morality from the disease is still enormous.
BOSTON, Oct. 28.--The liabilities of E.C. Holmes, seeds, who failed recently, are $13,735, mostly due in New-York and the West. His assets are of uncertain value.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28.--The present and closing week of the Democratic campaign, as directed from the State Committee, headquarters, shows extraordinary activity. About 80,000 private letters have been sent out to the individual Democratic voters of this city, and an equal number to the active workers in all the election districts of the State. FORT KEOGH, Montana, Oct. 28.--A cowboy herding some cattle near Bozeman yesterday conceived the idea of running a race with a freight train just passing.

TRENTON, N.Y., Oct. 28.--The Republican State Committee has just issued a circular headed "Robert S. Green as a Falsifier." Mr. Green, the Democratic candidate for Governor, in his speeches throughout the State is charging that Mr. Howey, the Republican candidate, as a member of Congress voted against the antiChinese Immigration bill.
ERIE, Penn., Oct. 28.--A board of officers from the War Department, consisting of Capts. Frederick A. Mahan, Edward Maguire, and Henry M. Adams, made a survey of the peninsula off Erie to-day.

A crowd gathered as early as 9 o'clock yesterday morning in front of the house in which Mrs. Stewart lay dead. A belief seemed to be quite generally held that when the body of Mrs. Stewart was placed in the coffin, the big double doors would be thrown open to the public. It required the influence of the police to convince many persons that the funeral would be private.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28.--The Second Assistant Postmaster-General in his annual report, after giving the statistics of and estimates for the service, says: "Under the present law regulating compensation for railway Post Office cars no pay is allowed for service in apartment cars under 40 feet in length.

The man who stabbed Thomas Igo, of No. 238 East One Hundred and Seventh-street, and Patrick McCarthy, of No. 172 East One Hundred and Second-street, during a fight Wednesday afternoon at Ninety-ninth-street and Thirdavenue, has not yet been arrested.

Brooklyn took a great deal of interest in yesterday's parade and contributed to it her Mayor and other municipal officers besides sending many thousands of spectators across the river. The City Hall, Municipal Building, and County Court House were very artistically decorated with flags and shields and varicolored bunting, and many of the larger stores on Fulton-street were similarly draped.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 28.--In the Court of Appeals to-day, the Hon. W.C. Ruger, Chief-Justice, and associates present, the following causes were argued: No. 96--In the matter of the judicial settlement of the accounts of John Hohman and another, Executors.--Argued by Richard W. McIncrow for appellants, F.G. Fincke for respondents.

LONDON, Oct. 28.--The diary of Bishop Hannington, who was put to death by order of King Mwanga of Uganda, Africa, has been published. Giving the details of the last week of his life, he describes the arrival of his party at Lubwas, where the chief, at the head of a thousand troops, demanded ten guns and three barrels of powder.

The first official report on the prospects of the cotton crop in the Bombay Presidency is as follows: "The forecast refers to the early districts of the Deccan only. Khandesch; Area roughly estimated at 1,000,000 acres, that is, 300,000 acres more than last year, and 225,000 acres more than last seven years' average. Sowings early, and unusually good season expected.

SCRANTON, Penn., Oct. 28.--At 1 o'clock this afternoon an explosion of fire damp occurred at Johnson's mine, by which nine men were severely, and it is supposed fatally, injured. There was a full force of men at work in the mine at the time of the explosion.
President Cleveland and his party left Jersey City for Washington at 5:37 P.M. The arrangements at the station were so complete that the departure was almost unnoticed.

WILLIAMSBURG, Ky., Oct. 28.--Eight persons were burned to death Tuesday night in the residence of William Poe, near Flat Lick, Knox County, which was entirely consumed. Not a soul of all those in the house was left alive to tell the story.
Henry George began his labors last evening at No. 10 Stanton street, where he addressed the United Hebrew George Club.

The colors of France and the United States blended last night wherever colors could be hung in the big dining hall at Delmonico's, where the Chamber of Commerce gathered in force to dine M. Bartholdi and the other French visitors.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 28.--The Woman's Board of Missions of the Interior finished its eighteenth annual session to-day. Most of the officers of last year were re-elected, including Mrs. Moses Smith, of Detroit, as President, 34 Vice-Presidents, Miss M.D. Wingate, of Chicago, ...

Mr. S. DANA HORTON is unquestionably the leading bimetallist of the United States. He contributes to the first number of the new Quarterly Journal of Economics, published for Harvard University, an article on "Silver Before Congress in 1886."

CHICAGO, Oct. 28.--Dr. Lyman reported to Judge Pendergast to-day that he had examined A.S. Gage and found him suffering from nervous exhaustion, consequent upon an imperfect recovery from a disease from which he was told Mr. Gage suffered some years ago.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28.--First Lieut. J. Walker Benet, Fifth Artillery, has been transferred to the Ordnance Department and ordered to report by letter to the Chief of Ordnance. First Lieut. Colville P. Terret, Eighth Infantry, has been ordered to temporary recruiting duty at David's Island, New-York Harbor.
CHICAGO, Oct. 28.--The counsel for the seven condemned Anarchists submitted to Judge Gary this morning a voluminous document upon which another motion for a new trial will be based.

The Prohibitionists have no cause to complain when all three of the candidates for Congress in the Western district [Republican, Democratic, and Prohibition] come out in favor of the Constitutional amendment, and urge the adoption of measures to see that it is not a failure.

"Tim" Campbell began his campaign work yesterday in earnest. He did not intend to make a personal canvass this year, feeling assured of victory, but he began to grow alarmed at the untiring efforts of the silver-toned orator from the Dry Dock district, and, after holding a consultation with friends, he started out last evening to "whoop 'er up."

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 29.--Edward Blake, a saloon keeper in East St. Louis, shot and instantly killed to-day William C. Vanderough, an engineer on the Indianapolis and St. Louis Railroad. Vanderough had been drinking a good deal, when a quarrel between him and the proprietor arose over payment for the drinks. Vanderough started for Blake. Blake ordered him to halt, and, meeting with a refusal, drew his revolver and fired at the engineer.
A Burlington girl, who is a great talker, says that it is better to be engaged in conversation than not at all.--Burlington Free Press.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29.--At a special meeting of the Chicago Coal Exchange to-day the retail price of coal was advanced 25 cents per ton all round for the month of November. This makes the price of nut and stove coal $7 per ton and egg and range $6 75.

An application was made to Judge Donohue, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, for an order extending for another year the life of the Assessment Commission, whose duty it is to determine the rightfulness of assessments for local improvements.

The Laura Franklin Free Hospital for Children, on One Hundred and Eleventh-street, near Fifth-avenue, is nearly completed and will be dedicated next Tuesday. The hospital is the work of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin H. Delano, in memory of their niece, and its entire cost, including endowment, will be about $300,000.

A raid on gambling houses in the Twentyninth Precinct last evening was attended with good results. Roundsman Saul with a couple of policemen went to No. 102 West Thirtysecond-street, and Roundsman Farley to No. 490 Sixth-avenue.

JAMESBURG, N.J., Oct. 29.--A smash-up occurred on the Amboy Division of the Pennsylvania Railroad at Lower Jamesburg, just below this place, this morning, in which several freight cars were demolished and the freight somewhat damaged.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 29.--On the night of May 4, 1885, William O. Jones, asleep in the house of his mother, in Bartow County, was rudely awakened, and found in his room A.G. Ballock and W.F. Gaston, with their revolvers pointed at his head.
District Attorney Martine yesterday refused to say what had been the report of the medical experts who were appointed to determine whether Alderman Francis McCabe was insane or not.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 29.--The Earlham College Faculty has expelled five students and placed 17 others on good behavior for breaking the rules by attending a representation of "Richard Ill."

CHICAGO, Oct. 29.--The Canadian steam barge Isaac May was seized by the Custom House officers to-day for violating the American coasting laws. The May reached Chicago yesterday with three loaded barges in tow.

Evidently the new controllers of the Reading Railway mean business. They are seeking a new General Manager, and Col. F.K. Hain, General Manager of New-York's elevated lines, has been invited to accept the position at a big salary.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 29.--It is understood that an effort will soon be made by the Dominion Government to induce the American Government to reconsider the draft of the proposed extradition treaty between Canada and the United States.

The Thomas F. Geary Association, the Republican Club in the Fourteenth Ward, held an executive meeting last evening at No. 10 Spring-street, where George R. Jacobs presided. The object of the meeting was to devise the best means to bring out the full Roosevelt vote in the ward.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 29.--The steamer which arrived last evening from Puerto Cortez, Guatemala, brings news that great excitement was caused in the town of Guatemala on Oct. 10 by the exposure of an attempt to poison the President by two brothers, druggists of the city.

LISBON, Oct. 29.--East African advices say that the King of Inhambane twice repulsed the King of Muzilla at the head of 30,000 men, and in a third attack the latter was defeated by 16,000 Portuguese and natives under the command of the Governor of Mozambique, assisted by European military and naval officers.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 29.--The Democrats of the First District of Wayne County to-day renominated William Wood for the Assembly.
BELLOWS FALLS, Vt., Oct. 29.--A serious smash-up occurred this morning at Gasset's Station, on the Central Vermont Railroad, 17 miles north of here.

BOSTON, Oct. 29.--The steamer Istrian, which has arrived here from Liverpool, reports that on Oct. 28, in latitude 42 40', longitude 67 , she passed several pieces of timber about 40 feet long and a quantity of deals, which had apparently been a short time in the water. At the same time she passed a piece of wreckage with bolts through it, which appeared to be a part of a vessel's stern.

WATERBURY, Conn., Oct. 29.--William Finnerty, a young man 28 years old, cut his throat with a razor this morning while lying in bed. Before a physician could reach the house he was dead. Finnerty was a steady-going young fellow, who had never manifested any suicidal tendencies. He was prosperous, and was soon to have been married. It is believed that temporary insanity caused the act.

The fact that in many papers the death last week of the Rev. William Barnes was announced without further comment suggests that the peculiar merit of this very original and very charming poet cannot be widely recognized.

BRUNSWICK, Ga., Oct. 29.--The dead body of the Rev. J.G. Kitchen was found this morning near Sterling, in Glynn County. He had been shot to death. Glynn County has always had a colored member in the Legislature. At the election many negroes bolted the negro candidate, thus electing the white man.

LANCASTER, Penn., Oct. 29.--Hattie Wilson, a young but notorious woman, swallowed a teaspoonful of broken glass in the Lancaster County Prison to-day. She obtained the dose by crushing a lamp globe. Her sufferings are intense, but she may recover.

CHADWICK, N.J., Oct. 29.--Hardly anything remains to mark the spot where the illfated brig came ashore at this place Wednesday morning. Old wreckers can hardly call to mind an instance on the Jersey coast of so quick and so complete a destruction of a well built vessel.

The Shepard Rifles, Fifty-first New-York Volunteers, marched from New-York for the front in September, 1861. They were a full regiment Last night about 150 of the surviving members met at Morelli's, in West Twenty-eighth-street, for their first reunion and banquet.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 29.--The Canadian Government, in view of the failure of the Washington authorities to renew the fishery treaty, is making arrangements to renew patrol service next Spring. Its fleet will be augmented by the addition of three steam cruisers.

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 29.--New-Haven Democrats held a rally to-night and Edward Spicer Cleveland, candidate for Governor, Gen. E.E. Bradley, candidate for Lieutenant-Governor, and other members of the State ticket were here to aid the celebration.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 29.--Drafts on New-York--Sight, 17 cents; telegraphic, 25 cents.

BILOXI, Miss., Oct. 29.--For the past two nights there has been a palpable white frost at this place, and official medical intelligence presumes such to be inconsistent with the further existence of yellow fever.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29.--To-day was the third day of the Fall meeting of the National Jockey Club. The atmosphere was raw and chilly, the sky overcast and a light rain fell at intervals. The attendance was larger than on the previous days, and the track was in fair condition.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 29.--The political campaign is now well under way in this State, and is proving one of the liveliest within the remembrance of the most antique settler. Never before have the Democrats made so desperate and united an effort to win somewhat of success.

KEYPORT, N.J., Oct. 29.--Miss Jennie Anderson, a pretty and attractive young blonde of about 18 Summers, has for some time past been receiving the attention of Fred Joslin, an employe in Van Deventur's factory at Cliffwood. Mr. Joslyn urged his suit so well that in less than three months he had proposed, had been accepted, and the wedding had been set for yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 29.--The application of Judge Vastine to the Supreme Court, for a peremptory writ of mandamus to compel the Republican Central Committee of St. Louis to print his (Vastine's) name on their ticket as a candidate for Judge of the Criminal Court, was to-day refused.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 29.--Dr. Charles B. Converse, of Jersey City, was given a verdict for $14,000 in the United States Circuit Court today. He sued the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad Company for $25,000 damages.
NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Oct. 29.--Frank C. Bancroft this afternoon signed a contract as manager of the Athletic Baseball Club.

Nicoll the tailor's large establishment at Nos, 145, 147, and 149 Bowery is now visited by hundreds every day, for the Fall trade is at its height. The merry handlers of the tailor's shears and those dexterous with the tape measure are kept busy all the time.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 29.--Charles Doll, exmember of the Board of Public Works, was arrested this afternoon on a charge of making out false bills. He is already under bond on a similar charge. The amount charged to have been stolen is about $800.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Oct. 29.--Private dispatches report the arrival of the whaling bark Europa at San Francisco yesterday from the Japan Sea, with 16 whales, making 1,400 barrels of oil and 15,000 pounds of bone. Reports from Dundee, Scotland, say that the Davis Straits fleet have taken 7 tons of whalebone this season, against 21 tons last season. Two steamers and one bark were lost.

The Kings County Grand Jury, which was expected to indict some one as responsible for the condition of affairs at the Flatbush Insane Hospital, came into court yesterday with a presentment finding that the medical directors had been remiss in their duties in not alleviating the condition of the patients.

TRENTON, Oct. 29.--When the Republican Convention, which met here a little over three weeks ago, got through with its work and went come there was perhaps but one man in the state who thought its nominee was going to be elected, and that was the nominee himself--Capt. Benjamin Franklin Howey.
PARIS, Oct. 29.--The floods in the valley of the Rhone are subsiding.

NOGALES, Arizona, Oct. 29.--There is a good deal of talk in Mexican political circles regarding an early revolution in Sonora, Mexico. The trouble seems to have grown out of a revolutionary fight against Senor Torres, the present Governor of Sonora, by the adherents of Ortiz, in which Ortiz was beaten, and he and a number of his friends were expelled from Mexico.

VICTORIA, British Columbia, Oct. 29.-- Robert Evan Sproule was hanged here this morning at 8:10 o'clock for the murder of Thomas Hammil in June, 1885, in the Kootenay mines. The condemned man ascended the scaffold without a tremor, and made a short speech protesting his innocence.

HUDSON, N.Y., Oct. 29.--Oscar F. Beckwith, murderer of Simon A. Vandercook, was today sentenced by Judge Ingalls for the third time, to be hanged on Dec. 16. The crime was committed in the town of Austerlitz, Columbia County, Jan. 10, 1882. The sentence to-day was by direction of the Court of Appeals, which affirmed the previous sentence.

CHICAGO, Oct 29.--A circular letter issued by the New-York creditors of A.S. Gage Co., was received in this city to-day. It is signed by the committee appointed to make the endeavor to secure a settlement of the indebtedness at 45 cents on the dollar, payable in cash the l5th of December, provided the creditors promptly agree.

The story of the shocking accident at Rio shows again the terrible work of the car stove. There was a coal stove in the passenger coach. The shock scattered its glowing contents through the car, and in an instant the highly inflammable woodwork was blazing.

KEYPORT, N.J., Oct. 29.--Miss Jennie Murphy, the younger daughter of Mr. John Wesley Murphy, of this place, was to-day committed by Judge Alfred Walling to the State Lunatic Asylum at Trenton, N.J. Miss Murphy's father, who is about 60 years of age, became insane about three years ago, and is now an inmate of the same asylum that his daughter was sent to.
"F.T.B."--You have lost the right to vote at the coming election.

TORONTO, Oct. 29.--At a reform demonstration at Guelph last night, Mr. Blake, leader of the Opposition, stated that within the last 24 hours he had received information that the dissolution of Parliament would be announced immediately.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29.--The Secretary of the Treasury this afternoon issued the one hundred and fourty-fourth call for the redemption of bonds.

LONDON, Oct. 29.--The private sweepstakes of 1,000 sovereigns each, half forfeit, arranged to take place to-day at the Newmarket Houghton meeting, proved a failure. The Duke of Westminster's 3-year-old b.c. Ormonde was the only horse to appear, and he walked over the course.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 29.--D.S. Fotheringham, the Adams Express messenger who was robbed last Monday night, has not yet been arrested, although he is accompanied wherever he goes by a detective.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29.--The Chicago Baseball team has disbanded for the Winter. President Spaulding said, regarding next year's team: "I have signed Burns, Hardie, Sunday, Daly, Pyle, Pfeffer, Baldwin, Ryan, Clarkson, Flynn, and Darling. Darling is the famous catcher of the Toronto Club, and I signed him yesterday.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 29.--The attendance at the races to-day was fair. The day was everything that could be desired. The track, however, was still slow from dust.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 29.--In the United States Circuit Court to-day the equity case of Mr. John N.A. Griswold, of New-York, against Mr. Rowland Hazard and other creditors of the now famous Credit Mobilier, were entered and the bill of complaint was dismissed with costs for defendants.

Walter A. Brady, the Chambers Clerk of the Supreme Court, was registered as a voter in the Twentieth Election District of the Twentyfourth Assembly District. He moved the other day into the Thirteenth Election District, and on the last day of registration applied to be registered there, presenting to the inspectors of election a certificate of removal made by the inspectors of the Twentieth District.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29.--William Klinkhammer's death was reported to Coroner Hertz this morning, and investigation leaves little doubt that it was caused by hydrophobia. Klinkhammer, who was a carpenter, living at No. 71 Waller-street, was on his way to work on the morning of Sept. 11 when a large bulldog rushed upon him.

Murray, retired, would be named in a few days, but the office is still vacant and gossip about it is lively. ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct. 29.--The first Republican torchlight parade and mass meeting of the present campaign was held this evening.

The Paris milliners have hit upon a novelty. The difficulty of the "new color" has proved almost insuperable. Even with the rainbow in the skies it is impossible to produce every Autumn, Winter, Spring, and Summer a color that shall be confessed to be new.

PEORIA, Ill., Oct. 29.--Samuel Woolner, a prominent distiller, was nominated to-day by the Republicans for Alderman in the Fifth Ward. His brother, Jacob Woolner, who is a wealthy brewer and leading Democrat, was immediately nominated by his party for the same office. The situation creates much interest, and a repetition of the Taylor brothers' Tennessee campaign is being eagerly discussed.

TORONTO, Ontario, Oct. 29.--The steamer Lake Huron, of the Beaver Line, from Liverpool, grounded on Madame Island and sustained serious injury to her bottom. She, however, steamed up as far as Indian Point, about seven miles below the city, where she was run ashore.

The animating topic of conversation at Henry George's headquarters and at the Central Labor Union headquarters yesterday was the speech which Terence V. Powderly, of the Knights of Labor, has agreed to make on behalf of Mr. George next Monday evening.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29.--The Hartley Reclining Chair Company made an assignment this morning to W.D. Gibson. The liabilities are stated at $19,000, and assets at $25,000. No schedule has been filed. A number of confessions of judg ment were made yesterday.

UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 29.--Alderman Edward M. Brown was to-day held in $500 bail on a charge of procuring the registration of 13 men who were not voters. Brown made a canvass for the Republican candidates in the Seventh Ward.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29.--The proceedings of the court-martial convened in this city for the trial of Capt. William S. Johnson, retired, have been made public. Capt. Johnson was tried under charges of duplicating his pay accounts, and the court-martial returned a verdict of not guilty. Lieut.-Gen. Sheridan, who reviewed the proceedings, set aside this verdict, however.

LONDON, Oct. 29.--The steamship Plato, (Br.,) Capt. James, from New-York Oct. 16, arr. at Liverpool today.

Dr. John H. Brunner in his Union of the Churches puts the number of negro Methodists at 700,000, which is more than half the number if the statistics of the various churches are correct. They are as follows, viz.; African Methodist Episcopal Zion, 400,000; African Methodist Episcopal, 391,000; Methodist Episcopal, 225,000; Colored Methodist, 155,000; all others combined, 25,000, Total, 1,196,000. The doctor is probably more accurate on other subjects.

The committee of property holders residing in the vicinity of Madison-avenue and Fiftyeighth-street who are charged with the work of preventing the New-York Steam Company from erecting a boiler house in the neighborhood held a meeting last night at the Madison-Avenue Hotel with about 30 members present.

The Brooklyn Magazine began, in its July issue, a discussion of the question, "Which is the ablest American newspaper?" The controversy was put to the ballot and at once excited a lively interest in every part of the United States, and extended even to the countries of Europe. The total vote reached the large number of 12,054, which exceeded the expectations of the editor of the magazine.

A German version of Lecocq's "Cent Vierges," called "One Hundred Maidens; or, The Green Isle," was given at the Thalia Theatre last evening with noteworthy success. The house was crowded to quite a remarkable extent, not even standing room being to be had when the curtain rose, and interest in the performance was manifested to the end.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30.--The Fall season in Washington affects the appearance of its streets and lawns just as it does those of other cities that have lawns and shade trees and public gardens. The grass will wither, the leaves will fall, and where the contractors fail to do their duty the streets become untidy.

The great event in the Mayoralty contest to-day will be the mass meeting of business men to be held at 3:15 o'clock this afternoon on the steps of the Sub-Treasury Building, in Wallstreet. It promises to be the most successful meeting ever known in a Mayoralty canvass in this city, and will result in a great assemblage about the Sub-Treasury to hear what the future Mayor may have to say.

TORONTO, Oct. 29.--The Imperial Railway Commission, which was appointed to inquire into railway concerns in Canada and report on grievances and the necessity of appointing a permanent railway commission, resumed its session here to-day.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Oct. 29.--The bunko steerers "Pete" and "Joe," of New-York, who were arrested here on Wednesday, and who gave their names as E. Leffingwell, of Boston, and Henry Price, of Reading, gave bail in the sum of $1,000 this morning and were released.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29.--At a meeting this afternoon of the special committee of the Law Committee of Councils, to which was referred the question of the impeachment of the Mayor, it was agreed unanimously to recommend that the resolutions for the appointment of a committee of two to prepare articles of impeachment be indefinitely postponed.

The Western Union has lately received proof that it is not at all points above the law. This demonstration was grievous but wholesome. It has had the effect of leading that corporation to believe that it is better to try circumventing the law than overriding it.

ERIE, Penn., Oct. 29.--Erie is being afflicted with a burglar scourge. The gang which has been terrorizing Corry, Westfield, and the neighboring towns commenced operations here a few nights ago. Last night they were overhauled by the police force, and a running street fight took place, in which both officers and burglars fired promiscuously. No one was hit, but one of the gang was caught to-day. He gives his name as James Graham.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29.--An explanation of the big jump in corn yesterday was furnished today in the story of how one or more Kansas City bucket shops were "played for suckers" and bit eagerly at the bait. There is a boy living in Lee who suffers from a singular hereditary tendency to bleeding at intervals for periods of nine days, with danger of bleeding to death, whenever the skin is broken in the slightest manner.
HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 29.--The Republican Convention for Hartford nominated tonight Leverett Brainard for Senator and Francis A. Pratt and Alexander Harbison for Representatives.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29.--A rare combat took place this afternoon in a building occupied by the Fish Commission between two little pets of that institution whose likes have probably never found themselves in such close proximity since the ages of featherless birds, winged reptiles and web-footed quadrupeds.

ALBANY, Oct. 29.--The Court of Appeals passed to-day on the test case on the new oleomargarine law, chapter 183 of the Laws of 1885. Lipman Arensberg was convicted in the Kings County Sessions last January of violating section 7 of the amended law, and the case was carried up to test the constitutionality of the law.

Thomas J. Lipton, of Glasgow, who is said to be the most extensive retail provision dealer in the world, being the proprietor of over 30 stores in Great Britain, is awaiting a big consignment from New-York in the shape of 15 monster cheeses that are now on their way over the ocean. They are the biggest cheeses ever made.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Oct. 30.--A double tragedy occurred this afternoon at the Bennett slope of W.G. Payne Co.'s colliery, near Kingston. William Moses, one of the oldest mining engineers in Luzerne County, was on duty at this colliery.

The vast emigra tion from Germany in modern years and its causes are now commonplaces of contemporary history. No pause is needed here for dwelling upon the innate force and healthy stamina of the breed, its domestic family habits, its calm self-reliance, and its adventurous spirit.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 30.--The valuable library bequeathed to Redwood Library of this city by the late Judge Emott, of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., has been assorted and arranged, and the patrons of the library are receiving the benefit of it.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., Oct. 30.--The Hon. J.H. Dimmick, Postal Stamp Agent, has left his office in New-York City to devote his entire time to the election of the Hon. George W. Greene to the Assembly, whose renomination outraged the more respectable portion of the Democratic party.
MONTREAL, Oct. 30.--A Mrs. Lamoureux has just died under very suspicious circumstances, and a warrant has been issued for her husband's arrest for beating her to death.
CHICAGO, Oct. 30.--A final decree was entered to-day before Judge Tuley in the case of C.H. Aldrich against the Dalziel National Printing Company and others.

ERIE, Penn., Oct. 30.--The drug store of Dr. G. Ulrich was destroyed by fire to-day, originating from a lamp in the basement. Dr. Ulrich, who was in the basement, was surrounded by the burning oils and was barely rescued alive. His burns are serious. The loss is about $6,000; insurance, $5,000.

LANCASTER, Penn., Oct. 30.--William Irwin, of Rowlandsville, Md., went to his room at the residence of his nephew, L.H. Bachler, in this city, about midnight last night, and was found dead in bed this morning, suffocated by illuminating gas. He had either blown the gas out or not turned it off properly, and his death was the result. He leaves a widow and 10 children.

The intelligence contained in the special cable dispatches of THE TIMES this morning that Mr. Henry Irving will visit this country next September, in his professional capacity, bringing with him his company and Mr. Wills's version of "Faust," with all its elaborate scenery and appointments, will not surprise any person familiar with the drift of theatrical affairs.
A paragrph has gone the round of the papers about Monaco and "the victims" of its gambling season, it being asserted that there have been 81 suicides.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 30.--Late last night, while a man and woman were talking together on Jefferson-avenue, a stranger stepped up and called for help to remove the body of a dead man, which he said he had found on the street.
Mr. Lawrence Barrett will be in Indianapolis this week. Mr. John White commences his series of organ recitals at Chickering Hall on Nov. 26.

It has been claimed erroneously that Clarke Howell of Atlanta, aged 23, will be the youngest member in the lower house of the next Georgia Legislature. Washington County has elected as one of her Representatives Beverly D. Evans, Jr., born in Sandersville, May 1865, who is therefore, only 21 years old. Dudley Du Bose, of Wilkes is also Mr. Howell's junior.

United States Treasurer Conrad N. Jordan came on from Washington yesterday to attend a dinner party given in his honor by E.F. C. Young, President of the First National Bank of Jersey City. With him were Controller of the Treasury Trenholm and Assistant Treasurer Canda, of New-York. Pinard spread the board, and among the guests were ex-Gov. Bedle, Gov. Abbett, Judge Knapp, James Fleming, and 14 others. Mr. Jordan will return to Washington to-day.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30.--East-bound freight business continues to improve. The shipments of dead freight from this city to all Eastern points by the various pool lines during the past week show an increase of nearly 1,000 tons over the previous week. This satisfactory showing is due to the increased demand for our products in the East and in Europe, the bulk of shipments...

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 30.--The Anti-Prohibitionists on the committee for nominating city officers have secured the nomination of the Hon. John Tyler Cooper for Mayor. Mr. Cooper is strongly identified with the Anti-Prohibitionists, and for this reason was bitterly opposed by the prohibitionists.
Michael Leyden, of No. 207 Thompsonstreet, was startled yesterday when, in a lot of junk he had just bought, he found what seemed to him to be an infernal machine.

Mr. A.M. Palmer will begin his Winter term at the Madison-Square Theatre to-morrow evening, when his excellent company will appear in a new play. The pretty house has been freshened and repaired during the last week, the only week in its history, by the way, in which it has been closed.
