EUFAULA, Ala,, Oct. 30.--Reports to-day from Headland, some miles below here, give an account of the murder of "Abe" Saunders, white, who was found in his store yesterday morning with his throat cut from ear to ear. Nothing was missing from the store, which does away with the theory of robbery as the cause of the murder. There is absolutely no clue to the perpetrators, nor to the object of the deed.

CABUL, Oct. 30.--The Ghilzai tribe and a portion of the Hazaras have been joined by the renowned robber Sadu, and, under command of the sons of the notorious Mushki Aleem Mollahs, have risen against the Ameer. Near Ghuznee they attacked and dispersed an Afghan regiment which was acting as escort to a treasure train. The rising is attributed to the popular discontent over the excessive rate of taxation.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 30.--The Highway Committee of the City Council had the proposed beach improvement uuder consideration this evening and will report favorably a proposition made by several parties to build a pavilion and bathing houses in accordance with City Engineer Bentley's plans, on condition of receiving the exclusive lease of the beach for a term of years.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30.--Attorney-General Garland has given an opinion to the Secretary of the Treasury that national banks must deposit interest-bearing bonds to secure their circulation and that called 3 per cent. bonds cannot be used as a basis of circulation. A big crowd of men and women squeezed into Steinway Hall last evening to hear Theodore Roosevelt close the hottest campaign that the Republicans of this city have seen in a long time. For the moment a realization of the tremendous results pending is lost in exhilaration over the fact that something tangible is on the stage at last.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30.--This morning about 9:20 o'clock, Dr. Charles Raymond, a twelve-hundred-dollar clerk in the Southern Division of the Pension Office, dropped dead while at his desk. The police were notified and his body was removed to his late home, No. 1,028 North Capital-street. The deceased was about 65 years old. He was appointed a clerk in the Pension Office from the Seventh District of Indiana Aug. 30, 1884, and was promoted the following year.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Oct. 30.--Joseph B. Anthony, of this city, was drowned at Westport Harbor yesterday afternoon. The tide runs 10 miles an hour in the river, and his body was probably carried out to sea. Mr. Anthony was for years prominently engaged in the insurance business in Boston, but withdrew recently, being in independent circumstances. He had a wide circle of acquaintances throughout the country. Mr. Anthony was about 44 years old and unmarried.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 30.--The total number of voters registered in Buffalo this year is 43,045, showing a falling off of about 1,500 from last year.

Charles Reiche Brother, of No. 95 Park-row, this importers of animals, have just received from Brazil one of the rarest of marine animals. CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 30.--One of the most disastrous fires that has visited Haddonfield for many years broke out there this morning at 11 o'clock. It resulted in the complete destruction of Riley's St. John's Military Academy and St. Agnes Hall for the second time in 16 years. The fire broke out in the northwest corner of the roof, and is said to have been caused by a defective flue.

BOSTON, Oct. 30.--The Boston Baseball Club practically completed its nine for 1887 and its quota of players to-day by signing Richard B. Conway, of Lowell, last year of the champion Lawrences and this season of the champion Portland team.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct 30.--An important announcement was made to-day in regard to the coming celebration of the two hundred and fiftieth anniversary of Harvard. From Tuesday next until Monday evening following all visitors who attend the celebration will be required to register at room No. 4 in University Hall.
TROY, N.Y., Oct. 30.--Michael F. Collins was unanimously renominated to-night by the Demo crats of the First District of Rensselaer County for the Assembly.

PARIS, Oct. 30.--Despite the strong and sober protests of papers like the Temps and Siecle the belief prevails in informed circles that M. de Freycinet has determined to go forward with the scheme demanding from England a definite statement of the period of its occupation of Egypt, with a declaration that France will not consent to an indefinite continuance.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 30.--It is reported on good authority that the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company has secured passenger and freight connections as far south as New-Orleans, with an extension of its express business.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 30.--The Abbott Iron Company is closing up its affairs. It is the largest concern of the kind in this city. Its works cover 10 acres of ground. It has not prospered of late.

LONDON, Oct. 30.--An international handicap double sculling sweepstakes took place to-day on the Thames. The race consisted of two trial heats and a final, and was rowed over a course from Wandsworth foot-bridge to a point a little below Hammersmith Bridge, a distance of about two miles and a half. The first heat was between G. J. Perkins and Dave Godwin and Wallace Ross and G. W. Lee.

News reached this city to-day that Elisha John Morrison, aged 75 years, the oldest and wealthiest hermit in the State of New-Jersey, is dying alone in his little hut, situated about four miles south of here on the road leading from Asbury Park to Poplar. Morrison has lived a hermit life for nearly half a century. He was at one time a well known produce merchant in New-York.

NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 30.--At 3 o'clock this morning the Old Dominion Line steamer Wyanoke collided off Sewell's Point with the coal barge Morro Castle, of New-London. The barge was loaded with coal for Providence, and was badly damaged. The Wyanoke's wheel was disabled, but she sailed for New-York this evening.

SOFIA, Oct. 30.--Gen. Kaulbars has issued an ultimatum to the Bulgarian Government. He complains that Russians in Bulgaria are maltreated and terrorized, and says that if in three days he does not receive a satisfactory answer to his ultimatum he will rupture his relations with the regency and leave Sofia, taking with him the whole personnel of the Russian Consulate.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 30.--Joseph Green, bookkeeper of W.H. Metz Co., was found lying insensible with a fractured skull at Fourteenth and Lexington streets this morning. He had been struck with a slungshot and robbed of clothes, money, and valuables. He left the office for home at 9 o'clock last evening. He will die. There is no clue to his assailant.

TORONTO, Ontario, Oct. 30.--Two tramps were killed on the Grand Trunk Railway track near Little York station to-day. It appears that five tramps belonging at St. Albans, Vt., were stealing their way from Kingston to this city. They got off the train just before it reached the station and then started to walk along the track for Toronto. They were shortly overtaken by the train and got out of the way.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 30.--Samuel S. Payton was discharged from the State prison at Jackson to-day on the expiration of his sentence for five years for a bank robbery committed in this city. He is a grandson of Commodore Payton, and leaves the prison to step at once into the possession of a fortune left him by the death of a relative in New-York. His fortune is estimated at from $75,000 to $250,000.

OTTAWA. Oct. 30.--The Hon. Mackenzie Bowelle, Minister of Customs, has returned from Halifax. He stated that he had arranged with Consul-General Phelan that hereafter all American vessels short of provisions will be able to obtain supplies any where in the Provinces without any special permit, and that in case of subsequent seizure and infliction of fines the amounts may be deposited with the Collector at Halifax instead of where the seizure is made.

PORTAGE, Wis., Oct. 30--An old building in Rio was converted into a temporary morgue yesterday, and therein repose all that is mortal of the human beings who perished in the wreck of night before last. The bodies are placed upon sheets, and articles found near them in the wreck are laid upon the remains for the purpose of identification.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30.--It is estimated at the Treasury Department that the reduction of the public debt during October amounts to $12,000,000.

ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, Oct. 30.--The schooner Mary Brown has been lost off Bacalicu and three of her crew and a lady passenger, Miss C.H. Iver, have been drowned. The vessel broke in two soon after striking, and only the Captain and three of the men succeeded in reaching the shore.

Mr. Edward Mitchell, the Republican candidate for Judge of the Supreme Court in this city, is in every way fit for the position, and should receive a large vote. He is a New-Yorker by birth, a man of the highest personal character, and a lawyer of exceptionally good standing. He comes of good stock, his father having been for eight years a Judge of the Supreme Court.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Oct. 30.--A tri-weekly Government mail service between the United States and Cuba will go into effect on Tuesday, Nov. 2. Steamships of the Tampa and Havana Line will leave Tampa tri-weekly on the arrival of the West India fast mail train, making the distance between New-York and Tampa in 41 hours.

The Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers devoted yesterday's session to a discussion of the report of the Committee of Ten on the By-laws of the Insurance Association. One change is a division of the present $3,000 policy against death or permanent disablement into two policies or classes of $1,500 each, thus allowing a member to take one or both classes, the assessments being 50 cents on every death in each class.

VALDOSTA, Ga., Oct. 31.--E.J. Fowler, a prominent citizen of Stockton, died last night with 40 buckshot holes in his body. He had a quarrel with C.G. Murray, the station agent there. Murray drew his gun on Fowler three times, but did not shoot. Fowler turned to leave, when Murray followed him abort 40 yards and discharged the contents of both barrels into him. Fowler died in five minutes. Murray has escaped.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 31.--The wife of Thomas J. Laughlin, of Newark, was injured at the Market-street crossing of the Pennsylvania Railroad, in that city, in September, 1884. She died from the injuries a day or two later, and her husband brought suit against the company for $50,000 damages. A jury in the Federal court yesterday awarded him $15,000.

BOSTON, Oct. 31.--The fight for the Democratic nomination in the Fourth Congressional District will be carried to the polls. Last night's meeting of the convention, the eighth, failed to nominate and adjourned sine die. It is expected that all three candidates will have ballots at the polls.

ANSONIA, Conn., Oct. 31.--Thomas Feeney, the saloon keeper who is accused of murderously assaulting Joseph L. Hakes, an active Prohibitionist, has had his bonds increased from $500 to $5,000. Hakes is in a critical condition, the fracture of his skull having proved even more serious than was at first supposed. Public feeling is very strong against Feeney. His bondsman is James Dermody, keeper of the Railroad Hotel, of Ansonia.

DALLAS, Texas, Oct. 31.--The great attraction at the Dallas State Fair yesterday was an Indian war dance by 60 braves of the Kiowa and Comanche tribes. It was undoubtedly the greatest Indian dance ever witnessed in the State, except possibly when the Indians really meant business.

PORTLAND, Oregon, Oct. 31.--A westbound freight train on the road of the Oregon Railway and Navigation Company ran into a rock near Alkali at 6 o'clock this morning. The engine and 15 cars were piled up in a heap. L. Silva, the fireman, was instantly killed. F. F. Burke, head brakeman, had his leg broken and was scalded, and has died from his injuries.

NEWPORT, Oct. 31.--Rhode Island's Congressional election is attracting more attention than usual owing to the numerous candidates in the field. The unfortunate split in the Republican Party will lose many votes to the mominees of the Republican conventions.

Charges were made recently that Malcolm W. Ford, the champion all-round athlete of America, had, by entering a professional contest in Springfield, Mass., last July, as "T. Williams, of Baltimore," forfeited his right to be classed as an amateur. President Thomas W. Clark, of the Brooklyn Athletic Association, has submitted a report saying that the charges are true. The matter will be referred to the National Amateur Athletic Associations.

LONDON, Oct. 31.--The convention with China allows England full freedom as the ruling authority in Burmah for six months. Gen. White has established in Burmah 120 fresh posts, covering an area 100,000 square miles.

BRUSSELS, Oct. 31.--Five hundred women dressed in mourning to-day led a procession of 12,000 persons, gathered from surrounding towns, in a funeral march to Charleroi. They carried banners inscribed with mottoes in favor of universal suffrage and amnesty to the strike rioters. They formed a solemn and orderly cortege.
CRESSON, Penn., Oct. 31.--Mr. Andrew Carnegie is out of danger, and he is rapidly approaching convalescence.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 31.--The Trustees of the Case School of Applied Science met last evening and resolved to proceed to restore the burned building and refit it as rapidly as practicable. They hope to have it ready to be reoccupied before the next Fall term.

SCRANTON, Penn., Oct. 31.--Shortly after the fearful disasters in the Marvine and Fairlawn Colliery, by which 14 lives were lost, the Scranton Truth appealed for aid for the destitute widows and orphans, and the result was a relief fund of $2,424 raised through the columns of that paper.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 31.--Capt. Percy F. Hoxie died at Biloxi this morning of cirrhosis of the liver. Capt. Hoxie was born at Westerly, R.I., and took to the sea when 15 years of age. He was first officer with Capt. John Tyler, of the ship Hemisphere. In 1861 he was made Captian in the transport service.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31.--Business has been rather light at all the Chicago playhouses the past week, chiefly because of unpleasant weather and the reaction from the high tide of two weeks. The Florences, at McVicker's, have had pretty good houses during their two weeks' engagement.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 1.--Brig.-Gen. William A. Strong, late Secretary of State and present Secretary of the Louisiana State Senate, presented himself at Baton Rouge to-day and surrendered for trial in the District Court on a charge of embezzling State funds.

LONDON, Nov.1.--The Cabinet at the first council since the recess decided to instruct Sir William White, the British Ambassador at Constantinople, to insist upon an immediate conference at Constantinople to consider the Bulgarian question and to demand the suspension of Russian intervention, diplomatic and active, pending the decisions of such conference.

MADISON, Ind., Nov. 1.--A man giving the name of George D. Long, of Rising Sun, was arrested 12 miles above Madison last evening for murdering and robbing Charles Gordon, a school teacher, whose body was found in the river here two weeks ago. Long desperately resisted, but was placed in jail at Carrollton to-day for a preliminary trial.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 1.--Lewis Webster, recently acquitted of the murder of Perry Harrington on the third trial, was arrested to-night in Jefferson, Ohio, on the charge of shooting Mrs. Perry Harrington with intent to kill. He was released on giving $2,500 bail. The shooting of which he is now accused was done by him at the time Mrs. Harrington's husband was killed.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1.--United States Senator J. Donald Cameron paid a brief visit to Chairman Cooper to-day, but declined to talk politics except to say that Gen. Beaver would be elected. Gen. Beaver started for his home at Bellefonte early in the morning, and said that he would go to bed tomorrow...

The Republican candidate for Mayor in 1880 polled more than 98,000 votes. Every man with an ounce of sense knows that 98,000 votes will elect a Mayor to-day, and that there is no reason, why Theodore Roosevelt should receive a smaller vote than did William Dowd. Vote for Roosevelt!

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Nov. 1.--Detectives Quinlan and King arrested last night James Hindle, alias McDonald, a notorious counterfeiter and crook, who has been passing and disposing of in various ways for the past two weeks in this city finely counterfeit silver dollars. BERLIN, Nov. 1.--Prince Bismarck has invited M. Herbette, the French Ambassador, to visit him at Varzin.
CHATHAM, N.Y., Nov. 1.--Seymour Winchell, of Hillsdale, committed suicide with morphine yesterday. He was tired of life.

MADISON, Wis., Nov. 1.--The great personal interest which Postmaster-General Vilas takes in the election of a Democratic Legislature which may send him to the United States Senate, was shown to-day. He arrived in the city at an early hour this morning, accompanied by Gen. E.E. Bryant, Attorney-General for the Post...

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 1.--To-morrow's election in this State threatens to develop some genuine surprises to the Democrats of Delaware in the way of defeats at a time when there is no open Republican opposition. The Democratic ranks are more badly shattered than they have ever been in the past, and there is genuine fear, based upon the best...

CINCINNATI, Nov.1.--There is every prospect of a pleasant day to-morrow and a large vote for an off year. The Republicans are confident, too confident for the best results. The Democrats only hope to elect here and there a man. The estimate of the Republican pluralities ranges for the State at from 5,000 to 30,000.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Nov. 1.--The settlement of ex-Treasurer Carter's accounts does not progress as rapidly as the Selectmen wish, but their investigations so far show a deficiency of $30,000. They have accordingly attached Carter's property and cited him into court to prove his accounts. The suit is a civil action to recover, and no criminal proceedings will be taken against him.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 1.--A very disastrous railroad accident occurred near Parkersburg, West Va., on Friday last, the particulars and extent of which have been kept secret. BOSTON, Nov. 1.--The annual Fall handicap games of the Harvard Athletic Association, which were postponed on Saturday last on account of the weather, took place this afternoon on Holmes' Field, Cambridge.

DUBLIN, Nov. 1.--The Land Commission sat at Armagh to-day and examined a number of tenant farmers. The National League has boycotted the commission.

MANTOLOKING, N.J.,1.--The brig W.C. Warner, stranded at this place, retains an upright position and seems to be but slightly damaged by the heavy surf. Attempts will be made to get her off. The cargo of sugar is damaged to no great extent.

NORTH ELMIRA, Nov. 1.--When the first white settlers entered the Chemung Valley over 100 years ago they found the skulls of many horses piled in mounds on the spot where this village was subsequently built.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 1.--Easterbrook Co., of this city, the only manufacturers of oleomargarine in Connecticut, have suspended, as they regard the Government tax as prohibitory. From 80 to 100 persons are thrown out of employment.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 1.--The St. Louis Sugar Refinery, the largest in the West, shut down Saturday and discharged about 125 employes. The cause of closing is said to be the same which recently compelled the shutting down of several...

Whatever may be the result of the voting to-day, the municipal canvass that has just closed will be remembered as one of peculiar interest and significance. It was started by the movement of the labor organizations to concentrate their voting power upon a candidate for Mayor of the city and their selection of Mr. HENRY GEORGE for that purpose.

At about 11 o'clock yesterday morning a band of music took a stand on the balcony of Taylor's Hotel, in Jersey City, and crowds of Republicans of various degrees of importance flocked to the hotel corridors from all quarters.

CALDWELL, Kan., Nov. 1.--The discovery of silver in this vicinity has caused much excitement. Samples of the ore were sent to the State Assayer at Denver, Col., and the Assayer of the mint at Philadelphia. The former reports an assay of 342 ounces of silver to the ton, the latter 310 ounces, each with a trace of gold. The ore crops out in many localities. Caldwell now presents the appearance of a mining town.

LONDON, Nov. 1.--A Henry George meeting was held this evening in St. Andrew's Hall in this city. The hall was crowded. Mr. Maddison, of Hull, who claimed to represent 500,000 workingmen, presided. Resolutions favoring Mr. George were adopted with enthusiasm. Messrs. Vonswartwout, of Columbia University, and Silas Mainville, of New-York, addressed the meeting.

According to the French press the French railway companies are in alarm. They have long had the monopoly of English tourists making for the Riviera, and in consequence, perhaps, there is no Continental line more illiberally managed than that which connects Calais with the French capital.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 1.--James Frost, a well-to-do farmer aged nearly 55 years, living about half a mile from Dexter, in this county, went to his barn this morning at 6:30 o'clock to do his Chores. About half an hour later he was found by his family hanging to a beam dead. No cause, except temporary insanity, is given for the act. He leaves a widow and a grown-up daughter.

John Hanley, who was struck under the eye with an umbrella by john McGreevy Saturday night, and who was locked up until Sunday morning because an ambulance surgeon from tho Presbyterian Hospital said the man's stupor was the result of liquor, died in Believue Hospital early yesterday morning. McGreevy, who was defending himself from Hanley when he struck the fatal blow, was held in the Yorkville Court yesterday to await the Coroner's action.

The Columbia College Trustees, at their monthly meeting yesterday, gave Adjunct Professor A.C. Merriam a leave of absence for one year from June next, in order that he may visit professionally the American Classical Seminary at Athens, Greece.

Wall-street has been analyzing the statement made by the Reading Railroad Company for the year up to Sept. 30. Ten months profit of the railroad, canals, collieries, and barges, excluding rentals and interest, amount to $9,927,914,48.

A railroad transaction of consequence took place in Boston yesterday. The Duluth, South Shore and Atlantic Railroad Company secured the control of the Marquette, Houghton and Ontonagon Railroad by buying a majority of that road's stock.

MEDINA, N.Y., Nov. 1.--Stephen Temple, a venerable and revered retired farmer, aged 70. living with his son near here, went to his barn this morning and deliberately hanged himself to a beam. A year ago he attempted to cut his throat, but would give no reason. Age and approaching helplessness probably drove him to...

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 1.--The Farmer Rolling Mill Company, organized two years ago at Grand Rapids, filed a mortgage to-day for $21,000 to secure Romer W. Butterfield for indorsements. The company have closed their shops and, it is said, are contemplating going out of business. They claim that they will pay all their creditors in full. They attribute their troubles to the sluggishness of business.

Mrs. Cleveland narrowly escaped serious accident Thursday night while awaiting at the station the arrival of the special train, owing to a desire to be in a secluded spot away from curious gazers. The Presidential party returned from New-York at 11 o'clock on a special train. Mrs. Cleveland was at the station in the White...

DANVILLE, Va., Nov. 1.--An important meeting of the Chamber of Commerce was held this evening. Among other questions discussed was the practice of carrying concealed weapons. Finally a committee was appointed to draft a suitable law to be presented at the next meeting of the body. The Legislature at its next session will be asked to amend the State law, making the penalty imprisonment for carrying weapons concealed about the person.

BOSTON, NOV. 1.--The steamer Pavonia reached her dock at East Boston at 3:30 o'clock this afternoon. The entire force of steam pumps collected on her deck was set to work early last evening. All night long they poured forth huge volumes of water, but scarcely sufficient to percaptibly lower the flowing tide in her hold.

NEW-ORLEANS, NOV. 1.--Mgr. Straniero, the Papal Ablgate, has been in this city for some days, the guest of some of the most prominent Catholic citizens. He spent the last few days as the guest of Judge Poche, of the Supreme Court, at his plantation in St. James. He leaves in the morning for New-York, where he will at once take the steamer for Europe on his return to Rome.
I learn that the farmers in the Cape Colony intend to send the Queen a robe, dolman, and fan composed of ostrich feathers as a jubilee present. This will be a truly regal gift.

The interior of Cosmopolitan Hall was a wilderness of flowers last evening. The chrysanthemum, the "Queen of Autumn," was there in all its brilliant glory. Chrysanthemums of all shapes and sizes and colors--crimson and gold and blue and white and what not--were strewn around the floor until the place looked like a flaming October hillside.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 1--Edwin Penn Goodell, of the Class of '89, of Brown University, died this afternoon from injuries received in a football rush about three weeks ago. He belonged in Webster, Mass., was 22 years old, and was a member of the Delta Upsilon fraternity.

NYACK, Nov. 1.--Early this morning the dead body of a German named Thomas Lewis, living on Bingham's farm, near Closter, N.J., was found on the track of the Northern Railroad of New-Jersey, some distance from the switch. The head was badly injured and one arm was crushed. He had doubtless been run over by a late night train.
Janauschek acted Meg Merrilies for the first time at Albaugh's Opera House in Washington last evening. Prince Napoleon was among the audience.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Nov. 1.--Private dispatches received here from San Francisco report the arrival there yesterday of the barks Abraham Barker, of this port, from the Arctic Ocean with three whales, and the Francis Palmer, of San Francisco, with one whale.

LONDON, Nov. 1.--Mr. John Morley, accompanied by Sir William Vernon Harcourt, visited Hawarden to-day with the special object of inducing Mr. Gladstone to assent to a radical extension of the Leeds programme. There is small reason to expect that Mr. Gladstone will agree to make either the question of reform of the House of Lords or the church question a plank in the platform.

WASHINGTON, Penn., Nov. 1.--The body of a dead man was found to-night at Zediker's Station, on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, a few miles east of Washington. His head was badly crushed. Upon his person was a receipt for an express package to New-York with the name of J.W. Shultz attached. It is supposed that he was struck by a passing train and killed.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Nov. 1.--A physician of this city recently visited Jonathan Bass, of Cambria, Niagara County, whose case is believed to be without a parallel in medical records. Mr. Bass is 56 years of age. In the Summer of 1848 he was seized with a sharp pain in the bottom of his right foot. No cause for it could be discovered. The foot and leg became greatly swollen,

Mr. Edwin Booth made his first appearance here this season at the Star Theatre last night, acting in "Hamlet." The audience was exceedingly large, filling every seat in the capacious auditorium, and the progress of the performance was watched with deep interest, while the salient points were loudly applauded.
H.S. Beattie, Surveyor of the Port, was shot and seriously wounded in his office yesterday morning by Louis Bieral, a discharged employe.

ATLANTA, Nov. 1.--The Congressional election in Georgia will have a tinge of interest from the development of to-day that Dr. W.H. Felton, the celebrated independent ex-Congressman, has secretly flooded the Seventh District with ballots, hoping, by a flank movement on election day, to secure the election. Had not the secret leaked out he would have run J.C.

CORSICANA, Texas, Nov. 1.--Ben Agee, a lad of 18, who has been working on the railroad, committed suicide this evening by hanging. No cause can be found for the act. He had been in the house and seemed cheerful a few moment before his mother found him in an outhouse hanging to a beam.

There are probably half a dozen private fortunes in New-York larger than that divided by the will of Mrs. STEWART, yesterday presented for probate. Mr. STEWART's fortune was supposed, not indeed at the time of his death, but a few years before that time, to be the largest in the country.

MANASQUAN, N.J., Nov. 1.--The Prohibitionists of this place held their last mass meeting of the campaign this evening. The Rev. A. A. Phelps, of Lima, N.Y., addressed a large audience from Dickson Wainwright's porch.
SANDUSKY, Ohio, Nov.1.--Henry Winkler, aged 26, a farmer living in Huron Township, this county, was killed to-day near here by jumping from a moving train.

Policeman Wimmer, of the Sixth Precinct, was complainant in the Tombs Police Court yesterday against 82 men and 80 women, who had been captured in a raid made by Capt. McCullagh on the stale beer dives in Mulberrystreet in the nighborhood of "the Bend." They were a most disreputable looking lot, samples of the lowest depths of degradation to which the human being can desend.

FORT WORTH, Texas, Nov. 1.--Tarrant County will be the great battleground of the State to-morrow. The excitement is intense and scores of citizens are electioneering. The city was the birthplace of what is known as the "Dark Lantern" ticket, and the worst demagogues in the State are here plying their vocation.

FORT WORTH, Texas, Nov. 1.--The engineering corps for the Brownwood Road took the field this morning and has surveyed several miles. A locomotive has been purchased and is now on the way here, and two shipments of rails have been made to New-Orleans for the road, Grading will begin Wednesday.

The extensions of the St. Joseph and Grand Island Railroad, in Nebraska, are being pushed rapidly. Yesterday was the last day on which the holders of Grand Island Railroad stock had the right to subscribe to shares of the new company which is to build the extensions.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 1.--The sloop Adelaide, reported in THE TIMES yesterday as having been seen capsized off Brenton's Reef, was found to-day by a passing steamer and towed to Tiverton. Nothing has been heard from the Captain or his wife or from the sailor who were known to be on board.

The testimony of the train hands is also to the effect that either Mrs. Winter or Mrs. Latz had with her a little girl about 10 years of age.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1.--It is practically decided that Miss Rosina Vokes will not appear upon the stage again this season, if ever, and that the tour of her company will be given up after the Buffalo engagement. That will necessitate the canceling of the engagement at the Standard Theatre in New-York. Miss Vokes's condition is a source of considerable anxiety to her friends.

CAIRO, Nov. 1.--It is officially announced that the English Government is determined to maintain public safety in Egypt and not to leave the country to disorder and possibly to a fresh and disastrous revolution.

Ladies who are fond of looking at beautiful carpets will do well to visit the large store of John James Dobson, Nos. 40 and 42 West Fourteenth-street. For eight-years the firm has occupied the big six-story building at this point, and that their patrons have been perfectly satisfied in the past is apparent from the busy scene on the spacious floors that is observed every pleasant morning and afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1.--Col. Henry C. Wood, who will succeed Col. valkmar as Assistant Adjutant-General at the War Department, has arrived in this city. Col. Valkmar will leave for his post as Assistant Adjutant-General in the Department of the Columbia about the latter part of the month.
TORONTO, Nov. 1.--Charles Stern and Max Stern have been sent to jail for 10 days each for assaulting Editor McLean, of the World, with a rawhide. They were denied the privilege of an appeal.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 1.--A telegram received at the Harvard College Observatory announces the discovery of a new asteroid (No. 261) by Prof. C.H.F. Peters, of Clinton, N.Y. Its position at the time of discovery was, Oct. 31, 14 hours, Washington mean time; right ascension, 1 hour 57 minutes; declination north 4 29'13"; daily motion, in right ascension, 57"; in declination south, 4'. It is of the eleventh magnitude.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1.--The visible supply of grain on Oct. 30, as reported by the Secretary of the Chicago Board of Trade, is as follows: Wheat, 56,154 bushels; corn, 13,097,000; oats, 5,409,000; rye, 467,000; barley, 2,232,000. This shows an increase of 780,000 bushels of wheat. of 50,000 bushels of oats, and 31,000 bushels of rye, and a decrease of 339,000 bushels of corn and 71,000 bushels of barley.

District Attorney Martine yesterday appointed H.D. Parker to succeed Mr. Coman as chief clerk of the District Attorney's office, the appointment to take effect Nov. 15. Mr. Coman, however, will remain in the office until Dec. 1 to straighten out his work and give his successor points. Mr. Parker is a County Democrat, and was Collector Hedden's private secretary, which position be now holds under Collector Magone. It is said he has accepted the position.

BOSTON, Nov. 1.--The cabled announcement of the engagement of James Russell Lowell to the Dowager Lady Lyttleton appears to be a myth. It is indignantly denied by the friends of Mr. Lowell in this city, and Dr. Joseph Burnett, father of Edward Burnett, the latter a son-inlaw of Mr. Lowell, told THE TIMES's correspondent this evening that the report had not the slightest foundation in fact.

The most interesting incident of last evening's popular concert--the third of the season-- at the Metropolitan Opera House was the debut in this city of Miss Laura Moore, a young American, who distinguished herself a twelvemonth ago by carrying off the first prize for singing at the anuual concours of the Paris Conservatory.

CITY OF MEXICO, Nov. 2, via Galveston. --A discusston is going on in the newspapers and in political circles regarding the project for a constitutional amendment extending the Presidential term from four to six years and making the President eligible for re-election.

For several weeks past Mr. Leonard Jerome has directed his efforts toward restoring the social prestige of Jerome Park. The restoratives applied were a lunch and dance at the clubhouse, a band of music stationed at the extreme northern end of the grand stand, and an amalgamation of amateur and professional racing.

MILWAUKEE. Wis., Nov. 2.--The Republicans have carried the State by 15,000 majority. The fight has practically been made on the riot issue, and is a triumph for law and order, and an indorsemont of the prompt and vigorous action taken by Gov. Rusk to sup-- press the riots in this city in May last.

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 2.--The day has been fine and a large vote has been polled. There seems to have been much scratching of tickets throughout the State. It is not probable that any definite results will be known until to-morrow. This is especially the case in the Fffth Congressional District, where Anderson, the present incumbent, is running independently.

Mr. HEWITT has been elected Mayor by a vote of over 90,000 in a total vote of nearly 220,000. At this writing the returns have been received from every election district except one, and the figures stand thus: HEWITT, 90,296; GEORGE, 67,699; ROOSEVELT, 60,392; WARDWELL, 574--a total of 218,961.

LONDON, Nov. 2.--At Brighton to-day the race for the Autumn Handicap was won by Mr. J. Davis's 3-year-old Sandpiper by a neck. Mr. W. Gregory's 6-year-old Chicard was second and the Duke of Beaufort's 3-year-old Winter Cherry a bad third. There were nine starters. The betting before the start was seven to one against Sandpiper, ten to one each against Chicard and Winter Cherry, and nine to two against Lord Londonderry's 5-year-old Cambusmore, the favorite.

Andrew went out of Boston over 8,000 votes ahead, and returns from all over the State show small, but steady, Democratic gains. August Brentano, the well known stationer, who for many years lived in this city, died yesterday in Chicago. The body will be brought to this city for burial The day of the funeral has not been decided.

Returns from all the counties in this State gives Rufus W. Peckham for Associate Judge of the Court of Appeals an apparent plurality of 10,252. These figures of course are subject to revision, but it is improbable that the official vote will materially change the result indicated.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Nov. 3.--The Ackerman Hotel, a two-story frame building at Loogootee, Ind., was burned at 3 o'clock this morning, and three men perished in the flames. They were forgotten in the excitement until it was too late to save them.

BELFAST, NOV. 3.--Mr. Sexton has been declared elected to Parliament for the Western Division of Belfast, the petition of Mr. Haslett, the Conservative candidate, to have the seat vacated on the ground of bribery having been denied.

When Cappa's Band struck up the opening march, "The Queen of Autumn," at the chrysathemum exhibition yesterday afternoon, the flowers were surrounded by a throng of ladies that left little space unoccupied.

PANAMA, Nov. 3.--The Government recently sold at public competition the exclusive privilege of selling opium in Panama for five years. The privilege, or monopoly, was purchased by a Chinaman named Yip Cang Jung for $16,000 per annum, payable annually in advance. A portion of the proceeds is to go toward paying off the debt due by the State, and the balance is to be appropriated to the hospitals.

The completed returns of the election of Tuesday in this city, while they present some slight alterations in the figures, do not change the result in any way. The two districts missing in yesterday morning's table add 730 to the already heavy vote for Mayor, making it 219,436. Hewitt has 90,456; George, 67,930; Roosevelt, 60,474.

VIRGINIA, Nev., Nov. 3.--Returns are coming in slowly, but enough is known to warrant the statement that the entire Republican State ticket is elected, including the legislative ticket. This gives the Republicans the next United States Senator, to succeed Senator James G. Fair.

DUBLIN, Nov. 3.--Adelina Patti is indisposed, and the concert which she was to have given to-night was accordingly postponed. She is suffering from the effects of seasicikness experienced while crossing the Channel. She was to have opened Gunn's new hall, and the concert was to have been the first of her tour under the management of Henry E. Abbey.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 3.--Unofficial returns of yesterday's election from all parts of the State, except five small county districts, elect Benjamin T. Biggs (Dem.) Governor by a majority of 6,179 over James R. Haffrecker, the temperance Reform candidate.

BOSTON, Nov. 3.--In a total vote of about 240,000 Ames's plurality for Governor is 9,288 and Brackett's plurality 5,331. Of the Congressional delegation almost complete returns give the Republicans eight Congressmen and the Democrats four.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3.--The four Pinkerton guards charged with being accessory to the shooting of Terence Begley during the recent strike at the stock yards were released to-day on bail.

ROCHESTER, Nov. 3.--The boating interests of the State canals have employed a leading lawyer of Rochester to look after their interests relative to the old piers of the Poughkeepsie bridge. It has been discovered that the charter of the Poughkeepsie Bridge Company expires this Winter, and the renewal of it by the Legislature will meet with opposition from the boating interests.
BERLIN, Nov. 3.--Mme. Gerster-Gardini has become insane in consequence, it is reported, of loss of voice after her recent confinement.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 3.--There has been no change in the situation in this State. The entire State Democratic ticket has been elected and the independent and Republican county tickets in Berkeley, Hampton, and Chesterfield have been defeated.

Tuesday's election in Brooklyn and Kings County resulted in the election by the Democrats of all their county and city officers, 10 Assemblymen out of the 12 to which the county is entitled, 3 out of 4 Congressmen, and 1 more than half the 17 Supervisors. The Congressional victory may be still further extended when the official canvass in the Third District is made up.

NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 3.--William B. Lamb, C.B. Langley, and George W. Beach, prominent Republicans of this city, appeared before the Grand Jury to-day and asked for the indictment of the entire Electoral Board of the city.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 3.--The returns received up to midnight make no change in the Congressmen wired last night as elected throughout this State.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3.--"I was for Henry George," said Col. R.G. Ingersoll to-day, "and before leaving New-York I paired in order to save my vote. I hoped that George would be elected. He wants to do something.

The British have a serious task before them in subduing Burmah. There is little doubt that the revolt in Myingyan is increasing, and that a strong expedition must be sent to both that and the Memboo district.

RONDOUT, Nov. 3.--The towboat Connecticut, of the Schuyler Line, of Albany, burst its boiler to-day, near Coxsackie. A fireman named Matthew Quinn, of Coxsackie, was instantly killed, and a deck hand named Brown, was seriousty injured. The escaping steam enveloped the boat and poured out of the smokestack in dense columns. The report of the explosion was heard on shore and created much excitement.

Joseph Seaich, who has been engaged in the livery business in this city for over half a century, died at his residence, No. 47 East Thirty first street, yesterday morning. Mr. Seaich was born in London in 1811.

The advance which the Russians have been making of late in the breeding of roadsters was evidenced at the horse show yesterday afternoon when the turnout of Mr. Greger, Secretary of the Russian Legation, consisting of a droska drawn by a remarkably handsome black stallion, made its appearance in the ring.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Nov. 3.--While taking part in a very noisy demonstration of delight to-day over the sweeping Republican victory in Ohio and elsewhere, William W. Lawton, a leading lumber dealer, dropped dead of heart disease. He was an ardent Republican.

By an act of the Legislature passed last May it was provided that appeals from decisions of the City Court, General Term, in certain cases should go directly to the Court of Appeals, instead of going intermediately to the General Term of the Court of Common Pleas.

CONCORD, N.H., Nov. 3.--The latest returns indicate the election of L.F. McKinney (Dem.) in the First District and Jacob H. Gallinger (Rep.) in the Second District. Congressman Haynes conceded McKinney's election. This is a gain of one for the Democrats.

The largest lot of Continental currency presented to the United States Treasury within the memory of present officials was presented for redemption yesterday by Mr. Elliott Seawell, of No. 1,605 O-street, northwest. Frequently small sums of these Continental notes are presented ...

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 3.--The vote in this city is not yet one-third counted, and it will not be completed before to-morrow night. From the returns thus far received it would seem as if Swift (Rep.) was elected Governor by from 3,000 to 5,000 majority.
The polling of nearly 68,000 votes for HENRY GEORGE has surprised even those who did not make the common mistake of declaring his following to be made up of cranks and Anarchists.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3.--The extra meeting of the National Jockey Club opened to-day. The weather was clear and pleasant. The attendance was very large and the track was in excellent condition. The winners were Telie Doe, Relax, Boaz, Frank Ward, and Tennessee.

LONDON, Nov. 4.--The Standard, commenting on the unexpected number of votes cast to Henry George, asks New-York what it will do with the fact that one voter in three backs the opinion that the French revolution is about to be repeated in America, and says "such polls look as if the great nation was playing with edged tools with a recklessness dangerous for others than clildren."
The Supreme Court of Arkansas has decided that a Second Adventist cannot lawfully ignore the Sabbath because he observes Satur day as his Sabbath.

OTTAWA, Nov. 3.--Sir John Lister Kaye is here after a trip to the Northwest. He has been inspecting the lands along the Canadian Pacific as the representative of a syndicate that intends to take up lands along the line of that road, between Moose Jaw and Calgarry, to establish breeding stations for Clydesdale draught horses, sheep, and cattle. He thinks that the soil, grasses, and water of that section are excellent for the purpose mentioned.

Abram S. Hewitt passed the day yesterday in his office at No. 17 Burling-slip, receiving the few callers and answering the many telegrams and letters of congratulation received by him. Nearly all his Democratic associates in Congress sent him congratulatory telegrams, ...

RICHMONT, Va., Nov. 3.--Fuller returns from the election for 10 members of Congress in this state yesterday confirms the defeat sustained by the Democrats indicated in these dispatches last night. The Republicans have carried six out of the ten districts. This gives them a gain of four.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 3.--The election in this State on Tuesday afforded many surprises to the politicians of both parties. One of the most notable was the earnestness and honesty with which the Knights of Labor stood by their nominees in the various legislative districts where they had candidates in the field.

ST. PETERSBURG, Nov. 3.--The Journal de Saint-Petersbourg says the statement in yesterday's Official Messenger containing Gen. Kaulbars's reply to the Bulgarian Government that he would quit Bulgaria if another Russian was molested indicates the limit of Russia's patience.

GALVESTON, Texas, Nov. 3.--Returns received to-day and to-night from the 11 Congressional districts of Texas, although still incomplete, verify the election of the Democratic delegation, as previously telegraphed. Returns tonight from the fifth District place the election of ...

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 3.--The Republican plurality on the State ticket will range from 12,000 to 15,000. It is found that Robinson,the candidate for Secretary of State, suffered seriously by using traded for votes on Congressional candidates.

The schooner Anna B. Hutcheson, Capt. Zeeluf, which rescued a portion of the crew of the Spanish bark Tres Auroras, off the Tortugas, on Oct. 14, arrived here yesterday. The Hutcheson, which brought a cargo of ivory nuts from Aspinwall, was caught in a terrific hurricane at 6 A.M. on Oct. 10.

WHEELING, West Va., Nov. 3.--The Secand Congressional District must be kept in the doubtful column for at least another 24 hours, as the returns are too meagre to give any decisive result. Both Flick (Rep.) and Wilson ...

While of course regretting that a majority of his fellow-citizens did not ago fit to elect him their Mayor, Theodore Roosevelt accepts their decision in the matter with good grace and has nothing in asperity to say against those Republicans who saw fit to give their suffrages to Mr. Hewitt or Mr. George.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Nov. 3.--The annual meeting of the Directors of the Iron Steamboat Company was held at the Central Hotel here to-day. The report of President Samuel Carpenter showed the affairs of the company to be in good condition.

Miss Lena Potter, daughter of Assistant Bishop Henry C. Potter, was married yesterday afternoon in Grace Church to Mr. Winthrop Cowdin, son of the late Elliot C. Cowdin. Grace Church has seldom been the scene of a more largely attended wedding.

BOSTON, Nov. 3.--The races of the Grand Eastern Circuit were continued at Mystic Park to-day, the 2:32 and 2:27 classes being trotted. In the former Maggie Miller took the first heat, and many thought she should have won the race. White Oak, however, took the next three heats, winning first money. In the 2:27 class race White Socks won handily in three straight heats.

NEW-HAVEN, Nov. 3.--The following officers of the Yale Athletic Association were elected to-night: President--W.H. Seward, of Auburn, N.Y.,'88; Vice-President--C.B. Berger, '88, S., Denver, Gol.; Secretary and Treasurer-- H.F. Walker, Detroit, Mich., '89; Executive Committee--C.H. Sherrill, Washington, D.C., '89, and W.F. Bull, Newport, R.I., '88, S.

TAHILEQUAH, Indian Territory, Nov. 3.-- The Cherokee Council met yesterday. Both President B. Bell, of the Senate, and Speaker Hawk, of the Council, were in their chairs. There are 50 members of the lower house and 18 of the upper house.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Nov. 3.--The majority of Romeis in the Tenth Ohio District will be about 1,500. Frank Hurd accents his defeat gracefully, and left to-day for the mineral springs at Mount Clemens, Mich., as he is suffering from a rheumatic attack. From them he goes to NewYork.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., Nov. 3.--The eastward-bound St. Louis limited, on the Erie Railroad, this morning ran into a party of Italian laborers engaged in ballasting at Hawkins. They had stepped on the east-bound track to avoid a west-bound freight train which was then passing. Two of them mere instantly killed and two others fatally injured.

Since the price of New-Jersey Central Railroad stock took its big slump downward, a fortnight or so ago, going from 63 down below 50, there have been a good many theories afloat to account for this marked depreciation in market value.

Deacon White and his political mentor, Mr. Daggett, had little to say yesterday. They met in a restaurant near the Brooklyn City Hall at lunch time, and then Mr. White disappeared. There was good reason why Mr. White should wish to hide his diminished head. The police returns shaved his plurality from 143 to 60 in the banner Republican District of Kings County, ...

NEWPORT, Nov. 3.--Charles Engle, of Chicago, under indictment for burglary, was brought into court this morning, and, retracting his plea of not guilty, pleaded nolo contendere to the charge of larceny, and was sentenced to the county jail for six months. The light sentence provokes much comment.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 3.--The plurality of Gen. Beaver, (Rep.,) for Governor, over Black, (Dem.,) with four counties yet to be heard from, is 49,240. N. Hall (Dem.) is elected to Congress in the Twenty-sixth District and William L. Scott (Dem.) in the Twenty-seventy District. This leaves the delegation 20 Republicans and 8 Democrats.

BUENOS AYRES, Nov. 3, via Galveston.-- The republic of Uruguay is apparently passing through a political crisis. It is reported that President Santos is irritated because his Ministers, Senors Herrana, Tortega, Terra, and Herez, have resigned, refusing to sign a stringent law against the press.

OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 3. Additional returns to-day from the First Congressional District conclusively prove the election of John A. McShane, Democrat. Bolting Republicans and a liberal use of money have elected the first Democratic Congressman from Nebraska. There is no change in the other Congressional districts.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 3.--The patronage at the disposal of Governor-elect Green during the first year of his administration will be unusually great. Most of his appointments are subject to confirmation by the Senate. He will nominate a Secretary of State to succeed Henry ...

MONTPELIER, Vt., Nov. 3.--The House of Representatives to-day passed the bill granting suffrage to women by a vote of 135 to 82; also the bill making the salary of Judges of the Supreme Court $3,000 instead of $2,500 per year.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 3.--In the Ninth Congressional District John M. Glover has a majority of 62 over Nathan Frank, (Rep.,) and the certificate will probably be issued to Glover.

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 3.--Gov. Martin will have a majority of from 30,000 to 35,000, judging from the returns already received. The Congressional delegation is solidly Republican and is made up as follws; First District, C.N. Morrill; Second, E.H. Funston; Third, B. W. Perkins; Fourth, Thomas Ryan; Fifth, John A. Anderson; Sixth, E.J. Turner; Seventh, S.R. Peters.

LEEDS, Nov. 3.--The meeting of the Liberal Federation was held here to-day. Mr. Kitson, the President, was occupied the chair, read a report, showing that despite the secession of Mr. Joseph Chamberlain and his followers the association had increased by 100 branches. A resolution declaring the confidence of the meeting in Mr. Gladstone was carried amid enthusiasm by acclamation.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 3.--Workmen are busily engaged in erecting a handsome mortuary chapel in the Island Cemetery for Mr. and Mrs. August Belmont, of New-York, who intend, when it is completed, to present it to the cemetery Trustees for any Christian mortuary services.

The latest returns from the counties of this State indicate that Rufus W. Peckham, for Judge of the Court of Appeals, has a plurality of 8,405. Partial returns of the vote for a Constitutional Convention show overwhelming majorities in its favor in most of the counties, but whether it has a majority of all the votes cast, as required by law, is still a matter of some doubt.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 3.--The returns thus far received make the Republicans quite in claiming the State by at least 3,000 majority, although Mr. McDonald does not concede it, and says that to-morrow's official returns will cut down the Republican gains and replace Indiana ...

ST. PAUL, Nov. 3.--The entire Republican State ticket has been elected in Minnesota by 10,000 to 13,000 majority. A.R. McGill, for Governor, runs behind the rest of the ticket somewhat. A.E. Rice, for Lieutenant-Governor.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3.--The French visitors, M. Bartholdi, M. de Lesseps, and their companions, numbering, 22 in all, reached Washington early this evening in a special car attached to the limited express, and proceeded at once to the Arlington, where they had engaged rooms. At dinner they entertained Count Sala, the Marquis de Chambrun, and M. de Boevre, of the French Legation. They are to pay their respects to the President at noon to-morrow.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 3.--Full returns from the State do not change the result as announced last night. Five Democratic and one Republican Congressmen were elected. In the First District Charles H. Gibson (Dem.) received ...

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 3.--Returns received give the Republicans great encouragement and secure them the Legislature by a good working majority. The Senate will stand Republicans 14, Democrats 10. Last your it was Republicans 13, Democrats 11.

VICKSBURG, Miss., Nov. 3.--Mississippi sends a solid Democratic delegation to the Fiftieth Congress. Advices to-day show Democratic gains in every district except the Second, but J.B. Morgan will be elected by a handsome majority. Ex-Speaker John R. Lynch is overwhelmingly defeated in the Sixth District. His canvass was a quiet one and only announced on the 30th nlt. An extremely light vote was polled throughout the State.

The biography of Lincoln by Col. Hay and Mr. Nicolay, naturally takes its place as the leading articles in the current number of the Century, this first installment treating of "Lincoln as Pioneer."

The Brooklyn Magazine has taken a vote of its readers upon "the ablest American newspaper." The American is favored with 43 votes--more than all the other Baltimore papers put together. The result of the vote gives THE NEW-YORK TIMES the honor of being the leader in American journalism.

"Taken from Life" will be next week's play at the Windsor, with Miss Phosa McAllister in the principal part.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Nov. 3.--James S. Roberts, lately bookkeeper for a prominent pork packing firm here, was found dead on the mountain near here this afternoon by a boy who was hunting. He was hanging to a tree and had shot himself through the head. It is supposed that financial embarrassment caused him to commit suicide. Roberts was well known and highly respected.

At a meeting of the Board of Education yesterday afternoon, Commissioner Lummis read a letter received from Miss Jane P. Cattell, General Secretary of the Industrial Education Association. No. 21 University-place.

Mr. George W. Davis, the Norfolk machinist who died on Sunday last, at No. 526 Hartford-avenue, from paralysis, superinduced by an injury of the spinal column, was buried yesterday by the Knights of Labor.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 4.--Mr. John Jarrett, Secretary of the Tin Plate Association, has returned from Illinois, where he has been conducting the campaign in the Eighteenth District against Col. Morrison. He received large numbers of congratulatory telegrams all day over Mr. Morrison's defeat.
There was an election Wednesday night for Trustees of the Bethel African Methodist Episcopal Church, on Sullivan-street, of which the Rev. William B. Derrick is Pastor.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 4.--The new steel guns were tested at the naval ordnance proving ground to-day with good results, under the supervision of Capt. Howell and Lieuts. Meigs and Knight.

W.A.A. Carsey, who was employed by the Hewitt campaign managers to try and split up the labor vote in the interest of the Democratic Mayoralty candidate, has been suspended from his position of Inspector in the Department of Public Works by order of Gen. Newton.

MONTREAL, Nov. 4.--John F. Hoke, the absconding Cashier of the Merchants' National Bank of Peoria, was arrested here at a late hour last night and is being held awaiting the arrival of the officers of the bank. His offense dates as far back as May last, when a deficiency of $5,000 was discovered.

Tilghman, appellant, vs. William Proctor et al., and No. 895-- William Proctor et al. appellant, vs. Richard A. Tilghman.--Argument continued by R.H. Parkinson and William M. Ramsey for Proctor et al. and by George Harding for Tilghman.

At the meeting of the Commissioners of Emigration yesterday, a communication was received from the Treasury Department approving the board's resolution authorizing its President to make the necessary expenditures in order to return indigent immigrants subject to legal limitations. The communication stated that a written protest against the measure had been received from Commissioner Stephenson.

The American Institute of Christian Philosophy held its regular monthly meeting last evening at No. 4 Winthrop-place. There were about 50 people present, among them being Theodore C. Cone, the Georgia lawyer who has set out to puncture Ingersoll's philosophy.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 4.--The irrepressible Salvation Army Captain, Jennie Wilson, has bobbed up serenely in the Union County Court once more. The case of the State against Mrs. Berger, the name the fair Jennie now bears, was moved by Prosecutor Wilson this afternoon.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 4.--The boiler of a locomotive on the Texas and Pacific Railroad exploded this morning near Davis Station, killing Engineer George De Haven and a brakeman named Given. Conductor Charles Norton was severely injured.
BERLIN, Nov. 4.--Under Secretary Jacobi has been appointed Secretary of State for the Imperial Treasury.

The performance of "The Acharnians," a comedy of Aristophanes, in the original Greek by the students of the University of Pennsylvania has been definitely settled for Friday evening, Nov. 19, at the Academy of Music. A large number of yachtsmen were present yesterday noon at Richard Montgomery's auction rooms, No. 106 Wall-street, to see what the sloop yacht Atlantic, which was built to defend the America's Cup, would bring at auction.
NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 4.--The Coroner held an inquest to-day upon the body of Kirkpatrick, who was shot in the Crescent saloon on Tuesday by Dr. T.G. Ford, of Shreveport.

The exhibition of M. de Munkacsy's large painting, "Christ Before Pilate," has been postponed until about Nov. 13, when it will be shown in the Tabernacle on West Twenty-thirdstreet.

Gen. Corse says, in regard to the Boston Postmastership, that he does not intend to take that office until Jan. 1, at any rate, and that then his decision in regard to accepting or declining it will be made known.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Nov. 4.--Ground is to be broken at once for the erection of a new Opera House on Emory-avenue. It is to be 100 by 150 feet, and three stories high, and will eclipse any opera house in the State. It is also to be entirely fire proof and fitted up with all modern improvements. The building is to be finished by February.

LOUISVILLE, Nov. 4.--Kentucky is busily engaged just at present looking around for her 40,000 Democratic majority, which became badly displaced on Tuesday last, and in recovering from the surprises of that day. The best informed politicians in the party had reckoned on a solid delegation as probable, with some fighting to be done in the Third, Ninth, and Eleventh Districts.

NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 4.--The Grand Jury to-day refused to indict the Electoral Board of this city for refusing to appoint as judges of election parties recommended by the Republican Executive Committee, holding that the board had full power to act in the matter.

WARSAW, N.Y., Nov. 4.--Orrila Weed, a buxom, comely young girl, just of age, employed for some three years as a domestic in the family of Dr. E. Mattson, shot herself in the head to-day at about 4 P.M. with a revolver.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4.--The strike at the stock yards took a new and perhaps very serious turn to-night. To-morrow will probably decide whether there is to be a collapse or a protracted and more general struggle.

"The Future of Canada" was the title of a paper read before the members of the Canadian Club, at No. 12 East Twenty-ninth-street, last night, by Edmund Collins. Sir Roderick Cameron presided. Mr. Collins saw one of three things for Canada's future--federation, annexation, or national independence.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 4.--The moonshiners or illicit distillers of the Tennessee mountains are a rough set of people, but not half so bad as they are constantly represented to be, particularly in Northern papers. True they are constantly breaking the internal revenue laws, but not always with a spirit of outlawry.

READING, Penn., Nov. 4.--The puddlers at the Naomi Rolling Mill, at Naomi, this county, struck this morning. They were getting $3.75 per ton and wanted $3.80, a difference of 5 cents. It is probable that the matter will be compromised.

LONDON, Nov. 4.--Dispatches from Cabul say that the Ghilzais have surprised and annihilated a regiment of Duranis who were going to Cabul. The scene of the massacre was Mukhur, 70 miles south of Ghuzui. The insurrection started by the Ghilzai tribe continues to spread.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 4.--At 9:47 o'clock to-night a large and beautiful meteor burst over New-Haven. It was near the zenith, and after a flash of blinding intensity two long streamers of light spread out stretching across 20 degrees. They were visible for over four minutes, gradually fading out of sight. For size and brilliancy nothing like this meteor has been seen here for years.

SHELBYVILLE, Ill., Nov. 4.--A fierce forest fire is raging in Holland Township, this county. An area five miles long and three miles wide has already been desolated. The entire farming population have been fighting the flames 24 hours, but all efforts seem futile. Many barns, fences, and fields of corn have been destroyed. The loss of property is estimated at many thousands of dollars.

NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 4.--The trial of George M. Bain, Jr., Cashier of the defunct Exchange National Bank, commenced in the United States Circuit Court to-day, Judges Bond and Hughes presiding. The court room was crowded throughout the day. The indictment against Bain charges him with misapplying funds of the bank to his own personal use, and with overdrawing funds to the amount of $104,713.84. The trial will last several days.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 5.--Yesterday noon at Indiantown, Williamsburg Count, Sentry Brown, a negro, murderously assaulted Capt. Brown, white, aged 70, a peaceable citizen. The Sheriff sent a posse to the scene of disturbance.

The silent vote in this country is of more importance than politicians are willing to admit. It observes parties with a calm and penetrating gaze, and, having no axes to grind, can throw itself into a wavering scale with telling effect. It does not call itself independent. It is sometime distinctively Republican or Democratic. It is, however, never blindly partisan. This is the vote which helps make what are called tidal waves in politics.

HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., Nov. 6.--Last night the steam canalboat Saturn, loaded with iron and paper stock, was burned to the water's edge off Peck's Dock, at this place. The crew, three in number, were rescued.

UTICA, N.Y., Nov. 7.--In the suit of the town of German Flats against the Supervisors of Herkimer County in regard to the support of its pauper insane, Judge Vann, of the Superior Court, has filed his decision dismissing the writ, and holding that each town is by law charged with the expense of maintaining its indigent insane. This is an important decision, as it is the first judicial interpretation of the statute on the subject.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 7.--A sensation has developed in the discussion of the affairs of the Marietta and North Georgia Road. The builders of this road are Northern men, and they have been harassed ever since they started work by annoying suits.
--M. de Lesseps has in press in Paris a book about his mission to Rome in 1849, in which he gives an account of his relations with Mazzini.

PARIS, Texas, Nov. 7.--Information has just reached here of the killing of Deputy United States Marshal Campbell, in the Indian Territory last night. Campbell had been stationed on Red River, just across the river from the town of Arthur, which is in Texas.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 7.--Advices from the Creek Indian Nation are to the effect that the Council there has instructed its delegation to the next Congress to insist on the Government receiving back the money--15 cents per acre--it paid for the Oklahoma country to settle friendly Indians on.

SAN JOSE, Cal., Nov 7.--At a late hour last night Owen O. Leggett, an artist, the son of wealthy parents residing in England, was shot and instantly killed here by John Clark, 20 years old, employed on a ranch in the mountains near Madrone.

I gave some particulars a few weeks ago of the large amount of property which had been extracted from Bulgaria by Prince Alexander, who arrived at Sofia penniless except for a sum of money which was advanced to him by the late Emperor of Russia.
The Emperor William returned here this afternoon from Blankenburg, apparently none the worse for yesterday's exertions.
The recent death of the Hon. Mason W. Tappan, of New-Hampshire, calls to mind the fact that less than 30 years works almost an entire revolution in the men who compose the American Congress.
The mountain castles of the late King of Bavaria were closed for the season on Friday week. The entrance fees during the ten weeks that they have been open to the public amounted to upward of 10,000.
The official count makes Aaron Jones his open successor by 1 vote. In 1842 Lot Day, Sr., was the Democratic candidate for Sheriff and William Cosgrove was the Whig candidate.

During Saturday night's terrible storm John Williams, of No. 231 West Twenty-secondstreet, was noticed by an officer tenderly leading a well dressed but very intoxicated individual along East Seventeenth-street toward the river.

The woman suffragists are getting ready for a great bazaar in Boston. They expect that it will attract great crowds of visitors and put many thousands of dollars in the treasury, to be drawn upon for the Winter campaign.

In the American of Nov. 2 there was published an account of the death of George Davis, a machinist from Norfolk, Va., who had been kindly cared for by the Knights of Labor in this city until death came.

ST. PAUL, Nov. 7.--There is nothing new in the political situation, except that the Democrats have given up blustering and virtually admit McGill's election by a majority something above 1,000. The Republicans claim McGill will have not less than 2,000 majority and possibly 3,000. What few returns have been received to-day are favorable to McGill. The official canvass will be made Monday, and until then nothing more definite than the above can be stated.
DUBLIN, Nov. 7.--At a League meeting at Skibbereen to-day Messrs. O'Hea, Tanner, and Kenney, members of the House of Commons, advocated the United Ireland's programme.

SOFIA, Nov. 7.--M. Geschoff, Minister of Finance, has resigned. It is announced from St. Petersburg that the Czar intends to intrust the administration of Bulgaria to the Russian Senator Stojanowski until a Prince has been legally elected.

There is no crying here over the defeat of Burleigh. Our Republican friends were only waiting for an opportunity to "knife" him. He has been a chronic "kicker" always, and now the "chickens have come home to roost." Of course I supported him, but it was like an emetic.

John Mattow, a colored man, who lived at No. 652 East One Hundred and Fifty ninthstreet, had a fierce quarrel with his wife Saturday night about a table which needed repairs.

The Emperor William is beginning to display in rather eccentric ways those economical tendencies which have brought so much ridicule upon many members of the Hohenzollern family. The Emperor has taken of late to using a second time all the envelopes of the letters and documents which reach him in shoals, and he audited the accounts of his trip to Ems and Gastein with unwonted vigor.

Wallack's Theatre was crowded to the doors last night, and many persons who desired to pass Sunday elsewhere than in church were turned away from the doors after all the seats had been sold and all the standing room occupied.

MANASQUAN, N.J., Nov. 7.--J.B. Sutherland, at one time prominent in New-York City and throughout the United States as "Bob Hart," the minstrel, delivered an able temperance address to a well filled house at the Salvation army Temple here this afternoon. The Reform Club has secured Mr. Sutherland's services to hold a series of revival meetings here during this week.
MIDDLETOWN, Nov. 7.--Malignant diphtheria is reported as raging in Dingman Township, Pike County, Penn. It broke out in the family of Charles Garvolle, a French farmer.

The fight which has been going on during the past five months between the stockholders of the West Point Terminal Company and the Richmond and Danville Railroad has ended in favor of the Terminal stockholders.
James E. Wallace, a deserter from the United states [steamship Jamestown, was arrested at Newark last evening. He lives at No 557 West Forty-fourth-street, this city.
Sir Alexander T. Galt, of Montreal, is at the Brevoort House. Civil Engineer A.G. Menocal, United States Navy, is at the New-York Hotel.
Two instances of contemptible meanness have just been brought to light. Five visitors at Colwyn Bay went out in a boat and were caught in the gale.

PORT JERVIS, Nov. 7.--Five years ago Charles Menner, a prominent citizen of Honesdale, Wayne County, Penn., purchased a fruit farm at Toms River, N.J., and removed thither with his wife. The investment proved disastrous, and last Spring Menner sold his farm.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 7.--The two Pinkerton detectives who secured evidence against the liquor dealers while ostensibly engaged in selling rugs arrived on the steamer Pilgrim from Boston via Fall River this evening.

READING Penn., Nov. 7.--Miss Amelia Auge, a good looking young lady of 18, residing on Oley-street, has had an admirer living next door in the person of Mr. John Spears.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 7.--Nathan Haskins, 21 years old, was fatally shot by William Eaton at Warren, R.I., last night in an affray about a woman. Haskins appears to have been the aggressor.
BLACK RIVER FALLS, Wis., Nov. 7.--Congressman Price for the past few weeks has been confined to his house, and was unable to take any part in the recent campaign.
CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 7.--A moderately strong shock of earthquake was felt here at about 11:04 o'clock to-night.
PATERSON, N.J., Nov.7.--When the sexton of the First Reformed Church, on Divisionstreet, entered it just before 7 o'clock to-night he was driven back by a dense body of smoke and flame.

William Walker, the young man who was taken to Chambers-Street Hospital in a mysterious manner on Saturday evening, died yesterday morning from the effects of the pistol shot wound in his back. CHICAGO. Nov. 7.--The Southern Passenger Association and the representatives of the lines in the Chicago and Ohio River pool were again in session yesterday considering the subject of Winter tourist rates to points in the south.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7.--It is stated on authority that the opinion given by the AttorneyGeneral as to the unavailability of called 3 per cent. bonds as a basis of national bank circulation will make no change in the attitude of the Treasury Department, because this opinion only confirmed the rule heretofore followed.

Land speculation at Bar Harbor has been carried on more extensively and more crazily than ever this Fall, it is said. Lots in certain parts of the village have doubled in value since last Spring; while buyers have sought lands in remote sections of the island which nobody supposed would come into the market for 10 years at least.
The medical committee appointed to watch over Stefano Merlatti, the new fasting man, during the 50 days he intends to remain without food, met on Tuesday at the Voltaire offices.
Mrs. Lucy Parsons, wife of the condemned Chicago Anarchist, put in an appearance yesterday at Krobel's Hall, Jersey City Heights.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 7.--Charles W. Banks, one of the Cashiers of the Wells-Fargo Express Company, has disappeared, leaving $20,000 unaccounted for on his books. He has been missing since the 1st inst., and is believed to be on his way to Canada, via Victoria, British Columbia. His wife is in New-York.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 7.--William P. Dowd, aged 50, tried to commit suicide to-day by taking a dose of arsenic, ammonia, and belladona. He was taken to the hospital, and lies there in a precarious condition. Eleven weeks ago his wife left him, and resulting despondency is given as the cause of the act.

BOSTON, Nov. 7.--President Cleveland has communicated to the authorities of Harvard College his desire that the degree of LL. D. should not be conferred upon him, and consequently it will not be.

BOSTON, Nov. 7.--The skies were bright and clear this morning when the third and most important day of Harvard's great celebration dawned, as though the sun, ashamed of his conduct on Saturday, had resolved to join in making the remaining festivities a success untempered by the weather.

Campbell, mezzo-soprano, and Mr. August Spanuth, pianist, lent their assistance as soloists, and the band that took part in the preceding entertainment played once more under Mr. Neuendorff's direction.

The statue of Liberty was not illuminated by electricity last evening. The moon, however, made the statue rather plainer from the Battery than it was last week with electric lights thrown on it. A large crowd of sightseers visited Bedlow's Island during the day.

Baird, director of the Smithsonian Institution and ex-officio head of the National Museum, in his annual estimates for the museum asks Congress to appropriate $250,000, with which to begin the construction of a new building, to flank the Smithsonian building on the west as the present museuu flanks it on the east.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 8.--Larry Donovan's condition has greatly improved to day, and his broken and displaced rib is giving him but little trouble. The physicians may allow him to go out to-morrow. No signs of pneumonia or pleurisy have yet appeared.

At the meeting of the Directors of the Iron Steamboat Company at the company's offices, Pier (new) No. 1, North River, yesterday afternoon, the board was organized by the election of Samuel Carpenter, President; E.V. Loew, VicePresident; Lewis May, Treasurer, and Walter F. Parker, Secretary.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8.--The Supreme Court today granted the motion made last week to advance and hear together the telephone cases--six in number--now on the docket, and ordered that they be set for argument as one case on Jan. 24 at the head of the calendar.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Nov. 8.--A cable dispatch from St. Pierre Miquelon says a large bark on fire was sighted about nine miles southwest of that place at noon to-day. She was drifting east. A tug was sent out and returned for towing gear. She reported the hull ablaze from stem to stern. The bark was loaded with lumber. The name was obliterated, but the word "Swansea" was visible. There were no signs of the crew.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Nov. 8.--The legislative situation remains practically unchanged. The Republican State Central Committee to-day received by express certified copies of the bond and oath of office of Representative-elect Meagher, of Vigo County, which fastens the question of ineligibility.
LEARY, Ga., Nov. 8.--Mr. James L. Boynton, of this town, comes into a fee of $1,000 in a peculiar manner. He had an aunt in Manchester, N.H., who made a will disposing of $50,000.
Fire broke out early this morning in the top story of the Washington-street extension of Everett's Vesey-street hotel. In the lower part of that wing was Drohan Powell's poultry and game store.
RENO, Nev., Nov. 8--A slight shock of earthquake was felt here this morning.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 8.--The Rhode Island and Connecticut Boundary Commission met in this city this afternoon and discussed the proposed change of line between the two States.

SHERMAN, Texas, Nov. 8.--Frank Reeche, a well known merchant of this city, committed suicide this morning by blowing his brains out. He was found dead in his store by his daughter. Reeche left a letter telling what disposition should be made of his property, and blaming his son and other parties with being the cause of his death. Reeche came here from Rochester, N.Y., and had large land interests in Texas.

HOUSTON, Texas, Nov. 8.--Rumors are current among the traffic men in this city that the Texas Traffic Association will soon be dissolved. The reasons assigned are the widening of the St. Louis, Arkansas and Texas gauge and the coming of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe into the State. Beyond doubt a great reduction of freight rates will ensue.

Stickney, President of the Minnesota and Northwestern Railroad Company, which controls the stock yards company, dined with Erastus Wiman, and disclosed to him the details of the enterprise.
