TIRNOVA, Nov. 8.--The reply of the Sobranje to the speech of the Regents declares that the Deputies fully recognize the superhuman efforts the Government are required to make to maintain the law and peace, and are confident that the same abnegation will be continued until the throne is refilled. It also says the Deputies are mindful that their duty is ...
TORONTO, Nov. 8.--To-night the Loyal and Patriotic Union presented a congratulatory address to Prof. Goldwin Smith in recognition of his services in England in behalf of the loyalist cause.

Alfred Guitte, of Oakland, Cal., arrived here overland from California yesterday to intercept his daughter, Marcella, 14 years old, who ran away from San Francisco on Oct. 15, with Frank Duhan, the keeper of a low saloon in San Francisco.

In obedience to the decision of the court-- which his in this case the Board of Visitors of Andover Seminary--Dr. DEXTER and his associates, who accuse five Andover Professors of breach of trust, have amended their charges by making them more specific.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 9.--There was a big array of prominent lawyers before Justice Peckham in the adjourned October Circuit this morning, on the occasion of the trial of the suit of the People against John O'Brien, as Receiver of of the Broadway surface Railway, the Mayor, , of the city of New-York, the Broadway and Seventh-avenue Railroad, the Twenty-third-Street ...

MONTREAL, Nov. 9.--Mr. Poitras, a well known druggist of Riviere des Prairies, was granted a new trial by the Court of Review this morning in the litigation in which he is engaged against the authorities of the Church of Ste. Anne du Bout de I'Ile.
John F. Andrew, of Boston, is at the Victoria Hotel.

A prominent merchant and financier of this city became insured in The Mutual Life Insurance Company of New-York in 1843. During 43 years he has paid his premiums in full, and his policy is a most remarkable example of the results attained in this company, as the following statement will show:

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 9.--Following the appointment of Edward Gallup as General Manager of the Lake Shore, a report was circulated here to-day that President Newell is to be relieved of part of his duties to become President of the Bee Line. The opinion of a few that the move was to give Mr. Newell increased leisure ...

SOFLA, Nov. 9.--Russian partisans at Slivna, headed by recently liberated officers, made an attempt to incite a rising to-day. The authorities, who had been previously warned, suppressed the attempt and arrested the plotters.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 9.--There is nothing particularly new in the legislative situation. It is generally conceded that the Vigo County Justice of the Peace is ineligible, and the Democrats are not in good humor at their stupidity in keeping him on the ticket when they knew of his disqualification.

NEW-OREANS, La., Nov. 9.--The TimesDemocrat publishes an account by an eye witness of the execution on Oct. 18 of Gen. E. Delgado, Lieut.-Col. Indalecio Garcia, Commander Miguel Cortez, and Lieut. Gabriel Loyant, who were shot at Comayagua for leading an expedition against Honduras.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 9.--Last week Mrs. Judge J. Witherspoon Smith passed her one hundredth birthday, which has duly celebrated some days later on the arrival of descendants from California for that purpose. She is of historic lineage. Her maiden name was Duer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9.--First Lieut. William E. Birkhimer, Third Artillery, has been detailed as Acting Judge-Advocate of the Department of the Columbia, and has been ordered to report in person to the commanding General of that Department. Leave of absence for four months has been granted Capt. Thomas H. Bradley, Twenty-first Infantry.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 9.--The session of the Belgian Chambers was opened to-day. King Leopold, in his speech opening the session, said that Belgium's foreign relations were excellent. The Antwerp Exhibition had shown that industry in the country had made progress.

Railroad earnings for October were reported in Wall-street yesterday as follows: East Tennessee, Virginia and Georgia, $438,950, an increase of $38,671; Chicago and West Michigan, $124,543, an increase of $5,903; Wisconsin Central, $144,429, an increase of $812; Flint and ...
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Nov. 9.--Drafts on New-York--Sight, 17 cents; telegraphic, 22 cents.

The question as to who will be Assemblyman from Suffolk County was decided yesterday by the official count. The certificate of election was awarded to Henry A. Reeves, the Democratic candidate. Mr. Reeves's majority is 10. Capt. Henry Huntting, who was Mr. Reeves's opponent, will not contest the matter in the courts.

Fernando de Martin, a gentleman with Castilian blood in his veins, as he testified yesterday before Surrogate Rollins, will not profit try the will of Ross Burns if Mrs. Sparr, the mother of Miss Burns, can prevent it. Senor de Martin occupied the witness stand for several hours yesterday.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 9.--In connection with the order issued in Brooklyn yesterday, on application of W.H. Olmstead, for a Receiver for the Buffalo, Rochester and Pittsburg Road Mr. Olmstead said to-night: "Following the suit in equity commenced by stockholders of the ...
Rutherford B. Hayes, of Toledo, son of ex-President R.B. Hayes, will be married next month to Miss Mary sherman, of Norwalk, Ohio.

William George Elder, for many years a detective connected with the police force, died at his home, No. 69 West Ninth-street, Monday evening. He had been ailing for about eight months, but had not been confined to his bed until last Saturday evening, when he was stricken with apoplexy. He remained in an unconscious condition until he died.
We are unable to agree with the view taken by Harper's Weekly that the "misfortune" of a Republican nomination for Mayor this year "was proved by the result."

HACKETTSTOWN, N.J., Nov. 9.--A terrible explosion occurred at 3 o'clock to-day in the mixing room of the Forsythe Powder Company, at the lower end of Lake Hopatcong. The company has half a dozen buildings. Two of the smaller ones were shattered, while a third was considerably damaged.

STANFORD, Ky., Nov. 9.--The first killing that has occurred in our village for the past four years took place yesterday at noon, when Mart Smith shot and killed Oc Smith. Mart came up Main-street with a shotgun, and was crossing Depot-street when he saw Oc standing 30 feet away.

BOSTON, Nov. 9.--The old-time members of famous Harvard crews tried conclusions with a crew of undergraduates on the Charles River this morning. Some of the most famous oarsmen Harvard has ever had were on the graduate crew, including Bancroft, '75; Smith, '79; Sawyer, '83; Pfeiffer, '79; Curtis, ...

Strangers find it difficult as a rule to give the Assistant Commissioner of Indian Affairs the title which is his by right, and which should not be allowed to fall into a state of innocuous desuetude. The stranger generally addresses him as Mr. Upshaw, but he is prompt to correct the uninformed, and to demand "General, if ...

BOSTON, Nov. 9.--The National Academy of Sciences began its Mutumnal session at the Institute of Technology this afternoon, and the meetings will be continued through the next three days. About 50 members of the organization were present this afternoon, among them Profs. S.P. Langley, F.S. Hunt, Alpheus Hyatt, ...

The organizors of the assembly district organizations of the Henry George party met last evening at No. 141 Eighth-street. They decided to call a convention to be composed of delegates from the Assembly district organizations in the ratio of one to each 200 men who voted for George.

LONDON, Nov. 9.--The Liverpool Autumn meeting began to-day. The race for the Knowsley Nursery Stakes, for 2-year-olds, was won by A.B. Carr's b.c. Quicksand by three-quarters of a length. Mr. Hungerford's Pierrepont was second, three-quarters of a length ahead of Mr. Melville's Norton, third. There were nine starters. The betting was three to one against Quicksand, five to one against Pierrepont, and ten to one against Horton. Time--1:05.

NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 9.--The alleged arproaching duel between Congressman George D. Wise, of Richmond, and Col. William Lamb, of Norfolk, is the subject of much talk here today. That there is bad feeling existing between the two gentlemen named there can be no doubt, and Wise's presence in the city to-day is very significant.
The North German Lloyd steamship Ems, which arrived yesterday from Bremen, brought $104,142 in gold coin.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 9.--Miss Winnie Davis, daughter of Jefferson Davis, arrived in Syracuse from New-York this evening in company with Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Emory, whose guest she will be until Jan. 1. Gen. Emory, father of Dr. Thomas Emory, was a personal ...

The General Missionary Committee of the Methodist Episcopal Church yesterday made the following appropriations for Annual Conferences: East Maine, $1,000; New-Hampshire, $1,200; Vermont, $1,200; Detroit, $7,000; Michigan, $6,000; West Wisconsin, $4,000; Wilmington, ...

MONTREAL, Nov. 9.--Sheriff Hitchcock, of Chicago, arrived here this morning from Washington with the President's warrant for the extradition of John F. Hoke, the defaulting bookkeeper of the Merchants National Bank of Peoria, Ill. For fear of any possible defect in the original warrant for Hoke's arrest a second ...

The inmates of the four-story brownstone flat No. 210 East Seventy-third-street had a narrow escape from death or serious injury by a fire which broke out at 2 o'clock yesterday morning and which wrecked the premises.

MONTREAL, Nov. 9.--Justin McCarthy was presented with an address by the Montreal branch of the Irish National League this afternoon. At 3 o'clock Mr. J.J. Curran, member of Parliament, entertained Mr. McCarthy at dinner.

LONDON, Nov. 9.--Lord Salisbury, speaking at Lord Mayor Hanson's banquet in the Guildhall to-night, said the Conservatives occupied a position on Irish affairs which it was impossible to misinterpret. Their business was to legislate in favor of the integrity of the empire and to enforce laws which had long been neglected and trodden under foot.
At a meeting of the Veteran Corps of the Twenty-second Regiment at No. 4 Union-square last evening presentations were made by two other veteran associations.

PEORIA, Ill., Nov. 9.--It is definitely understood here that there will be a contested Congressional election in the Tenth District, and that Mr. Worthington is engaged on the preliminary declaration in the case. A formal request for an amicable recount will be made on Gen. Post.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 9.--John Torrent, of Muskegon, who recently bought the Hannah and Sylay lumbering interests in the Grand Traverse region, has sold the Long Lake timber tract, estimated to contain 112,000,000 feet, to Filer Son, of Manistee, for $400,000. Mr. Torrent paid $336,000 for this body or timber less than a month ago.

PORTLAND, Me., Nov. 9.--Fletcher Brook was the scene of a double tragedy yesterday. It is a small stream whose source is a small lake on the borders of Township No. 42. It flows across the northeast corner of Township No. 36 a distance of about 12 miles, and empties into the First Machias Lake.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 9.--The preliminary examination in the case of Dr. T.G. Ford, of Shreveport, for the murder of T.C. Kirkpatrick on Tuesday last at the Crescent Hall in this city, came up yesterday before Recorder Davey.

The big auditorium of the Brooklyn Academy of Music was floored over yesterday to provide sufficient space for the tables and booths which formed part of the annual fair of tho Brooklyn Orphan Asylum.
TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 9.--The lynching of Mingo Jack, near Eatontown, Monmouth County, last Fall, for assaulting a white girl was recalled to-day in the Supreme Court.

BOSTON, Nov. 9.--The Board of Visitors of Andover Theological Seminary met have last evening and received the amended complaint and charges in the heresy proceedings, copies of which were directed to be made and sent to the respondents, whose replies are expected on or before Nov. 27. No action was taken as to the time and place for a further hearing.

The New-York and Brooklyn Association of Congregational Churches held its Autumnal meeting yesterday in Plymouth Church. The Rev. Dr. James G. Roberts acted as Moderator and the Rev. William H. Ingersoll as Scribe. The reports read at the morning session showed that the churches in the association were generally prosperous.

FREEHOLD N.J., Nov. 9.--The trials of Phil and John Daly, the proprietors of the Long Branch gambling houses, which were to be had here to-day, have been put off for the term on account of the absence of the State's witnesses.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Nov. 9.--At a meeting of the Directors of the Aransas Pass Railway to-day U. Lott was elected President and General Manager; S.P. Swenson, of New-York. VicePresident, and B.F. Yoakum, Secretary, Treasurer, and Traffic Manager.

ALBANY, Nov. 9.--Gen. James W. Husted paid a flying visit to this city this afternoon to secure a house for the Winter. He said he would not make any active canvass for the Speakership of the next Assembly, and would not be a candidate unless the honor was pressed upon him. He was non-committal in regard to the Senatorship. Senator Vedder, who was also here, is a Morton man.

Announcement was made at the Produce Exchange yesterday of a decision in a case that has long provoked interest among the brokers of that Exchange, and so much consequence was attached to it that the Exchange authorities prepared a synopsis of it for the information of members.

Although the managers of the Aztec fair had insufficient time in which to properly prepare their exhibition at Cosmopolitan Hall, at Broadway and Forty-first-street, they received visitors on Monday evening, and yesterday showed that they have a thoroughly novel and entertaining show.
BOSTON, Nov. 9.--A drunken row on Federal-street late this afternoon resulted in the death of an unknown man, apparently a sailor. In company with Henry Ohern he entered a saloon and took a drink.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 9.--The Yale Freshmen held a meeting to-night and voted unanimously to challenge the Harvard Freshmen to a two-mile race on the Thames at New London next June. They also decided to raise $1,400 by subscription.

BURLINGTON, Iowa, Nov. 9.--Prof. Foster, the meteorologist, will publish in the Burlington Hawk-Eye to-morrow his prediction of a great storm period, extending from Dec. 4 to 17, durwhich will occur some of the most destructive Winter storms of recent years.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 9.--James Nixon, Treasurer of Chippy Chapel, a colored Methodist church, has disappeared, taking with him the plate, funds, and books of the church. Nixon recently resigned, and when his resignation was accepted and an account of his stewardship was asked for he left town. Warrants are out for his arrest.

The first of a series of three concerts, the programmes of which are to be devoted mainly to violin music, was given at Steck Hall last evening by Mr. Edward Mollenhauer, who has long borne an excellent name as a virtuoso and instructor.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9.--In addition to 1,000 men guarding the houses the packing house strikers to-day had to contend with a cold, drizzling rain, which fell most of the time from midnight till the sun went down to-night.

WASHINGTGON, Nov. 9.--The following business was transacted by the Supreme Court of the United States to-day: No. 383--William H. Fowle, Jr., Administrator, , appellant, vs. Alexander Hay.--Appeal from the Circuit Court for the Eastern District of Virginia.--On motion of H.O. Claughton ...

A policeman found two men wandering about in Seventh-avenue early yesterday morning, each wearing the Blackwell's Islaud Insane Asylum uniform. He took them to the Yorkville Court, where they gave their names as Bernard McLaughlin and Coruelius Enwright, ...

The statue of Liberty was not lighted last evening, and the fires in the furnace remained banked. E.P. Hampson Co. have not received and orders in regard to the running of the engine, and do not think the torch will be illumined for some time.
ST. PETERSBURG, Nov. 9.--The Novosti says that Russia proposes to tax coupons of guaranteed railway shares 5 per cent. and dividends 3 per cent.
The will of Judith Ann Ludlow, who died at Jamaica, Long Island, was filed yesterday in the Queens County Surrogate's office.

People who happened to be on Eighthavenue last evening, at about 9:30 o'clock, saw an ordinary looking street car moving over the tracks of the Eighth-Avenue Railroad, though no motive power was visible. Signs painted on the car told them that it was the Julien electric street car, and that it had taken the first prize at the Antwerp Exhibition of 1885.

Charles Biller, a bookkeeper in Fearey's telegraph office in Newark, was arrested in this city yesterday on the charge of forgery. Some person telegraphed from New-York early in the afternoon to Mr. Fearey, representing himself as ...

PITTSBURG, Nov. 9.--A large fly wheel at the Clinton Rolling Mill, on the South Side, burst this morning, scattering fragments in all directions and instantly killing Michael Burns, a workman, who was struck on the head with one of the pieces. The mill was not damaged.

Teresa Odell, who says she is a resident of Brooklyn, was arrested last evening while intoxicated, and taken to the Mercer-street station. Soon after her incarceration in a cell she was found by a roundsman hanging from the top of the door, having torn a piece of muslin off her dress and used it as a rope.

DUBLIN, Nov. 9.--The Irish Government has issued a circular from Dublin Castle denying that Gen. Sir Redvers Buller personally examines cases of dispute between landlord and tenant before granting police protection when asked for it.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 9.--The United States court has been lately considering a question of jurisdiction in reference to a murder committed on the Belgian steamer Noordland, lying at the wharf in Jersey City.
LONDON, Nov. 9.--The steamship Venetian, (Br.,) Capt. Traut, from Boston Oct. 28. arr. at Liverpool to-day.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 9.--One of the most remarkable and apparently best authenticated ghost stories ever reported here is the talk of the street to-day. For a number of years John Dewberry, an individual remarkable for his many eccentricities, kept a saloon on Sixthstreet, between Market and Jefferson.

The second session of the Sunday School Institute, conducted by the New-York Sunday School Association, was held in the Collegiate Church, Fifth-avenue and Twenty-ninth-street, yesterday afternoon. The theme of the session was "The Word Illumined."

There was an unusually large assemblage of citizen soldiers at the Fourteenth Regiment Armory, Brooklyn, last night. The attraction was the court martial of Lieut. W.H. Smith, of Company H, Thirteenth Regiment, on charges of insubordination, conduct unbecoming a gentleman, and other matters equally unpleasant and serious.

The Kings County Republican General Committee held a post-election meeting last evening in Everett Assembly Rooms, on Fultonstreet, Brooklyn. The committee proceeded to the discussion of a plan by which the defect of ...

Tom Gould is to be punished for keeping his place, in West Thirty-first-street, called Sans Souci, in operation in opposition to the law. Henry J. Rice is to be punished for assisting Gould in his transgressions. Judge Van Brunt decided, in the Supreme Court, Chambors, yesterday ...

YAZOO CITY, Miss., Nov. 9.--A letter from Tchula reports a terrible shooting affair there yesterday. Marshal Vantry McBee attacked a negro and severely wounded him. Later in the day he attacked another negro, and still later a third.

The contest between the two parties for the control of the next New-Jersey Legislature promises to be exciting, and in every district in which there is the smallest excuse for action recounts of the vote will probably be ordered.

ATLANTA, Nov. 9.--The inauguration of Gen. J.B. Gordon as Governor of Georgia took place under a shower of rain, which marred the military pageant. During the night the military came pouring in from the various Georgia cities, until at 9 this morning 21 companies with three brass bands made their appearance at the rendezvous.

Gov. Hill yesterday filled the vacancy created in the Electrical Subway Commission by the resignation of President Roswell P. Flower by the appointment of Daniel L. Gibbens, who has been acting as attorney for the commission since Mr. Flower became a member of the board, and who is also the private secretary of Mr. Flower.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 9.--Col. and Mrs. George R. Fearing returned from New-York this evening. They were called to New-York about two weeks ago on account of the serious illness of William R. Travers, who is Mrs. Fearing's father. They bring favorable news of the condition of Mr. Travers, whose illness was reported in THE TIMES of Sunday.

LONDON, Nov. 9.--Lord Mayor's Day opened gloomy and dark. There were few signs in the city to indicate that it was the day for the Lord Mayor's show. The display of bunting and the decoration of buildings usually made on this occasion were almost generally omitted, and the authorities and populace seemed to be imbued with a sense of oppression.

Boodle Alderman Arthur J. McQuade will be the next of the 1884 Aldermen to face the music. He will appear before a jury in the Court of General Sessions at 11 o'clock next Monday morning to endeavor to explain the charge brought against him by the people, that he accepted money to further the interests of the people concerned in the granting of the Broadway Railroad franchise in 1884.

Michael Kehoe, who denied on Monday that he knew anything about the shooting of William Walker, yesterday made an affidavit that he was present in the saloon at No. 139 Hester-street at the time Walker was shot, but was partly asleep, so that he did not see the shooting.

The leaders of what is left of the County Democracy as an organization tried last night to make Mayor-elect Abram B. Hewitt believe that they elected him, and not the leaders of the wicked Tammany cohorts. They sought to impress upon him this great fact at a dinner party given by Aqueduct Commissioner Christopher ...

MAYVILLE, N.J., Nov. 9.--Ed Haight, of Westfield, came very near having a free ride on a rail in this village to-night. His visits to Mrs. Fod Davidson here have created much scandal, and this evening, when it was observed that they were in the Odell House together, a crowd, including many business men, gathered at Firemen's Hall to await developments.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 9.--Max Schreider took a dose of morphine and died yesterday morning. He has been a member of the New-York State National Guard. He had no friends, and he was buried in Potter's Field.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Nov. 9.--Gentlemen from Jasper and Clinton Counties are in the city with a view to securing active measures to prevent the spread of pleuro-pneumonia, which has developed to an alarming extent among cattle within the last few days.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 9.--The Alabama Legialature met to-day at noon. The Senate was called to order by Govermnment-elect Seay, President of the Senate. The Senators qualified and the Senate adjourned to 10 to-morrow.

BOSTON, Nov. 9.--A case of probable wife murder is now being investigated by the police. Mrs. Mary Ann Madden, a young Irishwoman, died about midnight last night under such circumstances as lead the police to believe that death resulted from injuries inflicted by her husband in a drunken quarrel.

LINCOLN, Ill., Nov. 9.--The embarrassed banking firm of William M. Dustin Co., who closed their doors a couple of weeks ago, made a voluntary assignment yesterday. The firm reported to the court their condition as follows:

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., Nov. 9.--The store of P.V. Cole at Montague, Sussex County, N.J., was entered by burglars last night. The thieves piled sacks of flour around the safe after drilling it and then blew it to pieces. That secured $400 and a gold watch. The residents across the street heard the noise, but gave no alarm and the burglars escaped.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 9.--Ever since the murder of Gilbert Dykeman in his flagshanty near Rhinebeck, on the Hudson River Railroad, last Winter, all efforts to obtain a clue to the person who committed the deed failed, and for two or three months the matter has been out of the minds of the people.

A gorgeous floral horseshoe was suspended over the pulpit in St. Paul's Evangelical Church last evening, and floral designs decorated many portions of the interior of the church as part of the greeting to the new Pastor, the Rev. Martyn Summerbell, whose installation ...

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 9.--The National Prison Congress at its morning session discussed the question of the moral and religious instruction of prisoners. James Massie, Warden of the Central Prison of Toronto, presided and read the first paper. He laid great stress upon the character of the Warden and other officers of ...

William P. Campbell, a hatter of South Norwalk, Conn., is an occupant of a cell in Ludlow-Street Jail, where he is held on a charge of attempting to cast an illegal vote. Campbell claims that he is the victim of a conspiracy on the part of the saloon keepers of Hartford, Conn., who, he says, engaged a man to bring him to this city and entrap him into his present predicament.

Col. Bob Ingersoll is not going into the service of the condemned Chicago Anarchists--so at least said one of his intimate friends yesterday. Col. Ingersoll has briefs enough on his hands to make him one of the busiest men at the New-York Bar without accepting new clients. Corporations of consequence have lately retained him for regular counsel.

A notice in front of the Star Theatre last night told its patrons that there would be no performance until Thursday evening on account of Edwin Booth's indisposition. Mr. Booth was taken sick Saturday night with a cold, which on Sunday was worse and settled on the bowels.
CHICAGO, Nov. 9.--It seems to have become settled among the distillers and owners of slop-fed cattle that all animals which have been exposed to pleuro-pneumonia will have to be killed.

ERIE, Penn., Nov. 9.--Charles Bohall and Mrs. Cynthia Groger are on trial on a charge of murder. The victim was Mrs. Groger's little babe, and its murder was a most brutal one. Bohall, who is a giant in strength and a brute in intellect, was living with Mrs. Groger in his hut at the Tracy lumbering ...

SCRANTON, Penn., Nov. 9.--For more than a week timid and superstitious persons throughout the city have been kept in a constant state of trepidation by the appearance in various places and at unseasonable hours of an uncanny figure that is now quite generally spoken of as "The Woman in Black."

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 9.--All the railroad docks along the river are crowded three deep with vessels waiting to unload. The prices on iron ore are higher than they have been known for years, and every vessel owner is anxious to make one more trip before navigation closes.

A new bank, to be known as the Riverside Bank, was organized last evening at the office of John J. Clancy and Co., No, 1,783 Broadway. The capital was fired at $100,000, and $16,000 too much had been subscribed when the stockholders met to organize last evening.

Delury, the tailor, of No. 214 Sixth-avenue, whom the fashionable youth of the city consider the equal of the Fifth-avenue suppliers in everything but price, is at present contemplating a bush Winter season. His store is filled with new imported goods waiting to be made up for the cold weather.

When the latest claimant to the Tichborne estates, Charles Curtis, appeared in the United States Court in Brooklyn yesterday for trial on a charge of procuring pension papers belonging to one Charles Curtis, now dead, and ...

CHICAGO, Nov. 9.--Another cloud has made its appearance on the horizon of the Eastern pool, which threatens to develop a storm of more than ordinary severity. Extensions and combinations are now being perfected by the Canadian Pacific Railway Company that will soon enable it to successfully ...

Robert H. Noble, of No. 105 Broad-street, received yesterday morning from Fowler Brothers, of Chicago, a notice that they had inserted in sundry morning papers an advertisement inviting 1,000 able-bodied workmen to apply at his office for steady work and good pay.

Just before 7 o'clock yesterday morning a car on the East River Bridge track was declared at the terminus on this side of the river. A careloss switchman threw the switch before the last truck of the car had crossed, and the derailment followed.

HAWKINSVILLE, Ga., Nov. 9.--J.C. McCormick, aged 26, a prosperous cotton broker, who was to have been married to-morrow night to Miss Carrie Lewis, a lady of high social standing and great beauty, committed suicide this morning. He had been subject, to fits of despondency, and it is supposed that the excitement attending the preparations so worked on his morbid nervous sensibility as to promote self-destruction.
NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 9.--The last of the series of fashionable weddings of the season of 1886 took place this afternoon at Emanuel Protestant Episcopal Chruch.
"Sophia" has thus far drawn large audiences at Wallack's, and Mr. Moss thinks it will have a long run.

The mass meeting of Socialists in London yesterday was ridiculous or pathetic, according to the point of view. The distress of the unskilled working classes is real, however preposterous may be the remedies their orators prescribe.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 9.--Newport public schools are in receipt of a handsome sum of money from Major Gibbs, of New-York, a well known Newport cottager, and the purpose for which it is to be devoted is explained by the following, a copy of which is to be furnished to all the teachers:

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 9.--The Police Commissioners have decided to investigate the conduct of two of the five officers charged by Kate Rafferty with gross immoralities. Scores of applications for their positions in case of removal have already been made.

Whatever reason there is to regard the late elections as indecisive regarding the popular strength of the Republican and Democratic Parties, there is no room whatever for doubt as to the verdict on the spoils system in American politics.

Mr. ROSWELL P. FLOWER, having imparted life to the Subway Commission, secured the adoption of a plan for underground conduits for electric wires, made a contract with a corporation for laying the same, and apparently brought about an ...

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9.--In a letter read at the meeting of the Executive Committee of the Civil Service Reform Association this afternoon, and forwarded to the Civil Service Commission at Washington, the following statements were embodied: The Civil Service Reform Association ...

On a telegram received from Chief of Police Small, of Boston, Inspector Byrnes yesterday arrested Robert J. Tabraham, alias Charles Bogart, a broker, from Boston, who was charged with embezzlement. He was arrested at Broadway and Pine-street, and admitted his identity.
The citizens of Port Chester were thrown into a state of alarm soon after 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon by a terrific explosion and shaking up, as if by a second edition of the Charleston earthquake.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 9.--Judge Thayer's court was thronged this morning with spectators, who expected to see Fotheringham, the Adams Express messenger, brought in on the habeas corpus writ issued yesterday, and who were anxious to see that much talked about individual.
WINNEPEG, Manitoba, Nov. 9.--Stewart, the American absconder arrested here for bringing stolen money into Canada, was acquitted this evening. The acquittal was granted purely on legal technicalities.

ALBANY, Nov. 10.--Gov. Hill has appointed James M. Whitman, of Sandy Hill, County Judge of Washington County, to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Judge Betts. He is a native of Williamstown, Penn., and about 40 years old. The Governor says he will not name...
Yesterday was a big day with the banks. Being the 4th of November the obligations of the farmers and planters generally for the past year were due. Guano, agricultural machinery,

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10.--President E.P. Wilbur, of the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company, came to the city this morning, and in giving an authoritative denial to the stories connecting that corporation with the construction of a new through line to the West, said: "We have been...

TROY, N.Y., Nov. 10.--Aubrey J. Seale, bookkeeper for Holmes Ide, collar manufacturers of this city, has been arrested on the charge of robbing his employers of more than $1,000, and endeavoring to conceal his thefts by making false entries in his books.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 10.--Information from West Point was received here to-day to the effect that last evening, while the bark Alice M. Minnot, Capt. Dickerson, of Bath, Me.,was being loaded with cotton for Liverpool, a lamp was...
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 10.--Neither the Bell Telephone Company nor the people of Rochester, who are practically "striking" against what they consider exorbitant rates, show any signs of weakening.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 10.--The New-Brunswick Insurance Company to-day authorized its counsel to begin proceedings against the bondsmen of Treasurer Applegate, whose accounts are short, the bondsmen having refused to make good the deficiency.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 10.--Thomas R. Alleu, aged 25 years, employed as bookkeeper for Messrs. McLean, Harrison White, shot himself this evening in the store.

ROME, Nov. 10.--The Vatican is preparing for publication an encyclical letter condemning and stigmatizing the Italian Government, whose policy, the letter will say, places the Pope in the power of a revolution which menaces his liberty.

VICKSBURG, Miss., Nov. 10.--Gov. Robert Lowrey and staff arrived here to-day to open the State Colored Fair. He was met at the station by two companies of colored troops and escorted to his rooms at the Washington Hotel to martial music by a colored band. The opening ceremonies, however, had to be postponed until to-morrow on account of rain.

Yesterday the Grand Sobranje at Tirnova performed the chief task for which it had been called together--the selection of a successor to Prince ALEXANDER. Its choice fell upon the most prominent of all the candidates who had been mentioned--WALDEMAR, third son of King CHRISTIAN of Denmark--and the vote seems to have been enthusiastic and unanimous.

The Board of Trade and Transportation decided yesterday that hereafter no new business considered at its meeting until after formal shall be notice shall be sent to all the members, unless consideration be agreed to by a vote of threefourths of those present. NEW-ORLEANS, La., Nov. 10.--The report of the National Cotton Exchange just issued says: "The weather during the past month has been uniformly and exceptionally fine for picking, and it is generally estimated that nearly three-fourths of the crop has been already gathered. About a week ago, near Mr. Charlton Jones's, a cow with crumpled horns was licking her calf, and, by some means, the calf got its head in the circle of the horns and could not extricate it. The cow became excited, and, in her efforts to get rid of the calf, strangled it and broke her own neck, both dying instantly.
BROWNWOOD, Texas, Nov. 10.--In a fight between fence cutters and State, Rangers last night at a point 10 miles from here, two fence cutters, named Lovell and Roberts, were killed.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Nov. 10.--Mount Laffee, a mining village two miles to the north of Pottsville, was the scene of a brutal affair today. An old man named Dennis Hockney was chopping wood at his door when a young ruffian known as Jack McAndrews came along.

Cyrus W. Field, Jay Gould, and Russell Sage held the annual meeting of their Manhattan Railway Company yesterday, re-elected themselves, and all of their last year's colleagues to the directory of the company, and issued a lot of statistical reports to show in what a flourishing condition the elevated railroads are just now.
CAIRO, Ill., Nov. 10.--The crew of the Sidney Dillon, which arrived here last night, report a ghastly find about 30 miles below St. Louis, on the river bank.
LONDON, Nov. 10.--The steamship Oxfordshire, (Br.,) Capt. Jones, from Japan and China ports for New-York, passed Aden to-day.

Mr. H.M. Hoxie, First Vice-President and General Manager of the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company, who has been seriously ill in the apartments of Col. Hayes, at the Broadway, No. 1,425 Broadway, is not in so critical a condition as has been reported.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 10.--Dan Nary, a quarryman, of large physique, drank just enough liquor Monday to make him boastful of his strength, and in a saloon during the afternoon he boasted of his ability to "do up" anybody.

The President's speech at Cambridge gave new and striking evidence of that self-possession and balance of mind which observant Americans have long since recognized as a conspicuous trait of their present Chief Executive.

BANGOR, Me., Nov. 10.--Many persons here are firm in the belief that the murderers of the Game Wardens are McFarland and Graves, two men who poach every Winter, hunting deer with dogs. Their method is to run deer in the Fall and Winter, freeze the carcasses, and when an opportunity offers ship them out of the State.

Fire destroyed six game buildings on Coney Island between the Boulevard and Brighton Branch of the Sea Beach Railroad at an early hour yesterday morning. The loss is estimated at $15,000, and the insurance policies aggregate about half that amount.

Thomas Hughes, one of the residents of the delectable neighborhood in West Thirtyninth-street known as "Hell's Kitchen," is suing Policeman John Kennedy, of the Twentieth Precinct, for $2,000 damages, asserting that that officer unlawfully battered and bruised him with a club.

CITY OF MEXICO. Nov. 10, via, Galveston --The distinguished scientist, Senor Marino Barcena, who was sent by the Government to examine the Volcano Colima, reports that he ascended to the summit and made observations near the crater.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 10.--Gen. R.D. Lilly, Financial Agent of the Washington and Lee University at Lexington was stricken with paralysis in this city last night while addressing the Presbyterian Synod of Virginia, in session here. He is to-day reported to be in a critical condition.

Opposite the Traveller office, in the pavements of State-street, passers-by have noticed a large, wheel-shaped, round inlaying of the stones, like the spokes of a wheel, and a keystone for the centre, like the hub.

Assents to the proposed scaling of the interest on the old first and second mortgages of the Wabash were received yesterday by the Purchasing Committee from the holders of more than a million and a half of bonds, and word was sent of many more to come.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 10.--Mrs. Langtry's voice has almost entirely given out as a result of last night's efforts, and, in accordance with the advice of physicians, she will rest until Saturday afternoon.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10.--A new plan to suppress bucket shops and restore speculative trading to former channels is being agitated by a number of members of the Board of Trade. Two of the three members of the Art Committee of the Department of Parks have reported on the bust of Washington Irving now on exhibition in Central Park. The gentlemen fail to agree in their estimate of its artistic worth. The Park Commissioners yesterday received letters from, them.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10.--Until three weeks ago lake carriers and insurance men were congratulating themselves upon having enjoyed a prosperous season on the lakes. Freights had been more plentiful, and the rates of carrying had been higher than for many years.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10.--The General Managers and the General Passenger Agents of the various roads between Chicago, St. Louis, and Council Bluffs and Omaha met here to-day to make a final effort for the formation of a gross these points.

A newspaper paragraph is going the rounds to the effect that Admiral Porter realized $50,000 from his novel. While in Newport recently the Admiral stated to a friend that his publishers had sent him thus far less than $70.
WARSAW, N.Y., Nov. 10.--The following circular is being sent to every temperance organization in the State by influential temperance workers of this place:

Argument was heard by Judge Van Brunt, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, on a motion for the continuance of an injunction, obtained by Leopold Loeb, restraining William D. Judson and others from disposing of bonds of the Chicago and Eastern Illinois Railroad Company representing $500,000.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 10.--Yesterday Mr. Charles Kimball, of Providence, sold the b.g. G.F.D., raised and owned by George F. Davis, of Windsor, Vt., to Mr. Joseph Stickney, of the firm of Stickney, Conyngham Co., of NewYork City, for $4,000 after the horse had exhibited his ability to trot a mile in 2:20 over the Narragansett Park track.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10.--It is said at the Nautical Almanac office that on the evening of Friday next, Nov. 12, no less than six stars, including Aldebaran, which is of the first magnitude, will be occulted by the moon between 6 o'clock and midnight.

QUEBEC, Nov. 10.--At St. George de la Beauce a number of young men attacked a farmer named Wintle in his own house. The farmer seized a rifle and fired at his assailants, but the bullet flew wide of its mark and struck his niece, a young woman who was stopping with him, killing her instantly.

The Central Stock Yard and Transit Company, of Jersey City, which advertised yesterday for men to take the places of the 130 butchers who struck Monday at its packing house on the Hackensack River, received more applications in response than it could accommodate, and by noon it had a force of 110 men at work.

NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 10.--The French flagship Minerve left this port very suddenly last night for the West Indies. The reason of her sudden departure, as told by Admiral Contre, was that he had been snubbed by Col. W.H. Taylor, French Consul at this port. The ship arrived here last week, and the Consul did not...

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 10.--The official canvass is proceeding slowls and returns have been received from over half the counties in the State. These put a somewhat different aspect on the state of affairs.

BERLIN, Nov. 10.--Emperor William is more vigorous. Yesterday he received Minister von Puttkamer and Count Herbert Bismarck, worked four hours over reports, and afterward drove in the Thiergarten. To-day he was able to give attention to the reports of the Ministers of War and Marine.

NORFOLK, Va., Nov.10.--The trial of John B. Whitehead, President of the broken Exchange National Bank, commenced in the United States Circuit Court to-day. Several witnesses for the prosecution were examined. The indictment upon which he is being tried charges him with willfully misapplying funds on deposit.

DUBLIN, Nov. 10.--The Cork Harbor Board has invited numerous companies in Leinster and Munster to join in sending a deputation to the Postmaster-General to ask that longer contracts be made with the Cunard and White Star Companies, as the threatened monthly contracts would result in loss to Ireland.
PITTSBURG, Nov. 10.--At a meeting of window glass manufacturers of Pittsburg and the West, held here to-day, a syndicate was formed to regulate prices and control production.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 10.--The freight trainmen of the Cleveland and Pittsburg Road have asked for an increase of wages and for an adjustment of other complaints in regard to hours and service similar to the grievances lately set forth by the New-York, Pennsylvania and Ohio men. The complaints were presented in writing to Manager R.F. Smith, who has in turn sent them to General Manager McCrea, at Pittsburg.

BOSTON, Nov. 10.--A large and cultured audience gathered in Sanders Theatre this evening to listen to a lecture on the rise of European universities by Prof. Mandell Creighton, Senior Fellow of Emmanuel College, Professor of Ecclesiastical History in the University of Cambridge, Canon of Worcester, D.D., LL. D., and delegate from Emmanuel to Harvard's celebration.

LARNED, Kan., Nov. 10.--Intelligence has been received here from Hodgeman County of a crime which rivals in inhumanity and brutality the butchery of his family by Willie Sells, the boy murderer. The scene of the tragedy is near Marena, in the extreme southeast corner of Hodgeman County.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 10.--The Baltimore and Ohio Express Company will begin on Dec. 1 running over the Queen and Crescent lines, succeeding the Adams between Cincinnati and Chattanooga and the Southern Express Company between Chattanooga and New-Orleans and the Western branches. BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 10.--The following call was issued to-day: The fifth annual convention of the Citizens' Law and Order League of the United States will be held at Albany, N.Y., on the 20th, 21st, and 22d days of February, 1887.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Nov. 10.--On Oct. 13 the bark Ivy, owned at Quebec, arrived at this port with sugar from Batavia, Java. The championship game of football between Harvard and Princeton will be played on Saturday of this week at Princeton at 2:30 o'clock. Arrangements have been made to stop the fast express train on the Pennsylvania Railroad leaving New-York at 11 o'clock. The players will probably be through in time to take the 5 o'clock train back from Princeton.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10.--Prince Komatsu, uncle of the Mikado of Japan, called at the White House to-day, in company with the Princess Komatsu and the members of his suite, and paid their respects to the President. They were received in the Blue Parlor.

Lawyer Sterne Chittenden appeared in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, and asked Judge Van Brunt if the Supreme Court had authority to remove the Tax Commissioners from office for failure to perform their whole duty.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Nov. 10.--The American Turf Congress met in secret session at the Gibson House to-day, and spent the day in revising rules. No decisions were arrived at, the work being divided up among committees, which will report to-morrow.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10.--The packers came to the conclusion to-day that they had been too hasty in placing an embargo upon all members of labor organizations who might apply to them for work, agreeing that such action brought "unintentional injustice upon numerous persons who may be members of such organizations."

BOSTON, Nov. 10.--The famous case of Wilson-Moen is again in the courts, and a second trial was begun to-day in the United States Circuit Court before Judge Carpenter.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Nov. 10.--Next Saturday, Nov. 13, at 12 o'clock, the twenty years' lease of the Union Railroad between Scranton and Mill Creek, Penn., to the Lehigh Coal and Navigation Company, expires, and the road reverts to its owner, the Delaware and Hudson Canal Company.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 10.--Exchange-- Sight drafts on New-York, 17 cents; telegraph ic. 22 cents.

The constitutional amendment conferring the right upon women to vote at elections for school officials met with but little opposition. Few paid any attention to the matter, and at many voting places no tickets were to be found.

A suit brought by the Stormont Silver Mining Company against Rufus P. Lincoln is on trial before Judge Beach and a jury, in the Supreme Court. It is on a note for $76,987 15, made by the Hite Gold Quartz Company in February, 1883.

"The Chouans," produced at the UnionSquare Theatre last evening, showed Mme. Modjeska in a new character. She was Marie de Verneuil, employed by Fouche to entrap the Marquis de Montauran, a leader of royalist insurgents in Brittany in the year 1799.

UVALDE, Texas, Nov. 10.--Col. John Weymiller, father of Mrs. Hewlett Griner, the wealthy ranchman who was so brutally murdered near Las Vegas, Mexico, Monday evening, returned here to-day, having failed to bring the body of his son-in-law home with him. Weymiller was accompanied by half a dozen of Griner's most intimate friends.

There is no danger of an overgrowth of industrial business at the South. If the iron States of the South were to manufacture onetenth of the iron goods consumed here at home, there would be room for ten times the present number of forges and factories.

The wedding of Miss Mary Brewster, daughter of Cullen Brewster, of this city, to Lieut. S.L. Reamey, of the United States Navy, attracted many friends to the Church of the Holy Spirit, in Madison-avenue, last evening.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 10.--William Chisholm, George Warmington, H.D. Coffinberry, J.H. Wade, Jr., R.R. Rhodes, and other capitalists have organized the Cleveland Shipbuilding Company with a capital stock of $250,000 to build vessels and manufacture plate and sheet iron.

A meeting of the Democratic State Central and Executive Committee has been called to meet at Frankfort Tuesday, Nov. 23, to consider the time and place of holding a State Convention to nominate candidates for Governor and other State officers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10.--The incoming members of the House of Representatives are being called upon promptly upon their arrival to give opinions about the causes of the results of election day. PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10.--When the Hon. Put Darden, Master of the National Grange Patrons of Husbandry, called to order the twentieth annual session this morning, Musical Fund Hall, where the session is held, presented a beautiful appearance.

John Crothers keeps a blacksmith's shop at No. 525 West Thirty-eighth-street, where he employs two men who do not belong to the Blacksmiths' Union. Jack Hughes and James Mitchell, union blacksmiths, went into the shop and ordered the men to quit work and join the union.

Charges growing out of the recent troubles in the Thirteenth Regiment, of Brooklyn, which culminated in the trial of Lieut. Smith for conduct unbecoming an officer, were formulated yesterday against Col. Fackner, and will be sent to Albany in a few days. Lieut.

Dr. Samuel M. Fisk, a prominent physician of Brooklyn, Eastern District, and an inspector for the Brooklyn Health Department, dropped dead last night at his home. No. 184, South Ninth-street. Apoplexy was the immediata cause of death.

The women of Hyde County, Dakota, went to the polls on election day and voted. They did not meddle with the law sanctioned ballot box, but had one at each precinct of their own, with an arrangement for having the voted counted and announced. They wanted to help express public opinion.

AUBURN, N.Y., Nov. 10.--Dr. John G. Johnson, of Brooklyn, the family physician of James D. Fish in his prosperous days, arrived in Auburn early this morning, and immediately after breakfast called upon Fish's daughter, who is living quietly in East Genesee-street.

Mr. Bram Stoker, the genial manager of Henry Irving's prospective tour in 1887, was in high good humor at the Brunswick Hotel yesterday afternoon. He had completed his list of engagements, and he was highly gratified by the kind treatment he had received everywhere.

Archbishop Ryan, in carrying out the decrees of the recent council at Baltimore, has enjoined the priests in this diocese from performing marriage ceremonies in the evening. He insists that weddings in church must take place with a nuptual mass, or, failing in that, as early in the afternoon as possible.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 10.--Jesse Howard Lord, an old and well known newspaper writer, was found this morning on the grave of his wife in the old North Cemetery. He was lying on his back, with a 32 calibre revolver grasped in his right hand.

The Southern Railway and Steamship Association met yesterday at No. 46 Bond-street, discussed classification and minor freight rates between competing points, and succeeded in adjusting many little differences of no special public importance.

Mr. Edwin Booth will not act again until next Monday night. He is recovering from the sickness which compelled him to temporarily suspend his performances, but his physician advised him last evening not, to attempt to resume his labors this week. The risk might entail serious consequences. Therefore the Star Theatre will by closed until Monday evening, when the distinguished tragedian will be seen as Iago in "Othello."

DALTON, Ga., Nov. 10.--Yesterday morning a driver discovered the dead body of a white woman in Mill Creek. Her head showed a large indenture over the left eye and one over the left ear, which was nearly severed from the head.

Schaeffer.--Appeal from the Circuit Court for the Western District of Missouri.--On motion of M.F. Morris, for appellee, dismissed with costs, per stipulation.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Nov. 11.--The Ulster County Board of Supervisors is a tie politically, and the members have been in session for two days trying to select a Chairman. Up to this evening 105 ballots had been taken.
The first performance of "A Foregone Conclusion," Mr. W.D. Howells's dramatization of his own novel, will be given at the MadisonSquare Theatre next Thursday afternoon, Nov. 18.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11.--When Worthy Master Put Darden, of the National Grange, called the meeting of the Patrons of Husbandry to order at 3 o'clock this afternoon every seat in Musical Fund Hall was filled, and a good many men were standing.

MONTREAL, Nov. 11.--The corporation today decided to adopt the plan suggested by the Government to prevent future floods, namely, to fit up four tugs to run up and down the river below Three Rivers, to break up the ice as it forms. The expense is to be divided between the Government, the city, and the Harbor Commissioners.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11.--A daring attempt at highway robbery was made last night near Overbrook. About 10:30 o'clock an elderly gentleman, accompanied by a young lady, was driving on the Lancaster Pike, this side of Overbrook, a place which is particularly lonesome, there being woods on both sides of the road.

Jenks, the Brooklyn Corporation Counsel and the Referee in the case, in his office ...

BOSTON, NOV. 11.--The President and Fellows of Harvard College to-day filed in the Circuit Court their answer in the suit of Francis R. Brooks to recover $50,000 for injuries received in March last, caused by the bursting of a retort containing sulphuric acid.

Gen. John M. Schofield was last evening elected an honorary member of the Union League Club.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 11.--Ex-Gov. Bedle and William Muirhead, of counsel of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad Company, appeared before the State Board of Assessors to-day and presented a supplemental statement setting forth the position of the company in reference to its taxes.

TIRNOVA, Nov. 11.--Prince Waldemar has sent a telegram to the Regents expressing his grateful sense of the honor conferred upon him by the Sobranje in electing him Prince of Bulgaria. He states, however, that the decision as to his acceptance rests with his father, the King ...

BERLIN, Nov. 11.--The Prussian military budget, which has just been submitted to the Bundesrath, places the regular expenditures at 267,577,000 marks, an increase of 4,226,000, and the non-recurring expenditures at 27,811,000 marks, an increase of 12,476,000, arising chiefly from the purchase of additional supplies of arms.

ERIE, Penn., Nov. 11.--Charles Bohall, the child murderer, was convicted to-day of the second grade of murder. Bohall is a giant lumberman and lived at Tracy, a lumber town in the western part of this county.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Nov. 11.--In the Supreme Court here to-day, before Judge Barnard, the case of F.B. Thurber, of New-York, against Sheriff Clauson, of this county, to recover the value of property alleged to have been levied on wrongfully was tried. A bill of sale which had not been recorded figured in the case. The court nonsuited the plaintiff on the ground that sales in the nature of chattel mortgages not recorded are void.

In a conversation to-day with a clerk in the Pension Office, who was passing through Chicago, he told me that few people had any idea of the colossal check of some of the people who apply for pensions.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 11.--At Myrtle Grove Plantation, in Plaquemine Parish, owned by Congressman-elect Wilkinson, the boiler of the draining machine exploded yesterday, killing the engineer in charge, Gabriel Burroughs, and badly scalding and dangerously injuring the fireman and another hand. The boiler was blown an eighth of a mile, and the concussion was felt for miles up and down the river.

The school fund of the State appears to be well handled and to be made to produce the best possible results. Last year the State school fund amounted to $506,328 08, and towns and counties raised by special taxes $209,328 08 more.

Justice of the Peace William Sherlock died at his home in Brooklyn yesterday of paralysis of the brain. He was taken ill two weeks ago upon the death of one of his children. He had been sitting up night and day with the little one for nearly a month, and upon its demise the father's nervous system gave way. Justice Sherlock was 50 years of age and a printer by trade.

There was a very meagre attendance at Chickering Hall yesterday afternoon when the tenth annual congress of the American Secular Union began. Col. Robert G. Ingersoll opened the proceedings with a long address, in which he said a great many of the things he has been saying for some years. He devoted much time to an explanation of the reason why men made comparatively little progress, as he understood it.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11.--The twentyfirst annual meeting of the General Committee of the Church Extension Society of the Methodist Episcopal Church began this afternoon in the assembly room of the board, at No. 1,026 Archstreet.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 11.--The Democrats re greatly interested in the legislative situation. Senator Voorhees is already here, and Mr. McDonald will be here to-morrow. Other leading Democrats are here, and a general consultation will be held over the status of the case.

LONDON, Nov. 11.--Mr. Gladstone publishes a letter inviting the Liberals to reunite. He says: "After reading the Marquis of Salisbury's speech it seems to me that we have arrived at the testing situation for all Liberals really desiring Liberal union.

More litigation has grown out of the differences between Charles C. Sears and his wife, Frances M. Sears, than out of the mutual dislike of any wedded couple that have put themselves before the public eye for a long time. Sears is well known among railroad men and politicians.

Mme. Valda's business agent said last evening that she would probably soon announce that the Italian opera season would be continued under her management. The artists of the company had remained here in the expectation of being engaged under the new management. Signor Angelo said that he knew nothing about the arrangements of the new management.

LONDON, Nov. 11.--The steamship India sld. from Naples for New-York yesterday. The steamship Ovingham sld. from Benisaf for Philadelphia yesterday. The steamship Elpis, (Br.,) Capt. Burnett, from New-York Oct. 24, arr. at Leith to-day.

Calvary Episcopal Church, which can be rightly termed the home of weddings, was crowded yesterday afternoon, when the marriage of Miss Sara Randolph Foote, daughter of Frederick W. Foote, and Mr. Robert Sale Hill was celebrated. A merry wedding march rang out as the bridal party advanced to the altar.

The United States Catholic Historical Society, which was organized for the purpose of exciting an interest among Catholics in the past history of the church in America, by collecting historical material bearing on the subject, held its fifth annual meeting last evening in St. Agnes's Church, East Forty-third-street.

Lieut. Henn and his wife are living aboard the cutter Galatea at her Winter anchorage in Manning's basin, in South Brooklyn, as they prefer the "home" comfort thus obtained to that furnished in the hotels ashore.

Commissioner Moss, as the surviving officer of the Subway Commission, took the chair at the meeting over Wallack's Theatre yesterday afternoon, and was at once nominated by Commissioner Hess to succeed Mr. Flower as President.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 11.--Samuel Allen, Jr., keeper of the life-saving station at Block Island, received a letter this evening from Secretary Manning asking him to resign his position. Many ugly charges have been made against Allen, and they were investigated by order of ...

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11.--The PostmasterGeneral to-day ordered the discontinuance of 92 fourth class Post Offices, mainly for the reason that there were no candidates for the Postmasterships. In a large number of cases the business of the offices did not justify their continuance. Nearly every State and Territory is represented in the list. During the 11 days of the present month there have been 139 Post Offices discontinued and 24 established.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 11.--Newport, from a fashionable point of view, begins to look quite deserted, but the local residents have the satisfaction of knowing that the Summer visitors have left a goodly sum of money behind them, and they refer, with pardonable pride, to the fact that all the taxes have been gathered.

Nothing pleases the American mind more than speculations as to Presidential contests a year or two distant, and nothing is more uncertain than the fate of such speculations when the average American comes to cast his vote.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11.--Shortly afternoon today the Sun, a paper published at the stock yards, posted a bulletin in its window announcing that Mr. Powderly had ordered the striking packing house men back to work. The news spread rapidly, and groups of strikers here and there discussed the matter in an excited and very much pleased manner.

Prince Kamatsu, the uncle of the Mikado of Japan, with his wife and suite, sailed yesterday for Liverpool on the White Star steamship Germanic. The Japanese Consul and several other Japanese residents of this city went down to the steamer to take leave of Prince Kamatsu.

PARIS, Nov. 11.--Railway traffic in the South of France has been stopped by the floods. A young American woman, who for the present refuses to divulge her name, has entered upon a 30 days' fast in this city under the surveillance of a committee.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11.--The "fine work" of State Treasurer Quay for the Senatorial nomination is coming to fruition. Six of the seven Republican Senators from this city met yesterday at Quay's invitation, and five of them "made profuse protestations" of support.

The widow of S.S. Prentiss, of Mississippi, is Principal of the best female school in New-Orleans. She is educating her daughters there. Her son, S.S. Prentiss, Jr., is practicing law in the same city.

BROWNWOOD, Texas, Nov. 11.--Tuesday Capt. W. Scott, of the State Rangers, with headquarters here, received information that a party of wirecutters would cut the wire fences on Mr. Morgan Eboughe's place that night, 12 miles from here.

PARIS, Nov. 11.--The French press continue to discuss Lord Salisbury's declaration about the British occupation of Egypt, but all the comments are made in a very moderate tone. Mgr. Straniero, the Papal Ablegate who brought the beretta to Cardinal Gibbons, is staying in this city prior to his departure for Europe to-morrow. Since the consecration at Baltimore on June 21, Mgr. Straniero has traveled 20,000 miles in the United States and Canada, and has visited all the noted places in both countries.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 11.--Edward J. Routly, William Walsh, and Joseph Young, fishermen, were lost, with their boat, in the recent gale off Manitoulin Island, Lake Huron. The men were at Core Bay and sought to make their home at Cape Robert, 25 miles away, but have not since been heard from. Routly hailed from Windsor, Ontario, and Young and Walsh from Bay City.

ASBURY PARK, Nov. 11.--Dr. George F. Wilbur, one of the leading physicians at this place, was quietly married to-day to Miss Fannie Apple, a Jewess and the daughter of H. Apple, a manufacturer of ladies' straw goods in New-York City.

CRESSON, Penn., Nov. 11.--Andrew Carnegie has been able to sit up a little to-day for the first time since his illness. He has not yet been told of his mother's death.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 11.--When the anti-organ convention of United Presbyterians met this morning the resolutions and plans of organization presented by the Committee on Resolutions were taken up and discussed at great length.
HAVERHILL, Mass., Nov. 11.--C. Haven Coffin, shoe manufacturer, of this city, has made an assignment to H.G. Case for the benefit of his creditors. His liabilities are $75,000.

An irritated gentleman dropped down into Wall-street yesterday from the country. His grievance was that a mining company in which he was a stockholder had suddenly suspended dividends and was now levying assessments instead upon the shares.

The revenue cutter Manhattan, which was thought to have been lost off New-Haven last Sunday, came into port yesterday and was moored at the Barge Office pier.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12.--Anthony Comstock, of New-York, appeared in Magistrate R. R. Smith's office this afternoon against L. Lum Smith, editor and proprietor of the Agents' Herald, charging him with criminal libel. Mr. Comstock was accompanied by his counsel, Samuel...

LOS ANGELES, Cal., Nov. 12.--Albert G. Baynton, who shot and killed his wife and J. B. Kipp on the 17th of September last, was hanged here this afternoon. On the day of the murder Baynton beat his wife and she fled to Kipp's house for protection. Baynton pursued and shot her and then shot Kipp, who had attempted to defend her.

LONDON, Nov. 12.--The Sebright divorce case was brought up for preliminary hearing today. The action is brought by Mrs. Arthur Sebright, who asked to have her marriage declared void on the grounds that she was induced to consent to have the ceremony performed by...

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12.--The following business was transacted in the Supreme Court of the United States to-day: No.40--The Memphis and Little Rock Railroad Company, (as reorganized,) appellant, vs. Robert K. Dow et al., Trustees.--Argument concluded by Wager Swayne for appellant.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Nov. 12.--Early in the Summer Emmet Lawther, aged 21, a blacksmith, was arrested for setting fire to a farmer's barn in Alexander, this county, where he lived. He had been in jail only a short time before he made an attempt to escape by cutting a hole ...

CLEVELAND, Nov. 12.--Tennessee has no monopoly of the "brother business" in politics. To fill a vacancy in the Board of Councilmen in this city the Republicans last night nominated John Ingraham, and to-night the Democrats nominated his brother James. Although both are capable men, the Tennessee example probably had much to do with their choice.
One point in Gen. MILES'S official report of his operations against the hostile Chiricahuas, which has only recently been given in full to the public, is specially worth notice.
ALBANY, Nov. 12.--The following reports have been filed with the Railroad Commission for the quarter ending Sept. 30:

HURLEY, Wis., Nov. 12.--Two burglars went through the new Burton House, pillaging 15 rooms and securing several hundred dollars' worth of watches and jewelry. They overlooked a guest who had $8,000 in cash in his room, and others who had smaller amounts. The thieves were captured in their room with the plunder and a kit of burglar's tools.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 12.--At the National Prison Congress this morning the Hon. A. L. Weeden, of Rhode Island, described prison methods in that State. Capt. Daniel Russell, State agent for reformed convicts in Massachusetts, gave his experience.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 12.--There probably never was a more humorous and recklessly daring highwayman than the individual who recently robbed the Adams Express car on the St. Louis and San Francisco Railroad of over $75,000, and who is pleased to be known as "Jim Cummings." He captured one of the largest amounts of money ...

Henry George was the guest of the Homeless Club last evening. Although the club is not a political organization several of its members were hearty supporters of Mr. George in his campaign, and one of them, as it happened, nominated him for the Mayoralty.

POCAHONTAS, Va., Nov. 12.--R.A. Miller, owner of Miller's Hotel, which was burned on Nov. 3, when the business portion of the town was swept away, was arrested yesterday by detectives on a charge of firing his own house and causing the conflagration. He waived examination and was bailed in $3,000.

One of New-York's "hotel hermits," whose idiosyncrasies were recently described in an article in THE TIMES, died suddenly at the Grand Central Hotel yesterday morning, in the person of Noah S. Hunt, a gentleman of 84 years, who had resided at that hotel during the past four years.

ATTICA, Ind., Nov. 12.--Samuel Girard, who has been terrorizing Warren County for several years, was killed yesterday. For two weeks the people of Battle Ground have been missing household goods and other articles, and a clue to the thieves was given last Tuesday, ...

Mr. E. Heron-Allen, the young Englishman whose expositions of the art of palmistry or "cheirosophy," as he terms it, were the rage in London during the past "season," has come to this country, and under the management of Major James B. Pond will deliver lectures and give "seances" in this city.
William A. Poucher, of Oswego, is at the Union-Square Hotel. Assistant Postmaster-General A.D. Hazen is at the Hoffman House.
TROY, N.Y., Nov. 12.--Mayor Whalen received to-day another letter from Webb Co., of New-York, as follows:

Gen. Newton made no changes in the Department of Public Works yesterday, and said that none were in immediate contemplation. The impression that one or two heads of bureaus will be asked to resign soon is gaining ground, although neither the Commissioner nor his Deputy, David Lowber Smith, will say aught to confirm the rumors.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 12.--The Superior Court yesterday granted a peremptory mandamus compelling the Board of Freeholders of Monmouth County to pay the bills presented by Assistant Prosecutor Swartz and Detective Irving, who were engaged for the county in the Mingo Jack lynching case. The bills were thrown out by the Board of Freeholders on the ground that they were excessive. Both bills amounted to $1,231.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 12.--The trial of Emil Meyer, charged with bigamy, was begun in the Court of Session yesterday. Mrs. Meyer No. 1, of New-York, testified that she was married to Meyer in Germany, and came to America in 1872. Her husband left her and went to Detroit.
READING, Penn., Nov. 12.--A fire at 4 o'clock this morning in the southern section of the city, which consumed a cooper shop and a barn, was the occasion of a thrilling experience.

The Cigarmakers' International Union held a mass meeting at the Cooper Union last evening to consult as to what should be done regarding the operatives wlio are being thrown out of work by the introduction of new labor-saving devices in the shape of bunching machines.
MARLBOROUGH, N.Y., Nov. 12.--An eviction case which has excited a great deal of interest in the Central Hudson was decided yesterday in favor of the plaintiff.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12.--The National Butter and Egg and Cheese Association to-day elected the following officers for the ensuing year: President--H.B. Gurler, De Kalb, Ill.; Secretary and Treasurer--A.M. Littler, of Iowa, re-elected for the thirteenth time; Vice-Presidents--W.H. Duckworth, New-York; Charles Utley, Boston; H.C. Garrett, Philadelphia; James Hewes, Baltimore; G.M. Oyster, Washington; W.L. Distin, Illinois; the Hon. W.H. Hatch, Missouri; W.D. Hoard Wisconsin.
TROY, N.Y., Nov. 12.--Last night Policeman Dwyer met William A. Donohue, Alderman of the Third Ward of Albany, near the Adamsstreet dock in this city.

LONDON, Nov. 12.--Mr. Phelps, United States Minister to England, delivered a lecture to-day before the Institute of Philosophy, at Edinburgh, in the course of which he said that law is a reflex of public opinion and should thus be maintained, or it would perish in a free country.

Much excitement was caused among the loungers about the Court House, in Brooklyn, yesterday by the circulation of a rumor that a mistake of 200 votes had been discovered in the returns from the Nineteenth Ward among the ballots cast for S.V. White and James D. Bell for Congress.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 12.--A body was burned at the crematory in this city this afternoon. Many persons were present to witness the incineration, it being public. The body was that of David Lee Ford, a son of David M. Ford, of Chicago. It reached here at 5 P.M. and was immediately taken to the crematory. There were no religious ceremonies.

Saffold, Thirteenth Infantry, has been granted four months' leave of absence. Second Lieut. Charles S. Hall, Thirteenth Infantry, has been granted one month's leave of absence.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 12.--Another of the Milford gang of firebugs was arrested in this city to-day and taken to Milford. He is Virgil F. Bidwell, a young fellow 21 years old. The charge against him is complicity in the arson cases, and the detectives are inclined to believe that he is the last of the gang. Henry McCaroll, who was arrested yesterday, was today held in $1,000 bonds. Bidwell will be arraigned to-morrow.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 12.--Matt C. Atwood shot himself three times at Akron to-night because a grass widow named Clark refused to marry him. He fired bullets into his left breast, left eye, and forehead. Twelve years ago, upon the death of his wife, he shot himself, but recovered.
The case of John Chestnut was on the calendar for trial in Part I., Court of General Sessions, yesterday. His counsel asked for a delay on the ground that he had been but recently retained.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12.--The steamer Bessemer, which reached Chicago last night with a cargo of ore, had a very stormy passage down Lake superior, and had she not been picked up in midlake by the steamer B. W. Blanchard she would have probably gone to the bottom.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 12.--The noted imported stallion Prince Charlie, the property of Mr. Dan Swigert, died at the Elmendorf farm, Fayette County, last night, of colic. He was worth $20,000.

AURORA, Ill., Nov. 12.--Franz Kranz and wife were to-day brought back to Aurora on a State requisition from Richmond County, Neb., to answer the charge of causing the death of Fred Shoger, Mrs. Kranz's former husband.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 12.--A man ran into a low groggery on Burnet-street last night and told Thomas Wylie that his wife had taken a dose of strychnine and was dying. Wylie cursed his wife and the informant and called for another drink.

The court martial of Lieut. W.H. Smith, of Company H, Thirteenth Regiment, for insubordination and ungentlemanly conduct was continued last evening in the Fourteenth Regiment Armory, in Brooklyn, and a number of members of the regiment were examined. The witnesses were cautious in their statements, and nothing very damaging to the Lieutenant on trial was elicited.

SANDUSKY, Ohio, Nov. 12.--The propeller Northerner, laden with lime and bound for Duluth, sprung a leak off Kelly's Island to-day and the slacking of the lime set fire to the boat, which was burned to the water's edge. All on board were rescued by tugs. Loss estimated at $75,000.

HUNTINGDON, Penn., Nov. 12.--About a year ago Andrew J. Kimball, of Forsyth, Montana, sought an acquaintance with an Eastern lady with a view to marriage. Meeting a friend who was coming East he requested him to hunt up a lady with whom he might correspond.
ALBUQUERQUE, New-Mexico, Nov. 12.-- Capt. Edward Friend, of the El Paso Rifles, arrived here Tuesday night and opened a roll for recruits to join Cutting's filibustering expedition into Mexico.

SOFIA, Nov. 12.--The King of Denmark, on behalf of his son, Prince Waldemar, has sent a telegram to Tirnova expressing thanks for the honor conferred upon his son, but declining upon any condition to allow him to accept the throne. It is therefore needless to send a deputation to Cannes to meet Prince Waldemar.

KINGSTON, N. Y., Nov. 12.--Some years ago Jennie Mosier, of Esopus, was known far and wide as the belle of Ulster County. She was as accomplished as she was beautiful, and many suitors wooed the young girl. Among her lovers was a young man named Ozias Hermance.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 12.--A month ago Miss B.C. Callahan, a young lady of Macon, came to this city to be treated for her eyes. Soon afterward James Larden, one of the Superintendents or overseers at the Stone Mountain granite quarries, visited Atlanta and put up at the same hotel.

Charles B. Reynolds, who is indicted for blasphemy under the laws of New-Jersey, spoke for two hours yesterday at Chickering Hall before the tenth annual congress of the American Secular Union. " I went to Boonton, N.J., last Summer," he said.

MONTEVIDEO, Minn., Nov. 12.--At 2 o'clock this morning the Court House of Lae Qui Parle County, was broken into, presumably by a Madison delegation.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12.--At 2:55 o'clock this morning fire was discovered in the basement of the Chicago-Avenue Church, better known as "Moody's church," at the corner of Chicago and La Salle avenues. An alarm was given, but before the engines could respond the flames had burst through the first floor into the lecture room.
PARIS, Nov. 12.--The city of Nice has been visited by enormous waves from the Mediterranean. The water swept away the quays and the promenade on the Anglais plantation.

Since Oct. 1 Andrew Bennett, who makes wooden patterns at No. 388 Marion-street, Brooklyn, has been on the lookout for the burglars who have during that time broken into the place on five occasions and succeeded upon each of them in getting away with something of value.
Just before the night boat from Albany reached her dock at the foot of Vestry-street yesterday three boys were found concealed in the coal bunkers.

NEW-LISBON, Wis., Nov. 12.--A short time ago John Cavanaugh, of Cincinnati, Ohio, came to this village for the purpose of removing the remains of his mother, which were buried in the Catholic Cemetery in this place, to Cincinnati for final burial.

PARIS, Nov. 12.--At the meeting of the Budget Committee to-day M. Aube, the Minister of Marine and the Colonies, declined to modify his naval plans, declaring that without the additional credits asked for he would be unable to guarantee the security of the country.
DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 12.--The much-litigated affairs of the bankrupt banker, Vincent J. Scott, of this city, have been finally wound up by a compromise between all interested parties.

The sale of the Duke collection of autographs, consisting principally of letters by men famous in American colonial and Revolutionary history and of documents on Indian and frontier subjects, was begun yesterday afternoon at Bangs Co.'s auction rooms, No. 739 Broadway.
