Resolution were adopted congratulating the Democracy on the victory achieved in the election of Abram S. Hewitt as Mayor. Henry George was termed "a wild theorist" and " a veiled prophet of the Khorassan." The resolutions did not explain why Mr. Georgo carried the district against Mr. Hewitt.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 12.--Mr. Sam Small, the Georgia revivalist, is in this city making arrangements to assume the duties of Commissioner of Education for the colored race in the South.

BOSTON, Nov. 12.--The features of the day in the Wilson-Moen trial were the cross-examination of the defendant, Moen, and the introduction into the case of Hattie Engley, a central figure in this peculiar suit as a witness for the defence. Mr. Moen, when he took the stand, began with a correction of his evidence of yesterday. Lawyer West then resumed the crossexamination of Moen.

The Master Plumbers' Association held a public meeting last evening at No. 54 Unionsquare. There was a large attendance and the reports made seemed to indicate that the journeymen were weakening all along the line.

NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 13.--Col. William Lamb was seen to-night in regard to the alleged trouble between Congressman George D. Wise and himself. He says he knows of no difficulty between Wise and himself, and is much annoyed at being paraded in newspapers as a duelist.

The Supreme Court has affirmed the judgment of the lower court finding John W. Stokes guilty of adultery. The defendant had appealed on the ground that he and his wife were married under assumed names, and consequently the marriage was invalid.

The Harvard football team went down to Princeton yesterday and met the college champions on their native heath. It was a great game of football, and, though Harvard played well, she was unable to overcome the heavy metal of Princeton's nassive rush line.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 13.--Benjamin S. Wheller and his wife June, 81 and 78 years of age respectively, were a miserly old couple, and although worth about $500,000, lived, or rather existed in a state barely removed from squalor.

Marshal Bazaine has had a severe fall while walking in the Retiro. He had to be carried by the police and the bystanders to his house. There is a fracture of the right leg, causing much suffering.

KINGSTON, N. Y., Nov. 13.--Louis Willett alias Charles Crosby, was hanged in this city on January last, for tha murder of a saloon keeper named Kelland. Willett was arrested in a house on Cherry-street, New-York City, by Officers Thomas Murphy and Owen Hunley, of the Fourth Precinct.

The lays of Ohio require all property to be listed for taxation "at its true value in money." National bank stock is, as a rule, worth in the open market more than 100 cents on the dollar.

Col. E. C. Farrington, of this city, Maine's Inspector ol Rifle Practice, has received a letter from the Nevada Militia Inspector proposing a match, and replied giving the terms on which his men would shoot, which included team shooting, regimental matches, skirmish matches, , at 200 to 500 yards.

OTTAWA, Nov. 13.--An order in Council has been passed embodying a new set of rules applicable to all foreign vessels trading on the coast or entering the harbors of Canada from sea or inland waters. Foreign vessels are not allowed to take freight or passengers at one Canadian port and land them at another Canadian port under penalty of $400 fine.

The Hon. Jefferson Davis recently gave the site of his birtbplace, near Fairview, Ky., to a Baptist congregation, and a handsome brick church edifice has been erected thereon and the donor was invited to deliver an address at its dedication. Mr. Davis replied by letter that he regretted that the quarantine at Biloxi prevented his being present.

The clergy men who accuse five Professors in the Andover Theological Seminary of breach of trust have amended their charges by adding to them numerous quotations from the Professors' published writings.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Nov. 13.--William M. Hughes, of Hazleton, a well known patron of the turf and a popular politician of Luzerne County, got into a quarrel this afternoon with a man named Clem Wells, of Berwick, while at work on a railroad at Orangeville, rear Bloomsburg.

BERLIN, Nov. 13.--The programme of the Reichstag opens with the discussion of the report of the budget commissions on Foreign Affairs and Marine. It is uncertain whether the Government will propose new or augmented taxation.

The exhibition to be opened on Monday, the 22d inst., in the Madison-Square Garden, by Buffalo Bill and his Indians, cowboys, and Mexican vaqueros, will be entirely different in form from the Wild West exhibition which proved so successful on Staten Island last Summer.

It was common talk, at Richmond during the session of the General Assembly of the Knights of Labor that Litchman was elected Secretary because he could be depended upon to do exactly as he was ordered by the leaders of District Assembly No. 49, of this city. Brooklyn Knights who may not have entertained such a belief have probably changed their minds since the receipt of Secretary Litchman's latest manifesto.

MONTPELIER, Vt., Nov. 13.--Three freight engines on the Central Vermont Road were wrecked in a blinding snowstorm this morning, north of Montpelier. Joseph A. Weller, a member of the prominent wholesale dry goods firm of Tefft, Weller Co., of No. 335 Broadway, died at 9 o'clock last night of brain fever at his residence, No. 749 Fifth-avenue. Mr. Weller was born in Montgomery, Orange County, this State, in 1846.

Archbishop Corrigan administered the sacrament of confirmation to a large number of persons yesterday morning in St. Joseph's Church, Middletown, Orange County. The assistants were the Rector, the Rev. Peter J. Prendergast, the Rev. John P. McClaney, and the Rev. Charles E. McDonnell.
A public meeting of the Church Industrial Community of St. Johnland was held last evening in the Church of the Incarnation, Madison-avenue and Thirty-fifth-street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14.--The President had never been in Boston before he visited it on Monday last. He went there with assurances that he would be cordially welcomed, and he has returned feeling that all the promises held out to him were more than fulfilled.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 14.--The report of the Referee in the divorce suit of Frank B. Robinson against Yetta Robinson was submitted to Justice Vann, of the Supreme Court, yesterday. There was no defense, and the decree asked for will be granted almost as a matter of course.

FORTRESS MONROE, Va., Nov. 14.--The Yantic has received orders to coal at Norfolk and proceed to Aspinwall.

PHILIPPOPOLIS, Nov. 14.--The examination of a number of persons accused of conspiracy has revealed the face that an extensive revolutionary scheme, which was fostered by the Russian Consulate, has been nipped in the bud by the discovery of the plot.

Two ladies who were lately parishioners of the Rev. Dr. J.D. Newlin have given $250,000 for the erection of a Protestant Episcopal Memorial Church at the northwest corner of Eighteenth and Diamond streets.
DULUTH, Minn., Nov. 14.--Interesting statistics of new lake tonnage under contract and in process of construction have been gathered here.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Nov. 14.--The Minneapolis and Pacific Railway, work upon which was begun late in June last, will to-morrow commence running regular trains to Buffalo, Wright County, 40 miles distant from Minneapolis.

The quarrel of the younger and older theologians at Andover concerning the proper way of converting the heathen was discussed by the Rev. Dr. Robert Collyer at the Church of the Messiah yesterday morning in a sermon on "Christ and Calvin at Andover."

BOSTON, Nov. 14.--The schism which seems destined to shake the relations between Harvard and Princeton, as a result of the poem of Dr. Olives Wendell Holmes and the utterances of James Russell Lowell on the occasion of Harvard's celebration a week ago, was brought to the attention of Dr. Holmes this evening.

MONTREAL, Nov. 14.--Billy Moloney's son was yesterday morning attacked at the Bonaventure station by a drunken carter, who beat him about the head, closing one of his eyes and otherwise disfiguring him, and winding up by throwing him under the horses' feet. A warrant has been taken out against the Carter, but he has not yet been arrested. The attack was altogether unprovoked.

LISBON, Nov. 14.--Advices from Mozambique say there have been frequent skirmishes of late between native insurgents and the Portuguese forces there.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 14.--The next issue of the Labor Tribune will contain a call for a convention of all the trades unions in the United States and Canada, to begin at Columbus, Ohio, on Wednesday, Dec. 8.
The building season now drawing to a close in Philadelphia has been the most remarkable for the improvements inaugurated and completed, in the history of the city.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 14--There is no longer any doubt that Gen. E.H. Alexander is in the race for the Presidency of the Central Railroad system. His friends are organized, determined, and confident. It is said that the block of stock owned by Mrs. Greene, of NewYork, will control the election this year, as it did when Gen. Alexander was beaten before.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 14.--The whole population of Niagara Falls surrounded the Suspension Bridge to-day and waited for hours in cold and wind for the Buffalo barber who was to make the leap a la Larry Dunovan. But the barber is a wise man. He staid at home and let the crowd wait.
HARRISON, Ark., Nov. 14.--Andrew J. Mulligan, alias James Page, the murderer of James N. Hamilton, was taken from the jail here by a mob last night and shot to death.
NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 14.--In the case of John B. Whitehead, after being out about 10 hours, the jury reached a verdict shortly before 1 o'clock this morning.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 14.--The Hon. John M. Glover, the Congressional representative from the Ninth Missouri District, started for Washington last night with a black eye.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14.--For some reason or another the great railroad boom which has been predicted all Summer does not come to light. Instead of an improvement business is getting worse from week to week, both on the Eastern and Western roads.
Capt. W. McMickan, of the Cunard steamship Umbria, yesterday completed his seven hundred and ninety-ninth trip across the Atlantic.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14.--Little Daisy Irich, 15 years old, died early this morning of what is supposed to have been hydrophobia. The child's father is a fireman, living at Danville, Ill. A year or more ago his house was broken up and Daisy was sent to this city to receive an education.

MONTREAL, Nov. 14.--The Canadian Pacific Railway Company will iu its next annual report produce figures to show that the assessed values of property in Montreal, Quebec, Toronto, and the other cities of Canada have, since the inception of the railway, increased more than the total amount the receive from the country in and of its construction, and that the country has thus been refunded for every cent paid out on this account.

The Rev. Dr. Henry Y. Satterlee, who is to preside to-day at the opening session of the Church Temperance Society's Convention, in Annex Hall, No. 16 Fourth-avenue, made an earnest plea yesterday, at Calvary Church, for the society and its work. The society, he said, was destined to accomplish much good.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 14.--An immense crowd, numbering nearly 10,000 people, gathered at the Pavilion last night to witness the Sullivan-Ryan contest. The building was packed to overflowing.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 14.--New-Haven doctors are discussing the question whether typhoid fever could be caused by oysters.

Aathur Rehan, manager of the company playing "Nancy Co.," and Clarence Harvey, of the "Night Off" company, who indulged in fisticuffs in front of the Grand Opera House, at Newark, on Saturday night, were arraigned in court yesterday. Both pleaded not guilty to counter charges of assault and battery. Rehan gave bail for the Grand Jury, and Harvey for an examination on the 24th inst.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14.--E.B. Townrow, of Brooklyn, about 45 years of age, committed suicide by taking arsenic to-day in his room at the Bound Brook Hotel, English and Spring Garden streets. He left a note stating that his life was a failure and requesting that his brother, F.W. Townrow, No. 90 Broadway, Brooklyn, be notified.

The committee appointed at the AntiSaloon Republican Covention, held at Binghamton in September to organize a State Temperance Republican League, has called a convention to meet at Cortland on Tuesday, Nov. 30, and on the following day.

DUBLIN, Nov. 14.--A partially successful operation has been performed on Mr. Kelly, who was shot between Ennis and Firgrove. The bullet has been extracted from his back, and his case is regarded as hopeful.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 14.--At 9 o'clock this morning, one of Lucky Baldwin's jockeys, named Monahan, was exercising Silver Cloud, the winner of the Chicago Derby, and other racers, on the Bay District track, this city. The draw gate had been carelessly left open, and the horse dashed through, ran against a fence, and was instantly killed. The jockey, a 13-year-old boy, sustained concussion of the brain and a broken collar bone, and will hardly survive.
"J.A.R."--Feb. 4, 1884. A performance for the benefit of the Actors' Fund of America is to be given by Manager Aronson, at the Casino, early in December.

About 50 deaf-mutes occupied seats in St. Ann's Church, on Eighteenth-street, near Fifthavenue, last evening. The Right Rev. Bishop Whipple, of Minnesota, delivered a sermon which was translated to the deaf-mutes by means of signs and the hand alphabet.

Some days ago the constabulary received information that a carpenter named Hugh Stewart, who has lately showed unmistakable signs of insanity, was starving himself to death. On the police proceeding to the house they found the doors barricaded and the windows nailed.

READING, Penn., Nov. 14.--The many recent violations of the Sunday liquor law in this city and the increasing number of drunken brawlers, besides stabbing affrays, all of which have occurred on Sundays within the last month or two, have led to steps being taken to prosecute all infringements of that character.

LONDON, Nov. 14.--Advices have been received at Plymouth that the Chinese steamship Takataman burst her boilers while running under high pressure in a gale off Niigata, and that 96 persons who were on board perished, including the officers, who were Englishman.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Nov. 14.--William M. Graham, at one time prominent in banking and political circles, and again an inmate of the penitentiary, died in this village last night of Bright's disease, aged 67 years.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14.--The Rev. Dr. Thomas went down to Packingtown to-day to preach to the young militiamen stationed there. Just before Dr. Thomas began the services he discovered that he had forgotten his Bible.

PRINCESS ANN, Md., Nov. 14.--A bold attempt was made last night to burn the Somerset County Jail, in this town. The man charged with the crime is James Stevens, colored, who was convicted at the October term of the Circuit Court of committing an assault upon an aged widow, and who is now under sentence of death.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Nov. 14.--The Dominion Government has demanded a deposit of $400 for the release of the Gloucester fishing schooner Flying Scud, which was seize yesterday for selling come of her gear.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14.--It looks very much as if the Washington Police Department would have to be thoroughly reorganized or else become an object of so much resentment on the part of Congress as to make it difficult to secure decent consideration from that body.

LONDON, Nov. 15.--This was the first day of the Derby November meeting. The race for the Chesterfield Nursery Handicap of 1,000 sovereigns, for 2-year-olds, distance about five furlongs, was won by Mr. Manton's br.c. Lourdes by a length.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 15.--The steamer Oceanic, which arrived to-day from Hong-Kong and Yokohoma, brings news of the foundering of the steamer Normantore off Pashima, Japan, with 72 persons on board, 12 of whom reached land. She was laden with tea for New-York and Canada. The date of the disaster is not given.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15.--First Lieut. Henry H. Dunwoody, Fourth Artillery, Acting Signal Officer, has been ordered to Philadelphia on special signal duty. The leave of absence of Major Charles I. Wilson, Paymaster, has been extended one month.
An oil tank at the Eagle Refining Company's works, at Caven Point, Jersey City, exploded last night, causing a damage of $2,000. William Parker, who was in charge of the still, was severely burned.

Additional railroad earnings for the first week of November were reported in Wall-street yesterday as follows: Indianapolis and St. Louis, $25,129, a decrease of $1,735; Burlington, Cedar Rapids and Northern, $71,559, a decrease of $1,681; Evansville and Terre Haute, $14,547, a decrease of $617; East Tennessee, Virginia and Georgia, $89,399, a dcrease of $1,803; Memphis and Charleston, $45,546, an increase of $12,323.

It is now settled that there will be no fight at the meeting for the election of new Directors of the Richmond and West Point Terminal Company at Richmond the latter part of this week. A large number of New-Yorkers will attend, and Alfred Sully will be chosen President of the company.

Amanda Quinn, the servant girl on whose complaint Dr. Herman W. Gedicke and Rudolph G. Schaaf were arrested in Newark on Saturday, died yesterday at St. Michael's Hospital. The girl was but 18 years of age and rather pretty.

BOSTON, Nov. 15.--Edgar Lombard, member of the old shipping firm of A.C. Lombard's Sons, of No. 53 State-street, committed suicide at Young's Hotel this morning under very peculiar circumstances. Mr. Lombard, a man of considerable wealth, for many years lived at Braintree.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15.--A marine mystery is reported from Escanaba. Saturday morning Capt. Coleman, of the schooner Moonlight, reached that port and reported sighting a large vessel on Whale's Back Reef flying a signal of distress.

Congressman-elect S.S. Cox entertained the members of the Young Men's Democratic Club last night by a few remarks on Democracy and the Henry George movement. He spoke generally against the theory of protection, and argued that the workingmen could be converted to the ranks of the tariff reform men.

To-day a motion is to be made in behalf of JACOB SHARP and the others charged with bribing the Aldermen of 1884 that the court compel the District Attorney to furnish those defendants with the evidence upon which the indictments against them were found.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Nov. 15.--Joseph McMeen, under sentence of death in the jail at Mifflintown for murdering his wife by poison last March, escaped about midnight last night and is still at large. He was accompanied in his flight by Aaron Carter, colored, awaiting trial on a charge of abduction. McMeen's case had been appealed to the Supreme Court, and a decision was daily expected.

The marriage of Miss Amy Hewitt, daughter of Mayor-elect Abram S. Hewitt, to Mr. James Green, son of Dr. Norvin Green, which took place yesterday at Ringwood, N.J., was a most pleasant home wedding. William L. Scott, of Erie, Congressman, capitalist, and political manager, is passing through an experience that has somewhat dampened his ardor for the turf and may much restrict the generous outlay which he meant to continue to provide for his stable of racers.

The congregation of the Fort Greene Presbyterian Church, of Brooklyn, held a public meeting last evening to decide whether the resignation of the Rev. Benjamin Staunton, who was recently found guilty of conduct unbecoming a minister by the Presbytery, should be accepted.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15.--The Post tomorrow will publish an article saying that the Bartholdi statue remains unlighted because different branches of the Government are waiting for each other to take the initiative.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 15.--The wife of Judge Higgins, of Dayton, accompanied by two other ladies, Sarah Apple and Harriet Dey, the latter 60 years of age, drove to the city to attend court to-day. On Neilson-street the horses ran away and all were thrown out. Mrs. Dey was severely injured, her right side being paralyzed.

The recount of the votes cast for Assemblyman in the Second District of Mercer County was finished at a late hour in Trenton last night. The total vote for Jones, Republican, is 2,282, and the total vote for Walter, Democrat, is 2,278.

Noah S. Hunt, who died suddenly on Friday at the Grand Union Hotel, was buried at noon yesterday from the residence of his brother, Gen. Samuel I. Hunt, No. 41 West Thirty-fourthstreet. As Mr. Hunt had lived in retirement a long time before his death and belonged to another generation, only his relatives and a few old friends were present.

Some time ago, after an examination was made at the Custom House of applicants for promotion in the service, the man who stood highest on the roll was passed over and another of lower grade was promoted ahead of him.

BERLIN, Nov. 15.--Prince Bismarck, before his departure for Friedrichsruhe, had a prolonged interview with Emperor William. The Chancellor will return on the 28th inst. to take part in the proceedings of the Reichstag.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 15.--The McCaull Opera Company appeared at the Opera House to-night in the opera of "Don Caesar." The demand for seats was enormous, every seat in the house being sold before the company arrived, and applications enough to fill the theatre for three nights were received.

The Baptist Pastors, at their weekly meeting at No. 9 Murray-street, yesterday, listened to a lecture on "Mormonism" by the Rev. Mr. Lamb, of Salt Lake City. Mr. Lamb is stationed in Utah by the American Baptist Home Mission Society.

BOSTON, Nov. 15.--The fishing schooner Morning Star, Capt. Jennison, was run into off Thatcher's Island last night, and sank in three minutes. The crew of six men were picked up and landed at Marblehead.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Nov. 15.--The crowd that gathered in Room C of the Common Pleas Court, No. 2, this morning, to hear the bones of the Bartol family skeleton rattle went away disappointed. Lawyer White, of counsel for Mr. Bartol, said to Judge Fell: "We do not know exactly how we stand in this case.

CALDWELL, Kan., Nov. 15.--A company of soldiers have been ordered to this place from Fort Reno to keep prospectors out of the Indian Territory. The greatest excitement prevails. Thousands of claims have been staked out in the Territory below Caldwell, where silver is believed to exist in large quantities.

LONDON, Nov. 15.--The Council of the Social Democratic Federation will send a letter to the Marquis of Salisbury demanding of him that he, as Prime Minister, receive a deputation of unemployed workingmen on next Sunday afternoon and hear from them a statement of reasons for Government assistance.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15.--Saturday afternoon a New-York lawyer named Stern appeared before Justice Kistler and secured three attachments on the effects of Edward T. Burton, manager of the "'Silver Spur' Company," then playing at the Standard Theatre.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15.--The chimes of old Christ Church, on Second-street, rang out this afternoon, announcing the marriage of Ellen Duane Gillespie, only daughter of Mrs. E.D. Gallespie, to Dr. Edward Parker Davis, of Chicago.

BOSTON, Nov. 15.--The meeting of the Committee on Federal Aid to the Common Schools, appointed in July last by the National Teachers' Association at Topeka and the American Institute of Instruction at Bar Harbor, which has been in session here for the past week, adjourned to-day.

Punctually at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon a number of gentlemen appeared at the dock of the Compagnie Generale Transatlantique, lured thither by deceptive telegrams which informed them that La Champagne, with the artist Mihali Munkacsy, would be at Quarantine by 3 o'clock.

In opening the fifth annual convention of the Church Temperance Society, at Annex Hall, opposite Cooper Union, yesterday afternoon, the Rev. Dr. H.Y. Satterlee, of this city, who presided, spoke encouragingly of the work from an educational point of view. Discouragements were in the minimum and productive results might be hoped for.

The Tammany Society of the Annexed District, known as "Little Tammany," will tomorrow night celebrate the election of Mayorelect Hewitt and the Twenty-fourth Assembly District candidates of the County Democracy by a torchlight procession.
A choice collection of weapons was taken in at the Tombs Police Court yesterday. The first consignment consisted of five revolvers and seven knives, taken from five Italians at Castle Garden.

The will of Petro Terry y Dorticos was offered for probate in the Surrogate's office yesterday. It was executed in Paris, Sept. 16, 1886. Dorticos died in that city and the will was sent here by Consul-General Walker.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Nov. 15.--In March last the proprietors of the Champion Bar and Knife Works, of this city, were informed by the bookkeeper, Frank B. Jones, that the safe had been opened and that the cash book, day book, and ledger were missing.

William H. Kiernan, the Assistant Secretary of the Chamber of Commerce, and a prominent Brooklyn Catholic, died Saturday at the house of a friend, Valentine E. Ward, No. 855 Willoughby-street, Brooklyn.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 15.--The First National Bank of Pine Bluff, Ark., closed its doors this morning. C.M. Neel, the principal owner, has been a heavy operator in real estate and cotton, and owns the Swan Lake Railroad. He explains that the suspension was caused by drafts on cotton and commission merchants not being honored. He is understood to possess large means, but nothing is as yet known of the extent of his liabilities.

McQuade, who was a member of the Board of Aldermen of 1884, and who is charged with having accepted a bribe to secure his vote in favor of the passage of a resolution giving the Broadway Surface Railway Company the right to lay tracks on Broadway, was brought up for trial yesterday before Recorder Smyth, in the Court of General Sessions.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15.--The action of the Republican members-elect of the Legislature in this city and Pittsburg, in declaring for State Treasurer Quay for United States Senator, has settled the fact that as things now are no candidate can make a hopeful contest against him.

PORTLAND, Me., Nov. 15.--James Young, of Farmington, has been murdered in a logging camp in the Moosehead Lake lumbering region. He engaged in a fight with a fellow-logger, and was stabbed in the throat. He soon commenced to bleed, and before help arrived was dead. His murderer has not been arrested.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 15.--The Federal Grand Jury reassembled this afternoon and began the inquiry into the many alleged election irregularities. The jury will have its hands full for a week or more.

TROY, N.Y., Nov. 15.--For over an hour to-day the occupants of the City Hall were engaged in seeking for the cause of a smell of burning oil and gas. The corridors of the building were filled with the odor and considerable uneasiness prevailed.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Nov. 15.--The Gloucester schooner Flying Scud is still held in custody. Consul Phelan thinks that when the Minister of Customs learns the true situation of affairs he will consider further detention of the vessel wmwarranted and will release her without a fine.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 15.--The Hon. Frank H. Hurd, who was defeated for Congress in the Tenth District, was in Columbus to-day, and in conversation expressed his belief in the final triumph of revenue reform and ultimate free trade.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15.--The American Opera Company sang "Faust" at the Academy of Music this evening to an immense audience. Miss Juch's Marguerite was very fine, but the other leading roles were rather weak. The opera was beautifully mounted. The performance was rather slow, and it was long after midnight before the opera was over.

The proposed court-martial of Col. Fackner and Lieut. Ackerman, of the Thirteenth Regiment, has been abandoned, and, upon the recommendation of Brig.-Gen. McLeer, a court of inquiry is to investigate the troubles in the regiment. The court will probably consist of Cols. Clark, of the Seventh Regiment; Scott, of the Eighth, and Camp, of the Twenty-second.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 15.--Dr. Hodge, Professor of Theology in Princeton Seminary, was buried here to-day. His funeral was very largely attended. The First Presbyterian Church, in which the ceremonies were held, was crowded to a most uncomfortable degree.

GREENVILLE, Texas, Nov. 15.--A few miles from Liberty Hill, Williamson County, is the plantation of Charles Baker, a well-to-do farmer, who recently lost his wife. About a month ago neighbors saw that Baker's mind was becoming affected.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 15.--The Hon. Alfred Shaw died this evening at 7 o'clock, aged 56. He was a Pennsylvanian of Dutch ancestry. He came here as a school teacher before the war, was a member of the Constitutional Convention of 1864, and subsequently Sheriff of the parish.

The annual meeting of the Brooklyn Maternity and the graduation exercises of its adjunct, the Training School for Nurses, which were held last evening in the hall of the Long Island Historical Society, in Pierrepont-street, attracted more people than the auditorium could accommodate.

In one of the most prominent editorial articles in its issue of yesterday the New-York Sun discourses of blackmail and in another of poison. The Sun has a deep interest in these subjects and an intimate acquaintance with them.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 15.--S.W. Seton, Karr, who was with Schwatka on Mount St. Elias, arrived here last night. He corroborates Schwatka's account of the discovery of Jones River, and says he ascended Mount St. Elias to a higher point than Schwatka.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 15.--Dr. McCosh, President of Princeton College, and Dr. Eliot, President of Harvard University, were very warm friends until quite recently. Last Winter Dr. Eliot paid a visit to Dr. McCosh and was handsomely entertained.

A gastronomical contemporary sets forth that the boiled juice of the clam is in great request as a breakfast by persons who have over night dined not wisely but too well. It adds that this corrective has long been known in London, but is just beginning to make its way in this country.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15.--Ten thousand men who were strikers Saturday formed in lines before the offices of the packing houses at the stock yards early this morning and one by one asked to be taken back to work on any terms. The packers imposed terms that a fortnight ago would have created a rebellion.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 16.--The body of the late Judge Alfred Shaw was conveyed to the grave this evening by a large procession of lawyers, graduates, and members of the various orders to which he belonged. He was the senior member of most of those bodies.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Nov. 16.--The Ulster County Board of Supervisors is a tie politically. The members have been voting steadily for a Chairman for a week with the invariable result of 13 to 13. The deadlock continues to-night. The expense is more than $100 a day, and taxpayers are becoming impatient. Apparently there is no prospect of the deadlock being broken.

Cyrus W. Field, Simon Wormser, and Thomas W. Pearsall are still seeking revenge upon somebody for their failure to get hold of the second mortgage bonds of the New-York and New-England Railroad Company recently sold by the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

KINGSTON, Ontario, Nov. 16--A citizen of this place went to New-York last week and purchased $1,000 in counterfeit bills for $80. He was under the impression that he had got what he had bargained for, but on opening his valise for inspection at Cape Vincent the customs officer found the supposed package of money to be merely a roll of sawdust and rubbish.

WILLIAMSBURG, Ky., Nov. 16.--At Kenzee coal mines in this county, while James and John Mills, brothers, were at work, a large piece of coal weighing about a ton fell from the roof of the mine striking James on the back, crushing him to the ground and killing him almost instantly. John Mills had his foot badly mashed, which necessitated amputation.

OWENSBOROUGH, Ky., Nov. 16.--Nora Brown, the stepdaughter of Mr. Jack Cull, of this city, while suffering with fever yesterday, created quite a stir in the family circle by suddenly exclaiming that she saw an angel, and the messenger said to her in clear tones: "Thou shalt live another year." She further said that she felt its hands on her knees. She was not given to exaggeration, and it was certainly a strange message.

The Real Estate Bulletin, a new and promising weekly publication, devoted to real estate, has made its appearance here to-day. Its special purpose is the advertising of real estate by illustration and otherwise. It is said to be backed by a publishing company with abundant capital, headed by a prominent Broadway real estate agent.

The establishment of the Whiting Manufacturing Company, the well known silversmiths, at Union-square and East Sixteenthstreet, is a bewildering place. Many customers and sightseers visit it every day, and find escape cut off by solid lines of silver on every side.

LONDON, Nov. 16.--Russia has designated Prince Nicolas of Mingrelia as her candidate for the throne of Bulgaria. The other powers have unanimously approved of him as the successor to Prince Alexander, and have invited Russia to propose a satisfactory solution of her conflict with the Bulgarian Regency.

KEYPORT, N.J., Nov. 16.--The stores of Commissioner Thomas Brown, John F. Runyan, Thomas Burrowes, and James Van Brakle were entered by burglars last evening and a large quantity of goods stolen. An attempt was made to force open the safe in Burrowes's store, but it was unsuccessful. There is no clue to who the burglars were.

OSWEGO, N. Y., Nov. 16.--John Crowley, an old man who was partially blind and deaf, was run over and killed by the cars while attempting to cross the track on the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad this afternoon.

The sale of the Brinley Library was continued yesterday at Leavitt's Art Rooms, Broadway and Tenth-street. The same people were on hand as on the first day, and displayed the same exact knowledge of what they wanted and of the limit of price they cared to give.

A public reception will be held to-morrow afternoon and evening at Primrose House, No. 356 West Thirty--third-street. This institution is the home of the Society to Befriend Working Girls, and was opened last May.

A new organ built by Mr. Hilborne L. Roosevelt for the South Church, situated at Fifthavenue and Twenty-first street, was performed upon by Mr. Clarence Eddy last evening to the gratification of an assemblage that filled the place of worship which the instrument graces.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Nov. 16.--For the past 23 years a large tree, familiarly known to Hudson River boatmen as the "Nine-mile tree," has served as a landmark. The tree was nine miles south of Hudson, on the east bank of the river. During the heavy winds of Friday night the old tree was blown down, and the once familiar landmark has disappeared forever.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Nov. 16.--The crew of the schooner Ishpeming, which was found deserted on Whale's Back, Green Bay, on Saturday, have turned up all right. They left Menominee this morning, bound for Chicago, by rail.

Moncrief, of Greenfield, on account of lunacy. Mr. Moncrief was not discharged from sercive until 1880, and the payment will be $12,244 14, with $72 per month thereafter.

WATERBURY, Conn., Nov. 16.--Waterbury's hospital has received a large gift from Erastus L. Deforest, of Watertown, who has sent a check for $25,000 to the Treasurer of the hospital fund. It is now probable that a hospital building will be bought of erected immediately.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16.--Palestine Commandery, Knights Templar, of New-York City, arrived in Washington to-night over the Pennsylvania Railroad. They are quartered at the Ebbitt House. Forty-five more machinists employed at the Brooklyn Navy Yard were discharged yesterday, making 120 men laid off since election day. Late last night Constructor Pook received word from Washington to discharge an additional lot on Dec. 1. Secretary Whitney has found that his appropriation for December will not permit the employment of the large force now at work. To-day the new cruiser Atlanta will make her final trial trip on the Sound.
TORONTO, Nov. 16.--The dissolution of the Ontario Parliament has been officially announced. New elections for the Province of Ontario will take place Dec. 29.

The final arrangements for the performance of "The Archanians," at the Academy of Music, on Friday night, are progressing with a harmony which promises well for the smoothness and excellence of the play. The rehearsals at Philadelplia have shown a most satisfactory advance over those of last Spring.

NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 16.While Joseph and Mary Tilman were away from home their three children--Lillie, Mary, and George--aged 6. 4, and 2 years, respectively, began playing with a can of kerosene oil. While pouring some oil on the stove the oil in the can exploded, throwing the burning oil on them. The two first named died about midnight and the youngest this morning.

Senator William B. Allison, of Iowa, is at the Brevoort House.

Ex-Sheriff Alexander Davidson is now sojourning in the city of Mexico, where he has been living since last February, when he suddenly left this city to escape civil and criminal actions. PORTLAND, Me., Nov. 16.--John Garbarrino, aged 23, and Mary Polardo, aged 15, two Italians, who ran away from Lynn a week ago, were arrested in Lewiston to-night. They were to have been married Thursday.

RED BANK, N. J., Nov. 16.--James P. Johnson was seriously wounded to-day while out gunning with a party of friends. Johnson had left his party, and was chasing a rabbit, when suddenly he heard a report and the next moment he received the contents of one of his friends' guns in his face and neck.

The annual report of the Oregon Railway and Navigation Company was made public yesterday for the year ending June 30. RICHMOND, Va., Nov, 16.--The Hon. George D. Wise was arrested this morning on a warrant charging him with being about to commit a breach of the peace. The arrest is the result of the publication in to-day's papers of a card by Mr. Wise, denouncing in the strongest language Col. William Lamb, ex-Mayor of Norfolk. Mr. Wise was put under $1,000 bond to keep the peace.

OTTAWA, Nov. 16.-- The schooner Flying Scud, which was seized at Halifax by Capt. Metzler, of one of the fisheries protective cutters, has been released upon the payment of a fine of $400, under protest. She is charged with contravening the letter and the spirit of the customs law through offering for sale fishing gear.

RALEIGH, N.C., Nov. 16.--A fire at Durham early this morning destroyed a large portion of the town. It orignated in the grocery store of R. H. Atwater, and the flames soon caught the great tobacco warehouse of E.J. Parrish, in the rear, and consumed that entire square, comprising 13 buildings, all of brick.

JUTLAND, N. J., Nov. 16.--William Fleming, living near Pattenburg, was instantly killed last night by being struck by a passenger train on the Lehigh Valley Railroad, between here and his home. His body was mangled almost beyond recognition. He leaves a large family.

The third day's sale of the Brinley library, at the Leavitt Art Rooms, brought out the usual buyers, and, except in a few instances, the prices did not rule much higher than before. The lots offered yesterday were dramatic works, fiction, popular literature, juvenile books, educational works, almanacs, and the theological writings of New-England clergymen.

Respectable and wealthy Adam Bickelhaupt a skylight manufacturer of No. 218 West Thirty-seventh-street, changed his way of living after he was nominated for Alderman in the Fifteenth Assembly District on the Labor and Irving Hall tickets, and associated with the lowest class of political heelers.

NEW-HEAVEN, Conn., Nov. 17.--After a fruitless conference to-day between a committee of the Knights of Labor and the Secretary of the Southington Cutlery Company about 100 men went out on strike. Their pay was reduced some weeks ago, and they demand an increase of from 5 to 10 per cent.

Mrs. Jane B. Andrews, who was taken from the Grand Union Hotel on Tuesday to Bellevue Hospital, suffering from opium poisoning, was in a delirious condition all yesterday and unable to talk coherently. Mrs. Andrews had been at the hotel for two days, and arrived there from Poughkeepsie. She told the hospital authorities that she had no friends, but no further information could be obtained.

The New-York creditors of the Rochester Distilling Company have received a circular calling upon them to attend a general meeting of creditors, to be held in Power's Hotel, at Rochester, and stating that the company is unable to meet its maturing obligations on account of the failure of the Duffy Malt Whisky Company.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 17.--The annual session of the Grand Lodge, Independent Order of Odd Fellows of New-Jersey, began in the Taylor Opera House to-day, and will be continued to-morrow, when the new officers will be elected.

The debut of the famous painting of Michael Schroder, of Munkasc, Hungary, called "Christ Before Pilate," took place last night in the presence of a number of clergymen. Applause was discreetly moderated, but it was plain from the intent countenances of the reverend gentlemen present that they were well pleased ...

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 17.--The Rome, Watertown and Ogdensburg Railroad was granted permission just prior to the adjournment of the Common Council last night to extend its tracks by bridge across the Genesee River, along Cliff-street and Lake-avenue to what is known as the Whitney homestead, where a station will be erected.

The gymnasium of the New-York Athletic Club was comfortably filled last evening when the regular monthly gymnastic exercises were held. The sport consisted of boxing by well known professionals and amateurs.
HAVANA, Nov. 17.--Bandits in the Province of Santa, Clara kidnaped the steward of the sugar estate Santa Lugarda. He was afterward ransomed for $5,500.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17.--There was a sudden drop in barometers to-day, and the Captains of a big fleet of vessels ready to leave port sought the signal service for an explanation. The observer told them that a storm of great violence was about to sweep over the lakes coming directly from the east and northeast and advised them to stay in port.

Thomas Bell McCreedy, of No. 315 East Fifty-fifth-street, has a son Robert. When the boy came home from school Tuesday afternoon he obtained permission from his mother to play in the street.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Nov. 17.--The Reserve Mutual Life Insurance Company has collapsed. Its risks will be reinsured in the Massachusetts Benefit Association. Gross mismanagement and bad risks are given as the causes of the trouble, there being no funds to pay 10 losses amounting to $23,000.

The independent voter as a practical force in politics was discussed at a meeting of the Constitution Club, at No. 64 Madison-avenue, last evening.

Two men were placed at the bar before Justice Vaughn on Staten Island two weeks ago, both charged with trivial offenses. One was educated and refined while the other was absolutely ignorant. After hearing the case the Judge delivered the following sentence: "You," (speaking to the educated man,) "are evidently well educated, while your brother in crime is absolutely illiterate--cannot even write his own.

The Church of the Messiah, on Park-avenue, was the scene last evening of the wedding of Miss Annie R. Rogers, daughter of Henry H. Rogers, and Mr. William Evart Benjamin--the edifice being crowded with friends of the bride and groom.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov . 17.--The snowstorm which set in Monday night gradually increased in fury until last night, when it developed into a blizzard of great size, which has been raging all to-day, and to-night shows no signs of abatement.

The rain in no way interfered to prevent an outpouring of ladies, with a liberal sprinkling of gentlemen, to attend the first matinee of "Love in Harness" at Daly's Theatre yesterday, and the house was packed to the curtains of the lobby. BALTIMORE, Nov. 17.--The Baptist Congress resumed its sessions this afternoon. It was decided to increase the membership. There are now 127 members. Dr. N.K. Davis, Professor of Moral Philosophy in the University of Virginia, read a paper on "Religious Instruction in state Education."

CHICAGO, Nov. 17.--The stock yards are once more resuming their wonted appearance, and the strikers are fast returning to their places. The First Regiment was withdrawn this afternoon, and with the departure of the militiamen a number of the non-union men have signified their intention of quitting and not resuming work in the morning.

The factory Nos. 20 and 22 Pell-street, which was badly wrecked by fire about three years ago, was again on fire early yesterday morning. It is a six-story building, and the fourth, fifth, and sixth floors were occupied by Rest, Fenner, Smith Co., manufacturers of walking canes.
Railroad earnings reported in Wall-street yesterday for the second week of November showed a decrease of $13,030 for the St. Paul Road and an increase of $1,200 for the St. Louis and San Francisco.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 17.--The Coroner is still investigating the death of Miss Emma Pearson. There is little additional information to be gathered in connection with the tragic death, and it now appears that the solution of the mystery must await the untangling of a long chain of circumstances.

The striking brassworkers held another meeting yesterday at Military Hall. The Executive Committee announced that negotiations were going on with the firm of Mayer Lane, of Mott-street, for the purchase of its plant for the Brassworkers' Union. Should the nenotiations succeed the union will start a co-operative shop for the manufacture of plumbers' supplies.
BERLIN, Nov. 17.--It is believed that it will be necessary to issue a loan for 72,000,000 marks to balance the next imperial budget.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Nov. 17.--It is positively stated that Mrs. Hetty Green, of New-York, sold her 6,450 shares of Georgia Central Railroad stock to-day. The Gen. Alexander Syndicate was the purchaser at 140, private sale. The market was excited, the stock selling at 112.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Nov. 17.--A telegram from St. Andrews, New-Brunswick, says: "The Dominion cruiser General Middleton has arrived here. On Friday last she seized in East Quaddy River four Eastport fishing vessels--a schooner and three sloops--for a violation of the customs regulations. The fact of the seizure was telegraphed to Ottawa, and orders were received to release the vessels upon the owners depositing $20 for each boat. The deposits were made and the boats released."

CONSTANTINOPLE, Nov. 17.--The Grand Cordon of the Imperial Order of Medjidie has been conferred on Mr. Cox, ex-United States Minister to Turkey.

The troubles in the old Bushwick Reformed Church, in Brooklyn, Eastern District, have culminated in the resignation of the Pastor, the Rev Robert H. Barr, which will take effect on Dec. 1. Three years ago Mr. Barr came to the church.

BERLIN, Nov. 17.--The Post says it is reported on semi-official authority that Gen. Kaulbars is about to be recalled from Bulgaria, and adds that the step will be accepted as indicative that the powers have arranged to replace the attempt to solve the Bulgarian difficulty by action on the spot by international adjustment.

LOWELL, Mass., Nov. 17.--The hearing in the suit against the Erie Telephone and Telegraph Company was resumed this morning, when the reading of the petition of A.S. Temple, agent in the Dakota purchase, was completed. He deposed that he placed no dependence on Glidden, Ingham, and Downs, as they all told different stories to him.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17.--A special dispatch to the Times from Washington says it is hinted in political circles that a movement is on foot in Pennsylvania to present the name of Lieut.-Gov. Black for the Turkish mission. It is understood that Mr. Black would not decline sucn an honor at the close of his present term.

READING, Penn., Nov. 17.--The disappearance of Thomas Wilson, Superintendent of the Foxhill quarries, at St. Mary's, has caused no little sensation, as he had left on Thursday to get the money to pay off the hands, the amount to be disbursed being $7,000 among stone cutters and quarrymen.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 17.--Drafts on NewYork, sight, 15 cents; telegraphic, 20 cents.

TORONTO, Nov. 17.--During a quarrel with his father to-day Charles McAuley, aged 40 years, a tinsmith, knocked the old man down and kicked his skull in with his heavy boots. Death ensued almost instantly.

The troubles of the Centennial Baptist Church and its Pastor, the Rev. Dr. Justin D. Fulton, have only just begun, according to the statement made by Dr. Fulton yesterday. The whole fight between him and Dr. E.H. Knight has been caused by the presence of Miss Anna Dannington in the family of the latter, and Dr. Fulton ...

The examination of Charles O. Ferris alias Charles Curtis, alias Sir Roger Tichborne, charged with obtaining $3,500 pension money under false pretenses, was continued yesterday in the United States court in Brooklyn. The old soldier, Dick, who testified to having known Ferris for 50 years, was rigidly cross-examined with the view of showing that he deserted from ...

BURLINGTON, Vt., Nov. 17.--The Jennie Saxton forgery case and the scandal in which it involved John L. Mason continue to be the almost sole topic of conversation on the streets and in business circles, and the indications are that the affair will take on a still more sensational aspect.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17.--The President to-day appointed Pay Director James Fulton to be Chief of teh Bureau of Provisions and Clothing and Paymaster-General of the Navy.
FREEHOLD, N.J, Nov. 17.--Minnie Anderson, the 13-year-old daughter of James T. Anderson, a farmer living about five miles from this place, has been missing from her home since Monday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17.--The Board of Directors of the National League Baseball association held their annual meeting to-day and duly awarded the championship of 1886 to the Chicago Club. N.E. Young was re-elected Secretary for the seventeenth consecutive time. Her man Doscher, expelled by the Detroit Club in 1882 for financial irregularities, was reinstated.

The twentieth annual meeting of the Telegraphers' Mutual Benefit Association was held yesterday in the Western Union Building. The reports of the Secretary and Treasurer show favorable results for the year ended Oct. 31. The net gain in membership was 230, the present membership being 3,102. There were 22 deaths during the year, a death rate of slightly over 7 per 1,000.

Mrs. Bridget Moran attempted to kill her four children and then committed suicide at her home, No. 141 Wayne-street, Jersey City, early yesterday morning. A year ago her husband went to New-Zealand, and afterward to Chili, to assist in railroad building. He sent his wife $30 a month with unfailing regularity until July last.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 17.--Nine men are in prison here awaiting trial for murder, and the police are hunting for three or four others, as yet unidentified. Alfred Smith, the first on the docket for trial, is supposed to be the man who in a fit of jealousy slew his wife and Mrs. Julia Wilson while they slept.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 17.--Frank J. Sullivan, Democrat, who was defeated by C.N. Felton, Republican, in the Fifth District for Congress, now announces that as soon as the official canvass is completed he will contest for the seat.

Charles Fingarr was an inspector at the Custom House until June 7 last, when Collector Hedden dismissed him. He was accused of insubordination by Deputy Surveyor Wyatt, whose complaint was indorsed by Surveyor Beattie.
DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 17.--The annual meeting of the Western Associated Press was held here to-day.

ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, Nov. 17.--The bark Caspar, from Miramichi, for Swansea, before reported afire off St. Pierre-Miquelon, was burned to the water's edge, only the shell of her bottom remaining. Her cargo was completely consumed. The wreck lies on a reef under Gallantry Head.

The committee of the dissatisfied stage drivers of the Fifth-Avenue Transportation Company met President E. Ely-Goddard by appointment yesterday afternoon to hear the company's reply to the grievances presented on Tuesday. The conference lasted about 40 minutes.

There was no end of rain in Westchester County yesterday, and, as the average farmer knows enough to stay indoors when it rains, the meeting of the Bedford Farmers' Club, at Bedford Station, was slimly attended. The club, which, during the Summer months, has met and dined at the big country places in the vicinity, ...

BUFFALO, Nov. 17.--A pair of what are supposed to be foreign bond swindlers were arrested here to-day. One of the men is Bruno Gottschalk, of Williamsburg, N.Y.; the other Charles F. Kopp, of this city. The former has been in town for a few days past trying to negotiate documents purporting to be bonds of various European cities, including Vienna and places in Italy and Russia.

A sensation has been caused in Christian Hook, town of Hempstead, Long Island, by the arrest of Mrs. Mary Anderson, a prominent resident of that place, on a charge of grand larceny. Mrs. Anderson is reputed to be wealthy and formerly owned Barnum Island. Daniel Pearsall, the complainant, charges Mrs. Anderson with stealing $250 from his house. He alleges that the money was missed immediately after Mrs. Anderson had left his house.

Health Officer Smith has pretty effectually driven the rag importation business away from this port by his rigid requirement of disinfection. The charges thus imposed amount to about $6 per ton, or 20 per cent. of the value of the rags. The raw material of paper manufacture is thereby subjected to an import tax equal to that borne by the manufactured article.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 17.--James Hope, the notorious burglar who was taken from Eastern officers by a writ of habeas corpus yesterday while en route East, arrived here from Sacramento to-day. The hearing of the writ had been set for to-day, but on the request of the attorney for the New-York officers it was continued until Monday next.

The Manhattan Athletic Club has been talking for two or three years of having a clubhouse with all the luxuries and conveniences of a club that is both social and athletic in its tendencies. Many persons have joined the club under the influence of the promises made in its ...

An unknown man, about 30 years of age, 5 feet 8 inches in height, and looking somewhat like a countryman, who entered the Dwinel House, on Fulton-street, Brooklyn, slightly under the influence of liquor on Tuesday night, was found dead in his bed at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon.
Marie, the 5-year-old child of Angelina Sargaresi, living in a dingy tenement, No. 9 Jersey-street, was cross and fretful yesterday morning, and her mother vainly endeavored to quiet her.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 17.--A novel suit for damages is reported from Aurora, Ind. William Hisey, a switchman on the Ohio and Mississippi Railroad, went out with others on a strike. A short time after the trouble was adjusted he was discharged for his part in causing the strike. He found employment on the Cincinnati, Washington and Baltimore Road, but was in a few days ...

Women may mix in politics, but it doesn't improve either the politics or the women.--Burlington Free Press.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17.--William Pope (colored) was tried in the Criminal Court of the District to-day. Judge McArthur presiding, on the charge of assault and battery with intent to kill Gen. C.C. Augur, a retired officer of the army. The evidence showed that Pope and some other negroes were disturbing the peace of the neighborhood when they were ...

A recent fire injured the top of the chimney of the Greepo Dye Works, at Riverside, Paterson, N.J. As the chimney was 180 feet high, it would cost hundreds of dollars to erect a scaffolding, and to put up supports or ladders inside would stop work in the shops for days. "Steeple Jack," a man who has made himself famous by climbing to great heights, was sent for from England.

In view of the continued and inexplicable neglect of Congress to give the subject proper attention the new rules formulated at Chicago by the committee of the National League and American Baseball Association, though they are a rebuke to our legislators, cannot fail to meet the approval of every thoughtful and patriotic citizen.

UTICA, N.Y., Nov. 17.--The annual meeting of the International Baseball League was held here to-day, with President George G. Campbell, of Syracuse, in the chair. The following delegates were present: Hamilton, Crooks and Strand; Syracuse, Campbell and ...

Edwards H. Goff, President of the American Electric Light Company, who has just returned from Washington, said yesterday he had no doubt that the Statue of Liberty would satisfactorily enlighten the world some time next week. "The matter was brought to the attention of the President for the first time Tuesday," ...

BUFFALO, Nov. 17.--Two gay and festive members of Assembly strolled into town to-day, one on "business only," the other on "business solely." The former was Gen. Curtis, of St. Lawrence, and the latter was Charles D. Baker, of Stenben. Mr. Baker's "sole business," however, was his canvass for the Speakership, and he made no bones about it.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17.--"Lakme" was sung at the Academy of Music to-night by the American Opera Company. The cast contained only two of the original artists heard here-- Mme. [L'Allemand as Lakme, and Miss Jessie Bartlett Davis as Mallika. Mr. Alonzo Stoddard, the baritone, assumed the part ...

CHICAGO, Nov. 17.--The Union Steel Company to-day filed with the Recorder a mortgage of its property for $1,500,000 to the Metropolitan Trust Company, of New-York, for 20 years. The mortgage draws 6 per cent. on the amount advanced. The date of the instrument was Aug. 14, 1886.

DENVER, Col., Nov. 17.--Prominent cattle men here and elsewhere in Colorado and in New-Mexico are signing a petition to the managers of railroads centring at St. Louis asking them to give their influence toward the establishment of cattle stock yards at the west side in St. Louis.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17.--Although drawing together fewer noted men than in previous years, the Iroquois Club's annual banquet at the Palmer House this evening was a brilliant and successful event. The big banquet hall was decorated as seldom over before, and ...
BALTIMORE, Nov. 17.--At the University Hospital this morning Prof. L. McLane Tiffany cut a set of false teeth out of the esophagus of William King, aged about 32 years, a farm hand, ...

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17.--Individual resentments,it could be shown, have as much to do with the alleged unpopularity of the Administration with the people as any designated shortcoming on the part of the President or his Cabinet.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Nov. 17.--Delegates from all parts of the country are in attendance upon the tenth annual session of the American Humane Association which opened in this city to-day. About one-third of the members of the association are ladies, and there are ladies in attendance as representatives of local societies, prominent among whom is the widow of the late Thomas A. Hendricks.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 17.--The arrest this afternoon of Mrs. Mary P. Sturgess, who held a prominent position in religious works for the past 14 months, caused considerable excitement in church circles. She came here from Boston, became active in Christian labors, earned a livelihood by soliciting insurance, and made many friends by her agreeable manners and conversational powers.

ALBANY, Nov. 17.--Joseph E. Nagle, Jr., the talented young actor playing Pete the Pincher in the "Pulse of New-York," at the Royal Museum, fell dead on the stage to-night. He had just finished his lines when he staggered and fell, dying within a few ninutes, of heart disease. Nagle was widely known in the profession. His father resides at Lebanon, Penn., and his wife is with the Sol Smith Russell Company at San Francisco.
GREEN BAY, Wis., Nov. 17.--The barge Dixon, Capt. Robinson, of the Justice Field's tow, foundered off Kewaunee this morning. Two seamen were drowned.

BOSTON, Nov. 17.--The Wilson-Moen case terminated late this afternoon in a verdict for the defendant, Philip L. Moen, and this result was reached without divulging that secret so darkly hinted at, if any such existed. The jury retired at 11:45 o'clock, the morning hours being ...

CHICAGO, Nov. 17.--Board of Trade and elevator and railroad men are considering a scheme of creating a market at Chicago for the No. 1 hard wheat produced in Minnesota and Dakota, which goes almost exclusively to Duluth elevators.

LONDON, Nov. 17.--The Court of Queen's Bench was crowded to-day with fashionable and distinguished people who went to attend the trial of the second action for libel brought against Lord Chief-Justice Coleridge by his son-in-law, Charles W. Adams. Mr. Adams declared that the Lord Chief-Justice wrote a ...

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17.--The Record tomorrow will say: "The peace policy which has been adopted by the Pennsylvania Company in its relations with the Reading is to be extended to the Baltimore and Ohio, if it is possible to accomplish this. President Corbin has been selected to act as mediator between President ...
LONDON, Nov. 18.--The steamship P. Caland, (Dutch,) Capt. Bonnjer, from New-York Nov. 6 for Rotterdam, passed the Scilly Islands yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17.--The President to-day made the following apointments: To be Consuls--Charles Jonas, of Wisconsin, at Prague; C.T. Grellet, of California, at Algiers; Edmund Johnson, pf New-Jersey, at Kehl; Alexander C. Jones, of West Virginia, at Chin Kiang.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 17.--Patton and Hollan, the murderers of Matilda Munger, in Dalton, were brought to this city last night after having run through a lively gantlet. Patton pushed the woman into a well, where she broke her neck and died. For six days the body was left there.

The first annual meeting of the Brooklyn Republican League was held last evening at the headquarters on Fulton-street, and five members of the Board of Directors were elected to serve four years. The retiring members were Jesse Johnson, Timothy L. Woodruff, Demas ...

The trial of ex-Alderman Arthur J. McQuade, who is charged with accepting a bribe of $20,000 to induce him to vote to grant a franchise to the Broadway Surface Railroad, will begin at 11 o'clock this morning. Twelve jurors who are to pass upon the question of ...

BALTIMORE, Nov. 17.--Shortly after 11 o'clock this morning in the four-story iron-front warehouse No. 92 Camden-street, occupied by Burroughs Brothers, manufacturers of patent medicines, a lighted gas bracket fell into a still containing alcohol. In the attempt to extinguish the flames another still was upset, and the fire spread rapidly.

DEXTER., Nov. 17.--Monday morning last Whillie Meyers, 16 years of age, and Johnny Flynn, one year younger, sons of neighboring farmers, left their homes to gather hickory nuts. They did not return Monday night, and yesterday a party was organized to search for the boys. Late last night the remains of Willie Meyers were discovered ...

CHICAGO, Nov. 17. --Speaker Carlisle, who came to Chicago to-day to attend the Iroquois banquet, does not seem to be all depressed by the narrow majority by which he was returned to the House of Representatives. In an interview to-day he said that the reduced majority he received was one of those accidents which occur in political life arising from sleepfulness and ...

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 17.--Mr. John N.A. Griswold, of New-York, won a decisive victory in the Court of Common Pleas to-day over the Newport hackmen and others who have for a long time presumed that they had equal rights with himself on Commercial Wharf, at which two-thirds of the Summer visitors land during the Summer season.

The sale of the collection of paintings owned by Thomas Robinson, of Providence, R.I., at Moore's Art Galleries, No. 290 Fifth-avenue, was continued last evening. There was a goodsized attendance in spite of the rain, and the bidding for the important pictures, though confined to a few persons, was at times spirited. More valuable pictures were put up last night, ...

RALEIGH, N.C., Nov. 17.--When prohibition was carried in Raleigh the Capital Club contended that inasmuch as they only sold liquor to members at cost price, and not for profit, the club was not prohibited by the result of the election from supplying members with liquors. A case was made up and carried to the Supreme Court, and to-day that tribunal decided the position of the club to be untebnnable, and that it cannot sell liquor.

Irving Hall was a miniature Switzerland last night. At the back of the hall was a scene representing a Swiss chalet and some Alps, while the Helvetian flag floated from the galleries and stands. A fair was being held for the benefit of the Swiss Benevolent Society of New-York, to supply funds for the home at No. 108 Second-avenue.

About 400 of the clergy, secular and regular, of the Catholic Diocese of New-Yorl assembled in synod at 9:30 A.M. yesterday in the cathedral, at Fifth-avenue and Fifty-first-street. Pontifical mass was celebrated by Archbishop Corrigan, assisted by the following: The Rev. Joseph J. Mooney and the Rev. James Dougherty ...

Wendel's Assembly Rooms, in West Fortyfourth-street, were brilliantly decorated and illuminated last night in honor of the second annual reception of the Manhattan League. The league is announced as "the first and only organization of colored men in this country bearing the same national relation to the colored ...
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18.--Benjamin Harris Brewster, who was Attorney-General of the United States under President Arthur, did not leave his home to-day.

The serious phase of ex-President Arthur's illness dates from early last Winter, when he and his friends first became alarmed at the symptoms, and all but the most hopeful arrived at the unwilling conclusion that a fatal termination was inevitable.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Nov. 18.--The Board of Commissioners of this place are in trouble. Their expenses for running the borough for the year ending May 1 next will be about $10,000, and to offset this the Treasurer has about $50 on hand. The deficiency is in a great measure due to the board's failure to secure a special appropriation that was made by the Legislature for ...

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18.--It is learned at the Department of State that the reappointment by the President yesterday of Charles Jonas, of Wisconsin, as United States Consul at Prague has no bearing upon the case of Mr. Keiley, who had been nominated as Minister to Austria, nor can it be construed to indicate a purpose on the part of either the United States or Austria to recede from the positions ...

BOSTON, Nov. 18.--It was not to be supposed that "Doc" Wilson would make no effort to retrieve his waning fortunes after the verdict of yesterday, and so a motion for a new trial filed this morning, created no surprise.

It is a graceful compliment which the friends of Gen. John M. Corse, our incoming Postmaster, have paid him in making and furnishing his official bond of $200,000 for him without his knowledge, thus relieving him from the delicate task of seeking proper bondsmen.

PARIS, Oct. 20.--The tragedy in verse of Mlle. Simone Arnaud, given this week at the Odeon Theatre, is of severe Biblical origin. The story takes place in the year 164 before Christ, in the reign of Antiochus.

The walking delegates held a special meeting yesterday to consider the advisability of ordering strikes in several buildings to help the striking plumbers. It was decided to take no action, as the conference committees of the Master Plumbers and the Journeyman Plumbers' Union were holding a meeting at No. 54 Union-square, and it was thought they might effect a settlement.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Nov. 18--Five years ago the laborers engaged in handling cotton here, the screwmen, yardmen, weighers, classers, and stevedores began a series of strikes for higher wages, and, after a prolonged contest, virtually secured their terms. The Cotton Men's Executive Council was formed, representing all laborers engaged in handling cotton and subsequently included the Trades Assembly, representing all organized labor bodies.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 18.--For many years the Assemblymen of Western New-York have had a habit of meeting in this city soon after election and discussing plans for the coming session.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18.--The cold weather of to-day kept most of the stock yards strikers from congregating at the places designated by the packers, where the old hands needed are picked out. Very few were taken back, because of the scarcity of hogs. A number of the wives of strikers have for the last few days been calling on the packers and ...

The Stock Exchange has taken official action in favor of recognizing dealings in the Mexican State bonds of 1851, and authority has been given for regularly quoting them among the unlisted securities. There were active dealings in these bonds all day yesterday.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 18.--At 2:29 o'clock this morning fire was discovered in the refrigerator and birdcage manufactory of George N. Pierce Co., on Hanover-street, in this city.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 18.--John McIntosh Kell, who was chief executive officer of the Confederate cruiser Alabama, has been appointed Adjutant-General by Gov. Gordon. Kell has been living in retirement in Georgia ever since the war.

Ex-Alderman McQuade's trial, now in progress, promises to be as sensational in its way as was that of ex-Alderman Jacline. ExAlderman Waite was on the witness stand for a short time last evening, and to-day it is expected that ex-Aldermen Duffy and Fullgraff will ...
LOWELL, Mass., Nov. 18.--In the telephone hearing this morning the cross-examination of Charles J. Glidden, ex-Secretary and Treasurer of the Erie Company, was resumed.

Two candidates for the Speakership were in the city yesterday. Frank B. Arnold came down from Otsego to learn what the Morton men were doing about his canvass, and much information about its progress and strength was conveyed to him by Messrs. Platt and Erwin. It seems more and more probable that the Morton men will all be in line behind Mr. Arnold before the month is out.

The news of Gen. Arthur's death spread quickly through the city and evoked many public tributes of sorrow. Flags were hoisted at half staff on the City Hall, the Post Office Building, and on other public and private edifices. The various hotels and clubhouses showed similar tokens.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18.--"Lohengrin" was produced by the American Opera Company this afternoon and was thought by many to be the best of the series thus far.

NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 18.--J.D. Potter, a young married man who was shot in the navy yard Monday by George Hill for making indecent propositions to the latter's daughter, died this morning. Hill was to-day indicted for murder in the United States court.
The wedding of Miss Adelaide Savage daughter of Mr. Samuel H. Savage, of this city, and Lieut. Francis Tiffany Bowles, United States Navy, was solemnized at Emmanuel Church last evening.

The Society of Amateur Photographers of New-York gave an interesting entertainment at Association Hall last evening. One of the features was a series of imitations, recitations, and humorous remarks by James S. Burdett.
Gen. Arthur was so long identified with public matters in this city that he became personally known to hosts of people in public and private station.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 18.--At the United States Circuit Court, now in session here, Hon. Martin I. Townsend announced the death of exPresident Arthur. Judge Wallace immediately ordered an adjournment of the court as a mark of respect to the illustrious deceased. In the city bells were tolled and flags hung at half mast.

Gen. Arthur is believed to have brought with him from Washington something over $100,000 of his salary as President. He owned considerable real estate in this city, and was always careful to keep it free of assessments and taxes. It includes property on Sixth-avenue above Central Park, known as the Red House ...

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 18.--Louisiana papers are amusing themselves over the sonorous pretences of the pious Robert Ingersoll on the land question. At a recent convention he is reported as saying: "No man should be allowed to hold land which he does not use. There are people who would bottle up the air if they could ...

KEYPORT, N.J., Nov. 18.--Some excitement was created here to-day by the attempted abduction of an 8-year-old child by its mother. About two years ago Mr. D.S. Anderson had a quarrel with his young and pretty wife, and it finally resulted in their separation. Anderson took his two children home to his parents, and his wife returned to her mother.
MONTPELIER, Vt., Nov. 18.--Following is a letter written by Senator Edmunds, which was sent to-day to the editor of the Daily Vermonter for publication by the person to whom it was addressed.

The President's action in the case of District Attorney BENTON, of Missouri, provokes varying comment. The Sun accepts it as a concession that its doctrine, the "Democratic doctrine," is the correct one, namely, that the office holder who does his duty in his office may do what he pleases in other matters.
The Jewelers' Association, of this city, held a banquet at Delmonico's last night, with the joyful accompaniments of good wine, good music, and good speeches.

Spiritualists are much excited over a new medium who has appeared here and who goes a step further than the materializing mediums, (who have been accepted by only a limited following of the believers in the ism,) in boldly proclaiming reincarnation, which is "seeing them and going one better."

VIENNA, Nov. 18.--The statement that all the powers had sanctioned the candidacy of Prince Nicolas of Mingrelia for the Bulgarian throne is semi-officially declared to be untrue. Count Kalnoky has not replied to Russia's proposals.

DURHAM, N.C., Nov. 18.--The Bank of Durham and Eugene Morehead Co., bankers, have recovered their safes from the ruins of the disastrous fire that occurred on Tuesday last. All the books, securities, , in these Herring's safes were uninjured by the burning. Nine more safes of the same make, belonging to business firms, have also been opened, and all their contents are preserved.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18.--The following business was transacted by the Supreme Court of the United States: No. 54--The City of New-Orleans et al., appellants, vs. J.D. Houston, State Tax Collector, et al.--Argument continued by John A. Campbell for appellees and concluded by J. Ward Gurley, Jr., for appellants. No. 56--William A. Coit, appellant, vs. the North Carolina Gold Amalgamating Company et al.--Argument begun by E.F. Hoffman for appellant and continued by R.C. McMurtrie for appellees.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 18.--Moses Ruslander, proprietor of the Union Clothing Company, made a general assignment to-day to Julius M. Georger for the benefit of his creditors. WASHINGTON, Nov. 18.--The news of the ex-President's death was received in Washington between 8 and 9 o'clock. President Cleveland was on his way to breakfast when a sergeant of police on duty at the White House informed him that a message had just come over the telephone that Mr. Arthur was dead.
LONDON, Nov. 18.--The steamship Acadia, (Br.,) Capt. Havnes, from New-York Oct. 30 for Genoa, passed Gibraltar to-day.

The New-York University and Staten Island football teams played yesterday at the St. George Ground, Staten Island. A number of the university boys were present and witnessed some good play. Although the Staten Islanders were the heavier, the New-York players were quick in their running and tackling--Young especially distinguishing himself by running the ...

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 18.--The following dates have been chosen for the dances of the cadets at the Naval Academy: Nov. 24, Dec. 11, 24, 31, Jan. 8, 22, 29, Feb. 12, 21, 26. The committee is composed of Cadets Bertalotte, Bonghter, Burrage, Churchill, Davis, Hurlburt, Long, Moale, Stone, and Wells.
Nothing is denied well directed labor, and nothing is attained without it--except poverty. --Rochester Union.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18.--At the Cattlemen's Convention to-day resolutions were submitted reciting the advance in live stock and dressed beef rates from Chicago and denouncing the actions of the railroads as in direct opposition to the interests of all the cattle growers and feeders of the West and an extortion which should no longer be endured.

The Metropolitan Association of Fire Underwriters met yesterday at No. 115 Broadway. Considerable routine business was disposed of, and further measures were taken to strengthen the association and block attempts to break or tamper with the compact under which the association was formed.
