It was wonderfully distinct, and yet so slow, so cold, so far away, that it sounded like ...

FLEMINGSBURG, Ky., Nov. 18.--At Morehead, in Rowland County, yesterday Moses Little, of the Tollivar faction, surrendered to Sheriff Rainey. Little was particularly wanted on the charge of having waylaid and killed John Marlow last December, since which time he has been outlawing as his taste inclined. After Little surrendered to the Sheriff his friend went on his bond.

BAY ST. LOUIS, Miss., Nov. 17.--M. Blaizer is a reputable storekeeper here. Some time ago family quarrels led to a divorce from his wife. Miss Estelle, a grown daughter, sided with her mother. To-day she procured a bottle of red pepper and a cowhide, and, accompanied by a party of friends, called her father from his store and charged him with making unkind remarks regarding her.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 18.--A brilliant audience assembled in University Hall to witness the production of "The Country Girl." The performance convinced those who saw it of the ability of this year's Dramatic Club of Princeton College.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Nov. 18.--The shores of Lakes Michigan and Superior are strewn with wrecks to-day. The storm has been continuous for more than two days, and vessels which were able to make port have not ventured out since Monday night.

Chester Alan Arthur was born in the little town of Fairfield, Franklin County, Vt., on the 5th of October, 1830. He had one brother younger than himself, William, who is still living and a Paymaster in the army, and four sisters older and one younger than himself.

James Russell Lowell and a party from Cambridge, Mass., arrived at the Westminster Hotel in this city last evening to attend the performance of "The Acharnians" at the Academy of Music this evening. Among the party were Profs. White, Eliot, and Norton, and Mrs. Agassiz. During the evening, while Mr. Lowell sat contentedly ...

READING, Penn., Nov. 18.--The crusade against the Sunday liquor sellers is being pushed with vigor. Damaging evidence against four saloon keepers has been obtained, and warrants for their arrest have been issued.

GOSHEN, Nov. 18.--The writer has been placed in possession of time tables published by authority of the New-York and Erie Railroad in the years 1845, 1847, 1849, 1850, 1851, and 1852, which are not only curiosities in themselves, but show in a peculiar way the growth of railroad traffic between New-York and the West and present in an amusing light the methods of ...
Mme. Patti was heard at the Academy of Music last evening in the first of a series of concerts to be given in all the large cities of the United States.

The second session of the Catholic Synod was held in the cathedral yesterday. Mgr. Preston said mass at 9:30 A.M., assisted by Archbishop Corrigan and about 400 of the clergy of the archdiocese. The meeting of the Synod was opened with the usual ceremonies, the reading of the litanies, and prayers.

CITY OF MEXICO, Nov. 18.--To the great surprise of railroad circles and the traveling public the management of the Mexican Central Railway has discharged every passenger conductor on the road, some 60 in all. It is said that the removals were on the secret reports of spotters sent out by the Boston Directors, who suspected an organized system of stealing. About 20 American station agents have also ...

Capt. Henry Vinal, of Scituate, Mass., who presented President Cleveland, when in Boston, with a cane made from wood of the old frigate Constitution, has received an autograph letter from the President, thanking him for the gift.

CAPE May, N.J., Nov. 18.--The large sea-going tug Norman, Capt. A.L. Fuller, of Philadelphia, from New-Orleans, for Philadelphia, was caught outside the capes in yesterday's storm and sprung a leak. In order to save the lives of his crew Capt. Fuller beached the ...

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Nov. 18.--The Wyoming Valley was swept by a terrible cyclone this morning, between the hours of 8 and 9 o'clock. The wind blew with great velocity and tore down the mountains surrounding the valley like maddened waters let loose from a reservoir.

In accordance with the wishes of United States District Attorney Walker Judge Brown yesterday instructed the jury in the case of Gen. Adam Badeau to find a verdict for the defendant. This suit was brought by the Government to recover the sum of $10,572, said to be due from Gen. Badeau as Consul-General at London.

MONTREAL, Nov. 18.--In view of the approaching Dominion elections, the French Liberals met last night to make arrangements for a mass meeting on the Champ de Mars on Sunday next to renew the Riel agitation.

DUBLIN, Nov. 18.--The Government has decided not to prosecute the nine constables charged with murder in shooting people during the Belfast riots. The Government came to this decision notwithstanding that the Coroner's jury had rendered a verdict of murder against the constables.

The Oratorio Society's first concert of this season took place in the Metropolitan Opera House last evening in the presence of a very large audience, which testified to its pleasure by frequent and hearty applause. The lack of popular affection for "Israel in Egypt," the oratorio ...
The sale of the Thomas Robinson collection of paintings was brought to a successful close last evening at Moore's Art Galleries, No. 290 Fifth-avenue.

New-York City took a big wash yesterday morning, and then dried off in a 40-mile wind. The weather maker, who climbs ladders to get into his shop on the top of the Equitable Building, was inclined to believe that the big storm was the equinoctial which got lost out West last September.

The Assistant Pastor of the Roman Catholic Church of the Epiphany, in Second-avenue, is the Rev. Father Patrick R. Hickey. Among the members of his congregation is Mary Sheridan, who is long past the scriptural limit of human life.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 18.--Gov. Hill has issued an order that flags be placed at half mast on all armories in the State, out of respect for ex-President Arthur. The Governor left Albany at 1 o'clock for Havana, his native town, where he is to deliver an address on Saturday, at the unveiling of a bronze bust of the Hon. Charles Cook. Before his departure he issued the following proclamation:

The conspicuous public office which CHESTER A. ARTHUR attained was due rather to accident than to any previous achievement in statesmanship, and yet he met its requirements in a manner that gives him an honorable place in the roll of American Presidents.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Nov. 18.--A strike, in which 20,000 cotton operatives will take part, will be inaugurated here within a month, unless the manufacturers grant an increase in the wages of their employes.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 18.--The Masonic Relief Association of the United States and Canada held only a morning session to-day. The only business of importance which was transacted was the election of officers, which resulted as follows: President--Martin Collins, of St. Louis; First Vice-President--John R. Pope, of NewYork; Second Vice-President--J.R. Robinson, of Toronto, Canada; Treasurer--William De Lanto, of New-York; Advisory Board--M.J. Higgins, of Milwaukee; L.C. Williamson, and H.R. Mitchell, of Toronto, Canada.

MARION, Ind., Nov. 18.--A fire with terrible and fatal results is reported this morning from the village of Laudisville, in the northeastern part of the county, 12 miles from here. James Johnson, a prosperous farmer, and his family resided a quarter of a mile from the village.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 18.--The news of the death of ex-President Arthur was received in this city with surprise. The conflicting reports concerning his health, closing recently with a statement that he was very much better than usual, left no ground for the supposition that the end of his career was at hand. To-day's announcement occasioned regret, but there was no public demonstration of grief. Senator Harrison said:

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 18.--The Buffalo Cyclorama Company has been incorporated. The object of the company is to acquire lands upon which to erect buildings, where it is intended to give exhibitions and entertainments. The capital stock is $100,000, in shares of $100 each, all of which, it is said, has been subscribed. The company's term of existence is to be 50 years.

NYACK, N.Y., Nov. 18.--The installation of the Rev. J.C. Van Deventer, formerly of Paramus, N.J., as Pastor of the First Reformed Church of Nyack, last night, was an event of much interest. There was a large congregation present, every church in this part of the country ...

Primrose House, at No. 356 West Thirtythird-street, the home of the Society to Befriend Working Girls, gave its first public reception yesterday, opening its doors to those interested in the work from noon until 10 o'clock.

ST. JOHNS, Newfoundland, Nov. 18.--The Peterhead whaler Catherine, Capt. Benzie, left port on March 18 on a whale and seal fishing voyage in Davis Straits and Cumberland Gulf. The ship's company numbered 25.

MOBILE, Ala., Nov. 18.--The schooner Annie B. Hoffses, with lumber for Philadelphia, cleared Oct. 10, and inquiry from her home port shows that she has not made the voyage. The Captain of the schooner Lizzie reports having passed floating lumber and debris on the 20th ult., and they are supposed to be remnants of the missing schooner.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 18.--The limited express coming east on the Pittsburg, Cincinnati and St. Louis Railroad which was due in this city at 6:30 o'clock this morning was wrecked by a land slide at Jones's Ferry, on the outskirts of the city, and a number of persons were injured.
On a large map of the hemispheres the printers could hardly make a dot small enough to represent the proportionate size of the Bermuda Islands.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 18.--The Rev. Dr. Charles E. Robinson, Pastor of the First Presbyterian Church of this city, has resigned his pastorate, assigning ill health as the reason for his action. Dr. Robinson is one of the best known clergymen in the city, and his church is one of ...

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 18.--A report is current here that the Northern Pacific Railroad Company is negotiating for the purchase of the Oregon Navigation Company's Puget Sound steamers, with a view of offering greater competition to the Canadian Pacific for the control of the Victoria, British Columbia, and Puget Sound trade.

Americans enjoy in Europe the reputation of being the most skillful and successful of showmen. It is true that when that now venerable exhibitor, Mr. P.T. BARNUM, was in his prime he was perhaps the most eminent deviser of attractive advertisements that the show business has ever seen.

The mystery surrounding the death on Nov. 7 of Linda Poole, the pretty young type writer, was not at all cleared up by the Coroner's inquest held in her case yesterday. The Coroner recently received an anonymous letter which informed him that the name of the ...

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18.--Secretary Whitney, in pursuance of a plan for the better organization and control of those branches of the Navy Department which are intrusted with the purchase of supplies and are charged with accountability for them, has issued the following order creating a special board to arrange the details of the proposed change:

Dr. George A. Peters, speaking yesterday of some of the features and incidents of Gen. Arthur's illness, said he had never known a more heroic patient. Either of his ailments--Bright's disease or enfeebled and enlarged heart--was dangerous.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18.--A large number of vessels still continue to arrive at this port badly damaged from recent storms. Many of their officers report having passed great quantities of wreckage close to the coast, showing that a number of vessels must have foundered.
James Tate appeared before Mayor Fulton yesterday and asked to be sent to the workhouse. He said he had no money and no friends and could not secure work.

The New-York Society for the Suppression of Vice has just issued a card showing the results of its work for the month of October and also for the 10 months since Jan. 1. During October 24 arrests were made. Of these 11 were for obscene matters. Five gambling saloons were raided and their paraphernalia seized. About 24,000 indecent pictures and cards were seized.

SEDALIA, Mo., Nov. 18.--A remarkable case of stubbornness terminated at the Pettis County Poorhouse yesterday. Nine years ago a colored woman, Sarah Anderson, became almost crazed with anger one day at the keeper of the poor farm. So wild was she in her rage that she was locked in her room alone, and left to meditate until the following morning.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18.--The estimates for the Consular Service of the United States for the fiscal year 1888, which went into the printer's hands to-day, show an increase of nearly $250,000 over last year's appropriation.
Gen. Viele denies in the most emphatic manner the statement published yesterday that he was to succeed D. Lowber Smith as Deputy Commissioner of Public Works.

The court-martial which is trying Second Lieut. William K. Smith, of the Thirteenth Regiment, for unofficerlike conduct and insubordination met last night in the Fourteenth Regiment Armory, on North Portland-avenue, Brooklyn. Col. Edward Fackner, of the Thirteenth Regiment, was called as the first witness, and Lieut. Smith's counsel objected to his testifying on the ground that he had been present at each meeting ...

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 18.--Joseph Hoffman, a tailor, 40 years of age, resides with his family at No. 1,209 South Broadway. He is small in stature, but nevetheless has always endeavored to impress upon his household that he was a wonderful man.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 18.--Drafts on NewYork, sight, 15 cents; telegraphic, 20 cents.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18.--The Record tomorrow will say: "The next meeting in the interest of peace between the Pennsylvania and Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Companies, it is understood, will be held in this city. Presidents Roberts and Garrett were to have come together to-day, but the latter had an engagement which prevented their meeting.

The Rev. Mr. Holbrook, the new Rector of St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Jersey City, is accused of having brutally abused Frank Kennedy, one of his choir boys. The little choristers gathered in the choir room Wednesday evening, and while waiting for the choral exercises to commence, engaged in some boyish pranks.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Nov. 18.--Miss Minnie Anderson, who has been missing from home since Monday morning, relieved the anxiety of her parents late last evening by walking calmly into the house. It seems that Tuesday afternoon, after leaving her aunt, she met her grandfather, who lives five miles out in the country.

The attainment of 40 years of uninterrupted service in one church is such a rarity that fully 1,500 friends of the Rev. Dr. Richard S. Storrs went to the Church of the Pilgrims, at Henry and Remsen streets, Brooklyn, last evening to congratulate him upon his celebration of that event.

LONDON, Nov. 19.--The Daily News, referring to the death of ex-President Arthur, says: "His death will be regretted beyond the limits of America. As President he exercised the office in a manner which won for him the lasting gratitude of his countrymen."

A most important work has been undertaken by the Woman's National Indian Association, the annual meeting of which occurred in this city yesterday, and if not misguided into sentimental rather than practical channels, much good may result from the zeal and determination shown.
PESTH, Nov. 18.--Count Kalnoky informed the Budget Committee of the Austrian Delegation to-day that a Minister to the United States would soon be appointed.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Nov. 18.--Ella Wickham, a handsome girl of 18 years, and the daughter of respectable parents at Port Jervis, disappeared from her home on Monday night last under circumstances which lead her friends to fear that she has eloped with John S. Shafer, a married man belonging in Dingman's, Penn.

The applause at the Star Theatre last evening at the close of the third act in "Richelieu" was of a most tempestuous character, and Mr. Booth, who perhaps never appeared to better advantage as the great Cardinal, was compelled to appear in front of the curtain three times before the enthusiastic audience was appeased.
The two recent editions of the "Arabian Nights" have awaked a new interest in regard to these Oriental stories, and very extended researches as to their origin have been presented.
The first of a series of special afternoon performances of new plays, called by Mr. Palmer "Authors' Matinees," was given yesterday in the Madison-Square Theatre.

BERLIN, Nov. 18.--The Post (semi-official) says that the draft of a bill fixing the peace effective footing of the army for the septennate beginning in January, 1889, was sent to the Bundesrath to-day, and that the increased demands of the bill do not exceed the limits absolutely necessary for the safety of the empire.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 18.--Charlie Harvey, the 15-year-old son of Dr. Harvey, of Anchorage, met with a very serious accident while attempting to board a moving train this morning. The boy attends the High School in this city and comes in every morning on the 7 o'clock train.

LANCASTER, Penn., Nov. 18.--News was received this afternoon of the death of Albert Seitz to-day near Beaver Mill, in Strasburg Township. Early this morning Seitz, in company with Benjamin Miller, of Refton, started on a gunning expedition from the Green Tree Hotel. Toward noon the men became separated, and some time later Miller, hearing the report ...

ALBANY, Nov. 18.--The Rural Cemetery, where ex-President Arthur will be laid to rest on Monday afternoon, is beautifully situated on a ridge overlooking the valley of the Hudson, two miles north of this city.

The growing interest women are taking in the Indian question was manifested yesterday by the large numbers who met in the chapel of the Broadway Tabernacle to take part in the annual meeting of the Woman's National Indian Association.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 18.--The Baptist Congress now in session in Baltimore held its final sessions to-day in the Eutaw-Place Baptist Church. The Rev. L.A. Crandall, of New-York, opened the proceedings with prayer. "The Future Life," was discussed in three phases. "Endless Punishment," "Conditional Immortality," and "Future Probation."

Joseph Hopkins, of 25 Eighth-street, Hoboken, a deck hand on a Hoboken ferryboat, fell overboard as the boat was entering the slip in Hoboken on the 11:30 o'clock trip from Barclay-street last night. He was drowned.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 18.--The liquor question is again to the front in Atlanta. The law permits the sale of domestic wine, and since prohibition went into effect 36 wine rooms have been licensed, so that there is as much drinking as ever. Twelve of these have been licensed within the last 10 days, and not less than ...

Ex-President Chester Alan Arthur died at 5:10 o'clock yesterday morning at his residence, No. 123 Lexington-avenue. The immediate cause of his death was cerebral apoplexy, due to the rupture of a small artery within the brain during Tuesday night or early on Wednesday morning.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 18.--The annual session of the Grand Lodge, Independent Order of Odd Fellows, of New-Jersey, came to a close this afternoon. Among the visitors present were John H. White, of New-York, Grand Sire, and Theodore A. Ross, Grand Secretary, of the ...

About 6:50 P.M. yesterday a freight vessel of the Fall River Line, bound out, collided off Governor's Island with an oil scow of the Standard Oil Company, sinking it, and scattering its cargo of petroleum in all directions. The Fall River boat was considerably damaged about the bow. Nobody was hurt by the collision.

Nothing is now lacking to make the performance of "The Acharnians" of Aristophanes at the Academy of Music to-night the most brilliant presentation of a Greek play which has taken place during the revivals of Greek drama in the last decade.

MADISON, Ga., Nov. 18.--Thirty years of litigation has been brought to a close here by the settlement of the Eubanks estate. In 1840 a young man named Alfred Eubanks came here from North Carolina and became overseer for Dr. Randolph. By sharp trading he soon became the owner as ...

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 18.--A party of journalists and artists representing the Harper Brothers arrived here this morning over the East Tennessee Road from Knoxville. They visited the factories, Lookout Mountain, Missionary Ridge and other historic points, and were banqueted at the Stanton House. They leave for Nashville to-morrow.

A somewhat romantic story was revived yesterday by the appearance of Albert C. Starey in this city. He is the agent of an English corporation that has capital invested in a number of Eastern cities. He arrived from Yokohama on the last steamer, and started for ...

The present volume is a well timed and valuable contribution to apologetic literature of the nineteenth century. The writer is one of the more progressive of those Scottish clergy of our day who have advanced a long way beyond the dogmatic detinitions and averments of John Calvin, the Westminster Confession, and the standards of the established Church of Scotland.
This is a most excellent edition of a work that has long been famous with the bibliophiles and which Mr. Swinburne has recently included in his list of the hundred greatest books.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 18.--There is great excitement in the town of Parma, Monroe County, over the no-license law, which is now in effect there. Several hotel keepers have been suspected of selling liquors. A preliminary examination before a Justice of the Peace is now in progress to determine if there is sufficient evidence to issue warrants.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18.--The First Presbyterian Church of the town of Lake was totally destroyed by fire this morning. The loss is about $50,000; insurance unknown. The church was at the corner of Sixty-third and State streets, and burned with such rapidity that the entire structure was a mass of flames when the firemen arrived.

PARIS, Nov. 3.--The Temps attributes the return of Lord R. Churchill to England without having been interviewed by any reporter to the fact that he had nothing to tell them, his journey to Berlin and Vienna being in search of health, not of any political combination.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18.--Judge Gresham and Robert Lincoln, who will be two of the pall bearers at Gen. Arthur's funeral, left for New-York this afternoon, and exCollector Jesse Spaulding, who was an intimate friend of Gen. Arthur, took the evening train. "My acquaintance with Gen. Arthur," said Mr. Lincoln this afternoon, "really began with my official connection.
The Society for the Relief of Poor Widows with Small Children held its eighty-ninth annual meeting at noon yesterday in the lecture room of the University-Place Church.

The work of rebuilding the Stock Exchange goes on slowly. Yesterday a thin place in the roof broke open suddenly, just as 500 brokers underneath were most busily shouting themselves hoarse. The day's big storm was at its height.

The Atlantic for December is a very bulky number in consequence of a supplement containing the Harvard oration of Mr. Lowell and the poem read on the same occasion by Dr. Holmes. The latter is found to be a far longer effort than the first published passages may have led readers to suppose.

An important meeting was held in this city yesterday by the Directors of the Ohio and Mississippi Railroad Company. Special cars brought many of the Directors from distant points. There was an evident effort to keep quiet the purpose of the meeting, but enough was learned to show that a new departure of consequence is contemplated.

The sale of the fourth part of the Brinley Library at Leavitt's Art Rooms was concluded yesterday. The score or more of buyers who have attended all the sessions were present, and showed their customary exact knowledge of the value of what they were purchasing.

PARIS, Nov. 5.--The Theatre Francais gave this week the first representation of Richepin's "Scapin." To accompany this short three-act play M. Claretie suddenly decided to give hospitality to a one-act piece of M. Becque.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18.--The movement inaugurated on Sunday last to secure concerted action among the several trade organizations of the city, with the view of nominating a labor representative for Mayor, is steadily progressing. Knights of Labor vie with open trades unionists in the enthusiasm with which they regard ...

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18.--The Hon. Thomas H. Dudley, ex-Consul to Liverpool, today brought suit against United States Senator William J. Sewell for $25,000 damage for remarks made by the latter in a speech at a Republican meeting at Camden on the 7th of October last.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18.--Col. John Moore, of the Medical Department of the Army, was to-day appointed Surgeon-General by the President, to succeed Surgeon-General Murray, retired. Col. Moore, who is in San Francisco, has been directed to report at Washington immediately.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 18.--There was a good deal of time given to-day at the sessions of the American Humane Society to the matter of drives and driving. President Gordon said the greatest cruelty to horses is in New-York City, and is practiced by imported English drivers ...

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 18.--Official returns from all the counties in the State, with semi-official counts in San Francisco, give Bartlett (Dem.) a plurality for Governor of 632 over Swift, (Rep.) The Republicans have elected the Lieutenant-Governor, the Attorney-General, the Superintendent of Public Instruction, the Surveyor-General, and ...
Nothing in the career of the Subway Construction Company has proved so difficult of accomplishment as locating the points of connection of the wires of Maurice B. Flynn with its operations.

Mrs. Ryan, of No. 693 First-avenue, was on trial at the Tombs yesterday for violating the excise law. The complainants, Officers John J. Sheridan and Thomas F. Dorlan, of the Thirtyfifth Precinct, testified that they were sent out on Sunday, March 22, 1885, to look for violators of the law.

The committee appointed by the Republican County Committee to investigate the charge made by Robert Ray Hamilton against Capt. Michael Cregan of "selling out" Allen Thorndike Rice, the Republican nominee for Congress in the Tenth Congressional District, has not yet decided when the first meeting will be held. Ex-Judge Henry E. Howland yesterday declined to serve on the committee, and another member of the County Committee will be appointed in his place.

LONDON, Nov. 18.--A committee of the Cabinet, composed of Lord Randolph Churchill, Sir Michael Hicks-Beach, Lord Ashbourne, and the Right Hon. William Henry Smith, is preparing a land bill for Ireland.

The ninth annual convention of the Sunday schools of Kings County convened in the Simpson Methodist Episcopal Church, Brooklyn, yesterday. Officers were chosen as follows: President--J.W. Cummings; Vice-Presidents-- H.B. Griffing, A.B. Lewis, C.H. Liebout, J.L. Bergen, and G.L. Thatford; Secretaries--J.R. Morris and Charles Doughty.

Members of the Alumni Association of Williams College to the number of 40 united in the first social meeting of the year at Delmonico's last night and sang their college songs and enjoyed themselves generally in an informal manner.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19.--This was a big day for the stock yards strikers who had not been able to obtain employment since the trouble was officially declared off. About 5,000 of them were given tickets which entitle them to work at the first opportunity, and out of this number 4,000 were immediately set to work.

LONDON, Nov. 19.--Advices have been received here to the effect that a ship crowded with native laborers returning from Queensland plantations foundered in the Pacific Ocean, and that 140 lives were lost.

CHATTANOOGA, Nov. 19.--A few days ago Dr. N. E. Knox, a well known physician at Daisy, in the upper end of this county, left for Hot Springs. Ark., in the hope of curing a troublesome complaint, and carried with him a large sum of money. Last Saturday he was found ...

Gage Co. are very much incensed at what they consider the greediness of H. B. Claflin Co. to collect their claim against the bankrupt firm regardless of ...

OTTAWA, Nov. 19.--Peter Derose and J. Connolly, sentenced to be hanged in British Columbia on the 24th inst., have been respited to Dec. 22, pending an investigation into their sanity. Robert Maxwell, who had been sentenced to be handed at the same time, has had his sentence commuted to imprisonment for life. The prisoners were convicted of the murder of William Dillman, formerly of Nova Scotia, but latterly of Minneapolis.

Sherman in the recent controversy, and upon which Sherman based his charge that Davis threatened to use Lee's army to coerce the Southern States. It shows that ...

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19.--Leave of absence for four months has been granted Capt. Morris C. Foots, Ninth Infantry. Second Lieut. John P. Finley, Signal Corps, has been relieved from duty in this city and ordered to proceed to New-York City and assume charge of the Signal Service Station at that point.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Nov. 19.--Late last night Peter Englehart, who has been living apart from his wife for some time, entered her apartments, and going to a room where their 8-yearold child was king, fired two shots at the child. Mrs. Englehart ran to the child's rescue and her husband fired at her, the ball striking her in the the left side of the face, causing a dangerous wound. The child was unhurt. Englehart escaped.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Nov. 19.--The Buffalo Republican League has adopted resolutions on the death of ex-President Arthur and sent to Mrs. McElroy a telegram of condolence. Evidences of sincere regret at the death of the distinguished statesman are frequently met with.

Save for a small military escort from Governor's Island, ex-President Arthur's funeral will be that of a simple citizen. Knowing his aversion to display in any form, the relatives did not look with favor at first upon the suggestion of an escort, wishing to avoid the slightest appearance of a military funeral.

A motion was made before Judge Bookstaver, in Common Pleas, Chambers, yesterday, for an order setting aside the decree of divorce granted by Judge Cardozo to John Geschwinde and against Caroline Geschwinde, on Sept. 17, 1867. Mis. Geschwinde says she wants to clear ...

It was stated yesterday that the relation which the Ohio and Mississippi is to have with the Erie Road is to be a good deal closer than has yet been made known. The Erie people are counting on material benefits ot accrue from the business which the Ohio and Mississippi is to provide that line, and the Ohio and Mississippi is assured of a much larger and more remunerative traffic than it now enjoys.
NATCHEZ, Miss., Nov. 19--Jones Spry, colored, the murderer of Ada Coleman, was hanged in the jail yard here to-day. The drop fell at 11:42 o'clock.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 19.--There has been a very heavy sea on the Sound to-day from the effects of yesterday's great gale, and the coasting fleet remained at anchor in the harbors. The barge Grace Hills, one of the tow of ...

CHICAGO, Nov. 19.--One result of the Baseball League Convention which adjourned to-day is that the Detroit and Kansas City Clubs will probably withdraw from the League and join the American Association.

Both boys are about 13 years old. Bad blood has existed between them for a year or more, and every meeting has been the occasion for a fight. The physicians fear that the knife entered Hotch'S left lung.

TORONTO, Nov. 19.--Two Pullman sleeping cars, the Cimbria and the Leghorn, pars of the Grand Trunk Western express, were burned to the trucks this morning near Kingston. Few of the passengers saved morn than their night clothes. The loss will reach fully $40,000.

PANAMA, Nov. 11.--A new island is said to have been discovered in the Pacific by a British steamer while bound from Sydney for Shanghai. It was named Allison Island, after the commander of the steamer. It lies between Durour Island and the Echiquier group, in latitude 1 25 south longitude 143 26" east. It is between two and three miles long rises from 100 to 150 feet from the sea and is well wooded.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., Nov. 19.--Russell White, a fisherman at this place, yesterday caught a man-eating shark, 10 feet long and weighing 500 pounds, in his nets just off North Asbury Park. CLEVELAND, Nov. 19.--The preliminary hearing of Benjamin Wheller, the old man charged with killing his wife, was finished today, and Judge Hitchins withheld his decision until Monday. The case is as deep a mystery as ever. ELMIRA. N.Y., Nov. 19.--The Hon. John Arnot. Congressman for two terms from this district, lies in a very precarious condition at his residence on Clinton-street. A Tory contemporary announces that it is settled that Lord Lorne is to succeed Lord Dufferin as Viceroy of India. This is a flim-flam of the wildest kind, as Lord Dufferin's term of office will not expire for four years to come, so that it is decidedly premature to begin to speculate about his successor. There is no more chance of Lord Lorne being appointed Viceroy than of his being elected Prince of Bulgaria.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 20.--The English Derby winner, Kingcraft, by King Tom, dam Woodcraft, by Voltiguer, was to-day purchased, by cable, by D. Swigert, owner of the Elmendorf stock farm. He takes the place of Prince Charlie, who recently died. Kingcraft defeated Leapyear and Swift, the great English and French racers.

ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, Nov. 20.--The direct northern mail steamer Hercules, while passing through the Western Tickle, near Fogo, Notre Dame Bay, struck the sunken steamer Summerside. She proceeded toward Dean's Rock, fast filling and with all her fires out but one, and reached Fogo with 10 feet of water in her hold. The steam pumps were working constantly, and she barely reached the shore when she sank.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 20.--Ex-Gov. C.K. Davis, a candidate for United States Senator from this State, has temporarily lost the sight of his left eye, and the other is in danger. His physician is very reticent as to the outcome, and it is feared that total blindness may ensue. The cause attributed is overwork.

OPELIKA, Ala., Nov. 20.--A very interesting case, both as to the facts and the nice legal points involved, was tried this week at the Circuit Court in Seale. A negro was on trial charged with living in adultery with a white woman for a number of years.

HAVANA, Nov. 20.--Last night a body of police surprised tho notorious outlaw Jiminez and two other bandits in the city. Jiminez ran, but wos overtaken, when he made a stout resistance, wounding five of the police before he was killed. His two companions were killed while trying to make their escape.

The third representation of "Aida" at the Metropolitan Opera House, yesterday afternoon, brought together another large concourse of spectators. The performance of Verdi's melodious work moved smoothly and impressively--more impressively, in truth, than ever before.

LONDON, Nov. 20.--At last the Russian bear realizes the existence of a trap in his path, about which I wrote you months ago. He draws back a paw and hesitates. The question hangs trembling in the balance for the moment, whether he will retreat or rush into ambush with a resolve to crush the hunters in a mighty embrace or at least to die game.

MONTREAL, Nov. 20.--The lacrosse match to-day between the Toronto and Montreal clubs resulted in a draw. Montreal took the first game in 1 hour and 30 minutes, but darkness set in while the next game was in progress.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Nov. 20.--The schooner V.W.R., a two-master, Capt. Geo. McRae, owned by F.W. Parker, of New-York, bound for Boston, with 300 tons of coal, went ashore at the mouth of the Seaconnet River at 3 o'clock this morning. She sank in 75 feet of water and is a total loss. The crew was saved. The Captain mistook the Seaconnet Light for Gay Head Light, as the former is not down on his chart.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20.--Packingtown was today busier than ever, and it was estimated that more men were at work than at the beginning of the strike. All the old hands that showed up were set to work, and now there are but 100 or 200 of the late strikers left unemployed.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 20.--A Wellsville (Ohio) special says: "Maggie, the 11-year-old daughter of Angus McKinzie, a farmer living here, was burned to death to-day. The little one's clothing took fire from a grate during the temporary absence of the mother, and before assistance arrived the child was so badly burned that she died in an hour.

MONTREAL, Nov. 20.--Mr. J.S. McLachlan, of the firm of McLachlan Brothers, and a son of Mr. Sumner, of Hodgson, Sumner Co., went duck shooting yesterday, and not returning at night search was instituted for them, and to-day their guns, boots, and boat were found. It is considered certain that they have been drowned.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 20.--The telephone service in Rochester is, for the present at least, suspended. At noon to-day 750 subscribers out of 900 carried their threat of discontinuing the use of telephones into execution, and their intention was carried out with all the care and attention to detail of a well organized strike.

LONDON, Nov. 20.--News has been received here of a disastrous fire in the town of Tondo, on the Pasig River, nearly opposite Manila, in the island of Luzon, the largest of the Philippine group. One thousand houses were burned.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 20.--At 4 o'clock this morning a landslide occurred one mile south of Highland, on the West Shore Road. Both tracks were obstructed until noon, and passengers and freight were transferred.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Nov. 20.--David Kane, an employe in McEntee Dillon's foundry, was shot in front of the Rondout National Bank at about 10:20 o'clock to-night by Night Watchman Patsy Larkin. Kane had two bullet wounds in his temple, and the doctors say that he will die.

A reception will be given to Mr. Henry M. Stanley, Governor-General of the Congo Free State, on Monday, Nov. 27, by Mrs. A.B. Stone, at the Valencia, No. 150 West Fifty-ninth-street. A few days ago 100 of these fellows surprised some merchants traveling on business, and robbed them of everything. Afterward the band entered a Turkish village, murdered seven unprotected women, and set fire to the houses after pillaging them. The Turkish Government urges all travelers in those parts to take armed servants with them.

Hersey, New-York." Mr. Hersey was shown up to his room, which he occupied that night, and the first thing he did next morning was to shoot himself through the body.
PARIS, Nov. 21.--M. Bihourd, French Resident General in Tunis, has accepted the office of Minister Resident in Tonquin, made vacant by the death of Paul Bert.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 21.--William H. Daly, a young man of 23, went to call upon Miss Mary Breslin, of No. 92 Wallace-street, to-night. She declined to go walking with him, when Daly drew a revolver and leveled it at her. Before he could shoot Policeman Conners, who was in the next room, opened the door. Daly was put under arrest and lodged at the Grandavenue precinct.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 21.--Since the returns of the election of members of the Legislature have come in sufficiently complete to show the probable membership of the next Legislature the politicians of the State have been busy with estimates and speculations as to the election of a United States Senator this Winter.

SOFIA, Nov. 21.--All the Russian Consuls have left Bulgaria. The French Consul here will protect Russian subjects, the German Consul having refused to do so.

BOSTON, Nov. 21.--Charles Francis Adams died at 1:57 o'clock this morning, at his residence, No. 57 Mount Vernon-street, in this city. He had not been well for some time and had suffered more or less for the past five years from some brain trouble, the result of overwork.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Nov. 21.--David Kane, who was shot in the temple by Night Watchman Patsy Larkin, near the Rondout National Bank, at about 10:30 o'clock last night, died at 2 o'clock this morning without regaining consciousness.

ATLANTA, Nov. 21.--Gov. Gordon has designated the fourth Wednesday of November as Arbor Day. The action was taken in compliance with the request of the Defaniak Forestry Convention. Great preparations are being made in this city to have a general planting of trees next Wednesday.
MADISON, N.Y., Nov. 21.--A number of boy's played a very shrewd trick on the Treasurer's office in an adjoining town last week by which they secured the payment to them of $140.

The concert at the Casino last evening was mainly notable becauee of the distinctly popular character of the programme and its very marked popular success.

The steamer Mariposa, which arrived in this city on Saturday morning, had on board several distinguished guests, among whom were the Hon. George W. Merrill, Consul-General from the United States to the Hawaiian Islands; George S. Bates, of Delaware, Special Commissioner of the United States to Samoa, and B. Greenebaum, ex-Consul-General of the United States to Samoa.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20.--Provisions were tame and a shade easier today. The shipping demand was decidedly better, but the offerings of property were in excess of the demand, and a weaker feeling prevailed. Pork opened 2 c. lower, at $10 10 for January, declined to $10 07, and closed at that price bid, with December at 57c. discount and February at 10c. premium.

GOULDVILLE, Penn., Nov. 21.--Just before the arrival of the north-bound train yesterday a roughly clad, big-whiskered, strapping backwoodsman, accompanied by a well dressed and handsome young woman not more than 16 years old, arrived at the station on foot in a state of great trepidation.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 21.--The Americus, Preston and Lumpkin Railroad, S.N. Hawkins, President, has been completed to Antioch, a distance of 48 miles. Its objective point is Georgetown, on the Chattahoochee River, opposite Eufaula. Cars will run the entire distance this week.

The work of reorganizing the Navy Department on business principles, to which Secretary WHITNEY addressed himself more than a year ago, and which was delayed from a variety of causes, has now at last begun.

Last week an old German Jew named Levy Isaacs, a peddler of sponges, jewelry, and Turkey rhubarb, was burned at his house in Ashburner-street, Bolton, and the following day he died from his injuries. He had lived alone in the house for many years. The police, suspecting that valuables would be found there, searched the place, and concealed in various nooks and crannies upward of 600 has been found.

LONDON, Nov. 21.--Discount during the past week was quoted at 2 @2; there was no demand. On the Stock Exchange business was quiet and prices were well supported.

Jesse Smith came up from Babylon yesterday with his black colt Islip, and went over to Fleetwood Park, where he joined most of the city's lovers of the trotting horse gathered upon the broad porch of the clubhouse.

SCRANTON, Penn., Nov. 21.--The largest judicial sale of coal property that ever occurred in this section of the State took place here yesterday, when the coal lands and breakers of the Pennsylvania Anthracite Company were knocked down by Sheriff Lewis to R.K. Dow, of NewYork, for $550,000.
Mr. ADAMS, whose death is announced this morning, played a very important part and one of great usefulness and dignity in the history of his country.

Lord Ailesbury was out with the Queen's last week. Out of respect to the memory of his recently deceased grandfather he elected to follow the hounds in a trap. But there was a wordy altercation and a collision in a turnip field, which resulted in the noble lord's companion being thrown out amid the swedes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21.--The annual report of Naval Constructor T.D. Wilson, Chief of the Bureau of Construction and Repair, shows that, the steel cruisers Atlanta and Boston are at the navy yard, Brooklyn, N.Y.; they have both been docked and their bottoms cleaned and painted, and, independent of the work which had to be done by the Government to fit them for sea, alterations and additions ...
BOSTON, Nov. 21.--Augustus Lowell, for many years Treasurer of the Boot Cotton Mills of Lowell, has resigned, and his resignation has been accepted by the Board of Directors.

The completion of the Main canalization was celebrated at Frankfort on Saturday. The works were begun over 10 years ago. The River Main has been turned into a navigable waterway, 22 miles long, from Frankfort to its confluence with the Rhine, with a depth of six

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Nov. 21.--Bathing Superintendent Treat has just finished his report. He says that nearly 300,000 people bathed here during the past season and not a single accident occurred within his limits.
ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, Nov. 21.--The steamer Barrowmore, Capt. Honeyman, has just arrived here. She left Baltimore on the 15th inst., cotton laden, for Liverpool.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21.--J.J. Lewis, the husband of Lillian Lewis, the actress, secured a divorce in Judge Tuley's court yesterday on the ground of desertion. The couple were married in 1878, and for a time lived happily together. Gradually, however, the fascinations of a professional life proved more enticing to Mrs. Lewis than domestic duties, and in January, 1884, she left her husband for good.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21.--The Red Star steamer Switzerland, Capt. Buschman, arrived in port this evening from Antwerp, four days overdue, having encountered a perilous passage ever since leaving port on the 3d inst.

BOSTON, Nov. 21.--The first day's experience with the enforcement of the Sunday blue laws, under the decision of the Supreme Court of the State, was more amusing than annoying, except to those unfortunate individuals who were forced to go to church without their customary Sunday shave.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 21.--To-day at Fairview, on the line between Christian and Todd Counties, Ky., there was dedicated a Baptist church erected on the site of the building where Jefferson Davis was born.

The vote cast for Congressmen at the election on the 2d inst. foots up 86,653, of which the Democratic nominees received 62,197, the independents and Republicans 24,436, and scattering 40. The Democratic vote was small in all the districts, even where there was a semblance of opposition, except in the Fourth and Eighth.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21.--In her plainly furnished, but cheerful little parlor on Woodvale-avenue, Wissahickon, Mrs. Melville, the widow of the arctic explorer, to-day, surrounded by her three accomplished children, freely but anxiously discussed the prospects of her eldest daughter, Maud, who is about to prepare herself to enter the field of professional singing.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21.--When it is set down that "Around the World in Eighty Days" at McVicker's has drawn the best of any of the attractions at the south side theatres during the past week it can be readily understood that the managers have presented little appealing to the intellectual side of the playgoer.

ERIE, Penn., Nov. 21.--Society in Erie is greatly shocked over the suicide of one of its brightest members--Mrs. Mary H., wife of William Barnhurst.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 21.--The press of Louisiana has but one voice on the death of the late President Arthur, is that he kindly one. In brief, the sentiment is that he was a gentleman and a friend of the South. Mr. Arthur was very popular here while President.

ROME, Ga., Nov. 21.--Work will begin here to-morrow which will establish this city as a considerable railroad centre. The Rome and Carrollton Railroad Company has set out to build 300 miles of road from Rome as a base, and the Rome and Decatur people here have begun the building of a road 142 miles long to Decatur, Ala.

"Princess Ida" will be revived at the Fifth-Avenue Theatre to-night. The Standard Quartet Club will give its first concert this season at Steck Hall on Saturday evening.

KEYPORT, N.J., Nov. 21.--Young Frank Soling, who on Thursday last eloped with the daughter of Mrs. Holtznagle, returned to town to-day to see whether it would be safe for him to bring his young wife home.
ATLANTA, Nov. 21.--In the recent State election the Knights of Labor succeeded in electing several of their number to the Legislature, the most prominent of them being Mr. Schofield, of Bibb County.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov . 21.--For more than a year past the Star Rubber Company of this city has had trouble with the local labor organizations. It originated with a strike among the employes, owing to the dismissal of several men by Thomas A. Bell, the manager of the company.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 21.--The ceremonies in connection with the installation of the Right Rev. Alfred A. Curtis to the Bishopric of the Wilmington See were celebrated in the cathedral to-day, and were the most imposing and impressive ever conducted in this State.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21.--Judge Prendergast yesterday afternoon heard the application of Carl Rankin, of the Wilson Rankin Minstrel Troupe now playing at the Standard, to schedule out under the insolvent law. Rankin was arrested on Friday evening on a judgment for $200 in favor of W.H. McDonald.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 22.--The railroad boom in Georgia is still at high mark. New roads and feeders to old roads are daily projected. About a year ago Mrs. M.S. Robinson, a writer of short articles in the religious papers and periodicals, went to the town of Harrison, Westchester County, to secure quiet and freedom from interruption. She occupies a small cottage built into the side of a hill near the farm of Oscar Purdy.

The New-York Commandery of the Military Order of the Loyal Legion met yesterday at its headquarters, No. 202 Broadway, and passed appropriate resolutions in reference to the death of ex-President Arthur.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 22.--Sir John Macdonald, Premier of the Dominion, has announced that the Government proposed to appoint a Minister of Trade and Commerce, who would be charged with the supervision of numerous and important questions arising directly and indirectly concerning trade and commerce.
The semi-annnal conference of the Jewish Ministers' Association of the Eastern District was begun yesterday at the Temple Ahawath Chesed, Lexington-avenue and Fifty-fifth-street.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 22.--Drafts on NewYork--sight, 15 cents; telegraphic, 20 cents.

Treacy, of No. 239 West One Hundred and Twenty--ninth-street, and an insurance policy for $5,000 in the United States ...

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 22.--The recent flurry in mining stocks has brought small investors to the front again, and to-day one of the leading brokers, who did a large business with the lower classes, absconded, taking with him about $100,000 intrusted to him for the purchase of stocks.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 22.--There is a growing belief that the murder of Emma Pearson was not committed at Hills Grove, and this belief is strengthened by the fact that carriage wheel and foot prints were distinctly seen and traced. There were footprints going from but none leading to where the body lay. The wagon may have stopped where the knoll begins to ...

The merchant tailoring establishment of Mr. Marks Arnheim, at the Bowery and Springstreet, is to be enlarged a second time, owing to inadequate room for growing business. Nearly nine years ago the small store No. 192 Bowery met all reqiurements.

JACKSONVILLE, Texas, Nov. 21.--Comer, Farris Dial, the leading dry goods and grocery house of this town, was closed by L. H. Blum, of Galveston. Four other houses, owned by Comer, Farris Dial, Comer Farris, located ...

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 22.--The report of J.B. McFerran, Executor of the will of James C. McFerran, late proprietor of the Glen View stock and breeding farm, the most noted trotting stud in Kentucky, recently sold at an aggregate sum of nearly $400,000, and that of the Commissioner in the same matter were filed td-day in Chancery.

BERLIN, Nov. 22.--A conference of medical officers was held at the Ministry of Instruction to-day to inquire into the case of death from alleged Asiatic cholera at Breslau. Minister von Gossler presided. Reports were received showing that the victim was an emigrant from Austrian Silesia, who had reached Breslau in a dying condition. Orders have been issued requiring increased stringency in frontier examinations.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 22.--The revival tonight of Dellinger's opera "Don Caesar" was one of the old-time triumphs of Col. McCaull. The Opera House, on South Broad-street, was filled with an exclusively fashionable audience. The advance sale had been large, but the rush at night was altogether unexpected.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 22.--Some 25 gentleman, representing the principal creditors of the Rochester Distilling Company, met at Powers Hotel this forenoon to consider the affairs of that company. Samuel Woolver, of Peoria, was made Chairman, and H.A. Curiel, of NewYork, Secretary.

A beautiful bright red mansard roof has lately been added to the Mint. It is well worth looking at, for so far as known it is the first and only sample of Franco-Grecian architecture in this country. There is certainly nothing else like it in Philadelphia.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 22.--Late this afternoon a damage suit for $50,000 was filed in the Circuit Court by J.J. McCann and L.J. Smith in behalf of E.D. Coleman against the Adams Express Company. This is one result of the detective agency's efforts to ferret out the express robbery.

There is a movement at Peterborough to arrange for the adequate celebration next year of the tercentenary of the execution of Mary Queen of Scots. It is proposed to commemorate the event both at Fotheringay Castle, where she was executed, and also at Peterborough, as the cathedral was her first burial place.

While President Cleveland was in the Grand Central Station a yonug man worked his way through the police lines and approached a reporter who was standing near the President's carriage. He was a seedy-looking individual, and as he held a card toward the reporter he asked the latter to give it to the President. "Tell him I won't hurt him," said the young man; "tell him I am harmless.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 22.--A Texas steer which escaped Sunday afternoon from a slaughter house in this city was recaptured at Haledon this afternoon, but had enjoyed his liberty so much that he again ran off, overturning men, women, children, boxes, and barrels, and finally a wagon, the horse attached to which ran away and frightened two or three more into also running away.
ODEN, Nov. 22.--The natives of Ambodu have massacred the Captain and seven of the crew of the French man-of-war Pengouin. The Captain and his men had landed to obtain water for the ship.

After a rest of several weeks Liberty resumed her task of enlightening the world last evening. Her torch was lighted before the sun went down, and shortly after dark the lights on the fort began the illumination of the pedestal and the lower portion of the statue.

An excellent performance of "Das goldene Kreuz" delighted a large and very fashionable audience at the Metropolitan Opera House last evening. Brull's opera improves vastly on closer acquaintance, and, as may be supposed, its second representation, which was carried on with far more spirit and decision than its earliest rendering, added not a little to the effectiveness of the work.

BOSTON, Nov. 22.--It took the Democratic City Committee of Boston but a very short time to renominate Mayor Hugh O'Brien for a third term to-night. There was not the slightest opposition to his candidacy, and the proceedings were, therefore, of the most formal description. This renomination should be equivalent to an election, and doubtless is, but the County ...

It has been considered for some time past by thoughtful Democrats that Mr. Cleveland must be renominated as a political necessity. Just about this time it begins to be understood that he will probably be renominated as a matter of pleasure also.

The annual meeting of the Brooklyn Home for Consumptives was held in the Baptist Church, Pierrepont and Clinton streets, last evening. A large number of persons interested in this institution were present, and Gen. A.C. Barnes presided.

The members of the Philadelphia Baseball Club who recently went to the West Indies to play a series of matches returned yesterday on the Havana steamship Cienfuegos, having had an unsuccessful trip. They seemed glad to get back. They played but few games in Cuba. The men started for Philadelphia on an early afternoon train.

DUBLIN, Nov. 22.--A fight occurred to-day between the police and a mob at Listowel, County Kerry. Some bailiffs seized a number of cattle in an action for rent, and a mob of 400 men attacked the officers and attempted to rescue the cattle.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22.--Senator Edmunds has been devoting some of his recent leisure hours to the preparation of a speech, early in the coming session, in which he will attack the Administration for its enforcement or non-enforcement of the civil service law. As this speech is probably intended for political effect, it may be assumed as certain that ...

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 22.--President Robert Harris, of the Northern Pacific Railroad, arrived in this city to-day, and during the afternoon had a meeting with J.C. Bullitt and Charles B. Wright, of the Land Committee of the company. The business transacted was altogether of a routine character and occupied but little time. During his stay in the city President Harris is the guest of Mr. Wright.

The funeral train covered the distance between this city and Albany, 141 miles, in three hours and twelve minutes. Only one stop, and that of a couple of minutes at Poughkeepsie to take water, was made. There were no public demonstrations made along the route. It was generally understood that none were expected or desired, but at various stations as the train ...

The striking plumbers reported yesterday that two of the boss plumbers had accepted the union's concessions and resumed work. McManus, the builder, they said, had given the contract for the plumbing on eight buildings to the journeyman plumbers' co-operative shop.

Arthur J. McQuade, ex-Alderman, on trial for bribery in connection with the granting of a franchise to the Broadway Surface Railroad, slept in the Tombs last night. The jury who have been engaged in trying him for several days slept in the Grand Jury room in the brownstone Court House, they having failed to come to an agreement at midnight, after having ...

CHICAGO, Nov. 22.--The attempt to bring about a meeting this week of the representatives of the various lines interested in the transcontinental business in this city has proved abortive, as some of the roads refused to attend. The invitation extended to the Canadian Pacific to send a representative to the meeting has been declined.

Mrs. Caroline Von Eberstein yesterday began suit before Judge Ingraham in the Superior Court, for the annulment of her marriage with Ferdinand Von Eberstein on the ground that at the time of her marriage she was a lunatic. In her complaint and affidavit she declares that she was married in Jersey City on March 6, 1882, ...

RAHWAY, N.J., Nov. 22.--Mrs. Frank P. Bullman, of Clark Township, three miles from here, left her infant son of 8 months sleeping in a cradle on the second floor of her house while she went down to dinner last Friday noon. When she went up stairs half an hour later the child was dead. The bedclothes were wrapped tightly about the child's neck.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 22.--There has been no telephone service whatever in this city since Saturday noon. Most of the merchants have their telephones disconnected and placarded ...

The mystery surrounding the disappearance of Capt. Thomas Carpenter, of the schooner Long Island, who is believed by his relatives and friends to have been murdered and thrown overboard, is as deep as ever. The schooner was found ashore with all sails set on Sunday at the month of Hempstead Harbor, Long Island.

Among the passengers arriving by the Aurania yesterday was the young Hindu philosopher Babu Mohini Chattergee, who is one of the most prominent members of the Brahma Somaj, the great agnostic movement now taking place in India.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 22.--The American Opera Company to-night had the misfortune to meet with wretched weather, but nevertheless Music Hall contained a brilliant audience, and the opera of "Lakme" was presented in a manner to provoke enthusiasm. Mlle. Pauline L'Allemand made a most favorable impression and received unusual honors.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22.--The recommendations of the Central Traffic Association that freight rates be advanced to the basis of 30 cents per 100 pounds on grain from Chicago to New-York were submitted to the vote of the trunk lines by Commissioner Fink. To-day Mr. Fink sent the following dispatch to Commissioner Blanchard announcing the result of that vote:
"J.S."--Yes. "South Pole."--No one has ever been there to find out.

A number of old-time pupils and prominent clergy of the city met last night in the De La Sane Institute, in Second-street, to devise ways and means for purchasing land upon which to erect a new Catholic Institute in a more central location than the present institute.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22.--Some farmers living along the lake shore, seven miles north of Whitehall, on Lake Michigan, discovered the schooner L.J. Conway on the beach a total wreck last Thursday. The farmers made no effort to let the outside world learn of the discovery, and the news only reached this city to-day. The Conway left Chicago Tuesday last bound for Muskegon, ...

A capital burlesque on Gilbert and Sullivan's "Princess Ida" was produced at the FifthAvenue Theatre last evening. Another royal victim of the vicissitudes of fortune is now occupying the gossips of Milan. His story runs thus: Leon de Luzignano, Prince of Koricosz, descendant of the Kings of Armenia, died in Italy in the year 1876.

Fire started last night at the base of the dumb waiter in James Woods's four-story house, No. 2,149 Third-avenue, and in a very few minutes was up to the second floor, cutting off escape from above. On the top floor, in one room, lay Mrs. Mary Adams, a crippled widow, who had been infirm for a year and a half, ...

BOSTON, Nov. 22.--Peter Norton, a Metropolitan horse car driver, was arrested and held to-day in the Cambridge Court on the charge of causing the death of his wife, Margaret. The Nortons lived in Cambridgeport, and on the night of the 12th inst. Mrs. Norton presented herself at the police station clad only in her ...

Among the passengers on the steamer Wyanoke, of the Old Dominion Line, which arrived from Richmond, Va., yesterday morning were Mrs. Heloise L. Christian, of Richmond, and her son, John R. Christian, a young man of 25.

MONTREAL, Nov. 22.--Mgr. Lafleche, Bishop of Three Rivers, has issued a pastoral to his clergy asking them to do all in their power to put down the Riel agitation, which he says has been subversive of all the great principles of law and order.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Nov. 22.--A dreadful railroad wreck occurred at 7 o'clock to-night at Savoy, four miles south of this town. The way freight, bound north, was standing on the main track while some freight was being unloaded, and a stock train running in the same direction dashed into the caboose of the former.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 16.--The change made in the political complexion of the State Legislature, in which the Democrats now have a good working majority on joint ballot, whereas there was a balance against them of 37 votes in that body previously, is not the least of the noteworthy incidents connected with the recent election in California.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 22.--A scene of a decidedly interesting character occurred this afternoon at the police court. Justice King, a Democrat, was a candidate for the office for the third time this Fall, and the Express, convinced of his unworthiness, made a hard but unsuccessful fight against him.

There has been a marked change in the tone of the Republican organs touching the tariff since the election. Up to that time, and especially during the canvass, the old doctrine of the sanctity of the tariff was preached with great vehemence and solemnity. NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 22.--Capt. Corwin and the rest of Yale College spent an anxious morning to-day waiting for Capt. Savage's reply to Yale's ultimatum to Princeton about the football game on Thanksgiving Day. A little after noon a telegram arrived directed to Capt. Corwin. It ran thus:

BOSTON, Nov. 22.--During the very general observance to-day of the Mayor's order that flags should be displayed at half mast on all public buildings, as a token of respect to the memory of ex-President Arthur, one flagrant omission attracted considerable attention, and is exciting much comment.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Nov. 22.--The schooner Pedro Varela arrived here this morning from St. Michaels where she was 21 days in quarantine, having put in there on account of sickness, caused by being at Annabon, coast of Africa, where it is believed African fever was contracted.

Yesterday being the feast of St. Cecilia, the name's day of the Superior of the Sisters of Our Lady of Mercy of St. Catherine's Convent, at Lexington-avenue and Eighty-firststreet, the services were rendered more than usually impressive by the profession of two novices of the order.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 22.--United States Deputy Collector Hughes and Deputy Marshal Spurrier seized a large quantity of illicit brandy at the house of Bug. Gibbs, near Chestnut Mound, and arrested James A. Apple and Jack Hales, the proprietors of a licensed brandy distillery at that place. The latter had reported only a small quantity of liquor ...

LEBANON, Penn., Nov. 22.--A force of slaters at work to-day on the new portion of the Eagle Hotel left one of their number, Charles Gibson, on one side of the shed roof while they proceeded to the other side. When they returned they found their companion gone. He had fallen three stories down without making any outcry and was killed almost instantly. Mr. Gibson was 27 years of age.

New-York and New-England Railroad stock was boomed again in Wall-street yesterday, the old story of a New-York connection being revamped once more. Enough money has been subscribed, so this story went, to pay for building a line forthwith from this city to Danbury, where the New-England line will be met.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 22.--The veil of mystery which has enveloped the murder of Mrs. Wheller seems to be lifting and disclosing as the murderer old man Wheller himself. He has been under arrest, though little evidence to implicate him was found, and the preliminary examination was expected to close to-day without having produced any testimony directly inculpating ...

CINCINNATI, Nov. 22.--Judge Hill, of the United States court of Mississippi, has rendered a decision in the case of Frank S. Bond, Receiver, against the Railroad Commissioner of Mississippi, in which the right of a State Commissioner to fix a tariff for a railway which is not paying its current charges is denied.

BOSTON, Nov. 22.--The Eastern Railroad preferred stock scheme met a serious set-back to-day in the shape of a bill in equity which was filed in the Supreme Judicial Court by M.M. Canniff, of Boston, and other stockholders against the corporation and its officers.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 22.--John Miller, known throughout the chain of lakes as an eccentric character, who earned a precarious livelihood by rescuing hapless persons from drowning, by diving for dead bodies, and by fishing valuables out of the river and lake, died last night aged 62.

The "big gooseberry" has been enfonce. A letter from Paris says that an oyster measuring 60 centimeters in diameter was exhibited in the fish market the other day. It was sold for 7f. 75c., and must have taken at least three men to swallow it whole.
SOFIA, Nov. 22.--M. Karaveloff and M. Zankoff will soon leave Sofia. They have already obtained Russian passports.

Persons passing along Fourteenth-street will find it to their advantage to enter the Star Shoe Store, at No. 20 West. The eye will at once be attracted by the fine display of footgear, but the essential point pertains to prices. If a good bargain cannot be found in this establishment it will be a difficult matter to satisfy the buyer anywhere in New-York or vicinity.

BOSTON, Nov. 22.--About a week ago Michael Norton, a Cambridgeport horse car driver, was arrested and fined $20 and costs for beating his wife. The woman has been sinking slowly since the occurrence and died this morning. Norton was rearrested and held in $8,000.
James Coats, of Providence, is at the Buckingham Hotel. Henry S. Sanford, of Florida, is at the Brevoort House.

The Armanini family of mandolin players, to whose efforts at the Casino reference has already been made in this place, appeared at Koster Bial's Sunday, and delighted the frequenters of that establishment by their unique and artistic performances. Arrangements of "Carmen," Boccaccio," and "The Merry War," ...

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 22.--The British steamer Rossini, Capt. Woodruff, reached this port to-day from Huelva with 1,500 tons of pyrites. She had on board Capt. Hand and six men of the Philadelpliia schooner Rebecca S. Mulford, whom she took from their sinking vessel Wednesday last off Cape Hatteras. Capt. Woodruff said that when they took the unfortunate men from ...

Contrary to expectation, the Brooklyn Navy Yard was not closed yesterday, and the men felt very indignant over the matter. Commodore Gherardi explained that it would have cost the Government $6,000 to have closed the yard yesterday.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 22.--Charles H. S. Kirm, who has half a dozen aliases and who is said to be one of the most notorious horse thiefs in the country, was sentenced to four years in the State prison by Judge Stewart this morning. He stole a horse belonging to the Trenton Woolen Company two years ago, and was met by a Pennsylvania officer at Frankford.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 22.--Last night as William Dunn, of Theresa, was driving home from church with his wife and Mrs. A.N. Brittan, his horse became frightened and ran away, throwing Mr. and Mrs. Dunn out against a tree by the roadside. Mrs. Dunn was instantly killed and Mr. Dunn was badly bruised, though he will recover. Mrs. Brittan had one leg and shoulder broken, and her recovery is doubtful.

Mrs. Langtry will begin an engagement at Niblo's Dec. 6. Messrs. Murray and Murphy, the Irish comedians, amused a large audience at the Third-Avenue Theatre last evening in their well known farce called "Our Irish Visitors." The piece is broad caricature, but it has merit of a certain sort, and certainly pleases a large portion of the public. It will be the attraction at the Third-Avenue throughout Thanksgiving week.

GIRARD, Kan., Nov. 22.--A cyclone or an electrical storm struck Girard at 8:40 this morning and passed through the residence portion of the town from southwest to northwest. The path of the storm was only from 50 to 75 feet wide.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 22.--Capt. Easler, of the British schooner Carrie Easler, at the Delaware Breakwater, from Port au Prince, reports that during the passage she was in company with the schooner Kate Wentworth, bound from Port au Prince to New-York.

BOSTON, Nov. 22.--The 15 police divisions reported to Superintendent Small this morning 125 violations of the Sunday blue laws, a remarkably small number, which shows the very general unanimity with which the storekeepers and barbers obeyed the mandate of the Board of Police.

The effort made in Boston to enforce the Sunday laws of Massachusetts may perhaps have the good result of drawing public attention to the fact that those laws are obsolete. Gen.
