At Lexington-Avenue Opera House, Thanksgiving evening, S.A.L. Bentley's NewYork Church Choir Opera Company will perform "The Mikado" for the benefit of the widows and orphans of Hope Lodge, No. 244, F. and A.M.

Readers of Harper who recall the sumptuous Christmas issues of the past two years will not be disappointed at the treat offered them now. The regular serials have been omitted and the number wears a gorgeous Christmas aspect in its every part, from the frontispiece to the Du ...

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 23.--The recent sale of the Detroit, Mackinac and Marquette and Marquette, Houghton and Ontonagon Railroads to a new company, having in it several heavy Detroit capitalists, contemplates at once ...

Van Nest is an aristocratic little hamlet five miles from the Harlem River on the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad. The station is opposite the Catholic Protectory, and the nearest dwelling is half a mile away. At 6:45 o'clock Monday evening the station agent, J.B. Robinson, stepped outside and adjusted the time card case.

The Directors of the Children's Aid Society held yesterday afternoon their thirty-fourth annual meeting at which William A. Booth, who has been President for about 25 years, was reelected, as were George S. Coe and Charles L. Brace, who are veterans in the offices, respectively, of Treasurer and Secretary.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Nov. 23.--Nathan Schuler, whose exploits in New-York City yesterday, and at Albany in July last, then the bi-centennial was held there, published in THE TIMES today, can best be described by the Scotch phrase an "innocent."
VIENNA, Nov. 23.--Austria has commenced to issue money orders to England and the British colonies in sums of 200 florins and under.

A jury was impaneled yesterday before Chief-Justice Davis, in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, to determine whether John Lehman caused the death of his wife, who was found last July at the bottom of an air shaft at No. 2,214 First-avenue, close to which the Lehmans lived.

An officer of the Erie Railroad said yesterday that the express companies had finally reached an agreement, and that the fight which has lately waxed so hot has been settled, rates being advanced by all the companies. Contracts to maintain rates have been signed by representatives of the various companies, inclining the Adams, the Baltimore and Ohio, the Erie, and other important ones.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 23.--The Hon. W.H. English, being shown a Washington dispatch which states that in an interview with him in the New-York World he acknowledged that he was a candidate for United States Senator, said it was not true. "No such interview has been had with me, and I have made no such statements."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23.--The Secretary of the Navy to-day appointed Commander Evans, Chief Engineer Menocal, and Lieut. Hemphill to act as a board to inspect the buildings of the Washington Navy Yard and report upon the changes necessary to be made to transform the yard into an ordnance factory.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Nov. 23.--Company A, Third Regiment, N.G.S.N.J., held an election at its armory here last evening for a Captain and two Lieutenants. The election was presided over by Col. E.H. Ropes, and resulted in the selection of Jacob R. Borden as Captain, A.D. McCabe as First Lieutenant, and John R. Muddell as Second Lieutenant.

PARIS, Ky., Nov. 23.--The little town of Paris was roused yesterday over the report that A. Newhoff, a prominent merchant, had disappeared. Nothing was known of his whereabouts until to-day, when a note was found saying: "You will find me in the creek, near my old fishing place."

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 23.--Henry C. Kingsley, Treasurer of Yale College, is slowly recovering from the effects of a serious accident. While he was driving recently his carriage was run into by a coal cart and overturned. Mr. Kingsley was thrown upon a wheel, and two of his ribs were fractured. The accident was kept very quiet, and was not generally known about until yesterday.

Patrick Reynolds, 10 years of age, was one of the four boys sent from Newark to Pasteur for treatment last Spring. About a week ago he left his home and nothing was heard of him until last night, when his mother learned that he was hiding on a canal boat. She went to the boat, where she found him in the hold. She took him to Police Headquarters and he was locked up.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 23.--Reports received in regard to the condition of the cotton crop from 50 out of the 75 counties of the State, show the present crop to be the largest ever raised in Arkansas.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 23.--The roads running through the northern part of the State and in Dakota are having some trouble to-day. In the northern part of the State, along the Manitoba line, there is not much snow, but high ...

The latest of the outbreaks against Portuguese rule in Mozambique promises to be also one of the most formidable, since the hostile natives seem to have already routed a combined force of Portuguese and friendly natives in a great battle, in which the killed on both sides are thought to have numbered nine thousand.
The Directors of the Eden Munsee have engaged the famous Hungarian band, and it will begin its performances there early in December.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 23.--Ruddock, Nuttall Co. have sold their sawmill plant, pine and farming lands, and logging road to Buckley Douglass, of Manistee, for $550,000 cash, Ruddock, Nuttall Co. retain their vessel property, manufactured lumber, and Chicago interests. Buckley Douglass will rebuild the mill to make a specialty of cutting bill stuff. They own 275,000,000 feet of standing pine.
Mr. Booth will act Shylock and Petruchio at the Star Theatre to-night. Herr Niemann, Fraulein Brandt, and Fraulein Lehmann may be heard in "The Prophet" at the Metropolitan Opera House this evening.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23.--One of the regulations of the Railway Mail Postal Service is to the effect that postal clerks shall not take whisky with them, externally or internally, on their runs. Any small amount tucked away snugly in a pigeonhole would hardly be apt to bring its owner into trouble; but an unfortunate ...

The Subway Commission performed yesterday afternoon before a crowded house, and there was an overflow meeting in the adjoining hall. All the patent right comganies who have been clamorous for a section by means of which to convince the world that theirs is the only practical system in existence were represented by counsel, Directors, contractors, and engineers. President Hess presided and immediately called for the report of the engineers.

The thirty-fourth annual report of the Children's Aid Society has just been made public, and is summarized in our news columns. From the statements of Mr. CHARLES L. BRACE, the Secretary, and Mr. GEORGE S. COE, the Treasurer, the reader gets a clear view both of the current work and the immediate needs of the society, and of what it has accomplished since its foundation in 1853.

Over 300 employes of the Atlantic-Avenue Railroad Company packed Fallesen's Hall, at Third-avenue and Twenty-second-street, Brooklyn, from platform to door last night. The occasion was a friendly meeting between the men and the President of the road. President Richardson, usually known as Deacon Riohardson, sat upon the platform with Chairman McCormick ...

The inquest in the case of Miss Linda Poole, who died Nov. 7 at the apartments of her sister, Mrs. Eva Miller, at No. 297 West Twelfthstreet, was resumed yesterday before Coroner Messemer. Maggie McChesney, a domestic, was the first witness.

The Board of Aldermen yesterday considered the departmental estimates for 1887 as provisionally fixed by the Board of Estimate and Apportionment. Many changes, not however in the interest of economy, were made by the board, but their action is of no avail, being reviewable by the Board of Estimate and Apportionment in the consideration of the final estimates.

OTTAWA, Nov. 23.--The Dominion Government has decided to establish an experimental farm in British Columbia. Four or five thousand acres will be purchased on Vancouver Island or the mainland, and the capabilities of the climate and soil thoroughly tested within the next year or two.

If nothing unforeseen happens the ThirdAvenue Railroad's One Hundred and Twentyfifty-street cable branch, which has been under construction since the strikes last Summer, will be in successful operation next week.
Senator H.J. Coggeshall, of Waterville, N.Y., is at the Morton House. Ex-Gov. Alexander H. Rice, of Massachusetts, is at the Murray Hill Hotel.

The twenty-fifth anniversary of the ordination of the Rev. Nicholas Sorg was observed yesterday, in the Church of St. Nicholas, in Second-street. At 10 A.M. Father Sorg celebrated a solemn high mass, assisted by his brother, the Rev. Joseph M. Sorg, Rector of St. Louis Church, in Main-street, Buffalo, and and others.

There was no such thing as the Society of Alumni of the University of Pennsylvania until last night, when a permanent organization was established under the cheerful and invigorating auspices of Delmonico. A dinner was given by the Alumni to celebrate the event, and a thoroughly representative gathering assembled, ...

PESTH, Nov. 23.--It is stated that under pressure from the German and Polish members of the Austrian delegation, the Budget Committee's report has been amended so as to contain a censure of Gen. Kaulbars and to make less emphatic the passage referring to the peaceful character of the relations between Austria and Russia.

BOSTON, Nov. 23.--The Stock Board was treated to a surprise to-day, and financial circles received a shock that recalled the early days of the Gray and Snelling defalcations. This came in the shape of the arrest of William Reed Treasurer of the South Boston Horse Railroad Company, and also doing business as a stock broker at No. 53 Devonshire-street.

Henry George made his first public appearance since the campaign last night at Cooper Union. The way he was greeted must have reminder him of ante-election days, for hats and umbrellas waved in the air, and the stout lungs that bellowed for him had plainly become thoroughly rested during the past three weeks.

SHELBYVILLE, Ky., Nov. 23.--A man named Van Arsdale arrived here this morning, bringing particulars of the killing of the notorious Ike Arnold in Washington County. Yesterday afternoon he, with Tom Dugan, a wealthy farmer of Washington County, and two others were in a carriage driving from Springfield to ...

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 23.--W.W. Coles's Circus arrived here last week and has broken up. Its paraphernalia, horses, and animals are now being disposed of at auction. This is not a case of bankruptcy, for Mr. Coles says he has had a very fortunate season, and leaves the business some $2,000,000 ahead, but in pursuance of a contract which he has closed with P.T. Barnum.

We have noted the intention of Mr. EDMUNDS to make a speech on the record of the Cleveland Administration with regard to the civil service, and we have been compelled to doubt whether he will do this in the fair spirit in which he approaches other subjects.

The bill at Dockstader's this week has been freshened by the addition of a sketch called "Thanksgiving in Thompson-street." in which Mr. Dockstader impersonates a colored preacher who is fond of chickens. In this part of the entertainment the turkey of the season is duly honored, a live baby is christened, and there is a colored wedding.

The torpedo boat Peacemaker was entirely successful in its aquatic frolics yesterday afternoon, the members of the Submarine Monitor Company were filled with a great joy, and a large number of people who battled with the fog in order to witness the events indulged in vigorous applause.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23.--The Chicago branch of the sash, door, and blind factory of Carlton, Foster Co., of Oskcosh, Wis., who failed yesterday with liabilities estimated at $250,000, has been closed on attachments from the Superior Court.

MOBILE, Ala., Nov. 23.--The north-bound freight train on the Mobile and Ohio Railroad, after crossing the city line, and while passing an unlocked switch, this morning, turned the switch open, and two cars and a caboose mere ditched.

The sessions of the Eastern Conference of the Jewish Ministers' Association at the Lexington-Avenue Temple were brought to a close yesterday afternoon. NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 23.--The joint Committees of Finance and Budget of the City Council submitted to that body to-night a statement showing that the year 1886 will yield a surplus of revenue over expenditures. Owing to the peculiar system of collections the December pay roll has not been paid during the current month ...

ERIE, Penn., Nov. 23.--Daniel J. Brown, convicted of perjury, was to-day discharged on payment of costs. This course was partially the result of the suggestion of Mrs. Julia Dunn, the prosecutrix, through her attorneys. It will be remembered that Brown perjured himself to share Ezra Cooper from conviction for a criminal assault upon ...

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 23.--After a patient preliminary examination in the police court Benjamin S. Wheller, the old miser, was bound over to the Common Pleas Court to-day without bail to answer to the charge of murdering his wife. In his decision Judge Hutchins gave an exhaustive review of all the testimony and the strange circumstances of the case.

There will be a game of baseball on the Polo Grounds to-morrow between nines composed of prominent professionals living in NewYork and Brooklyn. The contest will be under the new rules recently adopted at Chicago. Following are the names of the men who are to compose the nines: Gerhardt, Hanlon, Crane, Connor, Deasley, Roseman, Nelson, Kennedy, Lynch, Burdock, Hankinson, Troy, Hayes, Force, Orr, Forster, Corcoran, and Wheeler.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Nov. 23.--Mr. Watkins, representing the Detroit League Baseball Club, came before the American Baseball Association at its session to-day, and made a statement which simplified the work of the association, He said that while the Association had in no manner solicited a bid for membership from the Detroit Club, and while no request for admission ...
LONDON, Nov. 24.--The steamship Carthagenian, (Br.,) Capt. McNicol, sld. from Liverpool for Baltimore yesterday.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Nov. 23.--Miss Jeanie Vivian Mansley, a handsome Englishwoman, 20 years old, died in convulsions on Friday, the first anniversary of the death of her lover, John Quinn, a dry goods clerk. It now appears that her death was caused by strychnine administered by herself. Her last request--to be buried by her lover in the Catholic cemetery--could not be complied with, as the Catholic Church forbids the interment of suicides in consecrated ground.

The experience which Mrs. D.S. Robinson had with a robber at her home, near Mamaroneck, Sunday morning, caused much excitement among her neighbors. Some were inclined to believe that the lady had been troubled with hysteria, but she still clings to the main points of her story, and several marks on her ...

The weary eyed, drowsy, unshaven jurymen in the McQuade trial staid in the General Sessions Court House again last night. McQuade slept once more in the Tombs uncertain of his fate. The jurymen had argued with one another from 9 o'olock on Monday evening until 8 o'clock last evening without agreeing upon a verdict and they were then locked up for another night.

CORK, Nov. 23.--At a meeting in this city to-day, the Mayor presiding, the action of the Postmaster-General in changing the mail contracts was condemned, and it was decided to watch the progress of the new system. Eight members of Parliament attended the meeting.

Miss Louise Seggermann, daughter of Mr. Henry Seggermann, was married last evening in the Church of the Heavenly Rest to Mr. Edward L. Norton. The church was well filled long before the time for the ceremony. It was very prettily decorated for the occasion with exotic plants and ferns, which nearly filled the chancel. A heavy white cord, tied in a lover's knot, was stretched across the centre aisle.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 23.--Drafts on New-York--Sight, 15 cents; telegraphic, 20.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Nov. 23.--The telephone fight has assumed a more determined aspect than ever, and there have been outbreaks of ill feeling between the company and the subscribers. In an altercation this morning a representative of the Bell Company and a subscriber came to blows.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 23.--The St. Paul, St. Croix and Lake Superior Railway Company filed articles of incorporation with the Secretary of State yesterday. DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 23.--The Michigan Central Railroad, it is now asserted, will build a gigantic ferry, intended to run across the Straits of Mackinac at all seasons. It will carry 30 cars and will put that line in a position to compete, to some extent at least, for the Eastern traffic from the great Northwest.

BERLIN, Nov. 23.--In spite of the closest watch kept on the barracks at Berlin, Spandau, and Potsdam thousands of copies of Socialist pamphlets have been found among the troops. The matter seized consists mostly of a newly issued appeal to the soldiers to join workingmen in hastening a social revolution. The source of the pamphlets has been traced to men frequenting soldiers' beer houses, and several of the men have been arrested.

We are frequently asked if the name of Franklin-square was derived from Walter Franklin, the noted merchant of a century ago, whose widow married Samuel Osgood, of the Treasury, and whose daughter married De Witt Clinton.

John Dettweller, whose store at No. 607 Myrtle-avenue, Brooklyn, was burned on June 21, made public yesterday an affidavit charging Fire Marshal Lewis with bribery in connection with the insurance on the property. This insurance amounted to $12,000, and on the final settlement $2,800 was obtained, although the actual ...

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 23.--The Lehigh Valley Coal Company to-day let a contract to Col. J.E. McIntire, of this city, for building a rail transfer trestle in Chicago. This trestle involves several new features, as a stocking, retail, and transfer trestle are all combined in one ...

A.H. King Co. are actually selling clothing at a sacrifice at their large establishment, Nos. 627 and 629 Broadway, between Bleecker and Houston streets. They are business men, and do not believe in selling goods at less than cost, but there are exceptions to all rules, and this firm has run against one of them.

The Nineteenth Century Club, which has been indulging in its customary Summer vacation, assembled last night to open a new season with discussions of politics, art, literature, religion, and lemonade. The club used to meet at the houses of its members, and the gatherings were informal affairs.

LONDON, Nov. 23.--The Rev. Joseph Parker, D.D., Pastor of the City Temple, publishes a letter opposing the inclusion in the Liberal Party platform of a plank favoring disestablishment. He says that to advocate disestablishment just now would be suicide for the Liberals.

EMPORIA, Kan., Nov. 23--The Rev. Robert Laird Collier arrived late this afternoon from Kansas City. The funeral services over his son, L.D. Collier, were held at 11 o'clock this evening, after which the funeral party left in a special car over the Atchison. Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad for Davenport. Iowa, where the interment will take place. Yarborough, the murderer of Collier, will have a hearing tomorrow.

Mayor Grace will give a hearing to-day to the property owners who opposed the scheme of the St. Nicholas-Avenue and Cross-town Railroad Company to lay tracks on upper St. Nicholas-avenue, Fourth-avenue, and One Hundred and Twenty-eighth-street.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 23.--It appears from information received at Collector Crenshaw's office that in April, 1878, the Georgia Land and Lumber Company of St. Simon began issuing scrip in the shape of bank paper, which was used to pay off their hands and other local indebtedness.

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., Nov. 23.--The excitement caused by the wholesale arrest yesterday of Knights is intense, though most persons look upon the entire proceedings as a farce. No one believes that the prisoners will suffer serious punishment, but it is hard to tell what the course of the local authorities may produce before the end is reached.

The Norwegian bark Sjodronningen went ashore on Robbin's Reef on Monday night, though the fact was not discovered, except by the crew, until yesterday. She was loaded with 5,000 barrels of oil, and after leaving the Standard Oil docks on Monday afternoon anchored off Tompkinsville.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23.--The General Managers of the various roads interested in the passenger traffic between Chicago, St. Louis, Council Bluffs, and Omaha, met again to-day to make a final effort to bring about the adoption of the proposed agreement for pooling the passenger business between those points.

DANBURY, Conn., Nov. 23.--George Bates, one of the most famous of the old-time NewEngland stage drivers, died at his home, in this town, last night, aged 78 years. At different times he drove between Ridgefield and Stamford and Danbury and New-haven. For eight years he was Guardian of the county jail here. Altogether Bates spent 40 years as a stage driver, and must have covered about 270,000 miles.

The New-York Philharmonic Club, which has now attained its ninth season, gave the first of its annual series of concerts at Chickering Hall last evening. GLOUCESTER, Mass., Nov. 23.--The schooner Frank L., of Annapolis, Nova Scotia, Capt. Cleveland, from New-York for St. John, NewBrunswick, went ashore on Bass Rocks at 4 o'clock this afternoon.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, Nov. 23.--About 1,000 coopers are out on a strike here, demanding an advance in the scale of wages of from 10 to 25 per cent. The outlook promises a long lock-out.
The cable has brought from Vienna the important announcement that "the Government has issued an order prohibiting the playing of poker."

Symonds, the story writer and exTexas ranger, at the latter's house, No. 2,607 Jessup-street, on the night of Oct. 22, is out of immediate danger and is steadily improving.

BOSTON, Nov. 23.--The New-England College Athletic Association was organized to-night by delegates representing Amherst, Bowdoin, Brown, Dartmouth, Trinity, Tufts, and Williams Colleges. A constitution and by-laws were adopted and the following officers were chosen: President--Applegate, of Trinity; First VicePresident--Austin, of Bowdoin; Second VicePresident--Abbott, of Williams; Secretary-- Smith, of Amherst; Treasurer--White, of Brown; Executive Committee--Messrs. Talbot, Cravens, White, Livermore, Cook, and Smith.

A glance at the history of Parliamentary privileges and secret sessions in Great Britain will facilitate a correct understanding of the intentions of the framers of our Constitution and its true construction.

AUBURN, N.Y., Nov. 23.--Levi Stackpool, aged 9 years, was killed by a calf yesterday. He was holding the animal by a rope, which, in play, he had tied around his neck. The calf started off, threw the boy down, and dragged him until death resulted from strangulation.

I learn that the Emperor of Austria, who is a great smoker, has been ordered by the doctors to give up the fragrant weed. They attribute his neuralgia to it. His Majesty was in the habit of smoking 20 cigars daily.

CHATHAM, N.Y., Nov. 23.--Beckwith, the Austerlitz criminal, who murdered one Vandercook, of the town of Austerlitz, and burned up the body in a stove, has another lease of life. Judge Ingalls to-day granted a new trial on the grounds of newly discovered evidence, and the case will go to the General Term. Beckwith was to be hanged on Dec. 16, the Court of Appeals having confirmed the decision of the lower courts.

HANOVER, N. H., Nov. 23.--The graduating exercises at Dartmouth Medical College occurred to-night, Prof. C. P. Frost presiding. The degree of M. D. was conferred upon 19 graduates. Prayer was offered by President Bartlett, and George D. Towne, M. D., of Manchester, delivered an address. The valedictory was delivered by E. E. Barrett, and President Bartlett also made an address.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 23.--While quarreling over a game of "craps" this afternoon William Ball shot and killed a lad named Seavers. Both are colored boys and work at oyster shucking. Ball managed to elude the police and has not yet been captured.
SANTIAGO, Nov. 22, via Galveston.--The flags of the different legations were hoisted at half mast yesterday on the receipt of the official notice of the deatn of ex-President Arthur.

DENVER, Col., Nov. 23.--Last evening while T.K. Stevens and his son, 20 years of age, were filling with giant powder a drill hole in Plutis mine, near Idaho Springs, the charge exploded, killing the son instantly. Mr. Stevens was so badly injured by being struck by pieces of rock that he died this afternoon.
VIENNA, Nov. 23.--The Government has issued an order prohibiting the playing of poker.

There is going to be a great fall in clothing for the next few days at the store of Ball Co., Nos. 628 and 630 Broadway. They have an immense store, eight stories high, with 50 feet front and 200 depth. Down stairs is their retail department and up stairs the manufacturing is done. Their counters are piled high with foods that must be sold, for $200,000 must be raised to settle an estate.

The Pennsylvania Railroad trains cross the main thoroughfares of Jersey City at grade, entailing loss of life and delay to travel. PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 23.--Gilbert F. Robbins was elected Mayor of this city to-day by 262 majority over Oscar Lapham, (Dem.,) and Henry C. Clark, (Ind. and Proh.) Mr. Robbins is a Republican, and has been Acting Mayor since the death of Mr. Doyle.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 23.--The Court of Appeals to-day rendered a decision in the case of the Globe Printing Company against Stahl. The suit was for recovery of an advertising bill which involved a nice question of law, namely, the admission of evidence of conversations through the telephone. The court affirms the judgment of the lower court in an opinion by Judge Thompson, and says:

The Hon. Erastus Brooks was dying at the point of death at his residence in West Brighton, Staten Island, last evening. Mr. Brooks was taken ill in September, but rallied and was able to leave his home for a short trip. On his return however, he was taken sick again and was obliged to take to his bed, where he has since remained.

BLOOMINGTON, Ill., Nov. 23.--Application for a supersedeas in the case of Spies, Parsons, and their convicted fellow-Anarchists was made to Justice Scott, of the Illinois Supreme Court, this afternoon, by Leonard Swett and Capt. Black.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Nov. 24.--The saw mills have closed down after having the shortest season on record, being one month to six weeks less than last year. As a result, 50,000,000 feet more lumber was sawed in 1885 than during the past season. This season the total cut of lumber was 262,636,019 ...

Mr. Robert A. Johnston, of the firm of J. C. Johnston, who resides in Riverdale, distributed turkeys last evening among the deserving poor of his neighborhood. This act of thoughtfulness on the part of Mr. Johnston made Thanksgiving Day a reality to many persons who otherwise would probably have fared poorly. Mr. Johnston supplemented his charitable act by giving a turkey to each of the employes of his establishment.
Mai, the wife of Chin Shun, a dealer in Chinese and Japanese wares at No. 139 Chathamstreet, died yesterday morning, after suffering for five months from "galloping" consumption.

LYONS, N. Y., Nov. 24.--The trial of David E. Converse, a farmer of the town of Rose, for the murder of his aged wife, Angeline, came to a close in this village last night, after a session of two days. The jury found a verdict of manslaughter in the first degree. The trial will be long remembered as the shortest and most exciting ever known in Wayne County.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24.--Ex-President Franklin B. Gowen made a somewhat startling claim to-day when the accounts between the Philadelphia and Reading and Central Railroad of New-Jersey were up before Master George M. Dallas.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 24.--Clifford Buckalew, a young jeweler of this city, quarreled with his wife last night and afterward purchased a bottle of oxalic acid, wrote a remorseful note, and, going to his father's house, was about to swallow the contents of the bottle, when the elder Buckalew entered the room and knocked the bottle from his son's hand.

Mr. Emmanuel Moor gave the second of a series of three recitals of piano music at Chickering Hall yesterday afternoon. RONDOUT, N.Y., Nov. 24.--A dense fog impeded navigation on the Hudson River last night and this morning. Steamboats and tows were compelled to anchor. Several boats were 10 hours late in reaching their docks.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24.--"There is absolutely nothing in the published report to the effect that an agreement has been reached between the Pennsylvania and Baltimore and Ohio Companies," said a high official of the former corporation to a TIMES reporter this afternoon.

Peter Farley, a resident of Ferry-street, Newark, went home late last night and brutally assaulted his wife. He kicked her in the eye and in the abdomen so severely that she had to be taken to the hospital. It is thought that she may not recover. The surgeon think that she is injured internally.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24.--The fact that Judge Prendergast has dissolved the injunction prohibiting A.S. Gage from going outside the jurisdiction of his court gave rise to the rumor to-day that the firm of A.S. Gage Co. had reached a settlement with their creditors.

BELLE PLAINE, Iowa Nov. 24.--Descents were made by the diver into the big well to-day, and the contractor says with encouraging results, although he refuses to give details. He has fenced in the well, and declines to admit spectators. Several visitors from a distance have gone away disappointed.
PESTH, Nov. 24.--The deputation appointed by the Bulgarian Sobranje to consult the powers touching the choice of a ruler will arrive here to-morrow.
The much-discussed game of football between Princeton and Yale for the college championship will take place at Princeton to-day.
SANTIAGO DE CHILI, Nov. 24, via Galveston.--Senor Zenoa Areire was elected President of the Chamber of Deputies to-day by a majority of two votes.
Mayor-elect Abram S. Hewitt took the oath of office yesterday before Mayor Grace. Ex-Assemblyman Maurice Houlahan expects to be appointed private secretary to Collector Magone.

MARQUETTE, Mich., Nov. 24.--The body of John S. Burroughs, a prominent citizen of this place, who had been missing since Monday evening, was found last night off an iron ore dock in 20 feet of water. The Coroner's jury rendered a verdict of accidental drowning, al though the theory of suicide is strongly supported by facts.

Dr. J. M. Browne, United States Navy, is at the Victoria Hotel. Gen. Wesley Merritt, of West Point, and the Rev. H. B. Hoffman, of Philadelphia, are at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 24.--The gymnasium was tastefully dressed for the opening hop of the Naval Academy this evening. In the centre was a moss-covered fountain in which the water fell in musical ripples. The pillars of the roof were covered with chestnut bark, and entwined with ivy. Hanging from the arches between the pillars were gaily colored Chinese lanterns.

Patriotic playgoers crowded MadisonSquare Garden last evening to applaud the first performance of Mr. Steele Mackaye's last great drama, which was acted with great spirit and power by Buffalo Bill, several dozen cowboys, cowgirls, and genuine greasers, besides a hundred and fifty Indians of various tribes in full fig and feather.

He has perfected, not reformed or ameliorated, but prefected the Government of the city of Chicago.

BOSTON, Nov. 24.--It is stated that expert examination of William Reed's accounts have already brought to light proof of more extensive crookedness than was at first believed.

At the hearing of the suit brought by her husband against Rosina Scheuffle for divorce, in the Chancellor's court at Newark yesterday, the woman's 20--year-old daughter was carried in on a bed as a witness for her mother.

BRODHEAD'S BRIDGE, N.Y., Nov. 24.-- John Rutherford, a farmer, while ascending a ladder to get hay to feed his stock here fell backward and broke his neck. He died instantly.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Nov. 24.--The firm of J. P. Phillips Co., dealers in agricultural implements, made a voluntary assignment to-day for the benefit of their creditors. The liabilities of the firm are unknown. The nominal value of thier assets is $70,000. The firm is composed of J. B. Phillips and C. E. Moody.

At a late hour last evening Erastus Brooks was steadily and gradually losing strength, and his death is considered near. His mind remains clear, however, and he was able to recognize friends last night. During the afternoon the Rev. Pascal Harrower, of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Ascension, of which Mr. Brooks was a warden, administered the sacrament to him.

Extra performances Will be given this afternoon at all the city theatres. A Private dispatch says that "Tangled Lives," Mr. John W. Keller's play, is likely to be produced at the Fifth-Avenue Theatre Dec. 6 for a run of a month or so, with Mr. Robert Mantell in the leading character.

CLIFFWOOD, N. J., Nov. 24.--About two months ago a cow belonging to Mr. John Kuhns, of this place, was bitten by a dog. Yesterday the cow was attacked with rabies, and ran around the barnyard biting the horses and other cows, many of them being lacerated in a horrible manner.

BOSTON, Nov. 24.--The Boston agents of the Furness Line of steamships received a dispatch this morning stating that the steamship Sulina, consigned to them, was stranded in a dangerous position near Cape Sable.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., NOV. 24.--Reports received from 51 of the seventy-odd counties of the State regarding the condition of the cotton crop show that the expectation of a large yield at the beginning of the season has been fully realized.
CHICAGO, Nov. 24.--George Gore, the well known centre fielder of the Chicago Club, was to-day released by President Spalding, and he will play in the future as a member of the NewYork Club.

BOSTON, Nov. 24.--The Governor and Council this morning completed their canvass of the votes cast at the recent State election and announced the result of the total vote of the State as 243,769. The plurality for Ames (Rep.) for Governor is 9,463; Brackett. (Rep.,) for Lieutenant-Governor, 4,978. For AttorneyGeneral Sherman leads the Republican State ticket with 124,269 votes, or about 12,700 plurality over the Democratic candidate.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., Nov. 24.--Last Monday evening while the Rev. J. C. Cobb, Pastor of the West Grove Methodist Episcopal Church, was try ink to quell a disturbance in the street opposite his church, he was assaulted and badly beaten by John Brinely, Frederick Johnson, Mrs. John Brinely, and another woman, all colored. To-day Brinely and Johnson were committed to the county jail to await the action of the Grand Jury.

Sipple was sentenced for complicity in a scheme to rob the Erie Railroad, and Condit was a heavy forger.

HILL'S GROVE, R.I., Nov. 24.--The residents of this place are discussing the sudden and strange illness of a Swede named John Anderson, who resides in the little gambrel-roofed house near the spot where Miss Pearson's body was found. According to a statement in the Journal of Commerce, the exposure last year of the imposition practiced upon the commerce of New-York by the extortion known as the patent disinfection of rags has not entirely suppressed that outrage. The law admits raw material in the form of rags free of duty.

CHESTNUT MOUND, Tenn., Nov. 24.-- Squire William Shoemaker, a veteran of the war of 1812, and perhaps the oldest citizen of the county, died at his residence near Chestnut Mound this morning. His exact age was not positively known, but from reliable data in possession of the family he was believed to be about 102 years old.

PALESTINE, Texas, Nov. 24.--Judge John H. Reagan left for Washington to-night to be present at the meeting of certain Congressional committees which sit prior to the convening of Congress.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 24.--Since Saturday, when Surrogate Stern decided to sustain the will of Millionaire Francis W. Tracy, the question as to the form of the decree has been constantly under discussion by the Surrogate and the representatives of either side.

KERHONKSON, N.Y., Nov. 24.--Farmer Kortright's hay stacks and an outbuilding were burned here on Saturday. To-day what is supposed to be the charred remains of a man were found beneath the debris. It is presumed that a tramp sought shelter in the stack, and that a spark from his pipe ignited the hay and burned him to death.

SALINA CRUZ, Nov. 24, via Galveston.-- The Department of Santa Ana, in San Salvador, has been placed under martial law, the Government having discovered the existence of a conspiracy. Various arrests have been made and the arms destined for the revolutionists have been seized. The Government has taken energetic means to maintain peace.

MONTREAL, Nov. 24.--The customs authorities to-day seized a consignment of oil paintings which were brought to this city by Mr. S. Marcusey, of London, England, to be sold by auction by Messrs. Hicks Co. These paintings were entered at the Custom House as works of art, and as such were not subject to duty.

A concert was given in Chickering Hall last evening by the instructors of the Grand Conservatory of Music. The most noteworthy incidents of the concert were the first appearances here of two gentlemen have recently joined the Faculty of the institution.

If Laura Tunstall had selected another traveling companion than her suspicious mother-in-law when she made a trip to Richmond, Va., last Winter she would not have had to defend herself against a charge of marital infidelity. Laura had been a bride for only three months when she made the trip. Homesickness and a yearning for the society of her mother were the motives of her long journey.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 24.--George C. Waldo, one of the editors of the Standard, was to-day formally offered the position of Commissary-General by Mr. Lousbury, the next Governor of Connecticut.

BISMARCK, Dakota, Nov. 24.--It is reported here that seven Indians--Big Thunder, the Crow chief, among the number--were drowned while attempting to cross the Missouri River at a point about 10 miles north of here.

Lowell, of the National Tribune, Washington, D.C., at the Trinity Episcopal Church, by the Rev. Dr. Breed, D.D. The Socialists of this city gave Wilhelm Liebknecht, who has been traveling about the country with Dr. and Mrs. Aveling, a tremendous farewell reception yesterday afternoon in the large hall at Cooper Union. Mr. Liebknecht will sail for Germany to-morrow.

TORONTO, Nov. 25.-The Toronto Lacrosse Club has decided to let the championship go to the Montreal Club by default. They claim that they have been unfairly dealt with by the committee of the National Association, who ordered them to play again in Montreal, and say that the Montreal players are welcome to the championship of which they enjoy a doubtful tenune.

The Rev. Dr. Elias Lyman Magoon, until recently Pastor of the Broad-Street Baptist Church, Philadelphia, died early yesterday morning at the home of his son-in-law, John Y. Huber, in that city. A pair of very strange and remarkable anomalies are presented in the present condition of the beef cattle trade of this Country. The first of them lies in the general fact that, in defiance of the laws of supply and demand, the enormous increase in the product of beef cattle which has taken place during the past few years has not been attended by any reduction in the price of beef to the consumer.

SOFIA, Nov. 25.--Another conspiracy against the Government has been discovered. Two officers, one of them a Russian, organized a plot to kill Col. Nicolaieff, Major Popoff, and the Regents. CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Nov. 25.--The Union Pacific Hotel, leased by the Pacific Hotel Company, was partially destroyed by fire this afternoon. The stock and furniture were totally destroyed. Loss on building and furniture, $25,000; partly insured. The fire caught in the third story from a defective flue. A man named McElroy, a Union Pacific employee, was killed by a falling porch. Several firemen were severely injured.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 25.--The schooner Owasso, it is feared, has gone down on Lake Erie with her crew of nine persons. She cleared on Saturday last from Fairport, Ohio, with a cargo of 6OO tone of coal, for Detroit. She is insured for $4,700.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Nov. 25.--Dr. William R. Cuthbert, who has offices in New-Benford and Providence, was arrested here to-day on charge of malpractice. His patient was a married woman, who had not lived with her husband for nearly a year and whose paramour was recently prosecuted for adultery. Cuthbert is usually here the first part of every week, but has been absent until to-day since Nov. 12, when it is alleged the crime was committed.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 26.--Mr. John B. Sewell, Jr., business manager of the Times, and Miss Henrietta Bailey Thornton, daughter of Mr. Thomas Thornton, President of the Bank of Commerce, were married in this city this evening. Mr. and Mrs. Sewell left here to-night to visit New-York, Washington, and other Eastern cities.

The legality of an ingenious means of getting an income without doing anything for it is about to be tested through suits brought by direction of the Attorney-General against the Calf Butchers' Association, of this city. There were about 50 such butchers when they organized, in April last.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26.--John Mullen and Peter McHugh, policemen, are at present in the county jail, under the Debtors' act, on a judgment secured against them three years ago.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 26.--Naval Cadets Fife and Clinton, who were tried by courtmartial in September last, have been reinstated in their class, which indicates that the proceedings against them were quashed.

IPSWICH, Dakota, Nov. 26.--Three Russians living near Roscoe, while going home last evening, found a bottle by the roadside which they supposed to contain alcohol and drank it. It proved to be aconite, and two of the Russians died last night from the effects. The third died to-day.
VICKSBURG, Miss., Nov. 26.--Information reached here to-night that the Court House of Winn Parish, La., was burned last night at Winfield, together with all the records of the parish.

Work on the Richmond, the man-of-war lying on the navy yard dry dock, is being rapidly pushed by order of Secretary Whitney, and she will probably go into commission on Dec. 25.

DUBLIN, Nov. 26.--Sir Michael HicksBeach, Chief Secretary for Ireland, has been busily engaged all day at Dublin Castle conferring with the legal and military authorities. The city is agitated by rumors of the wildest character relating to the Government's intentions.

Warner Miller's candidacy for re-election to the United States Senate was commended yesterday to the tender consideration of the Legislature by the Wholesale Butter, Cheese, and Egg Dealers' Association, of this city.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., Nov. 26.--The Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad Company has settled about half of the damage claims growing out of the disaster at East Rio on Oct. 26.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 26.--A long controversy between the various breweries of this city, now consolidated into an association for pur poses of defense, and their workmen, has at length culminated in the establishment of a formal boycott of formidable proportions.

FORT WORTH, Texas, Nov. 26.--A.K. Cutting arrived in Fort Worth yesterday, accompanied by Lee Clark, A.B. McKee, and M.V. Stevens. In an interview with Cutting and Mr. Clark they said they would take in all the Northern and Eastern cities during the Winter and Mr. Cutting would lecture.

GALVESTON, Texas, Nov. 26.--The British bark, Drumadoon, 865 tons, Capt. Thompson, for Liverpool, lying in the outer roads awaiting the balance of her cargo, was discovered to be on fire at an early hour this morning.
DARIEN, Ga., Nov. 26.--Joseph Cooper, colored, was to-day found guilty of murder, and was sentenced to be hanged on Jan. 14.

The "vindication" demanded by Deacons Graff, Young, Mapes, and Wilkinson, of the Rev. Dr. Fulton's church, in Brooklyn, was not achieved last evening, principally because the Reverend Doctor was too much for the Deacons in strategy.

The inquest in the case of Mrs. Annie Ellis, who was found dead in her home, No. 311 East Seventy-eighth-street, on Nov. 13, was held by Coroner Nugent and a jury yesterday. When found the woman was lying dead on the floor.

LONDON, Nov. 26.--At Manchester to-day the race for the Lancashire Cup for 500 in specie, added to a handicap sweepstakes of 5 each for starters, (the sweepstakes to go to the second,) for 3-year-olds and upward, distance one mile, was won by five lengths by J. Hope's 4-yearold Lady Lothian.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 26.-At noon to-day five shots in quick succession, and a few moments later a sixth shot, were heard in a room at No. 42 Broad street. The door was forced open, and Tony Hill was found lying dead on the floor, with five bullet holes through his heart.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26.--A dispatch was received to-day from Capt. Corbett, of the schooner Metropolis, dated Elk Rapids, announcing that his vessel went ashore at 3 o'clock this morning in a blinding snowstorm about three miles south of Old Mission, and that she was scuttled to prevent her from going to pieces.

LONDON, Nov. 27.--The steamship Brooklyn City, Capt. Fitt, from New-York Nov. 12 for Bristol, Brow Head yesterday. The steamship Gotenburg City, (Br.,) Capt. Harrison, from Montreal Nov.8 for London, passed Prawle Point yesterday.

Superintendent Murray made another raid on the dives last night. For several days 12 policemen from the School of Instruction have been collecting evidence on which, yesterday, Justice Gorman issued 34 warrants.

An attachment against the property of Philo P. Hotchkiss has been granted by Judge Donohue, in the Supreme Court, in a suit brought by William A. Wheelock, of the Central National Bank. Hotchkiss was a member of the old firm of Dale, Dutcher Co., dealers in dry goods, which was dissolved in January, 1883.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26.--The Executive Committees of the Lehigh and Schuylkill Coal Exchanges met to-day and agreed to make no changes in the present line and city and harbor prices of coal during December.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26.--Secretary Whitney has directed a board, to consist of Commodore Walker, Chief Constructor Wilson, and Engineer-in-Chief Loring, to consider the bids offered for the new cruisers and gunboats, and to report within four days from the time the bids were opened.

FORT KEOGH, Montana, Nov. 26.--Montana is anxious for Statehood. A committee of citizens at Helena is getting up a strong memorial to Congress, and will go to Washington in person to press the claim.

OTTAWA, Nov. 26.--The franking privilege is disgracefully abused by the civil servants in the departmental buildings here. The Montreal Trade Review recently took up the subject and condemned the Government so strongly that the Postmaster-General, Sir Alexander Campbell, has been stirred up to take action.

The funeral of Erastus Brooks will take place this afternoon at 2 o'clock, at the Church of the Ascension in West New-Brighton, Staten Island. DUBLIN, Nov. 26.--At a large meeting held in this city to-day it was resolved to urge the railway companies to connect the Kingston and Kingsbridge termini in order to facilitate the mail service.

CHRISTIANSBURG, Va., Nov. 26.--Gen. James A. Walker closed the sale of his large mineral property to-day to Bullet Co., the recent purchasers of the Foster Falls property. He also sold the mineral property known as Cave Hill, in the same vicinity, to a Northern syndicate. No prices stated.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26.--Fire Inspector Shay is still at work upon the investigation of the causes of the incendiary fire at the Continental Hotel early yesterday morning, but has not yet reached a point where he is prepared to make any definite statement or order any arrests.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 26.--Exchange-- sight drafts on New-York, 15 cents; telegraphic, 20 cents.

ROME, Nov. 27.--For the moment the Italian Ministers are too busy thinking of a possible war in the Spring and what Italy will get out of it to press matters against the Vatican, and a sort of breathing spell truce reigns between the two palaces.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27.--Commander Edwin White has been ordered to command the Portsmouth; Commander George F. Wilde to command the Dolphin; Lieut. M.F. Wright to duty at the League Island Navy Yard.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Nov. 27.--The jail at Somerville, Fayette County, Tenn., about 50 miles east of Memphis, was destroyed by fire early this morning. A prisoner named Love, who was arrested for shooting a man, is said to have set the jail on fire. The nine prisoners confined were rescued and will be brought here for safe keeping. The structure was of brick and cost $20,000.

LONDON, Nov. 27.--The Hamburg-American Line steamship Wieland Capt. Hebich, from New-York Nov. 18 for Hamburg, passed the Lizard to-day.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 27.--The stove molders at De Haven's foundry struck this morning against a reduction ordered several weeks ago. All the men are out, and the foundry is closed. The men say the strike will not affect the other foundries, as De Haven's was the only one where a cut in wages had been ordered. About 150 men are idle.

READING, Penn., Nov. 27.--A frame dwelling house, occupied by Frank Kerner and family, caught fire this evening from an overheated stovepipe, and Mrs. Kerner, aged 34 years, was burned to death. She was in bed sick, and at the time of the fire her husband was absent in search of a physician for her. Augustus Webekind, a fireman, was badly injured while at work on the fire.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27.--From the annual report of. Col. G.N. Lieber, Acting Judge-AdvocateGeneral of the army, it appears that during the past year there were 1,983, trials by General courts-martial, including 22 trials of commissioned officers, and two courts of inquiry. John N. Abbott has resigned his post as General Passenger Agent of the New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad Company. He retires to accept a more responsible position. He becomes Commissioner of the Southwestern Passenger Association. Few places in the American railway world are so important.

The residents and visitors in San Francisco are now enjoying the most delicious climate under the sun. At this season we have Autumn, Spring, and Summer all in one.

The concert at the Casino last evening was attended by an audience that crowded the building to its utmost capacity and regarded the proceedings with the liveliest interest and abundant evidences of hearty approval. The members of the company that is supporting Mme. Patti on her concert tour were the soloists.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 28.--Frank Davis, a prisoner at the Court Jail, died yesterday afternoon from concussion of the brain, caused by butting his head against the wall of his cell on Friday.
Mme. Patti sings at the Academy of Music to-night. "Aida" will have its last performance at the Metropolitan Opera House this evening.

BUFFALO, Nov. 28.--On Aug. 8 George Hazlett and William Potts made a successful trip through the whirlpool rapids of Niagara River, and have since that time enjoyed the modicum of fame which falls to the lot of all men who foolishly put their lives in danger. When Larry Donovan was here, and after his jump from the Suspension Bridge, he declared his intention of going through the rapids.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Nov. 28.--Walter O'Niell, another victim of Friday's explosion at the Conyngham shaft, died this evening. Michael O'Brien and Hugh Cannon, two of the most seriously injured, are not expected to live more than a few hours.

SALEM, Mass., Nov. 28.--The great strike of the tanners and curriers of Peabody and Salem, which began on July 12 with a demand that 59 hours constitute a week's work, was officially ended to-day, when the various assemblies of the Knights of Labor of the two places met in mass meeting and declared the strike off.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28.--A deliberate attempt was made on Thursday night to assassinate Harry Gilmer, the witness who gave evidence at the recent trial of the Anarchists, directly implicating Spies and Schwab in the throwing of the Haymarket bomb. Gilmer was shot at while on the threshold of his home, and the bullet passed between his legs lodging in the door.

The fine weather attracted large crowds to Central Park yesterday, and all the afternoon the usual centres of interest were surrounded. "Mr. Crowley" and the hippopotamus received the largest share of attention. There were a few runaway and other accidents.

A large fish was left stranded, but alive, in Flusling Bay, near Harry Hill's Pavilion, yesterday, and was placed in a crate in the water to await inspection by Commissioner Eugene G. Blackford. No fisherman or any other person who saw it had ever seen such a fish.

Charles Warner, a brass polisher of No. 85 Columbia-street, has for some time visited Annie, the divorced wife of John D. Young, a stove salesman, at No. 230 Stanton-street. He went there yesterday afternoon, and on the third floor was accosted by Mary Clark, who said that a man wanted to see him in the yard.

PESTH, Nov. 28.--A day or two ago a plot was discovered at Neusatz, Cettinje, and Antivari to seize King Milan of Servia, while hunting near Vranja, and carry him into Montenegro. As soon as he heard of the plot he boarded an express train for Belgrade, where he arrived in a state of mental and physical prostration. Detectives aye searching for the conspirators.

LONDON, Nov. 28.--Discount was easy during the past week at 2 to 2. The Stock Exchange loan rate until next account is 4 to 4. Prices on the Stock Exchange during the week were firm, the brighter political outlook, combined with the reduced speculative account at the settlement just concluded, favoring buying. American railway securities were strong under investment purchases, ...
The Record has been favored with the following copy of a valuable astronomical essay contributed by a suburban boy to the exercises on a recent examination day. He called it a "composition."
OSWEGO, N.Y., Nov. 28.--The schooner Camanche left here yesterday in tow of the tug C.W. Ferris for Ogdensburg with a cargo of wheat.

Adam Bickelhaupt, skylight manufacturer and defeated candidate for Alderman in the Fifteenth Assembly District, is becoming a frequenter of the Jefferson Market Police Court, although guiltless of any breach of the law.
A very, good proof of the better times is seen in the list of semi-annual dividends payable in Boston next month. Last year they amounted to $4,664,063 and this year to $5,436,355.
The Rev. Hugh Montgomery says that a few days ago he succeeded in purchasing a half pint of whisky from one of the lowest kitchen dives in the city.

No one will yet venture to predict how the betting dispute between William L. Scott and the bookmakers, Appleby Johnson, will come out. It is still the talk uppermost among sporting men, who consider it of great importance as illustrating the status of the bookmakers with those who control the race tracks in this section.
BRUSSELS, Nov. 28.--The police are tracking five travelers from Dover who are suspected of being implicated in the plundering of a mail car of the Ostend express yesterday.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 28.--The absorbing topic of to-day is the failure of Quinn Grey, the largest dry goods firm in this city, who closed their doors yesterday evening. The liabilities of the firm are now said to be over $100,000. The goods and fixtures are estimated at $150,000.
The Rev. Henry Ward Beecher is striving to awaken a more social spirit among the memders of Plymouth Church. To this end the parlors connected with the church will be enlarged.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28.--The week at most of the Chicago playhouses has not been one of great activity. Bad weather has had something to do with this, and indifferent attractions at two of the theatres explain the plethora of empty seats.

The Hedding Methodist Episcopal Church celebrated its twenty-fifth anniversary with three sessions yesterday, and plans were discussed, after addresses on the history of the church had been made, for placing the church on its old footing.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. There is plenty of business ready for Congress to take up when it is called to order a week from to-morrow, although it is probable that the order of introduction of bills will considerably add to the volume of work to be disposed of in the three months' session.

SANDUSKY, Ohio, Nov. 28.--A profound mystery is the topic on every tongue to-night. The Coroner was sent for this morning to go to a point in the woods four miles from here. A young man and lady had wandered into the woods, and stopped to rest where two large logs lay side by side. Looking over them they discovered the body of an elegantly dressed woman.

The Fifth Ward branch of the Irish National League called a meeting yesterday afternoon at Berrigan's Hall, Hudson and Desbrosses streets, for the purpose of reviving interest in Irish affairs, in view of the impending imprisonment of John Dillon and the threatened resumption of coercion in Ireland.

Henry Adams, of Boston, is at the Hotel Brunswick. Aquilla Jones, of Indianapolis, is at the Grand Central Hotel.

Recent mails from South Australia bring accounts of debates in Parliament on a motion providing that the proposed transcontinental railway shall be built upon the land grant system. The Australian colonies are passing through an experience similar to our own in this and many other respects.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28.--It was not generally known until to-day that Henry Jansen, who made a murderous assault upon his wife early Friday morning, was a member of the "North Side Group," one of the most rabid Anarchist organizations in the city, and on the night of the bomb explosion was within a few feet of the place from where the deadly missile was hurled into the ranks of the marching policemen.

Albert Most, a coal dealer, of No. 50 Sackett-street, South Brooklyn, is made a defendant in a disagreeable suit. Whether he is in fault is a question of veracity between himself and Miss Augusta Anderson, a young Swede, who lives with her sister, Mrs. Hermeson, at No. 52 Sackettstreet.

DUBLIN, Nov. 16.--The development of the cottage industries of Ireland has long been an acknowledged object of patriotic effort with all Irishmen, and is recognized as one of the most important aids to the solution of Irish difficulties by all the well wishes of the country.

Mme. Valda's Italian opera enterprise died finally on Saturday when the principal artists who were left sailed for Europe. They didn't decide to sail until Friday night, for arrangements had been made for a season of opera in some of the smaller cities in the East, beginning on Dec. 6.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28.--Admiral David D. Porter has submitted to the Secretary of the Navy a report embodying suggestions for promoting the efficiency of the navy. Ha says that in rehabilitating the navy there is no subject worthy of more consideration than that of home defense.
The Rev. W.T. Henry, of the First Baptist Church, has broken the record--in fact, doubled the highest record in Elmira--in performing marriage ceremonies.

JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 28.--The planters in the central or hill section of the State of Mississippi have noticed with a good deal of uneasiness the tendency of the negroes to go away towards the Yazoo Valley, and, in fact, some portions of the State have been almost totally denuded of their negro population.

M. Lockroy, as Chairman of the Committee of Management of the Universal Exhibition, has been served with a writ by the Comtesse de Poix, who demands that he shall cease from building the Eiffel Tower.

LANCASTER, Penn., Nov. 28.--A dispatch received in this city at 6 o'clock this evening announced the sudden death of James Stewart at Oregon, Wis. Mr. Stewart was one of the most prominent railroad contractors in this city, which is the home of more large contractors than any city of its size in the country.
PORTLAND, Me., Nov. 28.--The Rev. T.H. Wallace, Pastor of St. Joseph's Church, Lewiston, has recently given $10,000 toward the erection of a Catholic church there.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 28.--President George H. Watrous, of the New-York, NewHaven and Hartford Railroad, to-night said that the proposed New-York, Danbury and Boston Railroad would not give any shorter line between New-York and Boston than was now held by existing roads, nor would trains over it be able to lower the time between the two cities.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 28.--A Coroner's inquest was held yesterday afternoon in Parma to investigate the peculiar death of Mrs. Bdward Mahar, and the verdict was that she met her death at the hands of her husband. Mahar was immediately arrested by Constable Cobbett and lodged in jail in this city at midnight. There is great excitement in Parma over the case.

Last Winter a great stir was created in social circles at White Plains by the escapades of a dudish young man named J.D. Fiske, who styled himself a lawyer, and who, in his furlined and fur-collared overcoat, cut a great figure until Nemesis in the shape of his past record overtook him.

--Mr. Moncure D. Conway is engaged upon a biography of Edmund Randolph, who was Attorney-General and afterward Secretary of State under Washington. The descendants of the statesman and others have placed in his hands a large mass of letters and documents covering the period from 1782 until Randolph's death in 1813.

Mme. Patti's Boston engagement was even a greater success than her enterprising manager, Mr. Henry E. Abbey, had anticipated. Very nearly $14,000 was the net result in cash of the sale of tickets, and the limited capacity of the house only prevented this sum being exceeded.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 28.--The Keystone Bridge Company, of this city, has been awarded a large contract by the New-Jersey Railway Construction Company for the construction of an elevated railroad in Jersey City, which will be three miles long.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 28.--There were two shocks of earthquake at Summerville to-day, one at 10:30 A.M. and and at 3:20 P.M., which rattled things in a lively manner. People are more or less frightened. The latter shock was felt slightly in Charleston.
LONDON, Nov. 28.--The Farren jewels have been found in a cab and restored to the owner by the finder.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28.--A fire was discovered this afternoon in the upper floor of the threestory building comprising Nos. 220 and 232 Kenzie-street, owned by the Western Electric Manufacturing Company, and occupied by R. Rothschild's Sons Co., manufacturers of saloon, bank, and office fixtures.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 28.--The strike of the green glass or bottle blowers, begun last night, is not a popular move here. There are about 150 blowers and 250 apprentices and helpers affected by the strike in Baltimore and about 600 blowers and 3,000 other employes thrown out of work in other parts of the Eastern States.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28.--Congressman W.R. Morrison arrived at the Palmer Horse to-day on his way to Washington to be present at the opening of Congress. He seemed as cheerful as if Jehu Baker had not defeated him for Congress a few weeks ago.

It was on Dec. 21, 1829, that Laura Bridgman was born in Hanover, N.H., so that she is now nearly 57 years of age. As an infant she was sprightly and pretty, with bright blue eyes. Her constitution, however, was feeble, and she was subject to severe fits till she was a year and a half old. For the next six months her health materially improved and she soon manifested a fair degree of intelligence.

People who went to the little chapel of the Eighty-fourth-Street Presbyterian Church yesterday morning in the hope of hearing something about the trouble among the Trustees of the Phelps Mission went away disappointed. The Pastor, the Rev. A.G.P. Atterbury, made no mention of the proposed transfer of the mission to the church.

HONESDALE, Penn., Nov. 28.--Gov. Pattison has signed the death warrant of James P. McCabe, convicted in this place of the murder of his neighbor, Michael Riley, last New Year's Eve, and fixed Jan. 13, 1887, as the day for his hanging. The Supreme Court has refused McCabe a new trial.

The Rev. C.P. McCarthy, at his meeting held at No. 52 Union-square last night, considered Archbishop Corrigan's late encyclical letter concerning the land question, and opposed to it the views of Bishop Nulty, the Irish prelate who believes in and preaches the ideas of Henry George.

The Spanish "tramp" steamship Marco arrived at the California docks, foot of Thirteenth-street, Jersey City, on Friday, with a cargo of iron ore. Her crew is composed of Portuguese, Spaniards, Germans, and negroes. Saturday night several of the seamen and stokers began card-playing in the forecastle.
LONDON, Nov. 28.--The steamship Catania, (Ger.,) Capt. Knock, sld. from Shields for Savannah yesterday.

Strange to say, his first move in this direction was hatched and reared right here in Los Angeles.

At the Church of St. Francis Xavier, in West sixteenth-street, mass was celebrated yesterday by the Rev. John B. Prendergast, S.J., attended by the usual number of ministers. The Rev. H.C. Denny, S.J., continued the reading of Archbishop Corrigan's letter.

The Rev. Robery V. Griffiths, of the Welsh Presbyterian Church in East Thirteenth-street, last evening preached his farewell sermon to a large congregation. He spoke in the Welsh language and discoursed upon St. Paul's farewell address.

DULUTH, Minn., Nov. 28.--At 8 o'clock last night the most disastrous fire in the history of this place broke out in the top of Elevator Q, in the eastern part of the town, and in spite of the efforts of the Fire Department the flames communicated to the annex to Elevator A, a new building near completion, and finally to Elevator A itself, and all were consumed, together...

Frank W. Rockwell, who eloped from Red Bank, N.J., with Mrs. Mary West, and who is charged with robbing his employer, arrived at Jersey City last night in the custody of a detective. He was locked up at Police Headquarters and will be taken to the Monmouth County Jail at Freehold this morning. Mrs. West and her daughter accompanied him. She will return to her father's home at Keyport.

At yesterday's meeting of the Central Labor Union the Socialistic element was again in the ascendant, and succeeded in rushing through a resolution that the representative of the New-Yorker Staats-Zeitung should be furnished with no more news because that newspaper does not support Socialistic doctrines and theories.

GALVESTON, Texas, Nov. 28.--A fatal powder explosion, occurred three miles below this city at 11 o'clock this morning, resulting in the death of Joseph C. Lynah, traveling agent for the Hazard Powder Company, of New-York.
CHICAGO, Nov. 28.--The following crop summary will appear in this week's issue of the Farmers' Review:
Peter Norton, an orderly on the steamship City of Para, died suddenly yesterday while visiting friends at No. 70 Gansevoort-street.

RAMSEYS, N.J., Nov. 28.--Burglars have visited this little village several times of late, and have three different times entered the store of George Ryerson Sons. Finally, Ryerson had a burglar alarm arranged, connecting the premises with his residence.

READING, Penn., Nov. 28.--Frank Kerner, a peddler of herb medicines, lived in a two-story house at No. 1,228 Weimerstreet, occupying the upper floor with his wife Francisca, while the first story is tenanted by another couple.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Nov. 28.--A fatal collision occurred at Anderson's Station, on the Cincinnati Southern Railroad, eight miles below here, shortly after 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

The Liederkranz Society performed at its clubhouse last evening Max Bruch's cantata of "Achilleus." This work was composed for and first interpreted at the lower Rhenish festival held a twelvemonth ago, and three instrumental intermezzos were taken from its score and played in one of Mr. Thomas's popular concerts last Spring.

Burglars who understood their business broke into the large dry goods store of S.B. Jones, No. 309 Fulton-street, Brooklyn, some time yesterday, and carried away $400 in silver. The store is shaped like a letter L, and one wing reaches through to Johnson-street.
Upon the closing of the Brooklyn Navy Yard to-night 300 men will be discharged by Constructor Pook. He has applied for money to continue their wages, but has filed to receive it.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 29.--The American Opera Company was prepared to meet a cordial reception in St. Louis, but one has been tendered from a quarter and with a warmth that was entirely unexpected.
